Description: EACH YEAR, BIOLOGISTS FROM THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) S WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM ASSIST STAFF FROM VARIOUS PARTNERING AGENCIES IN CONDUCTING MONITORING AND RECOVERY PROJECTS FOR SPECIES EITHER DESIGNATED AS FEDERAL CANDIDATES OR THOSE FEDERALLY-LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. SUCH PROJECTS MAY RANGE FROM INTERAGENCY ROUTINE MONITORING EFFORTS (E.G. LEOPARD DARTER, ARKANSAS RIVER SHINER) WHILE OTHERS MAY BE RELATIVELY SHORT-TERM AND SPECIFIC (E.G. GENOMICS STUDIES OR POPULATION AUGMENTATIONS). ALL SUCH ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED WITH FEDERALLY-PERMITTED BIOLOGISTS ON SITE, MOST OFTEN A U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) BIOLOGIST. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FIELD-ASSISTANCE AND DATA FOR THE USFWS  ANNUAL MONITORING AND RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR SPECIES SUCH AS THE ARKANSAS RIVER SHINER, LEOPARD DARTER, RABBITSFOOT, AND NEOSHO MUCKET. THIS ADDITIONAL HELP SHOULD REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF TIME NEEDED TO COMPLETE THESE SURVEYS AND INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD THAT COMPLETE MONITORING SURVEYS CAN BE CONDUCTED EACH YEAR. ADDITIONALLY, ASSISTANCE CAN BE PROVIDED TO USFWS AS NEEDED FOR FEDERALLY-LISTED MUSSEL SEARCHES THROUGHOUT OCCUPIED STRETCHES OF VARIOUS RIVER SYSTEMS SUCH AS THE LOWER VERDIGRIS, UPPER ILLINOIS, AND NEOSHO RIVERS. THREE STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS EXIST WITHIN THE REACHES OF THE CIMARRON AND CANADIAN RIVERS THAT HAVE BEEN DESIGNATED AS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THE ARKANSAS RIVER SHINER. THESE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS CAN SERVE AS MONITORING SITES FOR THIS SPECIES. THE MONITORING AND DOCUMENTATION OF DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION SIZES OF VARIOUS FEDERALLY-LISTED SPECIES IN THE STATE WILL ADD TO THE KNOWLEDGE BASE FOR THESE SPECIES IN OKLAHOMA THAT IN TURN WILL HELP ODWC AND THE USFWS MAKE BETTER MANAGEMENT DECISION TO HELP PROTECT AND ULTIMATELY RECOVER THESE SPECIES.OBJECTIVES:TO ASSIST ESA SECTION 10 FEDERALLY-PERMITTED BIOLOGISTS FROM FEDERAL AGENCIES, INCLUDING (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND U.S. FOREST SERVICE WITH BOTH ROUTINE AND SHORT-TERM PROJECTS AIMED AT MONITORING, RESEARCHING, AND SURVEYING FEDERALLY-LISTED AND CANDIDATE SPECIES ACROSS THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA. EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON THE ARKANSAS RIVER SHINER, LEOPARD DARTER, NEOSHO MUCKET, RABBITSFOOT, AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY.BELOW ARE SOME SPECIFIC SURVEYS THAT MAY BE CONDUCTED UNDER THIS GRANT.1. LEOPARD DARTER ADULT POPULATION MONITORING SNORKEL SURVEYS WITH USFWS - 2 SURVEYS IN JULY2. LARVAL LEOPARD DARTER SAMPLING WITH USFWS - MULTIPLE SAMPLING TRIPS DURING FEBRUARY, MARCH, AND APRIL3. ARKANSAS RIVER SHINER POPULATION MONITORING SEINING SURVEYS WITH USFWS - 2 ANNUAL SURVEYS, 1 IN JUNE AND 1 IN OCTOBER4. RABBITSFOOT SUMMER SURVEYS FOR RANGE WIDE GENOMICS AND OR POPULATION STATUS PROJECT WITH USFWS - 1-2 SUMMER SURVEYS DURING JULY-AUGUST5. NEOSHO MUCKET SUMMER AND FALL SURVEYS FOR BROODSTOCK COLLECTION, POPULATION ASSESSMENT AND STOCKING OUT OF HATCHERY RAISED JUVENILES WITH NEOSHO NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY AND OKESFO6. OPPORTUNISTIC VISUAL SURVEYS FOR MONARCH BUTTERFLY STATEWIDE WITH WILDLIFE DIVERSITY

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SEEK FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO IDENTIFY, LIST, CONSERVE, AND RECOVER THE INDIGENOUS SPECIES AND SUBSPECIES (TAXA) OF AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES THAT ARE THREATENED OR ENDANGERED IN NEW MEXICO, AND ATTEMPT TO PRECLUDE THE NEED TO LIST OTHER RARE OR SENSITIVE AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES BEFORE THEY BECOME HIGHLY IMPERILED WITHIN THE STATE.THROUGH THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, WE (NMDGF) HOPE TO ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING: TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN INFORMATION REGARDING THE RARE OR IMPERILED NATIVE AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES OF NEW MEXICO, INCLUDING RANGES, NUMBERS, BIOLOGY, TAXONOMY, AND PROSPECTS FOR SURVIVAL AND RECRUITMENT WITHIN THE STATE. TO IDENTIFY SPECIES AND SUBSPECIES THAT MAY BE IN NEED OF ADDITIONAL MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION TO ENSURE THEIR PERSISTENCE WITHIN THE STATE. TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE TAXA IDENTIFIED IN NUMBER 2 (ABOVE), WITH THE GOAL OF IMPROVING THEIR STATUS TO THE POINT THAT THE PERSISTENCE OF THESE TAXA WITHIN NEW MEXICO WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED TO BE IN JEOPARDY IN THE PRESENT OR FORESEEABLE FUTURE. TO COMPLETE SPECIFIC PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN NUMBER 3 (ABOVE) FOR THE SPECIES OR SUBSPECIES IN GREATEST NEED OF ADDITIONAL CONSERVATION MEASURES.THIS PROPOSAL INCLUDES THE PROJECTS LISTED BELOW: PROJECT 1: INVESTIGATIONS OF THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG AND ASSOCIATED AMPHIBIANS IN THE GILA REGION OF NEW MEXICO PROJECT 2: POPULATION STATUS OF NORTHERN MEXICAN AND NARROW-HEADED GARTERSNAKES IN NEW MEXICO

THIS GRANT IS CRUCIAL FOR THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (NMDGF) TO DETERMINE THE OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION TRENDS OF TEXAS HORNSHELL MUSSEL POPENAIAS POPEII AND ITS HOST FISHES IN ORDER TO IMPROVE THEIR CONSERVATION STATUS. IN ADDITION, NMDGF ASSISTS PARTNERS THROUGH PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON TEXAS HORNSHELL CONSERVATION.

TO ASSIST PARTNERS IN ESTABLISHING A CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROGRAM FOR NATIVE SPRINGSNAILS AND TO CONDUCT MONITORING PROGRAMS FOR SOCORRO ISOPOD THERMOSPHAEROMA THERMOPHILUM, CHUPADERA SPRINGSNAIL, PECOS SPRINGSNAIL PYRGULOPSIS PECOSENSIS, AND ALAMOSA SPRINGSNAIL TRYONIA ALAMOSAE.

THE FUNDING PROVIDED THROUGH NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER F23AS00229 WILL ENABLE THE ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TO FUND SUBCONTRACTORS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH, SURVEYS, MONITORING AND RESTORATION OF ARIZONA S FEDERALLY-LISTED AND OTHER RARE PLANTS OF CONCERN. THIS YEAR WE RECEIVED 11 SECTION 6 GRANT PROPOSALS TOTALING  180,843.29. WE WILL ABLE TO FUND 7 PROPOSALS IN FULL AND ONE PROPOSAL IN PART WITH THE  136,454.31 AVAILABLE TO DISTRIBUTE. THESE PROPOSALS ARE SUMMARIZED HERE: 1) SAVE SEEDS FROM NEW POPULATIONS OF SENTRY MILK-VETCH (ASTRAGALUS CREMNOPHYLAX VAR. CREMNOPHYLAX), 2) QUANTIFY ABUNDANCE, PHENOLOGY, AND KEY SPECIES INTERACTIONS FOR NICHOLS TURKS HEAD CACTUS, 3) USE TRAINED DOGS TO DETECT THREE PEDIOCACTUS TAXA IN NORTHERN ARIZONA, 4) HABITAT DESCRIPTION AND HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL UPDATE FOR ARIZONA HEDGEHOG CACTUS (ECHINOCEREUS ARIZONICUS SSP. ARIZONICUS), 5) CONTINUED MONITORING OF GOODDINGS ONION (ALLIUM GOODDINGII) TRANSECTS IN THE APACHE SITGREAVES NATIONAL FORESTS, 6) COORDINATE SEED BANKING EFFORTS ACROSS MULTIPLE NATIONAL FORESTS FOR GOODDINGS ONION (ALLIUM GOODDINGII), 7) SURVEY FOR CORYPHANTHA ROBBINSORUM (COCHISE PINCUSHION CACTUS) IN AREAS OF MEXICO NEAR TO THE ONLY KNOWN LOCATION (IN ARIZONA), AND 8) NEW HOPE FOR A LARGE-SCALE, LONG-TERM RARE PLANT COMMUNITY SCIENCE PROJECT ON THE TONTO NATIONAL FOREST (TONTO RARE PLANT PROJECT). THIS WORK WILL ENABLE RECOVERY ACTIONS TO COMMENCE AND INCREASE OUR KNOWLEDGE ABOUT SPECIES CURRENT CONDITIONS, VULNERABILITIES, AND MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY NEEDS. THE RESULTING REPORTS WILL ENABLE THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO BETTER MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ON LISTING, DESIGNATING CRITICAL HABITAT, RECOVERY ACTIONS, AND DOWN AND DE-LISTING CRITERIA, AS WELL AS INFORM SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS AND 5-YEAR REVIEWS.

GRANT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THE 2022 MEXICAN WOLF RECOVERY PLAN. EFFORTS INCLUDE REPATRIATION OF MEXICAN WOLVES TO IMPROVE GENETIC RESILIENCE THROUGHOUT THE HISTORICAL RANGE OF THE SPECIES. ACTIVITIES WILL PRIMARILY INCLUDE FOSTERING OF PUPS FROM CAPTIVITY INTO SUITABLE WILD DENS. GRANT FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT ANNUAL CENSUS EFFORTS TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES TOWARDS MEETING RECOVERY CRITERIA.

NEARLY HALF OF THE HAWAIIAN FLORA IS CONSIDERED RARE AND 424 PLANTS ARE LISTED THREATENED OR ENDANGERED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THESE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS ARE IN DECLINE DUE TO THE IMPACTS FROM INVASIVENON-NATIVE SPECIES, WILDFIRES, AND LAND CONVERSION. AS A RESULT, REGENERATION OF MANY PLANT SPECIES IN SITU HASBEEN INTERRUPTED CAUSING A RAPID DECLINE IN THE NUMBERS OF POPULATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS. THE DLNR-DOFAW STATEWIDE RARE PLANT PROGRAM SUPPORTS THE GOAL OF IN SITU PLANT RECOVERY, WHEN THESE SPECIES CAN MAINTAIN STABLE ORINCREASING NATURALLY REPRODUCING POPULATIONS IN SECURE, ADEQUATELY SIZED, SUITABLE HABITAT WITH ONLY A LOW LEVELOF MANAGEMENT. HOWEVER, HABITAT PROTECTION ALONE WILL NOT PROVIDE FOR FULL RECOVERY OF HAWAIIS RARE PLANTS.DIRECT INTERVENTION BY THE DLNR-DOFAW THROUGH THREAT CONTROL, EX SITU PROPAGATION, AND HABITAT RESTORATIONEFFORTS ARE MAJOR AND NECESSARY ASPECTS OF AN INTEGRATED CONSERVATION STRATEGY. THE ACTIONS TO BE SUPPORTED BYTHIS PROJECT INCLUDE SURVEYING FOR AND MONITORING CRITICALLY RARE PLANT POPULATIONS, COLLECTING PROPAGULES FORSTORAGE AND REINTRODUCTION PROJECTS, STORING AND PROPAGATING SEEDS IN SEED BANKS AND NURSERIES, OUT PLANTING TOCREATE NEW POPULATIONS, AND IN SITU MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THREATS.

THIS PROPOSAL IS TO CONTINUE RESEARCH ON THE EFFECTS OF HABITAT RESTORATION TREATMENTS ON NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL (NIDGS) DEMOGRAPHY. RESTORING AND MAINTAINING HABITAT IS A PRIMARY COMPONENT OF THE NIDGS RECOVERY PLAN. SINCE 2012, THE IDAHO COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT AT THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO (UI) HAS COLLECTED DATA ON ANNUAL SURVIVAL, DIET, REPRODUCTION, AND SELECTION OF HIBERNACULA TO EXAMINE NIDGS RESPONSE TO FOREST THINNING AND PRESCRIBED FIRE. THE OVERARCHING COLLABORATIVE STUDY TO WHICH THIS PROJECT TIERS HAS AMASSED 10 YEARS OF DETAILED PRE-TREATMENT DATA THAT DESCRIBED VARIATION IN HABITAT QUALITY, GROUND SQUIRREL FORAGING AND HIBERNATION BEHAVIOR, AND GROUND SQUIRREL SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTION. FOR EXAMPLE, DATA HAVE SHOWN THAT NIDGS AT SOME SITES MOVE 100 M OR MORE INTO THE FOREST TO HIBERNATE, AND AS A RESULT, HABITAT COMPONENTS FOR HIBERNACULA DIFFER SUBSTANTIALLY FROM HABITAT COMPONENTS DURING THE ACTIVE SEASON. THIS SUGGESTS THAT NIDGS AS A POPULATION (ACROSS ALL AGE CLASSES) MAY REQUIRE A MORE HETEROGENEOUS LANDSCAPE THAN PREVIOUSLY BELIEVED.TREATING FORESTED STANDS TO BENEFIT NIDGS PROVIDES OPPORTUNITY TO AUGMENT NATIVE UNDERSTORY SPECIES IMPORTANT TO NIDGS. KNOWING WHICH PLANT SPECIES ARE PREFERRED BY NIDGS, AND WHICH CONTRIBUTE TO INCREASED VIGOR AND SURVIVAL, IS AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT OF HABITAT RESTORATION. THIS STUDY IS TRANSITIONING TO LARGE SCALE DIET ANALYSIS, TO OBTAIN A THOROUGH REPRESENTATION OVER THE ENTIRE ACTIVE SEASON FOR THIS SPECIES AND TO IDENTIFY COMPONENTS OF HABITAT RESTORATION THAT COULD POTENTIALLY PROMOTE NIDGS POPULATION GROWTH AND SPATIAL EXPANSION. THIS ANALYSIS WILL EXPAND ON EARLIER WORK WITH A GREATER NUMBER OF SAMPLES THAT REPRESENT MORE OCCUPIED SITES AND TIME PERIODS WITHIN THE ABOVE-GROUND SEASON TO PROVIDE A MORE ROBUST ANALYSIS. THIS INFORMATION IS ESSENTIAL TO ENSURE THAT HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ARE DESIGNED IN WAYS TO PROVIDE OPTIMAL FORAGE.

THE REFUGIUM FOR THE ENDANGERED PAHRANAGAT ROUNDTAIL CHUB (GILA ROBUSTA JORDANI) AT THE KEY PITTMAN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (KPWMA) WAS BUILT IN 2004 AND SUSTAINED A BACK-UP POPULATION THAT PROVIDED DEMOGRAPHIC SECURITY AND MAINTAINED GENETIC DIVERSITY FOR ONE OF THE MOST IMPERILED FISH IN NEVADA. THIS SPECIES HAS LOST NEARLY ALL OF ITS WILD HABITAT, AND KPWMA SITE WAS THE ONLY FUNCTIONING AND SUCCESSFUL REFUGIUM IN ITS NATIVE PAHRANAGAT VALLEY (LINCOLN COUNTY, NEVADA). AFTER 16 YEARS, A MECHANICAL FAILURE OF THE WATER WELL AT KPWMA LED TO DECREASED WATER LEVELS, POOR WATER QUALITY, DEGRADED HABITAT, AND LOSS OF THE REFUGIUM POPULATION IN AUGUST 2020. GIVEN THE LONG-TERM SUCCESS OF THE KPWMA REFUGIUM PRIOR TO THE MECHANICAL FAILURE, THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW) HAS SECURED PARTIAL FUNDING THROUGH OUR HABITAT CONSERVATION FEE PROGRAM TO RESTORE THE KPWMA REFUGIUM. HOWEVER, ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE NEEDED TO COMPLETE RESTORATION WORK BEFORE PAHRANAGAT ROUNDTAIL CHUB CAN BE REINTRODUCED. WE ARE SEEKING FUNDS TO PURSUE HABITAT RESTORATION, REPAIRS, AND UPGRADES TO THE AGING INFRASTRUCTURE AND IMPROVE THE WATER DELIVERY SYSTEM, INCLUDING VEGETATION REMOVAL, INSTALLATION OF A POND LINER, AN AUTOMATED WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND ALARM SYSTEM, AND A RECIRCULATION AND AERATION SYSTEM. IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE COORDINATED RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION OF THE KPWMA PAHRANAGAT ROUNDTAIL CHUB REFUGIUM AND ALLOW FUTURE RESTOCKING OF THE SPECIES AT THIS LOCATION. THIS PROJECT ALSO ADDRESSES MULTIPLE RECOVERY PLAN PRIORITY TASKS AND WILL ENABLE CONTINUED PROGRESS TOWARDS SPECIES RECOVERY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FILL THE CURRENT DATA AND KNOWLEDGE GAPS FOR TWO GENERA OF ARACHNID IN TEXAS. THESE TWO GENERA ARE HIGHLY DIVERSE BUT THEIR GENETIC RELATIONSHIPS AND COMPREHENSIVE SPECIES DATA ARE RELATIVELY UNKNOWN OUTSIDE A VERY RESTRICTED GEOGRAPHIC AREA. MANY OF THE SPECIMENS COLLECTED IN CAVES ARE IMMATURE AND IDENTIFICATION USING MORPHOLOGICAL TECHNIQUES IS NOT ALWAYS POSSIBLE. WITH ADVANCES IN MODERN GENETIC TOOLS THESE SPECIMENS MAY NOW BE IDENTIFIED. THE CURRENT DATA PORTAL HOUSING THE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE OF KARST OBLIGATE INVERTEBRATES HAS DEMONSTRATED THERE IS STILL A GREAT DEAL OF AVAILABLE SPECIMEN DATA THAT HAVE NOT BEEN FULLY DETERMINED TO SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY CLARIFY THE TAXONOMIC RELATIONSHIPS OF THE SPECIES IN THESE TWO GENERA BUT ALSO ADD TO THE EXISTING DATA AND HELP REFINE SPECIES RANGES WHICH ARE USEFUL FOR SPECIES CONSERVATION THE RECOVERY.

POPULATION AUGMENTATION AND REINTRODUCTION METHODS HAVE BECOME CRITICAL TOOLS TO MITIGATE THE GENETIC AND DEMOGRAPHIC RISKS OF SMALL POPULATIONS, AND HAVE THUS BECOME A CORNERSTONE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION. HOWEVER, OUTSIDE OF A FEW CHARISMATIC AVIAN AND MAMMALIAN SPECIES, CLOSE TO NOTHING IS KNOWN ABOUT THE EFFICACY OF THESE APPROACHES. OUR PROPOSED PROJECT WILL USE GENETIC MARKER TECHNOLOGY, ALONG WITH TRADITIONAL POPULATION SURVEYS AND ACQUISITION OF CLIMATIC DATA, TO DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF GENETIC AUGMENTATION IN A SMALL HIGHLY AT-RISK POPULATION OF THE RARE CENTRAL TEXAS ENDEMIC ANNUAL PLANT STREPTANTHUS BRACTEATUS (BRACTED TWISTFLOWER). THIS INFORMATION WILL GUIDE THE PLANNING AND USE OF THESE TRANSLOCATION METHODS IN THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF THE BRACTED TWISTFLOWER.

A CONSERVATION GENOMIC ASSESSMENT IS PROPOSED FOR A FEDERALLY AND STATE ENDANGERED SPECIES, THE COMANCHE SPRINGS PUPFISH, CYPRINODON ELEGANS. THE ENTIRE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE OF THE SPECIES FALLS WITHIN THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT ECOREGION OF TEXAS, WITH CONTEMPORARY POPULATIONS RESTRICTED TO FRAGMENTED, SPRING-ASSOCIATED HABITATS IN REEVES AND JEFF DAVIS COUNTIES, TEXAS. COMANCHE SPRINGS PUPFISH HAVE UNDERGONE POPULATION RANGE CONTRACTION WITHIN RECENT YEARS IN RESPONSE TO HUMAN ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING WATER EXTRACTION, POLLUTION, AND ARE ALSO IMPERILED BY THE INTRODUCTION OF NON-NATIVE SPECIES, INCLUDING THE SHEEPSHEAD MINNOW, CYPRINODON VARIEGATUS. A 2017 TPWD PILOT STUDY SHOWED REDUCED GENETIC VARIATION IN COMANCHE SPRINGS PUPFISH FROM THREE PROPOSED WILD POPULATIONS AND CONCLUDED THAT THERE WAS A NEED FOR MORE GENETIC RESOURCES TO BE DEVELOPED FOR THE SPECIES. CONSERVATION GENOMIC WORK WILL INVOLVE NEXT-GENERATION SEQUENCING TECHNIQUES, ALLOWING FOR A ROBUST ASSESSMENT OF STANDING GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN AND AMONG WILD POPULATIONS OF COMANCHE SPRINGS PUPFISH, AS WELL AS AN ASSESSMENT OF THE POTENTIAL FOR CURRENT AND OR HISTORICAL HYBRIDIZATION WITH OTHER PUPFISH, SPECIFICALLY C. VARIEGATUS. IN ADDITION, DIVERSITY IN WILD POPULATIONS WILL BE COMPARED TO THAT IN CAPTIVE (RESERVE) POPULATIONS TO ASSESS WHETHER RESERVE POPULATIONS ADEQUATELY REPRESENT STANDING DIVERSITY IN THE WILD. THIS INFORMATION WOULD ALSO HELP PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION GENETICS OBJECTIVES FOR CURRENTLY HELD REFUGIA POPULATIONS.

TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THE SECTION 6 ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM OF THE TENNESSEE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AGENCY, FUNDING IS NECESSARY TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY PROJECTS FOR LISTED SPECIES. PROJECTS TO BE IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE THE MONITORING OF 7 LISTED FISH SPECIES, PROPAGATION OF ONE LISTED FISH, SURVEY AND MONITORING OF ONE LISTED MUSSEL, PROPAGATION AND REINTRODUCTION OF TWO LISTED MUSSEL SPECIES, SURVEY AND MONITORING OF ONE CRAYFISH, SURVEY OF ONE LISTED TURTLE, SURVEY AND DEVELOPMENT OF ONE LISTED SNAIL AND ASSESSING THE VULNERABILITY OF ONE SALAMANDER PETITIONED SPECIES. FUNDING ASSOCIATED WITH THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY WILL SUPPORT NINE PROJECTS COVERING A HOST OF LISTED SPECIES IN THE STATE. THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE: PROPAGATION, REINTRODUCTION, AND MONITORING OF RARE TENNESSEE FISHES 2023  2025  CONSERVATION FISHERIES INC. ( 90,000), A REASSESSMENT OF THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE PALE LILLIPUT (TOXOLASMA CYLINDRELLUS) TENNESSEE TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY ( 52,881), NASHVILLE CRAYFISH MONITORING  NASHVILLE ZOO ( 11,000), SHADY VALLEY BOG TURTLE HABITAT RESTORATION  ZOO KNOXVILLE AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY ( 28,233), RECOVERY OF DUCK RIVER DARTERSNAPPER, EPIOBLASMA AHLSTEDTI, IN TENNESSEE THROUGH PROPAGATION, REINTRODUCITON, AND MONITORING TENNESSEE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AGENCY ( 54,500), MONITORING PROGRAM FOR ANGUISPIRA PICTA IN SHERWOOD FOREST: PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT, HABITAT MAPPING AND PILOT STUDY  DINKINS BIOLOGICAL CONSULTING LLC ( 13,761), ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SURVEILLANCE OF THE CHUCKY MADTOM (NOTURUS CRYPTICUS)  TENNESSEE TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY ( 45,270), ASSESSMENT OF NEWLY DISCOVERED BARRENS TOPMINNOW (FUNDULUS JULISIA) POPULATION IN THE MIDDLE COLLINS RIVER - TENNESSEE TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY ( 20,751), ASSESSING THE VULNERABILITY OF THE CUMBERLAND DUSKY SALAMANDER (DESMOGNATHUS ABDITUS) TO CLIMATE AND LAND-USE CHANGE  UNIVERSITY OF THE SOUTH ( 7,747).

IN LIGHT OF THE ANNOUNCEMENT THAT THE NOAA GALVESTON LABORATORY HAS ENDED ITS SEA TURTLE STRANDING AND REHABILITATION PROGRAM, THE GULF CENTER FOR SEA TURTLE RESEARCH AT TEXAS A M UNIVERSITY HAS TAKEN THE LEAD ON THESE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN 2019. IN DECEMBER 2020, THE GULF CENTER FOR SEA TURTLE RESEARCH AT TEXAS A M UNIVERSITY OPENED A SMALL, TEMPORARY REHABILITATION HOSPITAL ON THE TAMUG CAMPUS. ALTHOUGH A NEW REHABILITATION HOSPITAL AND EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH CENTER ON THE TEXAS A M UNIVERSITY AT GALVESTON (TAMUG) CAMPUS HAS BEEN PROPOSED, SUCH AN ENDEAVOR WILL TAKE  3-YEARS TO IMPLEMENT. IN THE MEAN-TIME, ADDITIONAL RESOURCES ARE NEEDED TO SUPPORT AND GROW THIS NEW SEA TURTLE RESCUE PROGRAM AND SEA TURTLE HOSPITAL UNTIL THE NEW FACILITY CAN BE FINANCIALLY INDEPENDENT. FURTHERMORE, WITH THE RECENT INCREASING NUMBER OF SEA TURTLES IN NEED OF RESCUE, RECOVERY, AND REHABILITATION DUE TO COLD STUNS AND OTHER PHENOMENON IN THE ENVIRONMENT CAUSING INCREASED STRANDINGS (I.E. 2022 LOGGERHEAD STRANDING EVENT), ADDITIONAL RESOURCES ARE IN GREATER NEED THAN EVER.

BIG RED SAGE (SALVIA PENTSTEMONOIDES) IS CRITICALLY IMPERILED ACROSS ITS RANGE, WITH FEWER THAN 10 POPULATIONS KNOWN IN THE EDWARDS PLATEAU ECOREGION OF CENTRAL TEXAS. THOUGH THIS SPECIES HAS EXHIBITED SOME SUCCESS IN CULTIVATION, THE PROVENANCE OF THE SOURCE STOCK IS GENERALLY UNKNOWN, AND THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT THESE INDIVIDUALS MAY EXHIBIT LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY COMPARED TO WILD POPULATIONS. THUS, CULTIVATED PLANTS MAY BE OF LIMITED USE FOR CONSERVATION ACTIONS SUCH AS REINTRODUCTION OR SEED BANKING. TO PROTECT THIS SPECIES IN THE FACE OF CONTINUED ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS, WE PROPOSE TO SURVEY FOR PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN POPULATIONS IN THE WILD AND USE CAREFUL NURSERY GROW-OUT, PROPAGATION, AND SEED BANKING TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND GENETIC DIVERSITY OF SEEDS AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION OF THIS RARE TEXAS ENDEMIC. WE REQUEST FUNDING FOR THREE YEARS, PRIMARILY TO SUPPORT STAFF AT THE LBJ WILDFLOWER CENTER TO SURVEY KNOWN AND NEW POPULATIONS, COLLECT SEEDS, AND LEAD PROPAGATION EFFORTS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL INCORPORATES CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THREE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) LISTED FISH SPECIES IN NEVADA: CLOVER VALLEY SPECKLED DACE (RHINICHTHYS OSCULUS OLIGOPORUS) ENDANGERED   RAILROAD VALLEY SPRINGFISH (CRENICHTHYS NEVADAE)  THREATENED   AND DESERT DACE (EREMICHTHYS ACROS)  THREATENED . IN ADDITION, NUMEROUS ENDEMIC SPRINGSNAIL SPECIES AND THE WESTERN RIDGED MUSSEL (GONDIDEA ANGULATE) OCCUR WITHIN THE GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE (NEVADA AND UTAH) OF THE PROJECT PROPOSAL AND ARE CURRENTLY UNDERGOING PROPOSED ESA LISTING REVIEW BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS). FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES, AND THOSE UNDER REVIEW, INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT ALL OCCUR IN GEOGRAPHIC PROXIMITY TO EACH OTHER, IN ISOLATED BASIN SYSTEMS IN NORTHERN AND NORTH-CENTRAL NEVADA. THIS PROJECT ALSO BENEFITS AT LEAST 19 OTHER IDENTIFIED AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), WHERE THEY OCCUR IN THE SAME OR ADJACENT HABITATS, WITHIN THE GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT.CURRENT, ONGOING ANNUAL EFFORTS INVOLVING SPECIES SURVEYS, STATUS MONITORING, IDENTIFICATION AND IMPLEMENTATIONOF ACTIONS TO SECURE AND ENHANCE HABITATS, AND RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION COORDINATION BETWEEN THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW), THE FWS, AND OTHER PARTNERS ARE ESSENTIAL TO PRECLUDE SPECIES EXTINCTION AND OR LOSS OF INDIVIDUAL FISH POPULATIONS AND MAINTAIN PROGRESS TOWARDS EVENTUAL RECOVERY OF THESE SPECIES. A SIMILAR APPROACH IS NEEDED IN REGARD TO PETITIONED MOLLUSK SPECIES SO THAT NDOW MAY ASSIST THE FWS IN THEIR REVIEW PROCESS AND DEVELOPMENT OF SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS (SSA). AN UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES  LIFE HISTORY, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CONDITIONS, AND SPECIES INTERACTIONS IS NEEDED IN ORDER TO ASSESS RISK AND DEVELOP SOUND MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERY STRATEGIES FOR ALL NATIVE, AQUATIC, NONGAME SPECIES.NEEDS, OBJECTIVES, APPROACHES, AND EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS FROM THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT ARE IDENTIFIED IN DETAIL WITHIN THE PROJECT STATEMENT. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE SPECIES SURVEY AND MONITORING, COORDINATION WITH FWS AND OTHER AGENCIES AND ENTITIES, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, IMPLEMENTING SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENTS, AND CONDUCTING HABITAT RESTORATION WHERE APPROPRIATE. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE THE ACQUISITION OF UPDATED POPULATION STATUS INFORMATION  ADDITIONAL COMPLETED HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS  CONTINUED COORDINATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTI-PARTY CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS  A REDUCTION IN NONNATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS  AND CONTINUED COORDINATED EXECUTION OF CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY STRATEGIES AND ACTIONS, AND EVENTUAL DELISTING FOR THESE LISTED SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL INCORPORATES CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR TWELVE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) LISTED FISH SPECIES IN NEVADA: DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH (CYPRINODON DIABOLIS)  ENDANGERED , MOAPA DACE (MOAPA CORIACEA)  ENDANGERED , RAZORBACK SUCKER (XYRAUCHEN TEXANUS)  ENDANGERED , BONYTAIL (GILA ELEGANS)  ENDANGERED , WOUNDFIN (PLAGOPTERUS ARGENTISSIMUS)  ENDANGERED , VIRGIN RIVER CHUB (GILA SEMINUDA)  ENDANGERED , WHITE RIVER SPRINGFISH (CRENICHTHYS BAILEYI)  ENDANGERED , HIKO WHITE RIVER SPRINGFISH (CRENICHTHYS BAILEYI GRANDIS)  ENDANGERED , PAHRANAGAT ROUNDTAIL CHUB (GILA ROBUSTA JORDANI)  ENDANGERED , PAHRUMP POOLFISH (EMPETRICHTHYS LATOS)  ENDANGERED , BIG SPRING SPINEDACE (LEPIDOMEDA MOLLISPINIS PRATENSIS)  THREATENED , AND WHITE RIVER SPINEDACE (LEPIDOMEDA ALBIVALLIS)  ENDANGERED . THESE FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ALL OCCUR IN GEOGRAPHIC PROXIMITY, IN SOUTHERN NEVADA WITHIN THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER BASIN AND TRIBUTARIES, IN DISJUNCT PORTIONS OF THE WHITE RIVER AND MEADOW VALLEY WASH DRAINAGE SYSTEMS, AND ADJACENT AREAS OF WHITE PINE COUNTY, NEVADA, EXCEPT FOR DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH, WHICH OCCURS WITHIN THE AMARGOSA RIVER BASIN, AND CERTAIN REFUGE POPULATIONS OF THE PAHRUMP POOLFISH IN CLARK COUNTY. THIS PROJECT ALSO BENEFITS MORE THAN 26 OTHER NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), THAT ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE NEVADA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), WHERE THEY OCCUR IN THE SAME OR ADJACENT HABITATS WITHIN THE GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT.CURRENT, ONGOING ANNUAL EFFORTS INVOLVING SPECIES SURVEYS, STATUS MONITORING, IDENTIFICATION AND IMPLEMENTATIONOF ACTIONS TO SECURE AND ENHANCE HABITATS, AND RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION COORDINATION BETWEEN THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW), THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), AND OTHER PARTNERS ARE ESSENTIAL TO PRECLUDE SPECIES EXTINCTION AND OR LOSS OF INDIVIDUAL FISH POPULATIONS AND MAINTAIN PROGRESS TOWARDS EVENTUAL RECOVERY OF THESE SPECIES. AN UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES  LIFE HISTORY, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CONDITIONS, AND SPECIES INTERACTIONS IS NEEDED IN ORDER TO ASSESS RISK AND DEVELOP SOUND MANAGEMENT,CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERY STRATEGIES FOR ALL NATIVE, AQUATIC, NONGAME SPECIES.NEEDS, OBJECTIVES, APPROACHES, AND EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS FROM THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT ARE IDENTIFIED IN DETAIL WITHIN THE PROJECT STATEMENT. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE SPECIES SURVEY AND MONITORING, COORDINATION WITH FWS AND OTHER AGENCIES AND ENTITIES, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, IMPLEMENTING SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENTS, AND CONDUCTING HABITAT RESTORATION WHERE APPROPRIATE. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE THE ACQUISITION OF UPDATED POPULATION STATUS INFORMATION  ADDITIONAL COMPLETED HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS  CONTINUED COORDINATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTI-PARTY CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS  A REDUCTION IN NONNATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS  AND CONTINUED COORDINATED EXECUTION OF CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY STRATEGIES AND ACTIONS, AND EVENTUAL DELISTING FOR THESE LISTED SPECIES.

KENTUCKY ENDANGERED PLANT PROGRAM PROJECT E-1-38 PROJECTS INVOLVE SURVEYS, MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND GLOBALLY RARE PLANTS IN KENTUCKY. THE PLANTS INVOLVED IN STUDY 166-170 INCLUDE BRAUNS ROCKCRESS (BOECHERA PERSTELLATA), PRICES POTATO BEAN (APIOS PRICEANA), GLOBE BLADDERPOD (PHYSARIA GLOBOSA), VIRGINIA SPIRAEA (SPIRAEA VIRGINIANA), CUMBERLAND SANDWORT (MINUARTIA CUMBERLANDENSIS), SHORTS GOLDENROD (SOLIDAGO SHORTII) AND SURVEYS OF AT RISK PLANTS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO RECOVER FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS IN KENTUCKY AND WORK ON GLOBALLY RARE PLANTS TO PREVENT FUTURE FEDERAL LISTINGS.

APPLEGATE S MILKVETCH IS AN EXCEEDINGLY RARE MEMBER OF THE FABACEAE FAMILY THAT IS RESTRICTED TO THE LOWER KLAMATH BASIN OF SOUTHERN OREGON, NEAR THE CITY OF KLAMATH FALLS. ODA IS PROPOSING A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT WHICH WILL INCLUDE  BASELINE AND TREATMENT-ASSESSMENT MONITORING AND USE RESEARCH FINDINGS TO PROVIDE BASIS FOR ODA USFWS APPROVAL OF OPRD PLAN FOR PARK MAINTENANCE. THE PLAN WILL SPECIFY APPROVED TREATMENT METHODS, CHEMICALS, AND TIMINGS. THE FINDINGS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL IMPACT HOW THE SPECIES IN MANAGED THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE.BRADSHAW S LOMATIUM IS A PERENNIAL HERB NATIVE TO WET PRAIRIE HABITATS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, OREGON ANDSOUTHWEST WASHINGTON. THE SPECIESWHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY FEDERALLY ENDANGEREDWAS DELISTED IN APRIL 2021,INITIATING POST-DELISTING MONITORING (PDM) REQUIREMENTS. THE FINAL PDM PLAN CALLS FOR A SUBSET OF 18 SITES TO BEMONITORED OVER SIX YEARS, DIVIDED INTO A AND B MONITORING YEARS. IN 2022, THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OFAGRICULTURE (ODA) MONITORED A SUBSET OF  B  SITES AND OTHER SITES NOT INCLUDED IN THE PDM PLAN. IN 2024, ODAPROPOSES SELECTING PRIORITY  B  SITES THAT DO NOT HAVE MONITORING REQUIREMENTS AND IDENTIFYING ADDITIONAL SITESTHAT ARE DEEMED HIGH PRIORITY, AND COLLECTING INFORMATION ON POPULATION SIZE, STATUS, AND SITE MANAGEMENT. THISDATA IS CRITICAL FOR THE USFWS. IF SUBSTANTIAL DECLINE OR INCREASE IN THREATS ARE DETECTED, THE SERVICE CAN TAKEACTION TO HALT THE DECLINE OR THE SPECIES MAY REQUIRE RELISTING.HOWELLS SPECTACULAR THELYPODY IS AN EXCEEDINGLY RARE MEMBER OF THE MUSTARD FAMILY THAT IS ONLY FOUND IN EASTERN OREGON. ODA PROPOSED A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT THAT WOULD INCLUDE 1) DEVELOPING A SEED-INCREASE PROGRAM TO GENERATE A LARGE VOLUME OF SEED OFF-SITE, 2) ADDITIONAL SURVEYS OF THELYPODY SITES ACROSS THE SPECIES RANGE, AND 3) CREATION OF A STAKEHOLDER GROUP. IN 2023, ODA WILL INITIATE YEAR 1 OF THIS PROJECT, WHICH INCLUDES YEAR 1 OF THE SEED INCREASE PROGRAM AND MONITORING OF THE TWO LARGEST NATURAL POPULATIONS. IN YEAR 2 OF THIS PROJECT, ODA PROPOSES SUBAWARDING FUNDS TO THE INSTITUTE FOR APPLIED ECOLOGY TO CULTIVATE ADDITIONAL THELYPODY IN A SECOND ROUND OF THE SEED INCREASE PROGRAM, COLLECTING SEEDS FROM YEAR 1 PLANTS (CULTIVATED BY ODA) AND DISPERSING SEEDS AT SELECTED SITES, AND MONITORING SEED INTRODUCTION SITES THE YEAR AFTER SEEDING (2025).TWENY YEARS AFTER ROUGH POPCORNFLOWER WAS FEDERALLY LISTED, THE SPECIES IS NEARING RECOVERY.  THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE PROPOSES A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT TO ADDRESS UNMEANT RECOVERY CRITERIA.  ACROSS TWO FUNDING YEARS ODA WILL MONITOR PRIORITY POPULATIONS, COLLECT WILD SEED FOR LONG-TERM STORAGE AT PRIORITY POPULATIONS, INITIATE A NEW ROUND OF SEED INCREASE USING BANKED SEED FROM CALAPOOYA CREEK RECOVERY UNIT, AND SPREAD BULKED SEED AT ADDITIONAL LOCATIONS TO INCREASE OCCUPIED HABITAT AREA AND NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS.  ADDITIONAL ODA PROPOSES USING ESA SECTION 6 AWARDS TO FUND LONG-TERM PLANT SPONSORSHIP OF EX-SITU P. HIRTUS SEEDS AT THE RAE SELLING BERRY SEED BANK.

THIS PROJECT INITIATES THE MONITORING OF ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF BULL TROUT SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS IN A COASTAL TRIBUTARY AND CONTINUES MONITORING IN A TRIBUTARY OF THE UPPER COLUMBIA RIVER. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO MONITOR BULL TROUT POPULATIONS THAT ARE LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND DOCUMENT CHANGES IN THEIR ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION SO WE CAN EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF LONG-TERM RECOVERY EFFORTS.

FENDERS BLUE BUTTERFLY (ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI  FBB), A FEDERAL THREATENED SPECIES, IS FOUND ONLY IN THEWILLAMETTE VALLEY OF OREGON. THE LOW ABUNDANCE OF THIS BUTTERFLY MAKES IT A HIGH PRIORITY FOR CONSERVATION ANDMANAGEMENT. FBB IS DEPENDENT ON NATIVE GRASSLAND HABITATS AND ITS PREFERRED HOST PLANT, KINCAIDS LUPINE (LUPINUSSULPHUREUS SSP. KINCAIDII), A FEDERAL THREATENED SPECIES. HABITATS SUPPORTING THESE TWO SPECIES ARE THREATENED BYINVASION OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS, WOODY PLANT SUCCESSION, AND DEVELOPMENT.SUCCESSFUL RECOVERY OF FBB IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY DEPENDS ON ENHANCEMENT OF EXISTING POPULATIONS THROUGHHABITAT MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE ENHANCEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND RESTORATION OFNATIVE PRAIRIE AT WILLOW CREEK AND COBURG RIDGE PRESERVES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WE WILL IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENTACTIONS ON OVER 170 ACRES OF FBB CRITICAL HABITAT AND SURROUNDING AREAS TO MEET THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE TOPROVIDE HIGH QUALITY NATIVE PRAIRIE HABITAT AND INCREASE AND SUSTAIN FBB POPULATIONS.TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES, WE WILL USE A COMBINATION OF MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES WHICH COULD INCLUDE MOWING,HERBICIDE APPLICATION, CLEAR PLASTIC SOLARIZATION, CONTROLLED BURNING, AND SEEDING. PLANT SELECTION WILL INCLUDENATIVE FORBS WITH AN EMPHASIS ON NECTAR PLANTS, KINCAIDS LUPINE SEEDS AND A SUITE OF UPLAND PRAIRIE ASSOCIATEDSPECIES. IN GENERAL, INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT WILL OCCUR IN EARLY SPRING OR FALL. FBB POPULATION MONITORINGWILL OCCUR IN LATE SPRING AND EARLY SUMMER AND BURNING, MOWING, AND SEEDING WILL OCCUR IN FALL WHEN CONDITIONSARE SUITABLE

THE MARIANA CROW IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES CURRENTLY ONLY FOUND ON THE ISLAND OF ROTA, COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. THE LAST PUBLISHED COUNT ESTIMATED THE POPULATION AT 178 INDIVIDUALS (KRONER   HA 2017). RECENT, UNPUBLISHED COUNTS SHOW THAT THE POPULATION HAS INCREASED TO 56 BREEDING PAIRS AND AT LEAST 200 INDIVIDUALS. POPULATION MONITORING IS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE CAPTIVE REAR-AND-RELEASE PROGRAM. THE MARIANA CROW CONSERVATION RESEARCH PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE TWO COMPONENTS: (1) A DEPARTMENT OF LANDS AND NATURAL RESOURCES-LED EFFORT TO OVERSEE THE RESEARCH PROGRAM AND ACT AS A POINT OF CONTACT FOR THE DEPARTMENT ON MARIANA CROW ISSUES, AND (2) CONTINUATION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON RESEARCH EFFORT ON ROTA, TO UNDERTAKE POPULATION MONITORING, NEST SEARCHING AND MONITORING, RADIO-TELEMETRY OF RELEASED BIRDS, AND OUTREACH (THIS GRANT PROPOSAL).

THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER HAS BEEN A SPECIES OF CONCERN IN OREGON FOR OVER 3 DECADES AND WAS STATE LISTED IN 1989 UNDER THE OREGON ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THE SPECIES WAS SUBSEQUENTLY LISTED ALONG THE PACIFIC COAST BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IN 1993 AND A DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN WAS DEVELOPED AND FINALIZED IN 2007 (USFWS 2007). THE LIMITING FACTORS ON THE COASTAL POPULATION IN OREGON INCLUDE CHANGES AND LOSS OF HABITAT, INCREASED HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND DISTURBANCE, INCREASED PREDATION DUE TO HUMAN CAUSED CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT, AND INSUFFICIENT KNOWLEDGE ON THE STATUS AND ECOLOGY OF THE SPECIES.STATE MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY ACTIONS HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN SINCE THE LATE 1970 S, INITIALLY ORIENTED TOWARD REDUCING RECREATIONAL IMPACTS ON AREAS USES BY PLOVERS. SINCE 1990, RECOVERY EFFORTS HAVE BEEN EXTENDED TO NEST AND BROOD PROTECTION, EXTENSIVE HABITAT RESTORATION, DIRECTED PREDATOR MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION AS OUTLINED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN (LAUTEN ET AL. 2021, USFWS 2007). IN OCTOBER 2007, THE OREGON PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT (OPRD) COMPLETED A REVISED HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN AND DRAFT EIS TO OBTAIN AN INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMIT FOR THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER ON COASTAL BEACHES (ICF INTERNATIONAL 2010). THE INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMIT ALLOWS SOME LEVEL OF TAKE (HARM) IN EXCHANGE FOR MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MONITOR AND PROTECT BREEDING PLOVERS ON LANDS MANAGED BY OPRD. OREGON WORKS CLOSELY WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANAGEMENT AGENCIES IN WASHINGTON AS PART OF THE SAME RECOVERY UNIT UNDER THE FEDERAL RECOVERY PLAN (WDFW 2008). SNOWY PLOVERS BANDED IN OREGON ARE NOW FOUND ON WASHINGTON BEACHES IN GREATER NUMBERS.THE POPULATION DECLINE OF THE 70 S AND 80 S HAS BEEN REVERSED. IN 2022 WE ESTIMATED 508 ADULT PLOVERS AT THE MONITORED SITES (THIS DOES NOT INCLUDE PLOVERS THAT HAVE BEGUN TO NEST IN AREAS NOT MONITORED BY OREGON BIODIVERSITY INFORMATION CENTER (ORBIC)). WE MONITORED 529 NESTS DURING THE 2022 FIELD SEASON AND DOCUMENTED AT LEAST 130 FLEDGLINGS. BECAUSE OF THE INCREASED PLOVER POPULATION, IT HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY DIFFICULT TO LOCATE ALL NESTS AND FOLLOW BROODS THROUGH FLEDGING WITH EXISTING STAFF. AS A RESULT, IN 2023 AND BEYOND WE PLAN TO BAND BETWEEN 50 AND 80  OF KNOWN BROODS FROM EACH SITE AND FOLLOW THAT SAMPLE THROUGH FLEDGING. WE WILL USE THIS SAMPLE OF BROODS TO ESTIMATE SITE AND OVERALL PRODUCTIVITY. WE WILL CONTINUE TO ATTEMPT TO LOCATE ALL NESTS AND DETERMINE THEIR FATE, TO ALLOW ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AND COORDINATION WITH WILDLIFE SERVICES.FIELD OBJECTIVES FOR THE 2024 WILL INCLUDE:- CONDUCT SURVEYS AT ALL CORE PLOVER SITES (FIGURE 1) TO COUNT ADULTS PRESENT DURING THE BREEDING SEASON- LOCATE AS MANY NESTS AS POSSIBLE DURING THE BREEDING SEASON (WE WILL ATTEMPT TO LOCATE ALL NESTS, THOUGH EACH YEAR SOME GO UNDETECTED)- DOCUMENT NEST LOCATIONS WITH GPS- DEPLOY NEST CAMERAS AS APPROPRIATE AND AS ALLOWED BY USFWS RECOVERY PERMIT- DETERMINE FATE OF ALL KNOWN NESTS- DOCUMENT PREDATION AND OTHER CAUSES OF NEST AND BROOD FAILURE- BAND BROODS AT 50-80  OF THE KNOWN NESTS. EXACT PERCENTAGE OF BROODS BANDED DEPENDS ON SYNCHRONICITY OF NEST HATCHING. BECAUSE OF CONCERN AROUND HIGHLY PARTHENOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA (HPAI), WE DO NOT ANTICIPATE HANDLING OR BANDING ADULTS IN 2023, UNLESS HPAI CONDITIONS CHANGE.- MONITOR BANDED BROODS TO DETERMINE FLEDGING SUCCESS- RECORD HUMAN-RELATED DISTURBANCE AT NESTING SITES- PROVIDE INFORMATION TO COOPERATORS DURING THE COURSE OF THE FIELD SEASON- PROMOTE SCIENTIFIC EXCHANGE WITHIN AND BETWEEN RECOVERY UNITS BY PARTICIPATING IN RU1 AND RANGE-WIDE WORKING TEAM MEETINGS

THE PURPOSE AND DESIRED FUTURE STATE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE ERADICATION OF LFA FROM THE DOAG-FSRD NURSERIES AND NEIGHBORING DOAG-DAWR RAIL YARD. INCLUDING, THE PREVENTION OF THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE LFA ACROSS MANAGEMENT AREAS TO PROMOTE SPECIES RECOVERY EFFORTS. THE GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FORESTRY AND SOIL RESOURCES DIVISION S (DOAG-FSRD) NURSERIES AND OPERATIONAL SPACES ARE BEING INVADED BY THE INVASIVE LITTLE FIRE ANT (LFA), (WASMANNIA AUROPUNCTATA). THE LFA HAVE SPREAD FROM THE ADJACENT PRIVATE PROPERTIES TO THE DOAG-FSRD AND DOAG DIVISION OF AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES (DOAG-DAWR) RAIL YARD.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPILE SURVEY AND MONITORING DATA ON STATE ENDANGERED, THREATENED, AND SENSITIVE VASCULAR PLANT AND LICHEN SPECIES FROM WASHINGTON STATE THAT MIGHT QUALIFY FOR STATUS UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) DUE TO HIGH THREATS, INADEQUATE PROTECTION, AND OTHER CRITERIA USED BY USFWS IN EVALUATING SPECIES FOR POTENTIAL LISTING. THESE SPECIES (39 TAXA IDENTIFIED IN THE LIST ABOVE) WERE DETERMINED THROUGH EARLIER WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (WNHP) SECTION 6 PROJECTS WITH USFWS THAT ASSESSED THE CURRENT STATUS OF G1, G2, T1, OR T2 PLANT SPECIES IN THE STATE BASED ON THE SERVICES FIVE LISTING CRITERIA AND THE ADEQUACY OF EXISTINGINFORMATION (E.G. FERTIG 2020), AS WELL AS RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE NORTHWEST LICHENOLOGISTS, A PROFESSIONAL GROUP OF LICHEN EXPERTS. THIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE AVAILABLE DISTRIBUTION, THREATS, AND TREND INFORMATION FOR EACH SPECIES, ALLOWING FOR THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF EACH SPECIES TO BE REVIEW. THE DATA RESULTING FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL BEMAINTAINED BY THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (WNHP) IN A SERIES OF DATABASES (BIOTICS, GIS, OBSERVATION DATABASE, WNHP DATA EXPLORER) THAT ARE AVAILABLE TO US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE STAFF, OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE RESORCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES (SUCH AS THE US FOREST SERVICE, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, WA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, WA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES) AND THE PUBLIC. CURRENT, ACCURATE, AND CENTRALLY DEPOSITED INFORMATION ON THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, THREATS, AND HABITAT NEEDS OF LISTED PLANT SPECIES IS ESSENTIAL FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND TO MEET REGULATORY AND RECOVERY OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. WNHP HAS PARTNERED WITH USFWS FOR OVER 40 YEARS IN PROVIDING THESE VITAL INFORMATIONMANAGEMENT SERVICES AND IN SHARING BIOLOGICAL EXPERTISE THROUGH STAFF PARTICIPATION IN SPECIES TECHNICAL COMMITTEES AND ANNUAL REPORTS SUMMARIZING ONGOING MONITORING AND RESEARCH. UPDATED INFORMATION ON THE STATUS, LIFE HISTORY, ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, AND DISTRIBUTION OF RARE PLANT AND LICHEN SPECIES HELPS USFWS AND OTHER FEDERAL AND STATEAGENCIES, LAND TRUSTS, CONSULTANTS, AND THE PUBLIC BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CONSERVATION NEEDS OF RARE PLANT SPECIES.

THE WESTERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO (YBCU) IS CURRENTLY LISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED. THE IDAHO STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN LISTS YBCU AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (TIER 1). THE PRIMARY THREAT TO YBCU ACROSS ITS RANGE IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES IS LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF MULTI-LAYERED RIPARIAN HABITAT. THE MOST EXTENSIVE YBCU HABITAT IN THE STATE OF IDAHO OCCURS IN THE COTTONWOOD RIPARIAN SYSTEMS OF EASTERN IDAHO ALONG THE SNAKE RIVER. FORMAL STANDARDIZED SURVEYS FOR YBCU CONDUCTED IN 2018 AND 2019 WITH SECTION 6 FUNDING DOCUMENTED YBCU IN AND DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO OUR PROPOSED RESTORATION AREA. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE RESTORATION STRATEGIES WITHIN FRAGMENTED HABITATS ALONG THE LOWER HENRYS FORK AIMED AT CREATING IMPROVED HABITAT FUNCTIONALITY AND HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR BREEDING SEASON YBCU. WE AIM TO CONTINUE A MULTI-FACETED RIPARIAN HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT THAT WILL SERVE MULTIPLE PURPOSES: (1) BUILD MOMENTUM FOR OUR SNAKE RIVER PARTNERSHIP BY INITIATING ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES IN YBCU HABITAT  (2) SERVE AS PILOT WORK FOR DEVELOPING METHODOLOGIES TO RESTORE THE MULTI-LAYERED RIPARIAN VEGETATION NECESSARY FOR YBCU PERSISTENCE  (3) CONNECT STRETCHES OF DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT THAT ARE FRAGMENTED BY VARIOUS ANTHROPOGENIC FEATURES AND PRACTICES  AND (4) ULTIMATELY CREATE MEASURABLE INCREASES IN USABLE YBCU HABITAT IN THE SNAKE RIVER CONFLUENCE AREA.

THE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL (UROCITELLUS BRUNNEUS  NIDGS) IS A FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED SPECIES. THE RECOVERY PLAN, PUBLISHED IN 2003, ESTABLISHED CRITERIA FOR ASSESSING HOW THE SPECIES WAS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY AND EVENTUAL DELISTING. THOSE CRITERIA INCLUDED GOALS FOR NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION ON THE LANDSCAPE. ANNUAL POPULATION MONITORING SURVEYS HAVE SHOWN THAT SEVERAL METRICS OF ABUNDANCE AND TREND HAVE BEEN ON AN UPWARD TRAJECTORY SINCE 2011 AND ARE SUBSTANTIALLY HIGHER THAN WHEN THE RECOVERY PLAN WAS PUBLISHED IN 2003. HOWEVER, NO POPULATION METRIC IDENTIFIED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN HAS BEEN ACHIEVED. NIDGS STILL OCCURS MOST FREQUENTLY IN SMALL POPULATIONS THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY AND GENETICALLY SEPARATED FROM ONE ANOTHER. WELL-DEFINED, REPEATABLE SURVEYS ARE NEEDED TO TRACK IF, AND TO WHAT EXTENT, THE NIDGS POPULATION IS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY. WITHOUT SUCH DATA, RECOVERY CRITERIA CANNOT BE MEASURED, AND IT BECOMES MORE DIFFICULT TO DIRECT MEANINGFUL CONSERVATION ACTIONS WHERE THEY WILL HAVE THE MOST BENEFIT. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OBTAIN CURRENT INFORMATION ON NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION USING A PROVEN SURVEY DESIGN, ANALYZE RESULTS TO ASSESS POPULATION TRAJECTORY, AND SHARE THIS INFORMATION WITH OTHER PARTNERS IN RECOVERY TO INFORM THEIR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HABITAT, EVALUATE NIDGS RESPONSE TO HABITAT TREATMENTS, AND DEVELOP CONSERVATION ACTIONS ON PRIVATE LAND. CHANGES IN DISTRIBUTION DETECTED ON SURVEYS WILL INFLUENCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL AID IN DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND, ULTIMATELY, RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. ANTICIPATED PRODUCTS INCLUDE (1) A STATISTICAL SUMMARY AND FINAL REPORT OF 2023 SURVEY DATA, INCLUDING ESTIMATES OF NIDGS ABUNDANCE, POPULATION TREND, AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION  (2) UPDATED SPATIAL DATA LAYERS OF NIDGS OCCURRENCE THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO RECOVERY PARTNERS  AND (3) A COMPLETE DATASET OF SURVEY RESULTS FROM THE 2024 FIELD SEASON.

THE AMOUNT OF WETLAND HABITAT IN NORTH AMERICA HAS DECLINED SIGNIFICANTLY DURING THE PAST CENTURY, AND AS A RESULT, POPULATIONS OF MANY MARSH BIRDS THAT ARE DEPENDENT ON EMERGENT WETLANDS APPEAR TO BE DECLINING (EDDLEMAN ET AL. 1988). THE WESTERN YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO (COCCYZUS AMERICANUS) IS A NEOTROPICAL MIGRANT THAT WINTERS IN SOUTH AMERICA AND BREEDS IN RIPARIAN WOODLANDS IN WESTERN NORTH AMERICA. THE CUCKOO HAS DECLINED FROM MUCH OF ITS HISTORIC RANGE IN THE WESTERN U.S., AND THESE DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO PESTICIDE USE, LOSS OF RIPARIAN HABITAT IN NESTING AREAS AS A CONSEQUENCE OF FRAGMENTATION, INUNDATION BY RESERVOIRS, STREAM CHANNELIZATION, AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT. THIS SPECIES IS ELUSIVE, SECRETIVE, AND OFTEN EXHIBITS ERUPTIVE BREEDING BEHAVIOR, ALL OF WHICH MAKE IT DIFFICULT TO DETECT, DOCUMENT NESTING ACTIVITY, OR ACCURATELY ESTIMATE THE TREND OF CUCKOO OCCURRENCE AND BREEDING IN NEVADA. LIKEWISE, THE YUMA RIDGWAY S RAIL (RALLUS OBSOLETUS YUMANENSIS-FORMERLY YUMA CLAPPER RAIL) A SECRETIVE, FRESHWATER MARSH-OBLIGATE, WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 1967 BY THE FWS, AND IS ALSO STATE PROTECTED ENDANGERED IN NEVADA. HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, STREAM CHANNELIZATION AND DREDGING, WATER FLOW AND FLOOD CONTROL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND DRAINING AND DRYING OF WETLANDS ARE PRIMARY CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE DEGRADATION OF HABITAT THAT HAS LED TO RAIL POPULATION DECLINES. ANOTHER SPECIES THAT THIS EFFORT COULD POTENTIALLY OBSERVE IS THE SOUTHWESTERN WILLOW FLYCATCHER (EMPIDONAX TRAILLII EXTIMUS  HEREAFTER FLYCATCHER). THE FLYCATCHER WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) IN FEBRUARY OF 1995 (USFWS 1995). THE FLYCATCHER BREEDS IN DENSE RIPARIAN HABITAT, AND THEIR RECENT POPULATION DECLINES HAVE BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO THE LOSS, FRAGMENTATION, ALTERATION AND OR DEGRADATION OF BREEDING HABITAT, BROOD PARASITISM BY BROWN-HEADED COWBIRDS (MOLOTHRUS ATER), NEST PREDATION, TAMARISK (TAMRIXAPHYLLA) DEFOLIATION DUE TO THE TAMARISK BEETLE (DIORHABDA SPP.), AND LOSS OF WINTERING HABITAT. SEVERAL RIPARIAN SYSTEMS IN SOUTHERN NEVADA PROVIDE IMPORTANT KNOWN AND POTENTIAL SUITABLE HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS ESA ENDANGERED, THREATENED, AND OR CANDIDATE SPECIES, INCLUDING THIS RAIL. NDOW WILL USE THIS FUNDING TO SYSTEMATICALLY EXPLORE THE USE OF PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING SYSTEMS AT SELECT SITES TO POTENTIALLY ESTABLISH HABITAT USE AND SURVEY EFFECTIVENESS FOR SPECIES DISTRIBUTION AND PREDICTIVE MODELING. THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY WILL ALLOW ESSENTIAL EQUIPMENT PURCHASING, DEPLOYMENT, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, AND EVALUATION OF USING PASSIVE ACOUSTICS SUPPLEMENTAL TO TRADITIONAL GROUND SURVEY TECHNIQUES. WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR MULTISPECIES USE THROUGH ACOUSTIC DATA COLLECTION (SPECIFICALLY WESTERN YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO, YUMA RIDGWAY S RAIL, AND POSSIBLE DETECTION OF SOUTHWESTERN WILLOW FLYCATCHER), NDOW COULD OPTIMIZE ACOUSTIC SURVEY TECHNIQUES USING ACOUSTIC FIELD EQUIPMENT, COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA USING AI SYSTEMS, AND SHARE MORE ACCURATE AND HIGHER ABUNDANCE OF DATA FROM FUTURE SURVEY EFFORTS.

THE VIRGINIA BIG-EARED BAT (CORYNORHINUS TOWNSENDII VIRGINIANUS) HAS BEEN DOCUMENTED FROM ELEVEN COUNTIES IN KENTUCKY. THESE SITES REPRESENT THE ENTIRETY OF THE WESTERN MANAGEMENT UNIT (DESIGNATED BY THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE) OF THE SPECIES (USFWS 2019). RECENT EFFORTS BY THE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES (KDFWR) HAVE RESULTED IN THE DOCUMENTATION OF THREE NEW MATERNITY SITES FOR THE SPECIES IN KENTUCKY. FURTHER DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS BY KDFWR HAS INDICATED THAT THE SPECIES MAY BE EXPERIENCING LIMITED REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS. ADDITIONALLY, BAND RECOVERY DATA MAY INDICATE THAT THE WESTERN MANAGEMENT UNIT CAN BE FURTHER DELINEATED INTO TWO GEOGRAPHIC AREAS WITH LIMITED MOVEMENT BETWEEN THESE AREAS. FINALLY, MICROCLIMATE DATA FROM WITHIN PRIORITY WINTER AND SUMMER SITES IS LACKING. AS CURRENT PROPOSED DOWN-LISTING CRITERIA FOR THE SPECIES INCLUDES PROTECTION OF 5-8 MAJOR MATERNITY AND 4-8 HIBERNACULA SITES (DEPENDING ON TOTAL POPULATION ESTIMATES FOR THE MANAGEMENT UNIT), SURVEY EFFORTS FOCUSED ON DETECTION OF NEW ROOST SITES ARE CRITICAL. FURTHER, CLARIFICATION OF REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND MOVEMENT BETWEEN FOCAL WINTER AND SUMMER SITES IS NECESSARY TO ADEQUATELY MANAGE THE SPECIES IN KENTUCKY.

TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE OR AT-RISK WILDLIFE, THE ALABAMA DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES MUST CONDUCT RESEARCH AND SURVEYS TO GAIN INFORMATIONAL DATA ON THESE SPECIES POPULATION STATUS, HABITAT, AND MOVEMENT TO MAKE INFORMED DECISION REGARDING CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY NEEDS. THIS ANNUAL ALABAMA SECTION 6 ENDANGERED SPECIES GRANT WILL FUND VARIOUS RESEARCH, SURVEY, MONITORING, AND PROJECTS AS WELL AS MANAGEMENT TOWARD HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS AND RECOVERY EFFORTS. THE ASSOCIATED GRANT PROJECTS HAVE VARIED OBJECTIVES RELATING TO CURRENT FEDERALLY LISTS OR AT-RISK SPECIES INFORMATION NEEDS THAT WILL ASSIST WITH SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVER ACTIONS NECESSARY TO SUSTAIN VIABLE POPULATIONS.

WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMAS) OWNED BY IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG) ARE HOME TO MULTIPLE POLLINATOR SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND MAY PLAY AN INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT ROLE IN POLLINATOR CONSERVATION INTO THE FUTURE. OF PARTICULAR INTEREST ARE THE WESTERN BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS) AND SUCKLEY CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS SUCKLEYI), TWO SPECIES THAT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN PETITIONED FOR LISTING AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED. THIS PROJECT WILL USE NEW POLLINATOR CONSERVATION AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT TOOLS PRODUCED BY THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST BUMBLE BEE ATLAS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR THESE TWO SPECIES AT IDFG WMAS. OVER THE COURSE OF TWO YEARS, THIS PROJECT WILL PURCHASE POLLINATOR FRIENDLY NATIVE SEEDS AND PLUGS AND PROVIDE THEM TO WMA MANAGERS TO HELP THEM IMPLEMENT HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIONS.

THESE FUNDS WILL SUPPLEMENT DATA MANAGEMENT EFFORTS WITHIN THE IDAHO FISH   WILDLIFE INFORMATION SYSTEM (IFWIS) BY FOCUSING ON THE PROCUREMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING SPATIAL AND TABULAR DATA FOR FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND PETITIONED SPECIES THAT ARE UNDER FWS REVIEW (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO: PINYON JAY, YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO, NORTHERN BOG LEMMING, LITTLE BROWN BAT, WOLVERINE,WHITEBARK PINE, MONARCH BUTTERFLY, WESTERN BUMBLE BEE, SUCKLEY S CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE, WESTERN RIDGED MUSSEL, GRIZZLY BEAR, NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL, SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS, SPALDING S CATCHFLY. INFORMATION GATHERED FROM CURRENT YEAR SECTION 6 GRANTS, PARTNER AGENCIES, NGOS, AND OR COMMUNITY SCIENCE EFFORTS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE IFWIS STATEWIDE COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE TO HELP INFORM FUTURE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN REVISION AND IMPLEMENTATION, IDFG TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND PROVIDE A FOUNDATION OF INFORMATION FOR THE IDAHO CONSERVATION PLANNER.

THE NON-NATIVE LAKE TROUT SUPPRESSION IN UPPER PRIEST LAKE (UPL) PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON REDUCING THREATS TO ESA LISTED BULL TROUT (SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS) AND OTHER NATIVE FISH SPECIES BY REMOVING NON-NATIVE LAKE TROUT FROM UPL. BULL TROUT IN UPL ARE LESS ABUNDANT THAN THEY HISTORICALLY WERE. LAKE TROUT EXPANSION IN UPL IS THE PRIMARY LIMITING FACTOR TO RECOVERY OF THIS BULL TROUT POPULATION. THEREFORE, LONG-TERM PERSISTENCE OF BULL TROUT IN UPL IS DEPENDENT ON MINIMIZING LAKE TROUT ABUNDANCE TO THE GREATEST EXTENT POSSIBLE. SPRING GILLNETTING IS AN EFFECTIVE METHOD OF SUPPRESSING LAKE TROUT IN UPL. AS EVIDENCE, BULL TROUT REDD COUNTS IN UPL SPAWNING TRIBUTARIES ARE TRENDING POSITIVELY FOLLOWING IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT IN PRIOR YEARS. THIS PROJECT WILL EMPLOY A COMMERCIAL SCALE GILLNETTING EFFORT IN MAY 2024 TO MAXIMIZE ANNUAL REMOVAL OF LAKE TROUT FROM UPL. COMMERCIAL GILLNETTING SERVICES, INCLUDING AN 11 M RESEARCH VESSEL AND CREW, WILL BE CONTRACTED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT. MORE THAN 49 KM OF GILL-NET EFFORT WILL BE APPLIED THROUGHOUT UPL IN A TWO-WEEK PERIOD. VARIABLE GILL-NET MESH SIZES WILL BE USED TO TARGET REMOVAL OF ALL SIZES OF LAKE TROUT. BASED ON IMPLEMENTATION IN PRIOR YEARS, WE ANTICIPATE REMOVAL OF 1,000 TO 3,000 LAKE TROUT IN THE TWO-WEEK NETTING PERIOD. SUCCESS OF LAKE TROUT REMOVAL EFFORT WILL BE EVALUATED PRIMARILY USING TRENDS IN BULL TROUT REDD OBSERVATIONS IN PRIMARY SPAWNING TRIBUTARIES OF UPL. A STABLE TO INCREASING LONG-TERM TREND IN REDDS COUNTED WILL BE AN INDICATION LAKE TROUT ARE BEING MANAGED EFFECTIVELY. IN ADDITION, TRENDS IN LAKE TROUT GILL-NET CATCH RATE WILL PROVIDE A METRIC TO EVALUATE PROGRESS MADE TOWARD MANAGING LAKE TROUT EXPANSION IN UPL.

A PETITION TO LIST THE PINYON JAY UNDER THE ESA WAS FILED IN THE SPRING OF 2022, LARGELY BASED ON LONG-TERM POPULATION DECLINES AND CONCERNS REGARDING THE CURRENT CONDITION OF THEIR PREFERRED HABITAT ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN (I.E., PINYON-JUNIPER). IN IDAHO, BREEDING COLONY LOCATIONS AND USE OF HABITAT LACKING PINYON PINES ARE POORLY UNDERSTOOD. SURVEYS TO DOCUMENT CURRENT BREEDING ACTIVITY AND POTENTIALLY UNIQUE HABITAT USE IN IDAHO WOULD INFORM FUTURE HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND FORTHCOMING SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT.

THE PACIFIC COASTAL POPULATION OF THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER (CHARADRIUS ALEXANDRINUS NIVOSUS) IS LISTED ASTHREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND AS ENDANGERED BY WASHINGTON STATE. MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ARE NEEDED TO SUPPORT THE PERSISTENCE OF THE SMALL POPULATION OF SNOWY PLOVERS FOUND IN WASHINGTON STATE AND FACILITATEPROGRESS TOWARD STATE AND FEDERAL RECOVERY. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON WINTERING AND BREEDING ADULT POPULATIONASSESSMENT, MANAGEMENT ACTION IMPLEMENTATION TO IMPROVE PLOVER NESTING SUCCESS, AND NEST AND CHICK MONITORING TO EVALUATE EFFICACY OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT RESTORATION ACTIONS FOR THE THREATENED OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (OSB)AT THE BIG CREEK MEADOW COMPLEX OF CARL G WASHBURNE STATE PARK. WORK WILL INVOLVE GROW OUT OF NECTAR PLANTS IN PLUG CONTAINERS, PLANTING OF THESE PLANTS, SEEDING WITH LARVAL HOST PLANTS AND NECTAR SPECIES, AND WEED CONTROL  COMPETING VEGETATION MANAGEMENT. RESTORATION OF EXISTING OSB HABITAT IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE SURVIVAL OF THE SPECIES. WITHOUT ACTIVE INTERVENTION TO REVERSE WEED AND SHRUB TREE INVASION OF MEADOW HABITATS, THE HABITAT THAT THE OSB DEPENDS ON WILL CONTINUE TO DECLINE UNTIL IT IS NO LONGER ABLE TO SUPPORT POPULATIONS.

HAWAII S INVERTEBRATES FACE DIRECT THREATS FROM HABITAT DESTRUCTION AND ALTERATION, LOSS OF HOST PLANTS, CLIMATECHANGE, AND THE INTRODUCTION OF NONNATIVE PREDATORS, COMPETITORS AND PATHOGENS. THE HAWAII INVERTEBRATE PROGRAM(HIP), WHICH ENCOMPASSES THE SNAIL EXTINCTION PREVENTION PROGRAM (SEPP), FACILITATES RESEARCH, CONSERVATION ANDAPPLIED MANAGEMENT OF SOME THE MOST RARE, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED NATIVE INVERTEBRATES ACROSS THE STATE. THEHIP AND SEPP PROGRAMS COLLABORATE WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AT MANOA (UHM), AS WELL AS OTHER STATE, FEDERALAND PRIVATE PARTNERS, TO IMPLEMENT NOVEL IN-SITU AND EX-SITU MANAGEMENT APPROACHES TO STABILIZE AND RECOVERDECLINING SPECIES. THE CAPTIVE REARING LABORATORIES CURRENTLY SUPPORT OVER 45 DIFFERENT INVERTEBRATE SPECIES FROMFIVE DIFFERENT ISLANDS. THESE FACILITIES PROVIDE A CRUCIAL GENETIC SAFETY NET FOR THE RARE SPECIES THEY HOUSE,SEVERAL OF WHICH ARE NOW EXTINCT IN THE WILD. FIELD STAFF CONDUCT SURVEYS, MONITORING, TRANSLOCATIONS ANDREINTRODUCTIONS OF TARGET SPECIES. CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF PREDATOR PROOF FENCES, PREDATOR CONTROL,HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ARE ALSO INTEGRAL TO SPECIES RECOVERY. FUNDS ARE REQUESTED TO CONTINUESUPPORT FOR HIP AND SEPP OPERATIONS AND STAFF ON OAHU AND MAUI. A SMALL AMOUNT OF FUNDING WILL ALSO BE DIRECTEDTO THE HAWAIIAN DROSOPHILA RESEARCH STOCK CENTER AT UHM, WHICH MAINTAINS STOCKS OF RARE PICTURE-WING DROSOPHILASPECIES, MANY WHICH ARE ALSO FROM POPULATIONS NO LONGER FOUND IN THE WILD.

PROJECT PURPOSEBULL TROUT IS A COLD-WATER FISH THAT IS NATIVE TO NORTHWESTERN NORTH AMERICA. WITHIN THE COTERMINOUS UNITED STATES, BULL TROUT OCCUPY STREAMS AND LAKES IN OREGON, WASHINGTON, IDAHO, MONTANA, AND NEVADA. BULL TROUT POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THEIR NATIVE RANGE HAVE DECLINED AS A RESULT OF HABITAT ALTERATION, FISHING PRESSURE, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, AND INTERACTIONS WITH NONNATIVE SPECIES. DUE TO THESE DECLINES, BULL TROUT WERE LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 1998.THE PRESENCE OF NONNATIVE BROOK TROUT POSES A SUBSTANTIAL THREAT TO BULL TROUT THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE. RANGE-WIDE, NONNATIVE BROOK TROUT ARE CONSIDERED TO REPRESENT A THREAT TO BULL TROUT WHERE THE SPECIES ARE SYMPATRIC DUE TO COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS AND HYBRIDIZATION. BROOK TROUT ARE KNOWN TO OCCUPY THE MINAM RIVER WATERSHED  HOWEVER, THE DISTRIBUTION OF BROOK TROUT AND THE EXTENT OF HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN BULL TROUT AND BROOK TROUT IN THE MINAM RIVER WATERSHED IS UNKNOWN. TO PROVIDE RESOURCE MANAGERS WITH CONTEMPORARY DATA NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS WITH RESPECT TO MANAGING BULL TROUT IN GENERAL, AND THE THREAT POSED BY NONNATIVE BROOK TROUT IN SPECIFIC, WE PROPOSE TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES FOR PORTIONS OF THE WALLOWA MINAM CORE AREA AND THE LITTLE MINAM CORE AREA: 1) ASSESS THE DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF BULL TROUT, BROOK TROUT, AND HYBRIDS IN THE HEADWATERS OF THE MINAM RIVER (A PORTION OF THE WALLOWA MINAM CORE AREA) AND THE LITTLE MINAM RIVER (THE LITTLE MINAM CORE AREA), 2) ASSESS THE RATE OF HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN BULL TROUT AND BROOK TROUT IN THE HEADWATERS OF THE MINAM RIVER AND THE LITTLE MINAM RIVER, AND 3) ASSESS POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTURE OF BULL TROUT WITHIN AND BETWEEN THE HEADWATERS OF THE MINAM RIVER AND THE LITTLE MINAM RIVER.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDWE WILL CONDUCT BACKPACK ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS IN PORTIONS OF THE MINAM RIVER WATERSHED TO SAMPLE BULL TROUT, BROOK TROUT, AND SUSPECTED HYBRIDS (I.E., CHAR). BACKPACK ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED BY A 2- OR 3-PERSON FIELD CREW AND SURVEYS WILL OCCUR AT SAMPLE SITES THAT ARE ABOUT 250 M LONG. BACKPACK ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED BY MAKING A SINGLE ELECTROFISHING PASS THROUGH THE SAMPLE SITE MOVING IN A DOWNSTREAM TO UPSTREAM DIRECTION. CHAR ENCOUNTERED DURING ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS WILL BE COUNTED, MEASURED FOR LENGTH, IDENTIFIED AS BULL TROUT, BROOK TROUT, OR SUSPECTED HYBRID, AND A SMALL TISSUE SAMPLE WILL BE EXCISED FROM THE UPPER LOBE OF THE CAUDAL FIN (FIN CLIP) AND WILL BE STORED FOR LATER GENETIC ANALYSIS. CHAR WILL BE RETURNED TO THE SAMPLE SITE WHERE THEY WERE COLLECTED  OTHER FISH SPECIES ENCOUNTERED DURING ELECTROFISHING SURVEYS WILL BE DOCUMENTED.WE WILL GENOTYPE CHAR TO CONFIRM SPECIES IDENTIFICATION. THESE DATA, COMBINED WITH SURVEY DATA, WILL ALLOW US TO IDENTIFY THE DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF CHAR IN THE STUDY AREA, IDENTIFY THE PROPORTION OF HYBRIDS IN THE STUDY AREA, AND ESTIMATED POPULATION GENETIC CHARACTERISTICS OF BULL TROUT IN THE STUDY AREA.DELIVERABLES, EXPECTED OUTCOMES, AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIESDATA FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN A REPORT TO THE FUNDING AGENCY AND AN ODFW REPORT. ADDITIONALLY, DATA FROM THIS PROJECT MAY BE USED BY RESOURCE MANAGERS FOR PRIORITIZING AREAS WITHIN THE WALLOWA MINAM CORE AREA FOR NONNATIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT.

THE KO KO  (HYPOTAENIDIA OWSTONI) AND SIHEK (TODIRAPMPHUS CINNAMOMINA) ARE TWO ENDEMIC GUAM SPECIES IMPACTED BY THE INTRODUCTION OF THE BROWN TREESNAKE (BOIGA IRREGULARIS). THESE SPECIES WERE BROUGHT INTO CAPTIVITY PRIOR TO THEIR EXTINCTION IN THE WILD IN THE MID-1980S. THIS PROJECT IS COMPLEMENTARY TO THE WORK DONE BY US ASSOCIATION OF ZOOS AND AQUARIUMS, WHICH ARE PARTNERS OF GUAM DEPT OF AGRICULTURE AND ARE CRUCIAL TO THE MAINTENANCE OF THESE BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY AND THE RESTORATION OF THEM TO GUAM. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE STAFF AND MOST NECESSITIES NEEDED TO MANAGE THE CAPTIVE POPULATIONS FOR KO KO  AND SIHEK ON GUAM. AS THE KO KO  AND SIHEK ARE TWO OF THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S TRUSTED RESOURCES, THIS PROJECT ENSURES THESE SPECIES WILL NOT GO EXTINCT.

HIGH QUALITY DATA ON FEDERALLY THREATENED, ENDANGERED. CANDIDATE, AND RECENTLY DELISTED SPECIES IS CRITICAL FOR ASSESSING POPULATION TRENDS, DEVELOPING RECOVERY PLANS, AND ASSESSING LONG-TERM OUTCOMES AFTER DELISTING. WNHP HAS PARTNERED WITH USFWS FOR OVER 40 YEARS BY PROVIDING CRITICAL RESEARCH AND MONITORING, VITAL INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SERVICES AND BY SHARING BIOLOGICAL EXPERTISE THROUGH STAFF PARTICIPATION IN SPECIES TECHNICAL COMMITTEES AND ANNUAL REPORTS SUMMARIZING ONGOING MONITORING AND RESEARCH. HERE, FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO PERFORM TARGETED MONITORING OF SIX FEDERALLY LISTED OR FEDERAL CANDIDATE SPECIES THAT WERE CO-IDENTIFIED BY USFWS ANDWNHP STAFF HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES FOR A TWO-YEAR PERIOD FROM 2024-2025. THE DATA RESULTING FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL BE MAINTAINED BY THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (WNHP) IN A SERIES OF DATABASES (BIOTICS, GIS, OBSERVATION DATABASE, WNHP DATA EXPLOER) THAT ARE AVAILABLE TO US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE STAFF, OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES (SUCH AS THE US FOREST SERVICE, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, WA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, WA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES) AND THE PUBLIC. CURRENT, ACCURATE, AND CENTRALLY DEPOSITED INFORMATION ON THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, THREATS, AND HABITAT NEEDS OF LISTED PLANT SPECIES IS ESSENTIAL FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND TO MEET REGULATORY AND RECOVERY OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. UPDATED INFORMATION ON THE STATUS, LIFE HISTORY, ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, AND DISTRIBUTION OF LISTED AND PROPOSED PLANT SPECIES HELPS USFWS AND OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, LAND TRUSTS, CONSULTANTS, AND THE PUBLIC BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CONSERVATION NEEDS OF RARE PLANT SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH, MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT PROJECTS THAT HAVE DIRECT CONSERVATION BENEFITS FOR FEDERAL LISTED, RECENTLY DELISTED, AND CANDIDATE PLANT SPECIES THAT ARE FOUND IN TENNESSEE. MANY OF THESE PLANT SPECIES ARE ONLY KNOWN FROM TENNESSEE. ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT WILL CONSIST OF THE MONITORING AND IMPROVEMENT OF PLANT POPULATIONS THROUGH DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MAINTENANCE, AND THE CONTINUATION OF RE-INTRODUCTION STUDIES AND SEED COLLECTION EFFORTS WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THREE FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES HAVE BEEN RECOVERED THROUGH THIS LONGSTANDING GRANT PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE STATE OF TENNESSEE.

THE PRDNER IS THE STATE AGENCY WITH THE MANDATE TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT THE NATURAL RESOURCES IN PUERTO RICO.  THE PRDNER PROTECTED SPECIES PROGRAM HAS BEEN IMPLEMENTING AN ARRAY OF INITIATIVES AND ACTIONS TOWARDS THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES.  THE FUNDING THAT THE STATE RECEIVES FOR THESE ACTIONS ARE LIMITED AND RELIES MAINLY ON THE IDENTIFICATION OF COLLABORATORS, VOLUNTEER WORK AND FUNDING SECURED THROUGH GRANTS.  FUNDING FROM THE COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND-TRADITIONAL CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAMS GRANT-IN-AID FUNDS (SECTION 6) IS ONE OF THE FEW FUNDING SOURCES USED BY PRDNER TO FINANCE THE ACTIONS IDENTIFIED AS NEEDED FOR THE RECOVERY OF THOSE SPECIES CONSIDERED THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND BY THE STATE. THE AVAILABLE FUNDING SOURCES ARE LIMITED FOR WHICH THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY MAKES FEASIBLE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIONS EXTREMELY SIGNIFICANT FOR THESE SPECIES.  THIS GRANT PROPOSAL INCLUDES, AS MENTIONED BEFORE, VARIOUS ACTIVITIES ADDRESSING DIFFERENT SPECIES, ACTIONS THAT COULD NOT BE IMPLEMENTED WITHOUT THESE FUNDS, AND THAT ARE NEEDED FOR THE RECOVERY OF THESE SPECIES. EACH WILL BE DESCRIBED FURTHER IN THE FOLLOWING SECTIONS AS JOBS, AND A STATEMENT OF NEED WILL BE INCLUDED FOR EACH WITH MORE DETAILS.  IN GENERAL, THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS PROPOSAL ARE (TABLE 1): CONTINUING SUPPORTING THE PROPAGATION OF THE PUERTO RICAN CRESTED TOAD (PRCT), PELTOPHRYNE LEMUR  THE WEST INDIAN MANATEE, TRICHECHUS MANATUS MANATUS, STRANDING RESPONSE CONDUCTED BY THE PRDNER MARINE MAMMAL RESCUE PROGRAM  THE RECOVERY OF THE SHARP-SHINNED HAWK, ACCIPITER STRIATUS VENATOR, WITHIN ITS HISTORIC RANGE THROUGH ENHANCEMENT OF ITS BREEDING SUCCESS, AND THE YELLOW-SHOULDERED BLACKBIRD, AGELAIUS XANTHOMUS  FURTHER THE STUDY OF ALSOPHILA AMINTAE (SYN. CYATHEA DRYOPTEROIDES)  CONDUCT RESEARCH ON THE DISTRIBUTION OF THELYPTERIS INABONENSIS   SUPPORT SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACHES RESTORATION AND THREATS MITIGATION  AND THE POPULATION STATUS ASSESSMENT OF THE PUERTO RICAN BOA, CHILABOTHRUS INORNATUS. GENERAL OBJECTIVES: SUPPORT PRCT TADPOLE RELEASES AND MONITORING. PROCURE THE MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED TO SUPPORT THE RESPONSE OF THE PRDNER MARINE MAMMAL RESCUE PROGRAM TO WEST INDIAN MANATEE STRANDING EVENTS AND OTHER ACTIVITIES OF THE PRDNER ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT LISTED SPECIES. SUPPORT SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACHES RESTORATION AND THREATS MITIGATION. EVALUATE CURRENT POPULATION STATUS OF THE FERNS ALSOPHILA DRYOPTEROIDES (SYN. CYATHEA DRYOPTEROIDES) AND THELYPTERIS INABONENSIS. CONTINUE SUPPORTING THE ONGOING RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE SHARP-SHINNED HAWK, ACCIPITER STRIATUS VENATOR, WITHIN ITS HISTORIC RANGE THROUGH ENHANCEMENT OF ITS BREEDING SUCCESS EXPAND THE PUERTO RICAN BOA, CHILABOTHRUS INORNATUS, POPULATION SURVEYS IN CAVES.
