THE LOGGERHEAD SEA TURTLE IS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED WORLDWIDE. NESTING IN THE UNITED STATES OCCURS PRIMARILY IN NORTH CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA, GEORGIA, AND FLORIDA, AND ACCOUNTS FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE-THIRD OF THE WORLD POPULATION (NMFS   USFWS 1991). THERE ARE FIVE LOGGERHEAD RECOVERY UNITS RECOGNIZED IN THE LOGGERHEAD RECOVERY PLAN BASED ON GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF NESTS, GEOGRAPHIC SEPARATION, GEOPOLITICAL BOUNDARIES AND GENETIC DIFFERENCES (TEWG 2009) AND SOUTH CAROLINA FALLS WITHIN THE NORTHERN RECOVERY UNIT (NRU). THE SOUTH CAROLINA SEGMENT OF THE NRU SHOWED A DECLINE IN NEST NUMBERS. GIVEN THE PROPENSITY OF NESTING FEMALES TO RETURN TO THEIR REGION OF BIRTH AND LOW GENE FLOW BETWEEN NESTING GROUPS, THESE INDIVIDUAL NESTING GROUPS ARE VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION LOCALLY.THERE IS A NEED TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR TRENDS IN THE NESTING POPULATION TO DETERMINE THE POSITIVE EFFECTS OF TURTLE EXCLUDER DEVICE (TED) USE AND NEST PROTECTION MANAGEMENT AND TO EVALUATE SHIFTS IN NESTING CAUSED BY HABITAT ALTERATIONS SUCH AS EROSION AND BEACH NOURISHMENT PROJECTS. LOGGERHEAD SEA TURTLES ARE LONG-LIVED AND SLOW TO MATURE, REACHING REPRODUCTIVE AGE AFTER 25-30 YEARS. IT IS NECESSARY TO MONITOR THIS POPULATION UNTIL AN UPWARD TREND CAN BE DETECTED AND DOCUMENTED AND THE POPULATION BE CONSIDERED AS RECOVERED. SCDNR IMPLEMENTS SEVERAL EFFORTS TO AID IN THIS RECOVERY FOR THE SOUTH CAROLINA COMPONENT OF THE NRU. EFFORTS INCLUDE MONITORING THE DISTRIBUTION OF NESTS LAID ON BEACHES, TRENDS IN THE NESTING POPULATION (FEMALE SEA TURTLES) AS A WHOLE, MANAGING A COAST WIDE NEST PROTECTION NETWORK ON BEACHES TO ENSURE THAT SCIENTIFICALLY APPROVED ACTIVITIES ARE CARRIED OUT AND DATA COLLECTED ON HATCHING SUCCESS ARE RELIABLE. THE AGENCY ALSO COORDINATES WITH FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO PREVENT THE DESTRUCTION OF IMPORTANT NESTING HABITATS AND DIRECT MORTALITY TO SEA TURTLES. LASTLY, PROVIDE INFORMATION TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC AND INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS TO FOSTER STEWARDSHIP OF OUR STATE S NATURAL RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG TERM RECOVERY OF THE LOGGERHEAD SEA TURTLE IN SOUTH CAROLINA AND THE NORTHERN RECOVERY UNIT.

THE COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND (SECTION 6 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT) PROVIDES FUNDING TO STATES AND TERRITORIES FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS ON LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND AT-RISK SPECIES AND RARE HABITATS OCCURRING ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS. THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES (LDWF) SEEKS 2023-2024 TRADITIONAL SECTION 6 FUNDING TO (1) ADMINISTER, PLAN, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ON ENDANGERED, THREATENED, AND AT-RISK FLORA AND FAUNA OF THE STATE OF LOUISIANA  (2) COORDINATE WITH USFWS, SEAFWA, AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS  AND (3) PARTICIPATE IN USFWS SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS. THE FUNDING WILL SUPPORT MONITORING EFFORTS FOR TWO FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES  THE LOUISIANA PINESNAKE (PITUOPHIS RUTHVENI) AND THE GOPHER TORTOISE (GOPHERUS POLYPHEMUS). PINESNAKE DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USING BOX-TRAP-ARRAYS AND CAMERA-TRAP-ARRAYS, AND THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO INFORM THE USFWS 5-YEAR REVIEW OF THE SPECIES. GOPHER TORTOISE SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN WASHINGTON, ST. TAMMANY, AND TANGIPAHOA PARISHES. THESE DATA WILL ALLOW BIOLOGISTS TO OBTAIN A MORE ACCURATE POPULATION ESTIMATE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE SPECIES IN THE STATE. THE FUNDS WILL ALLOW LDWF STAFF TO WORK WITH MANAGERS AND LANDOWNERS IN KEY GOPHER TORTOISE HABITAT AREAS TO ADDRESS (1) FIRE SUPPRESSION, (2) CLOSED CANOPY FORESTS, AND (3) COST-SHARE OPPORTUNITIES. LDWF ALSO SEEKS 2023-2024 TRADITIONAL SECTION 6 FUNDING TO SUPPORT RESEARCH EFFORTS LOOKING AT POLLINATOR DIVERSITY OF TEXAS TRILIUM (TRILLIUM TEXANUM), A SPECIES THAT IS CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW FOR LISTING BY USFWS.

BACKGROUND:THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS (TERRITORY, USVI) HAS 15 ENDANGERED AND THREATENED (T E) SPECIES AND OTHER CANDIDATE SPECIES OF WILDLIFE LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THE VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (DFW) HAS A LONG HISTORY OF RESPONDING WHEN T E SPECIES ARE IN DANGER OR REPORTED TO BE IN DANGER BY THE PUBLIC. SPECIFICALLY, DFW HAS RESPONDED AND ASSISTED WITH RESPONSE AND RECOVERY OF UP TO 100 T E SPECIES REPORTS BY THE PUBLIC ANNUALLY. IN THIS APPLICATION, WE PROPOSE TO PROVIDE RESPONSE AND BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY THAT IS GROWING ACROSS THE TERRITORY FOR THE RECOVERY OF T E SPECIES. TO BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY FOR RESPONSE AND RECOVERY, WE WILL WORK WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS OF ANIMALS AND PLANTS IN THE VIRGIN ISLANDS. OBJECTIVES: (1) REINTRODUCTION AND COORDINATION: DFW WILL ADMINISTER AND COORDINATE REINTRODUCTION, RECOVERY, AND RESPONSE EFFORTS IN THE TERRITORY, INCLUDING PROVIDING CONTACT ACROSS STAKEHOLDER ORGANIZATIONS AND THE WRITING OF INTERIM AND FINAL REPORTS RELATED TO T E SPECIES. (2) RESPONSE: DFW WILL ASSIST LOCAL ENTITIES MONITORING SEA TURTLE NESTS AND RESPONDING TO ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES OF SEA TURTLES. DFW WILL RESPOND TO ANY T E SPECIES IN DISTRESS OR DANGER OF EXTINCTION. (3) MONITORING: DFW WILL MONITOR STERNA DOUGALLII POPULATIONS ON OFFSHORE CAYS AROUND ST. THOMAS AND ST. JOHN APPROACH: DFW ENCOURAGES LOCAL CITIZENS TO LIAISON AMONGST EACH OTHER. THE BEST WAY TO BUILD CAPACITY TO RECOVER T E SPECIES IS THROUGH COMMUNITY COLLABORATION THAT WILL IN TURN CREATE LONGTERM STABILITY FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES RECOVERY AND PUBLIC ENTHUSIASM FOR THOSE SPECIES. EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS: THE DFW WILL MAINTAIN AN OFFICIAL CAPACITY ACROSS ALL T E SPECIES RESPONSE AND RECOVERY ACTIONS TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE OVERSIGHT INTO THE CARE OF T E WILDLIFE IN THE TERRITORY. INDIVIDUALS OF ALL T E SPECIES REQUIRING RESPONSE WILL BE GIVEN ADEQUATE RESOURCES FOR THEIR RECOVERY.

THE EASTERN SUBSPECIES OF THE BLACK RAIL (LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS JAMAICENSIS) HAS DECLINED THROUGHOUT MUCH OF ITS RANGE AND WAS ADDED TO THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST AS A THREATENED SUBSPECIES DURING 2020. COASTAL SOUTH CAROLINA CURRENTLY SUPPORTS A SUBSTANTIAL PROPORTION OF THE BLACK RAILS ON THE ATLANTIC COAST OF THE UNITED STATES. SOUTH CAROLINA ENCOMPASSES MORE ACRES OF COASTAL MARSHES (APPROXIMATELY 500,000 ACRES) THAN ANY OTHER ATLANTIC COAST STATE, INCLUDING APPROXIMATELY 70,000 ACRES OF IMPOUNDED TIDAL WETLANDS. BLACK RAILS IN SOUTH CAROLINA UTILIZE HIGH ELEVATION AREAS OF MANAGED TIDAL MARSH IMPOUNDMENTS, AS WELL AS UNIMPOUNDED HIGH ELEVATION TIDAL MARSH. WE WILL MONITOR THE STATUS OF BLACK RAILS IN COASTAL SOUTH CAROLINA DURING THE 2024 BREEDING SEASON, PROMOTE AND ASSIST WITH TARGETED HABITAT MANAGEMENT TO BENEFIT BLACK RAILS ON SCDNR PROPERTIES, AND MONITOR THE OUTCOMES OF TARGETED HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO INFORM THE REFINEMENT OF MANAGEMENT APPROACHES DURING SUBSEQUENT YEARS AND IN ADDITIONAL WETLANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT BLACK RAIL CONSERVATION THROUGH, CONTINUED MONITORING OF PRIORITY SITES TO INCREASE OUR ABILITY TO RECOGNIZE AND RESPOND TO POPULATION DECLINES. CONTINUING AND INCREASING TARGETED HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS ON SCDNR PROPERTIES WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE STABILIZATION AND EVENTUAL RECOVERY OF BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS IN SOUTH CAROLINA AND ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST. THE ASSESSMENT OF MANAGEMENT APPROACHES AND THE REFINEMENT OF MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL INCREASE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF CURRENT AND FUTURE CONSERVATION EFFORTS.THE ENDANGERED RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER (RCW) IS A KEY INDICATOR SPECIES FOR THE RESTORATION AND RECOVERY OF THE IMPERILED LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR RCWS ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH THE SAFE HARBOR PROGRAM AND STATE-OWNED WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS. THE SC SAFE HARBOR PROGRAM HAS BEEN EXTREMELY SUCCESSFUL SINCE ITS DEBUT IN OCTOBER 1998, LEADING TO CONTINUING HIGH DEMAND AND THE CURRENT ENROLLMENT OF 197 PROPERTIES. THE 361,000  ACRES OF POTENTIALLY SUITABLE HABITAT CONTAINED ON THESE PROPERTIES FACILITATES THE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 331 BASELINE AND 134 ABOVE-BASELINE RCW CLUSTERS. THIS REPRESENTS ROUGHLY 95  OF THE ACTIVE CLUSTERS ESTIMATED TO OCCUR ON PRIVATE LANDS IN SOUTH CAROLINA. MAINTAINING AND BUILDING ON THE MOMENTUM AND PARTNERSHIPS CREATED BY THIS PROGRAM IS A HIGH PRIORITY. WE WILL1. INITIATE AND ENCOURAGE PRO-ACTIVE RCW HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON PRIVATE LANDS IN SOUTH CAROLINA BY ENROLLING PROPERTIES IN THE SAFE HARBOR PROGRAM, CONDUCT INSPECTIONS AND GATHER ANNUAL REPORTS TO ENSURE CURRENT ENROLLEES ARE UPHOLDING AGREEMENT CONDITIONS, MONITOR, MANAGE, AND ENCOURAGE RCW POPULATIONS AT AIKEN GOPHER TORTOISE HERITAGE PRESERVE (HP), BONNEAU FERRY WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA), CHERAW FISH HATCHERY, DONNELLEY WMA, LONGLEAF PINE HP, LYNCHBURG SAVANNA HP, LEWIS OCEAN BAY HP, MASON WMA, SAMWORTH WMA, SANTEE COASTAL RESERVE WMA, TILLMAN SANDRIDGE HP, YAWKEY WILDLIFE CENTER AND WEBB WILDLIFE CENTER WMA AND WORK TO ESTABLISH POPULATIONS AT OTHER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS THAT MAY POTENTIALLY SUPPORT RCW. THIS PROJECT WILL PROMOTE RECOVERY OF THE RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER POPULATIONS ON STATE OWNED WMAS AND REVERSAL OF THE DECLINE OF RCWS ON PRIVATE LANDS STATEWIDE WILL BE THE RESULT OF THIS EFFORT.

ESA SEC 6 CESCF MM-081 EXPLORING VARIABILITY OF PERSISTENT ORGANIC POLLUTANTS (POPS) IN NORTHERN SEA OTTER (ENHYDRA LUTRIS KENYONI) FUR AND VIBRISSAE ABSTRACTVARIATIONS IN CONTAMINANT CONCENTRATIONS IN MULTIPLE SEA OTTER POPULATIONS OVER TIME CAN PROVIDE INDICATIONS OF POPULATION HEALTH FLUCTUATIONS, AND CONTAMINANT LEVELS ARE LIKELY TO PROVIDE FURTHER INSIGHTS INTO THE CAUSE OF POPULATION DECLINES AND ACT AS INDICATORS FOR THEIR RECOVERY. THIS STUDY WILL FOCUS ON THE UTILITY OF KERATINIZED TISSUES (WHISKERS AND FUR) FOR CONTAMINANT ANALYSIS IN THE THREATENED DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF SEA OTTERS IN SOUTHWESTERN ALASKA WHILE COMPARING DATA TO THAT OF THE NON-THREATENED SOUTHCENTRAL AND SOUTHEASTERN STOCKS. IN THIS STUDY, AN ARCHIVE OF NORTHERN SEA OTTER WHISKERS, COLLECTED OVER A NEARLY 30-YEAR PERIOD, IN THREE ALASKAN REGIONS WILL BE USED FOR ORGANIC CONTAMINANT ANALYSIS. THIS IS THE FIRST STUDY THAT USES WHISKERS, WHICH COMPARED TO OTHER TISSUES, CAN BE SAMPLED LESS INVASIVELY AND ARCHIVE ECOLOGICAL RECORDS OVER A LONGER PERIOD. A NOVEL SOURCE OF SEA OTTER FUR, VIA COASTAL GRAY WOLF SCAT, WILL ALSO BE VALIDATED. PERSISTENT ORGANIC POLLUTANTS, SPECIFICALLY POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS (PCB) AND POLYBROMINATED DIPHENYL ETHERS OR PBDES, ARE CLASSES OF FERTILIZERS AND FLAME RETARDANTS, RESPECTIVELY. WE INTEND TO DETERMINE TO WHAT DEGREE PCBS AND PBDES ARE INCORPORATED INTO THE KERATIN MATRIX OF SEA OTTER FUR AND VIBRISSAE, AND THEIR EFFECT ON OVERALL POPULATION HEALTH FOR FUTURE RECOVERY EFFORTS.
THIS GRANT WILL ADDRESS CONSERVATION AND RESEARCH NEEDS FOR THE DUSKY GOPHER FROG, FOUR MUSSEL SPECIES, TRICOLORED BAT, AND THE GOPHER TORTOISE.
THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE MONITORING, CONSERVATION, AND RESTORATION OF MULTIPLE ENDANGERED AND THREATENED AQUATIC SPECIES IN NORTH CAROLINA.

CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOS ANGELES COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF BEACHES AND HARBORS, LOS ANGELES AUDUBON SOCIETY (LAAS), AND SEA   SAGE AUDUBON WILL IMPLEMENT ACTIONS TO CONSERVE AND MANAGE THE FEDERALLY THREATENED WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER (CHARADRIUS NIVOSUS NIVOSUS) (WSPL) AND FEDERALLY ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA LEAST TERN (STERNA ANTILLARUM BROWNI) (CLTE) IN LOS ANGELES (LAC) AND ORANGE (OC) COUNTIES. BOTH BEACH-NESTING BIRDS FACE THREATS FROM HUMAN ACTIVITIES, DOMESTIC PETS, AND PREDATORS. PRIOR ACTIONS HAVE SUCCEEDED IN PROTECTING THE CLTE S NESTING AREAS AND BROUGHT NESTING WSPL BACK TO BEACH HABITATS IN COASTAL LAC AND OC. PROPOSED ACTIONS INCLUDE THE REPLACEMENT OF THE FENCE AT THE VENICE BEACH CLTE COLONY, AT DOCKWEILER STATE BEACH, ALONG WITH PREDATOR CONTROL AT THE SITE, EXPANDING USE OF WSPL PROTECTIVE ENCLOSURES TO HERMOSA AND ZUMA BEACHES, AND PROTECTING INDIVIDUAL NESTS OF WSPL WITH MINI-EXCLOSURES AND BUFFERS WHERE NESTS OCCUR THROUGHOUT OC AND LAC NESTING SITES. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE SUPPORTED THROUGH VOLUNTEER SURVEYS TO CONTINUE A 16-YEAR MONITORING EFFORT TO TRACK WSPL POPULATIONS AND A 20  YEAR EFFORT TO DOCUMENT CLTE NESTING AND PRODUCTIVITY, ALLOWING FOR ESTIMATION OF LONG-TERM POPULATION TRENDS. VOLUNTEER OBSERVATIONS WILL SUPPORT PERMITTED BIOLOGISTS MAPPING NESTS AND DETERMINING OUTCOMES, DOCUMENT THREATS TO THE WSPL AND CLTE AND INFORM PREDATOR CONTROL EFFORTS. THESE EFFORTS SUPPORT MULTIPLE GOALS ESTABLISHED IN THE RECOVERY PLANS FOR THE CLTE (SUBTASKS 1117, 114, 45, 45, 61, 7) AND THE WSPL (ACTION ITEMS 1.1-1.4, 2.1, 2.3, 2.4).

THE STUDY WILL REMOVE BARRED OWLS FROM 192,560 ACRES OF MIXED OWNERSHIP LANDS IN MENDOCINO AND SONOMA COUNITES, CREATE KEY BARRED OWL FREE AREAS FOR NORTHERN SPOTTED OWLS (NSO), AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF AN ICONIC THREATENED SPECIES. THE STUDY WILL SERVE AS AN ESSENTIAL BRIDGE TO THE FORTHCOMING FEDERAL BARRED OWL MANAGEMENT STRATEGY. RESEARCHERS WILL MONITOR THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BARRED OWL REMOVAL AND THE RECOVERY OF NSO FOR A MINIMUM OF TWO YEARS USING CALL-BASED SURVEYS AND A BEFORE-AFTER-CONTROL-IMPACT STUDY DESIGN. RESEARCHERS WILL ASSESS THE POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF BARRED OWLS ON OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE LISTED SPECIES, INCLUDING COHO SALMON, CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROGS, AND MARBLED MURRELETS, IN ADDITION TO SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), THROUGH COMPREHENSIVE GENETIC BASED DIETARY ANALYSES. RESEARCHERS WILL USE PROVEN APPROACHES FOR SCREENING BARRED OWL DIETS IN ANALYZING THE INTESTINES COLLECTED FROM LETHALLY REMOVED BARRED OWLS.

THE NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE   CONSUMER SERVICES  PLANT CONSERVATION PROGRAM (NCPCP) PROPOSES TO CONDUCT IMPERILED SPECIES MONITORING AND HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ACROSS THE STATE. WHILE NORTH CAROLINA, SPECIFICALLY THE NC NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM, HAS BUILT A SIGNIFICANT DATASET OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND OCCURRENCE OF RARE PLANT SPECIES, ADDITIONAL MONITORING INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO DETERMINE AND UPDATE POPULATION STATUSES FOR IMPERILED SPECIES. SUCH DATA ARE OFTEN A RECOVERY REQUIREMENT SPECIFIED IN SPECIES RECOVERY PLANS. WITHOUT REASONABLY DETAILED AND UP-TO-DATE DATA, THERE MAY BE LIMITED BASIS UPON WHICH TO DETERMINE POPULATION TRENDS OR LONG-TERM VIABILITY OF SPECIES AT A GIVEN SITE. WHEN SUFFICIENT BASELINE DATA CAN BE DEVELOPED, IT IS THEN NECESSARY TO CONTINUE BASIC MONITORING THROUGH TIME. THE NCPCP WILL CONTINUE OR EXPAND MONITORING EFFORTS TO FILL IN DATA GAPS FOR SELECTED OCCURRENCES AND SITES. THESE EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON EIGHT LISTED SPECIES: SMOOTH CONEFLOWER (ECHINACEA LAEVIGATA), SWAMP PINK (HELONIAS BULLATA), HELLERS BLAZING-STAR (LIATRIS HELLERI), PONDBERRY (LINDERA MELISSIFOLIA), MICHAUXS SUMAC (RHUS MICHAUXII), BUNCHED ARROWHEAD (SAGITTARIA FASCICULATA), MOUNTAIN SWEET PITCHER-PLANT (SARRACENIA JONESII), AND WHITE IRISETTE (SISYRINCHIUM DICHOTOMUM). WHENEVER POSSIBLE, MONITORING EFFORTS WILL TAKE PLACE ON NC PLANT CONSERVATION PRESERVES, SECONDARILY ON OTHERWISE PROTECTED LANDS OR MANAGED SITES, AND LASTLY TO INFORM THE STATUS OF SUCH POPULATIONS ON UNPROTECTED PROPERTIES THAT MAY BE OF CONSERVATION VALUE. NCPCP WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN AND SUPPORT ONGOING SPECIES STATUS SURVEY EFFORTS IN NORTH CAROLINA RELATED TO AT-RISK SPECIES SUCH AS MOUNTAIN PURPLE PITCHER-PLANT (SARRACENIA PURPUREA VAR. MONTANA). MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION OF IMPERILED PLANT POPULATIONS WITHIN NC PLANT CONSERVATION PRESERVES AND OTHER SELECTED SITES IS A KEY COMPONENT OF NCPCPS EFFORTS TO RECOVER LISTED PLANT SPECIES IN NORTH CAROLINA. IN PART, ACTIVE HABITAT MANAGEMENT IS NEEDED TO MEET THE INTENT OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, WHICH HAS THE STATED GOAL OF CONSERVING THE ECOSYSTEMS UPON WHICH LISTED SPECIES DEPEND. MANY OF THE SITES WHERE THESE SPECIES OCCUR HAVE BEEN DEGRADED BY LACK OF MANAGEMENT AND OR INCOMPATIBLE LAND-USE PRACTICES  ACTIVE MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS RESTORATION EFFORTS ARE URGENTLY NEEDED AT THESE SITES. IN SOME CASES, NCPCP WORKS WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS TO COMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT OF THEIR LANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF RARE PLANTS AND HABITATS. ADDITIONAL SUPPORTING TASKS TO THE MAIN GOALS OF POPULATION MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT INCLUDE NATURE PRESERVE MANAGEMENT PLAN DEVELOPMENT TO GUIDE AND DIRECT THE LONG-TERM SUCCESS OF THESE IMPORTANT PROTECTED AREAS AS REFUGES FOR IMPERILED PLANT SPECIES AND COORDINATING WITH USFWS ON IMPERILED SPECIES PERMITTING AT THE STATE LEVEL IN SUPPORT OF PROTECTIVE LAWS AND REGULATIONS.

GRIZZLY BEARS WERE LISTED IN 1975 AND RECOVERY EFFORTS HAVE BEEN UNDERWAY SINCE (USFWS 1993). BEAR NUMBERS AND DISTRIBUTION HAVE BEEN INCREASING, ESPECIALLY IN THE SELKIRK AND CABINET-YAAK ECOSYSTEMS, BUT ARE NOT YET AT RECOVERY LEVELS. IT IS IMPORTANT TO EVALUATE THE CURRENT POPULATION LEVELS, TREND, DISTRIBUTION, RELATEDNESS, AND GENETIC INTERCHANGE IN THESE ECOSYSTEMS. SOME OF THESE OBJECTIVES CAN BE MET WITH BARBED WIRE HAIR-SNARE SITES TO COLLECT DNA AND REMOTE CAMERAS COLLECTING GRIZZLY BEAR PHOTOGRAPHS. GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVES S111, S12, AND S33 WILL BE ADDRESSED THROUGH THESE ACTIONS (USFWS 1993).SECTION 6 FUNDS, IN CONJUNCTION WITH STATE FUNDS, WILL BE USED TO ESTABLISH NUMEROUS CAMERA AND DNA SITES TO DOCUMENT GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY PLAN CRITERIA. THIS WORK IS IN CONJUNCTION WITH A LARGER EFFORT COMPLETED BY USFWS, USFS, MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS, WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND LOCAL TRIBES TO DEPLOY 150  DNA CORRALS AND 1200 RUBS IN THE SELKIRK AND CABINET-YAAK ECOSYSTEMS. THIS WORK IS A KEY PART OF THE OVERALL CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE CABINET-YAAK AND SELKIRK ECOSYSTEMS WITH THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF ACHIEVING GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY.IDFG HAS RECEIVED SECTION 6 FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT IN THE PAST. IDFG HAS CONTRIBUTED TO RECOVERY OF GRIZZLY BEARS THROUGH MONITORING EFFORTS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, BEAR CONFLICT RESOLUTION AND MITIGATION, PARTICIPATION IN GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY TEAMS AND MEMBERSHIP ON THE INTERAGENCY GRIZZLY BEAR STUDY COMMITTEE AT THE REGIONAL AND ECOSYSTEM LEVEL. IDFG PROVIDES CONTINUITY ON THIS PROJECT AND PROVIDES A HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE OF RECOVERY OF GRIZZLY BEARS.

WITH 33 TAXA LISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED, THE NATIVE AVIFAUNA OF HAWAI I ARE THE MOST ENDANGERED BIRD FAUNA IN THE WORLD (REED ET AL 2012). THE MOST CRITICALLY ENDANGERED IN THIS GROUP ARE THE HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRDS, WITH TWELVE OUT OF 21 EXTANT SPECIES LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED (PAXTON ET AL 2018). THE MAJOR THREATS CONFRONTING ALL SPECIES ARE LOSS OF HABITAT, AVIAN DISEASE, LOW REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, PREDATION, AND COMPETITION WITH ALIEN SPECIES. CONSERVATION BREEDING (ALSO KNOWN AS CAPTIVE PROPAGATION) IS ONE OF THE MANY TOOLS NEEDED TO HELP RECOVER THESE SPECIES, PARTICULARLY THOSE THAT ARE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED AND ON THE BRINK OF EXTINCTION. DOFAW S CONSERVATION BREEDING PROJECT IS BEING USED TO INCREASE PRODUCTION AND PROVIDE INDIVIDUALS FOR RELEASE BACK INTO PROTECTED HABITAT TO AUGMENT DECLINING WILD POPULATIONS, AND TO REESTABLISH EXTINCT LOCAL POPULATIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS EFFORT IS TO PREVENT THE EXTINCTION AND PROMOTE THE RECOVERY OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS, USING HUSBANDRY, AVICULTURE, AND CONSERVATION BREEDING TECHNIQUES.THE PUAIOHI OR SMALL KAUAI THRUSH (MYADESTES PALMERI)  AKIKIKI OR KAUAI CREEPER (OREOMYSTIS BAIRDI)  AND AKEKEE OR KAUAI AKEPA (LOXOPS CAERULEIROSTRIS) ARE ENDEMIC TO KAUAI. THEY ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED BY THE FEDERAL AND HAWAII STATE GOVERNMENTS AND CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR CONSERVATION OF NATURE. THE POPULATIONS OF THESE THREE SPECIES ARE THOUGHT TO NUMBER FEWER THAN 500, 500, AND 1,000 INDIVIDUALS, RESPECTIVELY (CRAMPTON ET AL. 2017, PAXTON ET AL. 2016). A FOURTH SPECIES, IIWI (DREPANIS COCCINEA), IS LISTED AS THREATENED, WITH AN APPROXIMATE POPULATION OF 2700 BIRDS ON KAUAI (PAXTON ET AL. 2016). ALL FOUR SPECIES ONLY OCCUR IN THE INTERIOR OF KAUAI IN WET ( 3,000 MM RAIN YEAR) MONTANE FOREST IN NARROW STREAM VALLEYS AND ASSOCIATED RIDGES ABOVE 1,050 METERS ELEVATION. THEIR BREEDING POPULATIONS ARE RESTRICTED TO AN AREA OF   80 KM2 ON THE SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL PLATEAU OF THE ALAKAI WILDERNESS PRESERVE  FOR PUAIOHI AND AKIKIKI,THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESEARCH NATURAL HISTORY OF, AND THREATS TO KAUAIS ENDANGERED FOREST BIRDS, AND USE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT TO INVESTIGATE TECHNIQUES TO PROMOTE THEIR RECOVERY. RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT ARE FOCUSED AT THE POPULATION LEVEL TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE THREATS TO NATIVE BIRDS, THEREBY PROVIDING GUIDANCE FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT. THE ALAL OR HAWAIIAN CROW (CORVUS HAWAIIENSIS) IS ENDEMIC TO THE ISLAND OF HAWAII HISTORICALLY, AND IT, OR ACLOSELY RELATED AND ECOLOGICALLY SIMILAR SPECIES IS PRESENT IN THE SUBFOSSIL RECORD ON MAUI. DECLINES WERE NOTEDPRIOR TO 1900, AND BY THE 1980S ONLY RELICT AND WIDELY SCATTERED SMALL POPULATIONS REMAINED. THESE REMNANTPOPULATIONS WERE CONTINUOUSLY HINDERED BY A SUITE OF THREATS INCLUDING HABITAT LOSS ASSOCIATED WITH HUMANS, FERALUNGULATES, FIRE, AND INVASIVE PLANTS  DISEASE  HUMAN PERSECUTION  AND PREDATION BY NON-NATIVE MAMMALS. BY 2002, ALAL WAS EXTINCT IN THE WILD (USFWS 2003). CURRENTLY, OVER 125 INDIVIDUALS EXIST IN CAPTIVE BREEDINGFACILITIES. THIS GRANT OUTLINES THE RESOURCES NEEDED TO ACHIEVE THE NEW DIRECTIONS OF THE PROJECT, PRIMARILY THEPLANNING AND COORDINATION OF ALAL RELEASES WITHIN MAUI NUI, AND THE OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WORKNEEDED TO LAY A FOUNDATION OF SUPPORT FOR ALAL RELEASES AND NATIVE HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRD CONSERVATION WITHINMAUI NUI, AND SECONDARILY, PARTIAL FIELD SUPPORT FOR THE IO RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ON HAWAII ISLAND.

PRAIRIES ONCE COVERED VAST ACREAGE IN THURSTON AND PIERCE COUNTIES, YET TODAY THE MAJORITY OF SOUTH PUGET SOUND PRAIRIE HABITATS HAVE BEEN LOST. THE FRACTION OF PRAIRIE HABITAT THAT REMAINS IS FRAGMENTED, DEGRADED, AND THREATENED BY DEVELOPMENT AND INVASION BY CONIFERS AND NON-NATIVE VEGETATION. THIS RARE HABITAT TYPE IS HOME TO SEVERAL FEDERAL AND STATE LISTED SPECIES AND A HOST OF ADDITIONAL WASHINGTON STATE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. PROTECTING HABITAT FROM DEVELOPMENT AND OTHER USES IS A PRIMARY RECOVERY STRATEGY FOR ESA-LISTED SPECIES IN THIS LANDSCAPE.THE SOUTH PUGET SOUND SENTINEL LANDSCAPE IS A CONSORTIUM OF FEDERAL, STATE, AND OTHER PARTNERS WORKING TOGETHER ON SHARED GOALS THAT CREATE BENEFIT FOR WILDLIFE, AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, AND THE US MILITARY. WHILE THE PARTNERSHIP HAS A DEDICATED COORDINATOR, THERE IS NOT ADEQUATE CAPACITY OR EXPERTISE IN THAT ROLE TO STRATEGICALLY FACILITATE AND CULTIVATE HABITAT PROTECTION OPPORTUNITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FULFILL THAT NEED BY HIRING A WDFW PRAIRIE PROTECTION LEAD TO IDENTIFY, FACILITATE, AND IMPLEMENT PRIORITY PROTECTION PROJECTS.

CAPTIVE REARING OF THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (SPEYERIA ZERENE HIPPOLYTA) AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE OF LARVAEAND PUPAE TO SUPPLEMENT THREATENED WILD POPULATIONS IN SEVERAL LOCATIONS. CAPTIVE REARED BUTTERFLIES WILL BE USEDTO ENHANCE THE POPULATIONS THAT INCLUDE CASCADE HEAD, BRAY PT. AND ROCK CREEK. SIGNIFICANTLY, IN 2024 WEANTICIPATE A SEVENTH YEAR OF RELEASES AT NESTUCCA BAY NWR TO FURTHER INCREASE THE SECURITY OF THAT REINTRODUCEDPOPULATION AND A SIXTH YEAR OF RELEASES AT OPRDS SADDLE MOUNTAIN SITE, A RECENTLY REINTRODUCED POPULATION.THE RECOVERY CRITERIA CALLS FOR 10 POPULATIONS WITHIN 6 CONSERVATION AREAS. (2 AREAS CALL FOR JUST 1 POPULATIONEACH). CURRENTLY JUST 5 POPULATIONS EXIST AND 3 OF THE 5 ARE AT GREAT RISK OF EXTINCTION DUE TO UNSUITABLEHABITAT AND THE SMALL SIZE AND ISOLATION OF THE REMAINING POPULATIONS. THE LONG BEACH WASHINGTON HABITATCONSERVATION AREA IS THE NORTHERN MOST CONSERVATION AREA AND THE BUTTERFLY HAS BEEN EXTIRPATED THERE. THEWILLAPA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE HOPES TO REINTRODUCE A POPULATION THERE ONCE THE HABITAT HAS BEEN RESTORED. THECLATSOP PLAINS POPULATION IS ALSO LIKELY EXTIRPATED. THE BUTTERFLY HAS LOST THE WHOLE NORTHERN HALF OF ITSHISTORIC RANGE AND IS NOW ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THEAUGMENTATION PROGRAM IS TO PROTECT EXISTING POPULATIONS FROM EXTINCTION AND THEN TO REESTABLISH EXTIRPATEDHISTORIC POPULATIONS. EVERY YEAR SINCE 1999 THE TWO ZOOS HAVE SUCCESSFULLY MET THEIR PUPAE PRODUCTION RELEASEGOALS AND POPULATION EXTINCTION HAS BEEN AVERTED. CONTINUED POPULATION AUGMENTATIONS ARE NECESSARY TO MAINTAINEXISTING POPULATIONS AND REINTRODUCTIONS ARE NEEDED TO MEET RECOVERY CRITERIA.

DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION AND HABITAT REQUIREMENT INFORMATION FOR THE NORTHERN BOG LEMMING (SYNAPTOMYS BOREALIS  SYBO) IS LIMITED IN IDAHO. PRIOR TO THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG) INITIATING A SYBO SURVEY EFFORT IN 2022, ONLY 23 DOCUMENTED SYBO INDIVIDUALS HAD BEEN COLLECTED OR OBSERVED IN THE STATE WITH MOST DETECTIONS DATING BACK TO 1993 OR EARLIER. THIS CURRENT PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON THE SYBO SURVEY EFFORT THAT BEGAN IN 2022, CONTINUE TO FILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS AND CONTRIBUTE TO A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE SPECIES STATUS IN IDAHO.WHILE SYBO IS THOUGHT TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH PEATLAND SITES, THE SPECIES HAS ALSO BEEN DOCUMENTED IN OTHER HABITATS IN IDAHO, INCLUDING SEVERAL LOCATIONS DESCRIBED AS MATURE FOREST AND SECOND GROWTH OR OLD GROWTH FORESTS PRIMARILY CONSISTING OF WESTERN HEMLOCK (TSUGA HETEROPHYLLA) OR WESTERN REDCEDAR (THUJA PLICATA). ADDITIONALLY, WHILE SYBO HAS ONLY BEEN DOCUMENTED IN FAR NORTHERN IDAHO, IS HAS BEEN DETECTED MUCH FURTHER SOUTH IN NEIGHBORING MONTANA. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND SYBO SURVEYS TO A WIDER AREA AND RANGE OF HABITATS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF THE SPECIES. TARGET SURVEY LOCATIONS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL LARGELY BE DEPENDENT UPON RESULTS FROM PREVIOUS SYBO SURVEYS AND A HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL DEVELOPED FOR THE SPECIES. AN ESTIMATED 50 POTENTIAL SURVEY LOCATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND SURVEYED THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT. THESE SITES WILL CONSIST OF LOCATIONS IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL, LOCATIONS IN WHICH SYBO HAS BEEN DETECTED PREVIOUSLY, VARIABLE HABITATS (E.G., MATURE FORESTS) IN THE VICINITY OF LOCATIONS SYBO HAS BEEN DETECTED, AND POSSIBLY SITES FARTHER SOUTH THAT EXHIBIT HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS THOUGHT TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH THE SPECIES.OPPORTUNISTIC SCAT SEARCHES WILL BE THE PRIMARY METHOD TO SURVEY FOR SYBO. THIS METHOD HAS PROVEN TO BE MORE EFFECTIVE THAN WALKING TRANSECTS OR DEPLOYING SCAT BOARDS IN MONTANA AND IDAHO. OPPORTUNISTIC SCAT SEARCHES INVOLVE LOOKING FOR RODENT PELLETS IN IDEAL MICRO-HABITATS (SPHAGNUM MOSS-RICH AND MOIST) AND PROBABLE RODENT TRAVEL ROUTES (SMALL TRAILS, ROUTES AROUND OBSTACLES, AND UNDER OBJECTS). DOWNWARD FACING REMOTE CAMERAS MAY BE DEPLOYED IN AN EFFORT TO CAPTURE IMAGES OF SYBO IN LOCATIONS WHERE OPPORTUNISTIC SCAT SEARCHES ARE DIFFICULT, SUCH AS FOREST HABITATS. UP TO 80 SMALL MAMMAL PELLETS WILL BE COLLECTED AT EACH SURVEY SITE TO MAXIMIZE THE PROBABILITY OF DETECTING SYBO IF THE SPECIES IS PRESENT. PELLET SAMPLES WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE NATIONAL GENOMICS LABORATORY FOR WILDLIFE AND FISH CONSERVATION AT THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESEARCH STATION IN MISSOULA, MT FOR DNA EXTRACTION, AMPLIFICATION AND SEQUENCING. COURSE DOCUMENTATION OF PLANT SPECIES AND HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS WILL BE RECORDED AT SURVEY SITES WHILE CONDUCTING OPPORTUNISTIC SCAT SURVEYS. TEMPERATURE LOGGERS WILL BE DEPLOYED AT A SUBSET OF SURVEY SITES TO HELP DETERMINE IF SYBO DISTRIBUTION IS LIMITED BY MICROCLIMATIC CONDITIONS.

RECORDS OF POLLINATOR (MONARCH BUTTERFLY, WESTERN BUMBLE BEE, SUCKLEY CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE, MORRISON BUMBLE BEE) USE OF HIGH ELEVATION, DESERT SYSTEMS IN SOUTH-CENTRAL IDAHO ARE LIMITED. SURVEYS TO DOCUMENT HABITAT PREFERENCES AND TEMPORAL USE OF SAGEBRUSH-STEPPE SYSTEMS WOULD SERVE TO HIGHLIGHT PRIORITY HABITAT AREAS AND BENEFIT FUTURE MANAGEMENT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RECOMMENDATIONS.

THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS HAS 21 LISTED MAMMALS, BIRDS, REPTILES, AND INVERTEBRATES AS WELL AS 14 LISTEDPLANT SPECIES  MANY OF THESE ARE ENDEMIC SPECIES. AMONGST THESE, ARE FIVE ENDANGERED PLANTS FOURENDEMIC TO ROTA AND GUAM AND ONE ENDEMIC TO THE MARIANA ISLANDS. OUR CURRENT EFFORTS TO CONSERVE THESESPECIES HAVE DETECTED NO NATURAL RECRUITMENT OF HERITIERA LONGIPETIOLATA, OSMOXYLON MARIANNENSE, ORSERIANTHES NELSONII. NESOGENES ROTENSIS IS AN HERB ENDEMIC TO ROTA OCCURRING AT EXTREMELY LOWABUNDANCE, PRIMARILY IN ONE LOCATION  THUS, IT IS VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION. RETAINING THESE FOUR FEDERALLYENDANGERED AND ONE FEDERALLY THREATENED PLANT (HERITIERA LONGIPETIOLATA, NESOGENES ROTENSIS, OSMOXYLONMARIANNENSE, SERIANTHES NELSONII, AND TABERNAEMONTANA ROTENSIS) INTO THE FUTURE REQUIRES ACTIVEPROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING AS WELL AS AMELIORATING THREATS. WE FOCUS ON (1) SURVEYS, MAINTENANCE,PROPAGATION, AND OUTPLANTING TO SUSTAIN FIVE ENDANGERED THREATENED PLANTS, AND (2) PROTECTION OFOUTPLANTING THROUGH FENCING AREAS.

SEED BANKS (REPOSITORIES FOR NATIVE PLANT SEEDS) PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN RARE PLANT CONSERVATION BY PROVIDING EX SITU CONSERVATION OF RARE PLANT GENETICS (EDWARDS AND WYSE JACKSON 2019). FOR SEED BANKS TO BE EFFECTIVE, THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF SPECIES NEEDS TO BE WELL REPRESENTED, MEANING THAT SEEDS FROM ACROSS THE RANGE OF A SPECIES NEED TO BE STORED (EDWARDS AND WYSE JACKSON 2019). SUCCESSFUL SEED BANKING GENERALLY REQUIRES COLLABORATION BETWEEN ANUMBER OF PARTNERS, SINCE SEEDS MUST BE SOURCED FROM EXISTING PLANT POPULATIONS, STORED UNDER SPECIFIC CONDITIONS, AND EVENTUALLY OUTPLANTED WHILE THE SEEDS ARE STILL VIABLE (WALTERS AND PENCE 2021). IN THIS PROJECT, WE SEEK TO PERFORM RESEARCH, MAKE FIELD COLLECTIONS, AND DEVELOP INTERORGANIZATION PARTNERSHIPS TO BETTER CONSERVE THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON RARE PLANTS. TWO REGIONAL SEED BANKS IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST CURRENTLY ACT AS REPOSITORIES FOR SEEDS OF WASHINGTON RARE PLANTS: THE MILLER SEED VAULT IN SEATTLE, AND THE BERRY SEED BANK IN PORTLAND.BECAUSE OF LIMITED STAFF TIME AND RESOURCES, IT IS NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN HOW  ELL THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF WASHINGTONS PLANTS OF HIGH CONSERVATION CONCERN IS REPRESENTED IN OUR REGIONAL SEED BANKS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT STATUS OF RARE PLANT COLLECTIONS IN REGIONAL SEED BANKS, IDENTIFY HIGH PRIORITY PLANT POPULATIONS FOR FUTURE SEED BANKING, AND TO PERFORM A PILOT PROJECT COLLECTING SEEDS OF 2-3 SPECIES THAT WOULD BENEFIT FROM BETTER REPRESENTATION IN REGIONAL SEED BANKS. MORE BROADLY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS AMONG MULTIPLE ORGANIZATIONS WORKING IN REGIONAL RARE PLANT CONSERVATION TO HELP ENHANCE AND SUSTAIN THE CONSERVATION VALUE OF OUR REGIONAL SEED BANKS OVER THE LONG TERM

MONITORING, SURVEYS, AND RESEARCH WILL BE CONDUCTED BY THE ARKANSAS NATURAL HERITAGE COMMISSION TO DETERMINE THE HEALTH AND STATUS OF THREE FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES AND ONE PETITIONED SPECIES. THISINFORMATION WILL BE USED FOR HABITAT AND RECOVERY MANAGEMENT PURPOSES, OR TO SUPPORT LISTING DECISIONS. THE WORK INCLUDES MONITORING AND SURVEYS FOR PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN POPULATIONS OF GEOCARPON (GEOCARPON MINIMUM), SMALL-HEADEDPIPEWORT (ERIOCAULON KOERNICKIANUM), HARPERELLA (PTILIMNIUM NODOSUM), AND PONDBERRY (LINDERA MELISSIFOLIA). IT ALSO INCLUDES SUPPLEMENTAL SEEDING EXPERIMENTS FOR GEOCARPON AND PONDBERRY, IF CONDITIONS ARE SUITABLE. PONDBERRY SEEDS, ROOTS, AND SOIL SAMPLES MAY ALSO BE COLLECTED TO SUPPORT ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, PENDING THE SERVICE S APPROVAL OF THEIR RESEARCH PERMIT APPLICATION.

THIS IS A ONE-YEAR PROPOSED PROJECT WITH  250,474 REQUESTED FROM FEDERAL FUNDS AND  83,766 IN MATCHING FUNDS, INCLUDING  44,699 IN STATE MATCHING FUNDS,  0 IN LOCAL MATCHING FUNDS, AND  38,067 IN OTHER (I.E., PRIVATE ORGANIZATION) MATCHING FUNDS THAT PROVIDES FOR 11 PROJECTS TO DIRECTLY HELP RECOVER USFWS FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS AND A LICHEN SPECIES, AND AT-RISK PLANT SPECIES IN FLORIDA. 2 STAFF POSITIONS ARE PROPOSED AND WOULD BE MADE POSSIBLE WITHIN THE FLORIDA DEPT. OF AGRICULTURE AND CONSUMER SVCS. ONE STAFF ADMINISTERS THE FLORIDA STATEWIDE ENDANGERED AND THREATENED PLANT CONSERVATION PROGRAM (FPCP) AND UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND, ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), SECT. 6 TRADITIONAL CONSERVATION GRANTS FUNDS TO CONDUCT CONSERVATION EFFORTS (I.E., USFWS RECOVERY TASKS) FOR ALL FEDERALLY LISTED RARE PLANT AND LICHEN SPECIES IN THE STATE OF FLORIDA (UNDER COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH USFWS). ONE STAFF MAPS, MANAGES, AND MONITORS 15 FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS AND ONE LICHEN SPECIES IN ONE HIGH QUALITY CONSERVATION AREA, THE LAKE WALES RIDGE STATE FOREST. THE FPCP TARGETS A COMPARATIVELY LARGE NUMBER OF FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES (68 TAXA) AND THOSE THAT ARE CURRENTLY AT-RISK AND BEING PETITIONED FOR FEDERAL PROTECTION (27 TAXA). RARE PLANT CONSERVATION PROJECTS ARE COMPETITIVELY RANKED BY FPCP STAFF, AND STATE AND FEDERAL BIOLOGISTS AND PROPOSED HERE, TO BE CONDUCTED BY ARCHBOLD BIOLOGICAL STATION, BOK TOWER GARDENS, FAIRCHILD TROPICAL BOTANICAL GARDEN, COASTAL PLAINS INSTITUTE, FLORIDA NATIVE PLANT SOCIETY, FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITYS FLORIDA NATURAL AREAS INVENTORY, ONE PRIVATE RARE PLANT CONSERVATION FIRM, AN INDIVIDUAL EXPERT ON RARE PLANT CONSERVATION AND MANY VOLUNTEERS. TASKS AND OBJECTIVES FROM THESE PROJECTS ARE AIMED AT RECOVERY TASKS PROVIDED IN ESA RECOVERY PLANS AND INCLUDE LAND MANAGEMENT (INCLUDING INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT AND FUEL REDUCTION WOODY PLANT REMOVAL), FIELD SURVEYS, INTRODUCTIONS REINTRODUCTIONS AUGMENTATIONS, MONITORING, RESEARCH (INCLUDING GENETIC, DEMOGRAPHIC, BIOLOGICAL, ECOLOGICAL, ETC.), PLANT PROPAGATION, IN SITU AND EX SITU POPULATION MANAGEMENT, AND OTHER ACTIVITIES. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE PROPER ADMINISTRATION OF ESA TRADITIONAL SECTION 6 FUNDS THAT DIRECTLY ADDRESS EACH FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT AND LICHEN SPECIES RECOVERY TASKS THAT HELP RARE PLANT AND LICHEN SPECIES TO INCREASE IN VIABILITY AND SUSTAIN THEIR POPULATIONS NOW AND IN THE FUTURE. IMPORTANTLY, ALL SPECIES WITHIN EACH HABITAT BENEFIT FROM LAND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES PROVIDED FOR THE FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS. THESE PROJECTS OCCUR ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS. THE FDACS FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THIS GRANT IS ADMINISTERED TO MEET 2 CFR 200.302 FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT REQUIREMENTS.

THROUGH RCW SURVEYS, BANDING, AND MONITORING, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE 10 RCW SUBADULTS FOR TRANSLOCATION TO RECIPIENT POPULATIONS. RECIPIENTS OF THE OSCEOLA SUBADULTS WILL BE IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE RCW SOUTHERN RANGE TRANSLOCATION COOPERATIVE (SRTC) DURING THE ANNUAL SRTC AUGUST MEETING. THERE ARE 14 POTENTIAL TRANSLOCATION RECIPIENTS OF THE OSCEOLA DONOR SUBADULTS. DEPENDING ON THE ACTUAL DONOR-RECIPIENT ALLOCATIONS TO BE DETERMINED BY THE SRTC, THE OSCEOLA POPULATION WILL PROVIDE DONOR SERVICES TO 1  3 OF THESE RECIPIENTS. THESE POTENTIAL RECIPIENTS ARE LOGISTICALLY LOCATED AT SITES TO MOST EFFECTIVELY SUPPORT THE CAPTURE, TRAVEL, AND OTHER ACTIVITIES REQUIRED FOR TRANSLOCATION WHILE MINIMIZING STRESS TO BIRDS. AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED, TRANSLOCATION OF OSCEOLA DONOR SUBADULTS WILL CONTINUE TO AUGMENT RECIPIENT POPULATION GROWTH RATES AND SIZE, REDUCE ADVERSE RISKS OF LOCAL EXTIRPATION AND INBREEDING DEPRESSION, AND ENHANCE POPULATION STRUCTURE. THE CONTINUED FUNCTION OF THE OSCEOLA DONOR ALSO ENABLES OTHER SRTC TRANSLOCATION DONOR POPULATIONS SUCH AS THE APALACHICOLA NATIONAL FOREST TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE SERVICES TO OTHER RECIPIENT POPULATIONS, PARTICULARLY IN ALABAMA AND MISSISSIPPI. WITHOUT THE OSCEOLA DONOR, THE NUMBER OF SRTC TRANSLOCATION RECIPIENT POPULATIONS WILL BE REDUCED IN AL, FL, GA AND SC. THIS PROJECT CONTINUES EFFECTIVE PARTNERSHIPS AND COORDINATION AMONG MULTIPLE AGENCIES OPERATING THROUGH THE SRTC TO ACHIEVE RCW CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY. ADDITIONAL BENEFITS OF OPERATING THE OSCEOLA DONOR POPULATION ARE PROVIDED BY THE RCW MONITORING DATA ON NUMBER OF ACTIVE CLUSTERS, CAVITY CONDITIONS, GROUP SIZE AND COMPOSITION, PRODUCTIVITY, AND OTHER ATTRIBUTES. THESE AND OTHER DATA WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE OSCEOLA NATIONAL FOREST TO FURTHER SUPPORT RCW CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT.

THIS AWARD SUPPORTS FIVE ACTIVITIES FOR THE PERIOD COVERED INCLUDING,  ENDANGERED SPECIES PROJECT COORDINATION, GRANT ADMINISTRATION, AND ASSOCIATED SITE VISITS WITH GRANT RECIPIENTS ,  HABITAT IMPROVEMENT AND MONITORING OF CLEMATIS SOCIALIS (ALABAMA LEATHER FLOWER) AT THE NATURE CONSERVANCYS DRY CREEK PRESERVE ,  HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELING AND SITE VERIFICATION FOR THE TENNESSEE YELLOW-EYED GRASS (XYRIS TENNESSEENSIS) IN ALABAMA ,  GENETIC ANALYSIS OF THE ENDANGERED ALABAMA LEATHER FLOWER (CLEMATIS SOCIALIS) IN ALABAMA , AND  STATUS ASSESSMENT FOR SWAMP BUCKTHORN (SIDEROXYLON THORNEI) IN ALABAMA.

THIS PROJECT CONTAINS THE FOLLOWING SUB-PROJECTS: SUPPORT AN IN-HOUSE SEASONAL FIELD CREW TO SUPPLEMENT EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE AND EASTERN DIAMONDBACK RATTLESNAKE SURVEYS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN SOUTH GEORGIA  ENHANCE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF WOOD STORK COLONY LOCATIONS IN GEORGIA, BUILD BETTER RELATIONS WITH LANDOWNERS, AND ASSIST THEM WITH MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR COLONIES IF NEEDED  CONTINUATION OF A LONG-TERM SEA TURTLE NEST PROTECTION AND MONITORING PROGRAM IN GEORGIA  QUANTITATIVELY MONITOR THE STATUS OF EASTERN INDIGO SNAKES IN WHAT ARE VERY SIGNIFICANT PORTIONS OF THE SPECIES GEORGIA RANGE  IMPLEMENT COMPREHENSIVE MANATEE MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT IN GEORGIA ASSESSING STATUS OF AQUATIC SPECIES IN THE CONASAUGA RIVER SYSTEM AND EVALUATING CAUSES OF DECLINE  ASSESSMENT AND RECOVERY OF AT-RISK SPECIES IN COASTAL PLAIN PITCHER PLANT BOGS  SURVEY, DATA MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR PRIORITY RARE PLANT SPECIES.

THIS GRANT WILL FUND TWO PROJECTS TO BENEFIT FEDERALLY LISTED FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES. ARKANSAS HAS 14 FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS, MANY OF WHICH ARE IN REPRODUCTIVE DECLINE. WITHOUT INCREASED EMPHASIS ON EX-SITU SPECIES PROPAGATION AND AUGMENTATION OF CURRENT POPULATIONS, MANY OF THESE SPECIES FACE AN INCREASED RISK OF EXTIRPATION. THE FEDERALLY THREATENED ARKANSAS FATMUCKET (LAMPSILIS POWELLII) IS ONE SUCH SPECIES AND IS IN A DRASTIC DECLINE IN A LARGE PORTION OF ITS RANGE. THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED OUACHITA ROCK POCKETBOOK (ARCIDENS WHEELERI) INHABITS ONLY A SMALL PORTION OF ITS HISTORICAL RANGE IN ARKANSAS AND APPEARS TO BE LACKING CONSISTENT RECRUITMENT. THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED WINGED MAPLELEAF (QUADRULA FRAGOSA) APPEARS TO BE DECLINING IN A PORTION OF ITS RANGE IN ARKANSAS. AUGMENTATION OF THESE POPULATIONS ARE NEEDED TO ENSURE THE CONTINUED EXISTENCE OF THESE POPULATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, SOME LISTED SPECIES, SUCH AS THE PINK MUCKET (LAMPSILIS ABRUPTA) AND THE RABBITSFOOT (THELYDERMA CYLINDRICA), ARE IN NEED OF DEVELOPMENT AND OR REFINEMENT OF PROPAGATION AND CULTURE TECHNIQUES. THIS PROJECT WOULD INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION TO PROPAGATE AND RELEASE JUVENILE FRESHWATER MUSSELS. THE SECOND PROJECT WILL OCCUR ON AN ACTIVELY ERODING STREAMBANK ON THE LEFT DESCENDING BANK. AT THE TIME OF THE SITE VISIT, THE AREA OF CONCERN WAS 428 LINEAR FEET LONG WITH 9-10 FOOT HIGH VERTICAL BANKS. THE UPPER SALINE WATERSHED IS HOME TO FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED ARKANSAS FATMUCKET (LAMPSILIS POWELLII), ENDANGERED PINK MUCKET (LAMPSILIS ABRUPTA), THREATENED RABBITSFOOT (QUADRULA CYLINDRICA CYLINDRICA), AND ENDANGERED WINGED MAPLELEAF (QUADRULA FRAGOSA) FRESHWATER MUSSELS. THE NORTH FORK SALINE RIVER IS A STATE DESIGNATED EXTRAORDINARY RESOURCE WATERBODY (ERW), AND AN ECOLOGICALLY SENSITIVE WATERBODY (ESW) FOR THE ENDEMIC OUACHITA MADTOM (NOTURUS LACHNERI). ALSO CONTAINED WITHIN THIS RIVER IS A FAVORITE SPORTFISH FOR MANY ANGLERS, THE SMALLMOUTH BASS (MICROPTERUS DOLOMIEUI). STREAMBANK STABILIZATION WILL REDUCE SEDIMENT SOURCES AND PROVIDE STABILITY IN THE NORTH FORK SALINE RIVER CHANNEL. THE REDUCTION IN SEDIMENT AND A MORE STABLE STREAM CHANNEL WILL PROVIDE A HEALTHIER ENVIRONMENT AND HABITAT FOR THE LISTED T E, SGCN, AND SPORTFISH SPECIES LISTED ABOVE.

SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACH SURVEY PROGRAMS IN FLORIDA ARE OVERSEEN BY THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH INSTITUTE (FWRI) OF THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION (FWC). THE GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO FACILITATE AND OVERSEE NESTING BEACH SURVEYS THAT PROVIDE THE LONG-TERM DATA NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY ASSESS SEA TURTLE NESTING ACTIVITY AND NEST SUCCESS TRENDS ON FLORIDA BEACHES. STANDARDIZED, SYSTEMATIC SURVEYS OF SEA TURTLE NESTING IN FLORIDA ARE NEEDED TO CONTINUE ASSESSMENTS OF NESTING DISTRIBUTION, NESTING SEASONALITY, RELATIVE NESTING DENSITIES, AND HATCHLING PRODUCTION, AND TO MONITOR LONG-TERM TRENDS IN FLORIDA NESTING POPULATIONS. THESE ASSESSMENTS PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACHES. THERE ARE THREE NESTING BEACH SURVEY PROGRAMS IN FLORIDA. THE STATEWIDE NESTING BEACH SURVEY (SNBS) IS NEEDED TO ACQUIRE COMPLETE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL NESTING DISTRIBUTIONS OF THE VARIOUS SPECIES OF MARINE TURTLES THAT NEST ON FLORIDA BEACHES. THE INDEX NESTING BEACH SURVEY (INBS) PROGRAM IS NEEDED TO EXAMINE NESTING TRENDS. THE NEST ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (NPA) IS NEEDED TO ESTIMATE ANNUAL HATCHLING PRODUCTION (I.E., RECRUITMENT), AND IDENTIFY SOURCES OF EGG MORTALITY. ASSOCIATED WORK INVOLVES THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF THE WEB- AND MOBILE-BASED REPORTING PLATFORM FOR NESTING DATA THAT WILL STREAMLINE DATA ENTRY FOR ALL THREE PROGRAMS. A NETWORK OF TRAINED SURVEYORS (I.E., PERMIT HOLDERS AND AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL) FROM A VARIETY OF ORGANIZATIONS CONDUCTS NESTING BEACH SURVEYS AND NEST FATE EVALUATIONS UNDER FWRI GUIDANCE AND TRAINING FOLLOWING PROCEDURES DESCRIBED IN THE FWC MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION HANDBOOK. FWRI STAFF WILL (I) CONDUCT ANNUAL WORKSHOPS FOR PERMIT HOLDERS AND AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL TO REVIEW NESTING BEACH SURVEY AND NEST EVALUATION METHODOLOGIES AND PROTOCOLS  (II) CONDUCT SITE-VISITS OF SURVEY AREAS DURING THE NESTING SEASON AND MEET WITH THE LOCAL PERSONNEL TO ADDRESS ANY ISSUES RELATED TO PROPERLY FOLLOWING METHODOLOGIES AND PROTOCOLS AS THEY ARISE AND TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL HANDS-ON TRAINING AND  (III) CONTINUE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE STREAMLINED WEB- AND MOBILE-BASED NESTING DATA COLLECTION APPLICATION AND PROVIDE TRAINING TO THOSE WHO WILL BE USING THIS APPLICATION. AT THE END OF THIS PROJECT, WE ANTICIPATE THE COMPLETION OF ANOTHER YEAR OF HIGH-QUALITY NESTING BEACH SURVEY WORK AND AN ENHANCEMENT OF OUR ABILITIES TO MORE QUICKLY AND COMPLETELY ENTER AND EVALUATE ALL THE ASSOCIATED DATA AS WELL AS PROVIDING THESE DATA IN ANNUAL REPORTS TO ALL INTERESTED PARTIES.

THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES COORDINATION PROJECT INCLUDES FIVE ACTIVITIES FOR THE PERIOD COVERED:  OVERVIEW AND COORDINATION AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT SUPPORT ,  BUILDING RESILIENCY THROUGH REPATRIATION FOR THE FROSTED ELFIN (CALLOPHRYS IRUS) IN NORTH FLORIDA ,  ENHANCING CONSERVATION AND CAPTIVE BREEDING EFFORTS TOWARD THE RECOVERY OF THE EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE ,  A CRAYFISH INVASION THREATENS THE IMPERILED BLACK CREEK CRAYFISH: EVALUATING THE ROLE OF DISEASE AND OPTIONS FOR CONSERVATION  AND  EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE (DRYMARCHON COUPERI) OCCUPANCY SURVEYS AND POPULATION MONITORING IN THE NORTHERN AND CENTRAL FLORIDA REGIONS .

THE SOUTHERN SEA OTTER (ENHYDRA LUTRIS NEREIS) IS AN ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES THAT FACES NUMEROUS CHALLENGES, FROM DISEASE AND SHARK BITE MORTALITY TO RESOURCE LIMITATION IN LARGE PORTIONS OF ITS OCCUPIED RANGE. LISTED AS  THREATENED  UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND  FULLY PROTECTED  UNDER STATE LAW, CALIFORNIA S SEA OTTER POPULATION HAS BEEN SLOWLY RECOVERING FROM NEAR-EXTINCTION SINCE CESSATION OF THE MARITIME FUR TRADE. DURING THIS TIME, CALIFORNIA S COASTAL HUMAN POPULATION HAS ALSO UNDERGONE A MANY-FOLD INCREASE. AS A RESULT, SOUTHERN SEA OTTERS ARE COMING INCREASINGLY INTO CONTACT WITH HUMAN ACTIVITIES, ESPECIALLY IN HARBORS AND ESTUARIES, WHERE THE CHARISMATIC SPECIES IS A PRIMARY ATTRACTION FOR ECOTOURISTS. WITH THE GUIDANCE OF ADVISORS FROM THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), AND UNITED STATES (US) GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, SEA OTTER SAVVY HAS CREATED AND DEVELOPED A MULTI-TIERED APPROACH TO MITIGATING HUMAN-CAUSED DISTURBANCE TO SOUTHERN SEA OTTERS. THE MISSION OF SEA OTTER SAVVY IS TO FOSTER COMMUNITY AWARENESS AND INVOLVEMENT TO REDUCE HUMAN-CAUSED DISTURBANCES TO SOUTHERN SEA OTTERS AND PROMOTE RESPONSIBLE WILDLIFE VIEWING. USING BOTH IN-PERSON AND MEDIA-BASED TOOLS, WE WILL REACH OUT TO RESIDENTS AND VISITORS OF REGIONS IN CALIFORNIA WHERE SEA OTTERS ARE BOTH PRESENT IN PROXIMITY TO HUMAN DEVELOPMENT (SANTA CRUZ, MONTEREY, AND SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTIES) AND ABSENT (NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA) WITHIN THE SEA OTTERS  HISTORIC RANGE. OUR APPROACH WILL HAVE THREE MAIN COMPONENTS: DEVELOPING AWARENESS THROUGH INNOVATIVE OUTREACH  DEVELOPING BUSINESS NORMS AND ORGANIZATIONAL PARTNERSHIPS  AND LEADING COMMUNITY-SCIENCE-BASED RESEARCH.

THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILDLIFE DIVISION IS REQUESTING  75,859 IN FEDERAL FUNDS UNDER SECTION 6 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY (KBB  LYAEIDES MELISSA SAMUELIS), FEDERALLY THREATENED EASTERN MASSASAUGA RATTLESNAKE (EMR  SISTRUSRUS CATENATUS CATENATUS) AND ASSOCIATED SAVANNA AND BARREN HABITAT IN MICHIGAN. AS A RESULT OF MULTIPLE FACTORS, BOTH SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT HAVE BEEN REDUCED DRAMATICALLY IN ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION SINCE EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT (MDNR 2009). THIS PROJECT WILL MAINLY PROVIDE SUPPORT TO ENHANCE, RESTORE, AND MANAGE OAK-PINE SAVANNA AND BARREN HABITAT TO BENEFIT KBB IN MICHIGAN. HABITAT WORK WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING PATCH SIZE AND IMPROVING CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN OCCUPIED KBB SITES. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT MONITORING OF HABITAT AND POPULATION STATUS ACROSS KBB RANGE IN MICHIGAN. KBB MONITORING WILL EXPAND ONGOING ASSESSMENT OF KBB POPULATIONS RELATIVE TO HABITAT MANAGEMENT. BECAUSE THERE IS OVERLY LAP OF UPLAND SAVANNA AND BARREN HABITAT IN WHICH BOTH KBB AND EMR USE, THESE HABITAT TYPES ARE THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE GRANT, HOWEVER, WE WILL OPPORTUNISTICALLY WORK ON WET PRAIRIES AND FENS FOR EMR BASED ON BUDGET AND STAFF AVAILABILITIES.

THE YOLO HABITATCONSERVANCY WILL HOLD THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND ENROLL THE SITE IN THE YOLO HCP NCCP RESERVE SYSTEM TO EXPAND THE EXISTING NETWORK OF PROTECTED HABITAT WITHIN THE REGION AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF GIANT GARTER SNAKE BY PROTECTING LAND THAT CONTAINS A DENSE POPULATION OF GIANT GARTER SNAKES. THE SITE ALSO PROVIDES HABITAT FOR AVARIETY OF OTHER SPECIES, INCLUDING FIVE OTHER SPECIES COVERED BY THE YOLO HCP NCCP: WESTERN POND TURTLE,TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD, SWAINSONS HAWK, WHITE-TAILED KITE, AND BURROWING OWL.

THE SIERRA NEVADA DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) OF THE SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (VULPES VULPES NECATOR  SNRF) IS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (CESA) AND ENDANGERED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA  U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  2021). RECOVERY PLANNING FOR THIS DPS IS SEVERELY LIMITED BY A LACK OF DATA ON ITS ABUNDANCE, DENSITY, VITAL RATES, GENETIC STRUCTURE, DISTRIBUTION, RESOURCE SELECTION, DISEASE RISK, AND ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS TO ITS PERSISTENCE. THE RECENTLY COMPLETED GUIDING DOCUMENT FOR SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (SNRF) RECOVERY, A CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR THE SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX CONSERVATION ADVISORY TEAM  SCAT  2021 ), IDENTIFIES THESE DATA GAPS AS CRITICAL IMPEDIMENTS TO RECOVERY OF THE DPS. OUR GOAL IS TO ADDRESS THIS NEED BY DEPLOYING GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) COLLARS ON SNRF WITHIN THE KNOWN RANGE OF THE DPS IN THE SIERRA NEVADA.DATA FROM GPS COLLARS AND FROM BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES OBTAINED DURING CAPTURES WILL ALLOW US TO DOCUMENT HABITAT SELECTION AND SPACE USE OF SNRF, INVESTIGATE REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY, ESTIMATE VITAL RATES, DETERMINE CAUSE SPECIFIC MORTALITY, COLLECT MORPHOLOGICAL MEASUREMENTS, PERFORM GENETIC AND DISEASE ANALYSIS, AND IMPROVE THE SAMPLING DESIGN OF NON INVASIVE SURVEYS. THIS INFORMATION WILL DIRECTLY SUPPORT MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY OF THE DPS BY INFORMING LAND MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIONS WITHIN SNRF HABITAT, PROVIDING THE DATA NEEDED TO PERFORM ANALYSES OF THE BENEFITS OR RISKS OF AUGMENTING THE DPS VIA TRANSLOCATIONS, INDICATING WHETHER THERE IS A NEED FOR VACCINATION OR TREATMENT FOR DISEASES, AND DOCUMENTING CAUSES OF MORTALITY THAT MAY BE POSSIBLE TO MITIGATE THROUGH MANAGEMENT INTERVENTION.

THIS PROPOSAL REQUESTS  2,600,000 IN FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS FROM THE FISCAL YEAR 2022 COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND (SECTION 6 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT) NONTRADITIONAL HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN LAND ACQUISITION (HCPLA) GRANTS PROGRAM. THE FEDERAL GRANT WILL BE MATCHED BY NON FEDERAL FUNDS TOTALING  1,400,000 (35 ) OF THE TOTAL PROJECT COST. THIS FUNDING WILL RESULT IN PERMANENT PROTECTION OF CONSERVATION LANDS TOTALING 638.64 ACRES THAT WILL COMPLEMENT THE COACHELLA VALLEY MSHCP NCCP IN EASTERN RIVERSIDE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION FOCUSES ON CONSERVING PARCELS THAT SUPPORT COVERED LISTED AND AT RISK SPECIES AND NATURAL COMMUNITIES. THE PURPOSE OF THE LAND ACQUISITION PROPOSAL IS TO ACQUIRE AND PERMANENTLY PROTECT HIGHLYDEVELOPABLE BUT ESSENTIAL HABITAT ON LANDS IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT TO TWO CONSERVATION AREAS IDENTIFIED IN THECOACHELLA VALLEY MSHCP NCCP. SPECIFICALLY, THE INDIO HILLS JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK LINKAGE CONSERVATION AREAAND DESERT TORTOISE AND LINKAGE CONSERVATION AREA . THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION PROPERTY PROVIDES ESSENTIALCONNECTIVITY AND WILDLIFE MOVEMENT FUNCTIONS AMONG PROTECTED AREAS IN THE REGION AND PROVIDES CORE HABITAT FORTHE FEDERALLY THREATENED DESERT TORTOISE.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO PURCHASE A LARGE TRACT (APPROXIMATELY 2,077 ACRES) OF FORESTED CONSERVATION LAND IN THE HEADWATERS OF AMICALOLA CREEK IN DAWSON COUNTY, GEORGIA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY AND HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED ETOWAH DARTER AND OTHER AT RISK AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL SPECIES OCCURRING IN THE WATERSHED. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO ACQUIRE THE TRACT FEE SIMPLE SO THAT IT CAN BE MANAGED BY GEORGIA DNR FOR WATERSHED PROTECTION WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL USES SUCH AS HIKING. THIS PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN 3 YEARS AND IS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE THE VIABILITY OF THE ETOWAH DARTER POPULATION IN AMICALOLA CREEK.

THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE FEE SIMPLE PURCHASE OF THREE PARCELS TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 546 ACRES IN SOUTHERN SANTA ROSA COUNTY, FLORIDA. THE PURPOSE IS TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT RETICULATED FLATWOODS SALAMANDER BREEDING WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED PINE FLATWOODS, WHILE ALSO PROTECTING FORAGING HABITAT FOR DOCUMENTED RED COCKADED WOODPECKER FAMILIES AND GULF STURGEON HABITAT FOUND IN THE EAST BAY RIVER. DOCUMENTED OCCURRENCES OF PROTECTED PLANTS ARE ALSO ON THE PROPERTY. TWO OF THE PARCELS FRONT THE RIVER AND ACQUISITION WOULD PROVIDE A BUFFER TO THE RIVER AND PRECLUDE DEVELOPMENT AND ASSOCIATED DEGRADATION OF WATER QUALITY AND LOSS OF HABITAT. THE RIVERSIDE PARCELS ARE ALSO CONTIGUOUS WITH EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE AND WOULD PROVIDE BASE BUFFERING TO EGLIN AND INCREASE LANDSCAPE LEVEL CONSERVATION AND CONNECTIVITY. HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR THE SPECIES INCLUDED IN THIS PROPOSAL ARE CURRENTLY ON GOING ON EGLIN. ONCE ACQUIRED, THE PARCELS WILL BE MANAGED WITH APPROPRIATE HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, INCLUDING THE USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE, TO MAINTAIN HABITAT STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. UPON COMPLETION OF THE REAL ESTATE ACQUISITION, THE PARCELS WILL BE OWNED AND MANAGED IN PERPETUITY BY SANA ROSA COUNTY.

THE SANTA ANA SUCKER (CATOSTOMUS SANTAANAE, SAS) IS ONE OF FEW EXTANT FRESHWATER FISHES NATIVE TO SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND ARE LISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THEIR CURRENT DISTRIBUTION IS LIMITED TO THE SANTA ANA, SAN GABRIEL, AND LOS ANGELES RIVERS, WHERE THEY HAVE STEADILY DECLINED IN RECENT YEARS WITHIN THE SANTA ANA RIVER DUE IN PART TO NONNATIVE PREDATORY SPECIES, REDUCED SPAWNING HABITAT, AND DEGRADED HABITAT CONDITIONS. FISHERIES BIOLOGISTS HAVE EMPLOYED VARIOUS SURVEYING METHODS TO MONITOR THE SANTA ANA RIVER SAS POPULATION BUT INCONSISTENCIES IN SURVEY METHODOLOGIES HAVE MADE FOR LIMITED AND OFTEN BIASED ANALYTIC OPTIONS. FURTHERMORE, SAS SURVEYS HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN LIMITED TO THE NON BREEDING SEASONS OR USING LESS INFORMATIVE METHODS THAT CAN T QUANTIFY COMPARABLE ESTIMATES OF POPULATION STRUCTURE FOR ALL SAS LIFE STAGES (E. G., BANK VISUAL OBSERVATIONS). COLLECTIVELY, THESE LIMITED SAMPLING APPROACHES HAVE RESULTED IN AN INCOMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF SAS POPULATION DYNAMICS. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AND REFINE TWO LESS INTRUSIVE METHODOLOGIES FOR SURVEYING SAS  CAMERA MONITORING AND PIT TAGGING. THESE NEW METHODOLOGIES CAN BE USED IN COORDINATION WITH COMMON SURVEY METHODS AND DURING SENSITIVE SAS LIFE HISTORY PERIODS TO GAIN ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON MAJOR LIFE HISTORY EVENTS (E.G., REPRODUCTION) AND STANDARDIZE SAS SURVEYING METHODOLOGIES TO PROVIDE COMPARABLE DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION THROUGHOUT THE KNOWN SAS DISTRIBUTION.

THE LAND TRUST FOR SANTA BARBARA COUNTY SUBMITS THIS APPLICATION UNDER THE FY 2022 COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND, RECOVERY LAND ACQUISITION (RLA) PROGRAM FOR  3,611,197IN FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS FOR THE PURISIMA HILLS CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROJECT. THE PURISIMA HILLS RLA PROJECT SEEKS TO CONSERVE EIGHT ADDITIONAL PARCELS TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 880 ACRES THAT ARE OWNED BY LOCAL LANDOWNERS WHO HAVE PROVIDED DOCUMENTATION THAT THEY ARE SUPPORTIVE OF THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL (CRITERIA 6 AND 7). THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB) WILL PROVIDE 50.80 PERCENT LOCAL MATCH, WHICH IS GREATER THAN THE MINIMUM NON FEDERAL COST SHARE THAT IS REQUIRED (CRITERION 7). THE FEDERAL FUNDS REQUESTED UNDER THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE USED TO PURCHASE CONSERVATION EASEMENTS THAT WILL BE HELD AND MANAGED BY THE LAND TRUST FOR SANTA BARBARA COUNTY. FEE OWNERSHIP OF ALL PARCELS INCLUDED IN THIS PROPOSAL WILL REMAIN WITH THE CURRENT OWNER.THE PROJECT SUPPORTS 11 POND FEATURES, 6 OF WHICH ARE KNOWN CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER BREEDING PONDS, ALONG WITH EXTENSIVE HIGH QUALITY UPLAND HABITAT THAT IS KNOWN TO BE CURRENTLY OCCUPIED BY THE SPECIES AND REQUIRES NO RESTORATION TO BENEFIT THE SPECIES (CRITERION 2). ALONG WITH THE PREVIOUSLY CONSERVED LANDS AND THOSE CURRENTLY PROPOSED FOR ACQUISITION ADJACENT TO THE PROJECT, THE PURISIMA HILLS RLA PROJECT WILL SATISFY THE RECOVERY CRITERIA WITHIN THE PURISIMA METAPOPULATION FOR THE SANTA BARBARA COUNTY CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER AS WELL AS ADVANCE AND OR FULFILL TEN PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTIONS (CRITERION 1).THE PURISIMA HILLS RLA PROJECT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE SPECIES VIABILITY IN TERMS OF POPULATION RESILIENCY, SPECIES REDUNDANCY, AND SPECIES REPRESENTATION (CRITERION 3). THE STRATEGY TO RECOVER THE SANTA BARBARA COUNTY CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER FOCUSES ON ALLEVIATING THE THREAT OF HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION IN ORDER TO INCREASE POPULATION RESILIENCY AND REDUNDANCY. THE RECOVERY CRITERIA ARE BASED UPON SPECIFIC HABITAT REQUIREMENTS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THE SPECIES EXHIBITS RESILIENCY AND REDUNDANCY TO PREVENT ENDANGERMENT. BY PRESERVING ENOUGH AQUATIC AND UPLAND HABITATS, AND THEREBY MEETING THE HABITAT BASED RECOVERY CRITERIA, A LARGE PORTION OF THE INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE METAPOPULATION WILL BE PROTECTED THEREBY INCREASING THE SPECIES  ABILITY TO WITHSTAND OR BOUNCE BACK FROM ENVIRONMENT OR DEMOGRAPHIC STOCHASTIC EVENTS (I.E. RESILIENCY). THE CONNECTED SWATH OF HABITAT THAT WOULD BE PRESERVED THROUGH SUCCESSFUL FUNDING OF THE PROPOSED PURISIMA HILLS RLA PROJECT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PROTECTED AND CONNECTED AQUATIC AND UPLAND HABITATS THEREBY INCREASING THE SPECIES  ABILITY TO WITHSTAND CATASTROPHIC EVENTS (I.E., REDUNDANCY). THE PONDS WITHIN THE PROPOSED PURISIMA HILLS CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROJECT RETAIN WATER EVEN IN THE DRIEST OF YEARS. UNDER A SCENARIO OF WARMING TEMPERATURES AND LESSENING RAINFALL, THE PRESERVATION AND PROTECTION OF THE 11 PONDS WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA IS ESSENTIAL TO THE SANTA BARBARA COUNTY DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) OF THE CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER AND ITS LONG TERM CONSERVATION THEREBY IMPROVING THE SPECIES ABILITY TO ADAPT TO CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS (I.E. REPRESENTATION).

THIS PROJECT WOULD FUND CONSERVATION BIOLOGY INSTITUTE (CBI) TO CONTINUE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR THE STATE  AND FEDERALLY LISTED FISHER (PEKANIA PENNANTI) IN THE SOUTHERN SIERRA NEVADA. CBI WILL WORK WITH AN INTERAGENCY FISHER TECHNICAL TEAM (FTT) TO UPDATE THE SOUTHERN SIERRA NEVADA FISHER CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT AND  STRATEGY (SSNFCAAND S VL.0  SPENCER ET AL. 2015B, 2016) WITH NEW MODELS OF FISHER HABITAT, FOREST RESILIENCE, AND MANAGEMENT PRIORITY AREAS USING FOREST STRUCTURE DATA FROM THE CALIFORNIA FOREST OBSERVATORY (CFO). THE SSNFCAAND S VL.0 WAS ADOPTED IN 2016 BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS), AND NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) FOR USE IN ACTIVITIES THAT MIGHT AFFECT FISHERS. IT WAS TO BE UPDATED EVERY 4 6 YEARS AND WAS COMPLETED JUST AS HISTORICAL DROUGHT AND MEGAFIRES WERE SUBSTANTIALLY ALTERING FISHER HABITAT CONDITIONS. THE STRATEGY ESTABLISHED FISHER HABITAT AND POPULATION METRICS FOR TRACKING PROGRESS ON CONSERVATION GOALS, BUT LACKED QUANTIFIABLE METRICS FOR FISHER HABITAT RESILIENCE AND A SYSTEMATIC WAY TO TRACK CHANGES IN HABITAT AS FORESTS CHANGE WITH CLIMATE, FIRE AND OTHER DISTURBANCES. VERSION 2.0 OF THE STRATEGY WILL INCORPORATE METRICS OF FISHER HABITAT RESILIENCE AND ASSOCIATED DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS FOR FOREST MANAGERS. THESE NEW RESILIENCE AND DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS WILL BE LINKED TO THE REVISED STRATEGY TO GUIDE FISHER HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND FACILITATE EFFICIENT TRACKING OF QUANTITATIVE METRICS FOR FISHER RECOVERY GOALS. HABITAT AND POPULATION RESILIENCE GOALS ENABLED BY DYNAMIC MODELING WILL BE INCLUDED.

THE AMARGOSA VOLE S STATUS IS PRECARIOUS, WITH ABOUT 500 INDIVIDUALS REMAINING. CHALLENGES INCLUDE DROUGHT AND RESTRICTED WATER, COMPOUNDED BY DISEASE, GENETIC IMPOVERISHMENT, PREDATION, AND INTRAGUILD COMPETITION (I.E. DRAMATIC EXPANSIONS IN HOUSE MOUSE, LIKELY SIGNALING DEGRADED HABITAT. THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA DAVIS ARE WORKING TO ACHIEVE RECOVERY AND EVENTUAL DOWNLISTING OF THE VOLE. TO ACHIEVE THIS, WE PROPOSE TO STUDY ECOLOGICAL FACTORS THAT MAY IMPEDE RECOVERY AND UNDERTAKE TWO RECOVERY ACTIVITIES (TRANSLOCATIONS AND CAPTIVE BREEDING). SPECIFICALLY, WE PROPOSE TO  1) CONTINUE CAPTIVE BREEDING AT UC DAVIS AS INSURANCE AGAINST EXTINCTION  2) PERFORM TRANSLOCATIONS OF WILD TECOPA VOLES INTO RESTORED MARSHES IN SHOSHONE AND MONITOR OUTCOMES TO RECONSTRUCT A SUSTAINABLE SUBPOPULATION  AND 3) TRANSLOCATE VOLES INTO, AND REMOVE MICE OUT OF, INTACT AND DEGRADED MARSH PATCHES, MONITORING IMPACTS ON INDIVIDUAL AND POPULATION HEALTH AND CHANGES IN BEHAVIORS. WITHOUT THIS DATA, OUR ABILITY TO BUILD STEPPING STONE MARSHES FOR THE VOLE METAPOPULATION OR RESTORE MARSHES WILL BE IMPEDED, AND WE COULD SQUANDER LIMITING WATER RESOURCES, ALLOWING VOLE POPULATIONS TO PLUMMET. OUR WORK ENGAGES SECTION 6 THEMES  DIRECTLY SUPPORTING DE LISTING OF CURRENTLY LISTED SPECIES, LAND AND WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES, SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATIONS INTO THE ADAPTIVE RESPONSE OF LISTED SPECIES TO CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, INCLUDING PROLONGED DROUGHT, AND ALTERED WATER AND FIRE REGIMES, AND APPLIED SCIENCE THAT REDUCES THE IMPACT OF CHANGING CONDITIONS ON LISTED SPECIES OR PROMOTES RESILIENCE, BENEFIT TO MULTIPLE LISTED SPECIES .

THIS GRANT SEEKS  3,700,000 WITH A MATCH OF  1,300,000 FOR A TOTAL OF  5,000,000. THIS FUNDING WILL HELP CDFW ANDUSFWS MEET THE TWO GOALS OF THIS PROJECT. THE FIRST GOAL IS TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT HIGH QUALITY HABITAT ANDSTRATEGICALLY IMPORTANT DISPERSAL CORRIDORS FOR THE FEDERAL AND STATE ENDANGERED AND STATE FULLY PROTECTED SANTACRUZ LONG TOED SALAMANDER (AMBYSTOMA MACRODACTYLUM CROCEUM) (SALAMANDER), THROUGH THE VOLUNTARY SALE AND PURCHASEOF IDENTIFIED PARCELS VIA FEE TITLE ACQUISITION OR CONSERVATION EASEMENTS. THE PROJECT CONSIDERS NINE PARCELS,EACH OF WHICH CONSISTS OF HIGH QUALITY HABITAT OR IS IDENTIFIED AS AN ESSENTIAL DISPERSAL CORRIDOR. FEE TITLEAND OR EASEMENTS WILL BE HELD BY THE LAND TRUST OF SANTA CRUZ COUNTY, THE CENTER FOR NATURAL LANDS MANAGEMENT, ORTHE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPENDING ON WHICH PARCELS ARE ACQUIRED. THIS PROJECT WILL PREVENTTHESE PROPERTIES FROM BEING CONVERTED TO INCOMPATIBLE LAND USES AND WILL SUPPORT RECOVERY OF THE SANTA CRUZ LONGTOEDSALAMANDER IN PERPETUITY. THE SECOND GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSIST PRIVATE LANDOWNERS THAT ARE LARGELYUNABLE TO LAWFULLY DEVELOP OR DISTURB HABITAT OR SELL THEIR PROPERTIES DUE TO PRESENCE OF THE STATE FULLYPROTECTEDSANTA CRUZ LONG TOED SALAMANDER ON THE PROPERTY.

THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE FOREVER WILD LAND TRUST ARE PROPOSING A PLAN TO ACQUIRE, FROM A WILLING SELLER, KEY PARCELS OF LAND CONTAINING RED HILLS SALAMANDER (RHS) HABITAT, IN AN EFFORT TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT AND RESTORE SOME OF THE BEST HABITAT FOR AND POPULATIONS OF THE RHS ACROSS ITS RANGE, OVER THE LONG TERM STABILIZING AND EVENTUALLY IMPROVING THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES. THIS FEE SIMPLE LAND PURCHASE OF APPROXIMATELY 1,728 ACRES IN MONROE COUNTY, COMBINED WITH OTHER ADJACENT STATE OWNED LANDS ACQUIRED OR ACTIVELY BEING PURCHASED THROUGH HABITAT CONSERVATION PROGRAM AND RECOVERY LAND ACQUISITION FUNDS, WILL RESULT IN OVER 13,800 CONTIGUOUS ACRES OF PERMANENTLY PROTECTED HABITAT SUITABLE FOR THE RHS.

THE CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER (AMBYSTOMA CALIFORNIENSE   CTS ) IS THREATENED BY NON NATIVE HYBRIDIZATION THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE IN CALIFORNIA. EARLIER RESEARCH CLEARLY DEMONSTRATES THAT HYBRIDS BETWEEN CTS AND NON NATIVE BARRED TIGER SALAMANDERS (AMBYSTOMA MAVORTIUM   BTS ) DISRUPT VERNAL POOL ECOLOGY AND DISQUALIFIES THE ENTIRE CTS POPULATION FROM COUNTING TOWARDS RECOVERY IN THE CENTRAL CALIFORNIA DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT. EFFORTS TO PREVENT AND REVERSE THE SPREAD OF NON NATIVE BTS GENES, REQUIRE INFORMATION ON THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND MOVEMENT ECOLOGY OF NATIVE AND HYBRID SALAMANDERS. HYBRIDS ARE OFTEN  IMPOSSIBLE TO VISUALLY IDENTIFY, RECLUSIVE, AND HAVE BEEN SPREADING FOR DECADES. THE FORT ORD MANAGEMENT UNIT (MONTEREY COUNTY, CA   FOMU ), AS DEFINED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN, OFFERS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO QUANTIFY THE MOVEMENT OF NATIVE AND NON NATIVE ALLELES OVER SPACE AND TIME. WE PROPOSE A STUDY THAT COMBINES MORE THAN 30 YEARS OF HISTORICAL GENETIC SAMPLES WITH EXHAUSTIVE CONTEMPORARY SURVEYS TO COLLECT, SEQUENCE, AND ANALYZE 1,810 CTS SAMPLES SPANNING 30  YEARS OF GENETIC SAMPLING ACROSS THE FOMU. FROM THIS DATA, UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, LOS ANGLES (UCLA) WILL PRODUCE HIGH RESOLUTION MAPS THAT DESCRIBE THE EXTENT AND PREVALENCE OF NON NATIVE ALLELES IN THE FOMU AND IDENTIFY HABITAT FEATURES AND CORRIDORS THAT FACILITATE OR INHIBIT HYBRID MOVEMENT. UCLA WILL ALSO EVALUATE MULTI DECADAL TRENDS IN POPULATION SIZE AND GENETIC HEALTH OF NATIVE CTS IN THE FOMU. FROM THIS DATA, UCLA WILL DEVELOP A PANEL OF LOCI THAT MAY BE USED TO RAPIDLY IDENTIFY HYBRIDS IN THE FIELD. THIS WORK WILL CULMINATE IN A GENETIC MANAGEMENT STRATEGY THAT CAN BE USED AS A BLUEPRINT FOR MINIMIZING HYBRID EXPANSION AND IMPROVING NATIVE POPULATION HEALTH, ACROSS THE SPECIES RANGE.

THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY (ODF) THROUGH OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) IS REQUESTING 1,000,000 IN FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS FROM THE FISCAL YEAR (FY) 2022 COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND(CESCF) (SECTION 6 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA ) HABITAT CONSERVATION PLANNING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. WEANTICIPATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE STATEWIDE ODF PRIVATE FOREST ACCORD AQUATIC HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) ANDTHE CONCURRENT NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA) PROCESS SHALL OCCUR IN THREE PHASES. WITH PHASE 1CURRENTLY UNDER WAY, WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDS FOR PHASE 2 OF THE PLANNING PROCESS WHICH WILL INCLUDE THECOMPLETION OF A SECOND ADMINISTRATIVE DRAFT HCP AND THE EARLY STAGES OF THE NEPA PLANNING PROCESS. GRANT FUNDSWILL BE USED FOR CONTRACTED SERVICES.CONFLICT BETWEEN THE TIMBER INDUSTRY AND CONSERVATION GROUPS OVER TIMBER, AQUATIC, AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES CAME TOA HEAD IN EARLY 2020. WITH GUIDANCE FROM THE GOVERNOR S OFFICE, MEMBERS FROM EACH OF THE MAJOR INTEREST GROUPS ONBOTH THE INDUSTRY AND CONSERVATION SIDE CAME TOGETHER, SIGNED AN MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU), AND OVER AYEAR FOUND COMMON GROUND ON REVISIONS TO THE OREGON FOREST PRACTICES ACT (FPA) RULES. AS A RESULT OF MANY HOURSAND HARD WORK THE REVISED FPA ACTIONS WERE FORMALIZED IN THE PRIVATE FOREST ACCORD (PFA), WHICH WAS PASSED BY THESTATE LEGISLATURE IN MARCH OF 2022. THE LEGISLATION DIRECTED THE BOARD OF FORESTRY TO DEVELOP NEW RULES UNDER THEFPA TO IMPLEMENT THE TERMS OF THE PFA AGREEMENT AND TO DEVELOP A HCP FOR THE PURPOSES OF OBTAINING AN INCIDENTALTAKE PERMIT (ITP) UNDER THE ESA FOR THE COVERED AQUATIC FISH AND AMPHIBIAN SPECIES.THE PURPOSE OF PURSUING A PFA AQUATIC HCP IS TO PROVIDE REGULATORY STREAMLINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PRIVATE FORESTLANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT OREGON WHILE PROMOTING CONSERVATION OF AQUATIC SPECIES. THE PROGRAMMATIC NATURE OF THIS HCPALLOWS LARGE AND SMALL PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AS WELL AS THE POTENTIAL FOR TRIBES TO PARTICIPATE IN A STREAMLINEDAPPROACH TO PROTECTING COVERED SPECIES UNDER THE ESA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IDENTIFY, LIST, CONSERVE, AND RECOVER THE INDIGENOUS SPECIES AND SUBSPECIES (TAXA) OF AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES THAT ARE THREATENED OR ENDANGERED IN NEW MEXICO, AND ATTEMPT TO PRECLUDE THE NEED TO LIST OTHER RARE OR SENSITIVE AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES BEFORE THEY BECOME HIGHLY IMPERILED WITHIN THE STATE. THIS INCLUDES    DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN INFORMATION REGARDING THE RARE OR IMPERILED NATIVE AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES OF NEW MEXICO, INCLUDING RANGES, NUMBERS, BIOLOGY, TAXONOMY, AND PROSPECTS FOR SURVIVAL AND RECRUITMENT WITHIN THE STATE.   IDENTIFY SPECIES AND SUBSPECIES THAT MAY BE IN NEED OF ADDITIONAL MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION TO ENSURE THEIR PERSISTENCE WITHIN THE STATE.   DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE TAXA IDENTIFIED IN NUMBER 2 (ABOVE), WITH THE GOAL OF IMPROVING THEIR STATUS TO THE POINT THAT THE PERSISTENCE OF THESE TAXA WITHIN NEW MEXICO WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED TO BE IN JEOPARDY IN THE PRESENT OR FORESEEABLE FUTURE.   COMPLETE SPECIFIC PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN NUMBER 3 (ABOVE) FOR THE SPECIES OR SUBSPECIES IN GREATEST NEED OF ADDITIONAL CONSERVATION MEASURES.

HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP), FUNDED THROUGH AN FY2019 SECTION 6 PLANNING ASSISTANCE AWARD, WAS INITIATED INJANUARY 2021 TO ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION NEED OF LISTED SPECIES. THREE PHASES WERE IDENTIFIED TO COMPLETE THE HCPWITH THE FOLLOWING PURPOSE AS FOLLOWS  TO PROTECT AND CONSERVE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES AND THEIRHABITATS AND SUPPORT GUAM S RICH BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL HERITAGE FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS TO ENJOY WHILEFACILITATING SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. PHASE 1 WAS DEFINED AS INITIATE HCP, GATHER DATA, AND INITIATESTAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT. ALL ACTIONS DESCRIBED IN THE FIRST GRANT APPLICATION ASSOCIATED WITH PHASE 1 OF THE HCPHAVE BEEN COMPLETED. PHASE 2 OF THE HCP WAS ALSO FUNDED UNDER THE FIRST GRANT AND INCLUDES THE PREPARATION OF ACOMPLETE ADMINISTRATIVE DRAFT HCP. THIS PHASE HAS BEEN INITIATED AND WILL BE CONCLUDED BY SEPTEMBER OF 2023.PHASE 3 OF THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE PUBLIC AND FINAL DRAFTS OF THE HCP, THE INITIATION AND COMPLETION OFNATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA) COMPLIANCE, THE NECESSARY EXPANSION OF THE STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH PROGRAM,AND THE FUNDING OF A PART TIME POSITION AT THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TO PROVIDE ANTICIPATED INCREASEDINVOLVEMENT IN THE NEXT PHASE OF HCP DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION. THESE PHASE 3 COMPONENTS ARE LISTED ASOBJECTIVES BELOW.OBJECTIVE 1  EXPANDED STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT, MORE IN PERSON MEETINGS WITH STEERING COMMITTEE,AND CONTINUED PUBLIC OUTREACH.OBJECTIVE 2  FINAL PUBLIC DRAFT HCP.OBJECTIVE 3  PREPARE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT (EIS).OBJECTIVE 4  FUND PART TIME STAFF POSITION TO PROVIDE DEDICATED SUPPORT TO THE GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE FORTHE HCP.

THE SANTA CLARA VALLEY HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN NATURAL COMMUNITY CONSERVATION PLAN (HABITAT PLAN OR PLAN)COVERS 519,506 ACRES OF URBAN, RURAL, AND NATURAL LANDS IN SANTA CLARA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT PURPOSE ISTO SUPPORT THE HABITAT AGENCY IN ACQUIRING UP TO 2,925 ACRES OF LAND FOR THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF 18SPECIES COVERED BY THE PLAN INCLUDING 3 FEDERALLY THREATENED, 6 FEDERALLY ENDANGERED, AND ONE SPECIES PROPOSEDFOR FEDERAL LISTING. ONCE ACQUIRED, A CONSERVATION EASEMENT WILL BE PLACED ON THE LANDS TO ENSURE PERMANENTPROTECTION, AND LANDS WILL BE MANAGED FOR THE BENEFIT OF COVERED SPECIES AND THE ENHANCEMENT OF NATURALCOMMUNITIES.

THE SANTA CLARA VALLEY HABITAT PLAN (PLAN) COVERS 519,506 ACRES OF URBAN, RURAL, AND NATURAL LANDS IN SANTA CLARACOUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE PLAN PERMIT AREA INCLUDES THE CITY OF SAN JOSE, THE TENTH LARGEST CITY BY POPULATION ANDTHE SIXTH MOST DIVERSE, LARGE, CITY IN THE UNITED STATES (POLITIFACT 2022  U.S. NEWS AND WORLD REPORT 2020). THEPLAN PROVIDES A FRAMEWORK FOR PROMOTING THE PROTECTION AND RECOVERY OF NATURAL RESOURCES, INCLUDING THREATENEDAND ENDANGERED SPECIES, WHILE STREAMLINING THE PERMITTING PROCESS FOR PLANNED DEVELOPMENT, INFRASTRUCTURE, ANDMAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES OVER A 50 YEAR PERMIT TERM. THE PLAN IS IMPLEMENTED BY THE SANTA CLARA VALLEY HABITATAGENCY (HABITAT AGENCY) AND HAS BEEN IN IMPLEMENTATION FOR ALMOST A DECADE. AS OF REPORTING YEAR 2021, THE PLANHAS PERMITTED 361 PROJECTS AND CONSERVED 6,500 ACRES.THE PLAN AMENDMENT IS NECESSARY TO PROTECT ADDITIONAL FEDERAL AND STATE LISTED SPECIES AS WELL AS AT RISK SPECIESTHAT WERE NOT ORIGINALLY INCLUDED, BUT MAY NOW WARRANT INCLUSION DUE TO CHANGES IN LISTING STATUS, RANGE, OR LIFEHISTORY INFORMATION. THE AMENDMENT WILL ALSO ADD COVERED ACTIVITIES, EXPAND THE PERMIT AREA, AND POTENTIALLY ADDA NEW CO PERMITTEE. THE AMENDMENT WILL ENSURE THAT THE PLAN ACCURATELY REFLECTS AND EVALUATES THE AMOUNT OF TAKEOCCURRING IN THE PLAN AREA AND ENSURES THAT THOSE EFFECTS WILL NOT JEOPARDIZE THE COVERED SPECIES. IT WILL ALSOINCORPORATE SEVERAL TOPICS THAT HAVE BEEN ADDRESSED THROUGH MODIFICATION AND CLARIFICATION INTERPRETATION MEMOSWHICH INCLUDE ADMINISTRATIVE CHANGES TO LANGUAGE AND POLICIES WHICH ARE INTENDED TO INCREASE EFFICIENCIES ANDPROVIDE GREATER CLARITY FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE PERMIT TERM. FINALLY, THE AMENDMENT PROCESS WILL PROVIDE ANOPPORTUNITY TO FURTHER EXPAND PERMIT STREAMLINING FOR AQUATIC RESOURCES ALSO REGULATED BY FEDERAL AND STATEAGENCIES UNDER THE FEDERAL CLEAN WATER ACT (CWA) AND STATE PORTER COLOGNE WATER QUALITY CONTROL ACT (PCA.

TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED TEXAS HORNSHELL THROUGH RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS HOST FISHES. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT ANNUAL MONITORING SURVEYS AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SURVEYS OF GRAY REDHORSE, BLUE SUCKER, AND RIVER CARPSUCKER TO DETERMINE ITS OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION TRENDS. THESE FISHES ARE A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF THE TEXAS HORNSHELL LIFE CYCLE AND ARE INEXTRICABLY LINKED TO THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. IN ADDITION, WE WILL INVESTIGATE POTENTIAL REPATRIATION LOCATIONS FOR BLUE SUCKER AND CONDUCT FISH HEALTH ANALYSIS TO ASSESS POPULATIONS THAT ARE CANDIDATES FOR TRANSLOCATION.

CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE EAST CONTRA COSTA COUNTY(ECCC) HABITAT CONSERVANCY S (HABITAT CONSERVANCY) WORK THAT IS REQUIRED TO APPLY FOR AN EXTENSION OF THE PERMITTERM FOR BOTH THE EAST CONTRA COSTA COUNTY HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) (PERMIT NUMBER TE160958 0) AND NATURALCOMMUNITY CONSERVATION PLAN (NCCP) (PERMIT NUMBER 2835 2007 001 03). THE EAST CONTRA COSTA COUNTY HCP NCCP (PLAN)IS IN YEAR 15   THE HALFWAY MARK OF THE EXISTING PERMITS AND HAS EVALUATED THE PACE OF DEVELOPMENT, CONSERVATIONACTIONS, AND FUNDING STREAMS. THIS REVIEW HAS DETERMINED THAT DEVELOPMENT IN EAST CONTRA COSTA COUNTY HAS NOTOCCURRED AT THE PACE ANTICIPATED IN THE PLAN  THEREFORE, DEVELOPMENT FEES ARE NOT ACCRUING AT THE RATE NECESSARYTO FULLY FUND THE PLAN S ENDOWMENT BY THE END OF THE 30 YEAR PERMIT TERM (PERMIT TERM).
