THE SWEETWATER AUTHORITY (AUTHORITY) IS A PUBLICLY OWNED WATER AGENCY THAT PROVIDES POTABLE WATER TO A POPULATIONOF APPROXIMATELY 200,000 IN NATIONAL CITY, THE UNINCORPORATED COMMUNITY OF BONITA, AND THE WESTERN PORTION OF THECITY OF CHULA VISTA. MANY OF THE AUTHORITY S OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE (OAND M) ACTIVITIES ARE SUBJECT TOENVIRONMENTAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS, INCLUDING FEDERAL AND STATE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACTS (ESAS). THE AUTHORITY HASHISTORICALLY APPROACHED PERMITTING AND MITIGATION FOR STATE AND FEDERALLY REGULATED PROJECTS AND OAND M ACTIVITIESON A CASE BY CASE BASIS. HOWEVER, PREPARING THE NECESSARY ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION AND PROCESSINGPERMITS FOR ROUTINE OAND M ACTIVITIES IN THIS MANNER RESULTS IN DELAYS, BUDGETARY IMPACTS, OVERALL UNCERTAINTY ONTHE ABILITY TO PERFORM CRITICAL OAND M ACTIVITIES, AND INEFFICIENT IMPLEMENTATION OF HABITAT MITIGATION. CALIFORNIADEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE AUTHORITY S PROJECT TO COMPLETE ANADMINISTRATIVE DRAFT NATURAL COMMUNITY CONSERVATION PLAN (NCCP) AND HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) IN SUPPORT OFPERMITS FOR ITS OAND M ACTIVITIES.THE PLAN AREA FOR THE PROPOSED SWEETWATER AUTHORITY NCCP HCP INCLUDES LANDS OWNED, MANAGED, AND UNDER EASEMENT BYTHE AUTHORITY. THIS INCLUDES TWO RESERVOIRS (SWEETWATER AND LOVELAND RESERVOIRS) OWNED BY THE AUTHORITY. THEAUTHORITY HAS A LONG STANDING INTEREST IN THE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE SWEETWATER RIVER WATERSHED ANDSURROUNDING HABITATS OF THESE RESERVOIRS. THE LANDS OWNED BY THE AUTHORITY ARE LOCATED ADJACENT TO AND INTEGRATEDWITH LARGE BLOCKS OF LANDS CONSERVED AS PART OF THE SUBREGIONAL MULTIPLE SPECIES CONSERVATION PROGRAM (MSCP) HCP NCCP IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY AND REPRESENT AN IMPORTANT OPPORTUNITY FOR CONSERVATION. THE SWEETWATER AUTHORITY NCCP HCP WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN COORDINATION WITH THE MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OF SEVERAL ADJACENT SUBAREA PLANPRESERVES ASSOCIATED WITH THE MSCP WHICH INCLUDES THE SAN DIEGO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND OTHER ADJACENT ANDNEARBY PUBLIC LANDS. BY COMPLETING AND PERMITTING THE SWEETWATER AUTHORITY NCCP HCP, THE AUTHORITY WILL BE ABLETO FULLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE MSCP CONSERVATION GOALS AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR PROPOSED COVERED SPECIES ANDTHE NATURAL COMMUNITIES THAT SUPPORT THEM. THE NCCP HCP WILL ESTABLISH MEANINGFUL CONSERVATION ACTIONS, ANDAVOIDANCE, MINIMIZATION, AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO BE APPLIED ACROSS THE PLAN AREA ON A CONSISTENT BASIS.THE WORK TO BE COMPLETED UNDER THIS GRANT WILL INCLUDE ALL STEPS TO PREPARE AN ADMINISTRATIVE DRAFT OF THESWEETWATER AUTHORITY NCCP HCP. THIS WILL INCLUDE IDENTIFICATION AND COMPILATION OF BEST AVAILABLE DATA,EVALUATION AND DETERMINATION OF A COVERED SPECIES LIST, REVIEW OF COVERED ACTIVITIES, DEVELOPMENT OF ACONSERVATION AND FUNDING STRATEGY, AND PREPARE THE ADMINISTRATIVE DRAFT NCCP HCP DOCUMENT. THE AUTHORITY MAY SEEKFUTURE SECTION 6 PLANNING ASSISTANCE GRANT FUNDS TO COMPLETE ADDITIONAL TASKS RELATED TO COMPLETION OF THECALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY ACT (CEQA) NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA) PROCESS AND PREPARATION OFTHE PUBLIC REVIEW AND FINAL NCCP HCP. THE AUTHORITY WILL CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE CLOSELY WITH THE WILDLIFEAGENCIES, KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLIC DURING THE PREPARATION OF THE SWEETWATER AUTHORITY NCCP HCP.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SEEK FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED TEXAS HORNSHELL. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT ANNUAL MONITORING OF TEXAS HORNSHELL TO DETERMINE ITS OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION TRENDS. IN ADDITION, NMDGF ASSISTS PARTNERS THROUGH PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON TEXAS HORNSHELL CONSERVATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SEEK FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO IDENTIFY, MANAGE, CONSERVE, AND RECOVER ENDEMIC SPECIES OF MOLLUSKS AND CRUSTACEANS THAT ARE THREATENED, ENDANGERED OR CONSIDERED SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN NEW MEXICO. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL ASSIST PARTNERS IN ESTABLISHING A REFUGIUM FOR CHUPADERA SPRINGSNAIL, COMPLETE ANNUAL MONITORING OF SOCORRO ISOPOD, CHUPADERA SPRINGSNAIL, PECOS SPRINGSNAIL, AND ALAMOSA SPRINGSNAIL, AND INVESTIGATE PROPAGATION TECHNIQUES FOR CHUPADERA SPRINGSNAIL.

THE CITY OF LIVERMORE (CITY) IS LOCATED IN A UNIQUE SETTING IN THE EASTERN SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA WHERE OPENSPACE, WORKING LANDS, AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT MEET. THESE LANDS INCLUDE REGIONALLY RECOGNIZED AREAS THAT HAVE BEENDESIGNATED AS PRIORITY CONSERVATION AREAS IN ALAMEDA COUNTY. THIS PART OF THE BAY AREA SUPPORTS HABITATS OFSEVERAL LISTED AND AT RISK PLANT AND WILDLIFE SPECIES THAT ARE FOUND WITHIN AND SURROUNDING LIVERMORE CITYLIMITS.TO ADDRESS THE UNIQUENESS OF THE HABITATS WITHIN AND SURROUNDING THE CITY, THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THEDEVELOPMENT OF A CITY WIDE LIVERMORE HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP). THE PURPOSE OF THE LIVERMORE HCP IS TOESTABLISH AN EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE APPROACH FOR THE CITY TO MAINTAIN EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE AND DEVELOP NEWINFRASTRUCTURE WHILE MAINTAINING REGULATORY COMPLIANCE AND IMPLEMENTING A THOUGHTFUL AND COMPREHENSIVECONSERVATION APPROACH FOR THE AREA. THE LIVERMORE HCP IS NOT ANTICIPATED TO INCLUDE COVERAGE FOR DEVELOPMENTPROJECTS.ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT INCLUDE STRATEGIC PLANNING TO DETERMINE THE SCOPE OF THE LIVERMORE HCP, ENGAGE WITHSTAKEHOLDERS, AND DETERMINE THE CONSERVATION STRATEGY. THE CITY ANTICIPATES THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE HCP DOCUMENTSTO OCCUR OVER A THREE YEAR PERIOD, IN A PROCESS THAT WILL INCLUDE THE WRITING OF AN HCP PUBLIC DRAFT, NATIONALENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT (NEPA) AND CALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY ACT (CEQA) DOCUMENTS, PUBLIC OUTREACHMEETINGS, AND PREPARING RESPONSES TO PUBLIC COMMENTS. THE CITY HAS PARTICIPATED IN NUMEROUS CONSERVATION PLANNINGAND SPECIES MAPPING EFFORTS IN RECENT YEARS, INCLUDING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CITY S STREAM MAINTENANCE PROGRAM(SMP), THE EAST ALAMEDA COUNTY CONSERVATION STRATEGY (EACCS), AND THE EAST BAY REGIONAL CONSERVATION INVESTMENTSTRATEGY (RCIS) THAT HAVE ESTABLISHED A BASIS OF TECHNICAL KNOWLEDGE TO BUILD UPON AND INCORPORATE INTO THE HCPDEVELOPMENT PROCESS. THE CITY WILL COORDINATE WITH POTENTIAL STAKEHOLDERS WITH COLLECTIVE INTEREST IN THE PLANIMPLEMENTATION INCLUDING ALAMEDA COUNTY, ZONE 7 WATER AGENCY, ALAMEDA COUNTY RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT, EASTBAY REGIONAL PARK DISTRICT, THE COUNTY OF ALAMEDA, AND LIVERMORE AREA RECREATION AND PARKS DISTRICT.THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LIVERMORE HCP IS ANTICIPATED TO SIGNIFICANTLY STREAMLINE THE CITY SROUTINE MAINTENANCE AND CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (CIP) PROJECTS, ALLOWING THE CITY TO CARRY OUT CRITICALINFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS, SUCH AS STREAM MAINTENANCE AND ROAD WIDENING, WHILE CONSERVING IMPORTANT HABITAT ANDPROTECTING LISTED AND AT RISK SPECIES, SUCH AS CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER, CALIFORNIA RED LEGGED FROG, PALMATEBRACTEDBIRD S BEAK, AND NORTHWESTERN AND SOUTHWESTERN POND TURTLE IN LIVERMORE AND THE SURROUNDING AREA. THECITY ANTICIPATES DEVELOPING AN INTEGRATED PLAN THAT FACILITATES COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER FEDERAL AND STATEREGULATIONS TO DEVELOP THE MOST EFFICIENT AND COMPREHENSIVE POSSIBLE PROGRAM.

CATALINA ISLAND, LOCATED IN LOS ANGELES COUNTY 20 MILES OFFSHORE FROM THE LOS ANGELES METROPOLITAN REGION, SUPPORTS A BIOLOGICALLY DIVERSE ASSEMBLAGE OF NATURAL COMMUNITIES WITH AT LEAST 60 PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES ENDEMIC TO THE ISLAND. THE ISLAND IS OWNED, MANAGED, OR ADMINISTERED PRIMARILY BY THREE ENTITIES  THE CATALINA ISLAND CONSERVANCY (CONSERVANCY), THE TOWN OF AVALON (AVALON), AND THE SANTA CATALINA ISLAND COMPANY (COMPANY). THE CONSERVANCY OWNS AND MANAGES MORE THAN 88  OF THE ISLAND AND BALANCES ECO TOURISM AND CONSERVATION NEEDS WITHIN THIS AREA. TO MEET THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE CONSERVANCY S CONSERVATION STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, THE CONSERVANCY IMPLEMENTS ACTIVITIES TO MAINTAIN, MANAGE, AND ENHANCE THE UNIQUE BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES OF THE ISLAND. MANY OF THE CONSERVANCY S ACTIVITIES ARE SUBJECT TO ENVIRONMENTAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS, INCLUDING FEDERAL AND STATE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACTS (ESAS), MOST NOTABLY FOR THE STATE AND FEDERALLY LISTED SANTA CATALINA ISLAND FOX (UROCYON LITTORALIS CATALINAE).IN 1990, AN ESTIMATED 1,342 ADULT SANTA CATALINA ISLAND FOXES INHABITED CATALINA ISLAND (ROEMER ET AL. 1994). IN 1999 THE FOX POPULATION DECLINED TO  100 INDIVIDUALS DUE TO A CANINE DISTEMPER OUTBREAK CAUSED BY A COMMON RACCOON (PROCYON LOTOR  TIMM ET AL. 2000). THE CONSERVANCY AND IWS HAVE CONTINUED TO IMPLEMENT FOX MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING  (1) MONITORING 300 400 FOXES ANNUALLY ACROSS THE ENTIRE ISLAND USING TRAP MARK RECAPTURE TO DETERMINE FOX ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION ESTIMATE  (2) RADIO COLLARING 40 60 FOXES TO MONITOR HEALTH OF THE FOX POPULATION  (3) VACCINATING 300  FOXES AGAINST CDV AND RABIES  AND (4) REDUCTION OF EAR TUMORS BY TOPICALLY APPLYING IVERMECTIN AND REDUCING EAR MITE LOADS, AND (5) VETERINARY TREATMENT TO FOXES INJURED IN THE WILD. AS TIME AND RESOURCES ALLOW, THE CATALINA ISLAND CONSERVANCY CONTINUES TO STREAMLINE THE CATALINA ISLAND FOX PROJECT TO PROVIDE QUALITY CARE FOR THE POPULATION. CREATING A CATALINA ISLAND FOX HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) IS THE NEXT STEP TO PROACTIVELY REDUCING HUMAN IMPACTS ON FOXES, HOWEVER STAFFING AND RESOURCES ARE IN TOO SHORT SUPPLY TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL. CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS PURSUING THIS PLANNING GRANT IN SUPPORT OF THE CONSERVANCY DEVELOPING A CATALINA ISLAND FOX HCP IN THE FUTURE. IF APPROVED, THIS PROPOSAL WILL BUILD CAPACITY TO COMPLETE THE COMPREHENSIVE SINGLE SPECIES HCP. THE CREATION OF THE HCP IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE SCOPE OF THIS PROPOSAL.THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS GRANT WILL INCREASE THE CONSERVANCY S ABILITY TO COMPLETE A CATALINA ISLAND FOX HCP IN THE FUTURE BY DETERMINING COVERED ACTIVITIES VIA STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT (OBJECTIVE 1), EXISTING DATA ANALYSIS (OBJECTIVE 2), AND BASELINE SURVEYS (OBJECTIVE 3). THE CONSERVANCY WILL CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE CLOSELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND CDFW, COLLECTIVELY   WILDLIFE AGENCIES , KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLIC DURING THIS PROCESS TO ENSURE MANAGEMENT ORIENTED GOALS ARE MET. THIS GRANT WILL ALSO ALLOW THE CONSERVANCY TO CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES OF THE CATALINA ISLAND FOX THAT WILL INCREASE THE PROBABILITY OF SURVIVAL.THE CONSERVANCY WILL ALSO COORDINATE WITH THE WILDLIFE AGENCIES TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ENSURE THE DEVELOPMENT OF STAKEHOLDERS, RESEARCH, AND COVERED ACTIVITIES ARE APPROPRIATE FOR FUTURE HCP DEVELOPMENT.

THE STATE OF HAWAII IS SEEKING FUNDS FOR THE COMPLETION OF THE KAUAI ISLAND UTILITY COOPERATIVE (KIUC) HABITATCONSERVATION PLAN (HCP)AND ASSOCIATED ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTS. THE HCP WILL OFFSET THE INCIDENTAL TAKEOF NINE ENDANGERED OR THREATENED SPECIES IMPACTED BY KIUC S OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT OF POWERLINES AND LIGHTING.THE SPECIES AFFECTED INCLUDE SEABIRDS, WATERBIRDS, AND SEA TURTLES. KIUC WILL MINIMIZE TAKE THROUGH MODIFICATIONSTO POWERLINES TO REDUCE THE LIKELIHOOD OF COLLISION AND MODIFYING LIGHTING TO REDUCE DISORIENTATION. THECONSERVATION STRATEGY ON THE HCP INCLUDES THE ESTABLISHMENT, PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND MONITORING OF SEABIRDCOLONIES  FUNDING A SEABIRD AND WATERBIRD REHABILITATION PROGRAM  AND MONITORING NESTING SEA TURTLES.THE PROPOSED GRANT WILL FUND THE COMPLETION OF THE HCP AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT (EIS). PREVIOUS GRANTSWERE USED TO FILL IN DATA GAPS REGARDING THE SCALE AND SCOPE OF TAKE, COVERED SPECIES THREATS AND MANAGEMENTOPPORTUNITIES, AND RESEARCH INTO EFFECTIVE NOVEL MINIMIZATION TECHNIQUES. THE PREVIOUS GRANT ALSO RESULTED IN ACONCEPTUAL HCP DRAFT. UNDER THE PROPOSED GRANT TERM, THE APPLICANT WILL WORK WITH THE AGENCIES TO RESOLVEOUTSTANDING ISSUES AND FINALIZE THE DRAFT HCP FOR PUBLIC REVIEW. THE DRAFT HCP WILL BE REVIEWED BY THE STATE SENDANGERED SPECIES RECOVERY COMMITTEE WHICH WILL ALSO CONDUCT A SITE VISIT PRIOR TO MAKING A RECOMMENDATION TOTHE BOARD OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES REGARDING THE BIOLOGICAL MERIT OF THE PLAN.THE PROPOSED FUNDING WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE COMPLETION OF THE EIS, FOR WHICH A NOTICE OF INTENT HAS BEEN PUBLISHEDAND SCOPING MEETING COMPLETED. THE EIS WILL BE DRAFTED TO SATISFY THE BOTH FEDERAL AND STATE ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWLAWS. THE DELIVERABLES FOR THIS GRANT ARE A COMPLETED HCP AND COMPLETED EIS SUBMITTED TO BOTH AGENCIES ALONG WITHAPPLICATION FOR INCIDENTAL TAKE AUTHORIZATION.

THE NATIVE HISTORIC PRAIRIES OF SOUTH PUGET SOUND ARE AMONG THE RAREST HABITATS IN THE UNITED STATES.DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURE, AND FIRE SUPPRESSION HAVE LED TO A DRAMATIC DECLINE OF THE NATIVE PRAIRIE LANDSCAPE.TODAY, LESS THAN 10  OF NATIVE HISTORIC PRAIRIES REMAIN, WITH ONLY A SMALL PORTION OF WHAT REMAINS IS HIGHQUALITY NATIVE PRAIRIES. IN 2013 AND 2014, SEVERAL PRAIRIE SPECIES THAT ARE FOUND IN THE CITY AND ON PORTPROPERTIES, INCLUDING THE OLYMPIA POCKET GOPHER AND THE STREAKED HORNED LARK, WERE LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THEFEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA). THE PLAN AREA OF THE BUSH PRAIRIE HCP INCLUDES THE ENTIRE RANGE OF THEOLYMPIA POCKET GOPHER. THE OREGON VESPER SPARROW IS ANOTHER PRAIRIE SPECIES FOUND IN THE CITY AND ON PORTPROPERTIES THAT IS LIKELY TO BE ESA LISTED IN THE NEAR FUTURE. IN ADDITION TO THESE THREE PRAIRIE SPECIES, THEWETLAND AND STREAM COMPLEXES ASSOCIATED WITH THE BLACK RIVER DRAINAGE SYSTEM IN THE WESTERN PORTION OF THE CITYARE OCCUPIED BY THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG, WHICH WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ESA IN 2014. THE BUSH PRAIRIEHCP WILL COVER ALL FOUR OF THESE SPECIES, AS WELL AS PROVIDING INCIDENTAL CONSERVATION BENEFITS TO NON LISTED ANDSTATE LISTED SPECIES NOT INCLUDED IN THE HCP. APPROXIMATELY THE SOUTHERN TWO THIRDS OF THE CITY, WHICH INCLUDESTHE PORT S OLYMPIA REGIONAL AIRPORT AND NEW MARKET INDUSTRIAL CAMPUS, HAVE SOILS THAT ARE A NATURALLY LIMITINGFACTOR SUITABLE FOR PRAIRIE SPECIES, WHILE THE WETLAND AND STREAM COMPLEXES IN THE WESTERN PORTION OF THE CITYARE A NATURALLY LIMITING FACTOR SUITABLE FOR THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG. THE BUSH PRAIRIE HCP WILL COVER ALL FOUR OFTHESE SPECIES, AS WELL AS PROVIDING INCIDENTAL CONSERVATION BENEFITS TO NON LISTED AND STATE LISTED SPECIES NOTINCLUDED IN THE HCP. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT THE CITY AND THE PORT CONTINUE AND COMPLETE IN PHASE 3 THE WORKSTARTED IN 2016 UNDER PHASE 1 AND CONTINUED IN 2018 UNDER PHASE 2 OF THE BUSH PRAIRIE HCP. THIS WOULD ALLOW FORTHE PROTECTION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES WITHIN A FRAMEWORK THAT ALLOWS THE CITY TO MANAGE RESPONSIBLE URBANRESIDENTIAL, COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL, AND INSTITUTIONAL GROWTH CONSISTENT WITH ITS OBLIGATIONS UNDER THEWASHINGTON STATE GROWTH MANAGEMENT ACT (GMA).
MN RECOVERY ACTIVITIES FOR FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE AND AT-RISK SPECIES, E-24-R-1

MINNESOTA DNR MANAGED LANDS PROVIDE HABITATS FOR MANY RARE, FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND AT RISK SPECIES, WHICH DNR WORKS TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT. TO ENABLE BENEFICIAL MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS MEET OTHER AGENCY OBJECTIVES, DNR NEEDS A COMPREHENSIVE AND FORWARD LOOKING APPROACH TO ESA COMPLIANCE THAT INCORPORATES THE RANGE OF DNR ACTIVITIES AND DIVERSITY OF SPECIES OCCURRING ON DNR LANDS. WEPROPOSE AN ANALYSIS OF DNR ACTIVITIES TO IDENTIFY THOSE THAT MAY AFFECT FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND AT RISK SPECIES, AND TO SCOPE A POTENTIAL HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) OR SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENT (SHA). IN ADDITION, WE PROPOSE NEW RESEARCH ON RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE TO INFORM HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (HCP) OR SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENT (SHA) DEVELOPMENT. INTENDED OUTCOMES OF A POTENTIAL HCP OR HA ARE STREAMLINED ESA COMPLIANCE AND IMPROVED CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND AT RISK SPECIES IN MINNESOTA THAT MAY BE IMPACTED BY DNR ACTIVITIES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF WDFW S CHESTER BUTTE PROJECT IS THE FEE TITLE PURCHASE OF 650 ACRES OF SHRUBSTEPPE HABITAT IN DOUGLAS COUNTY, WASHINGTON, TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT (BRACHYLAGUS IDAHOENSIS), AND OTHER SHRUBSTEPPE OBLIGATE SPECIES BY BUILDING ON AN EXISTING BASE OF WDFW CONSERVATION LANDS. THIS PURCHASE SUPPORTS CONSERVATION OF COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT, GREATER SAGE GROUSE (CENTROCERCUS UROPHASIANUS), COLUMBIAN SHARP TAILED GROUSE (TYMPANUCHUS PHASIANELLUS COLUMBIANUS), AND WASHINGTON GROUND SQUIRREL (UROCITELLUS WASHINGTONI) AND OCCURS WITHIN AN IDENTIFIED RECOVERY EMPHASIS AREA FOR COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT WHERE RECOVERY ACTIONS HAVE BEEN ONGOING AND INCLUDE REINTRODUCTION AND HABITAT REHABILITATION. THIS ACQUISITION PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON THIS INCREASINGLY RARE HABITAT TYPE IN A STRATEGIC LOCATION IN WASHINGTON. ACQUISITION WILL EXPAND SPECIES PROTECTIONS AND SECURE SHRUBSTEPPE HABITAT AS WELL AS INCREASE OPTIONS FOR FUTURE RECOVERY ACTIONS THAT SUPPORT LISTED SPECIES.
NATIONWIDE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT FOR LISTED AND AT-RISK BUMBLE BEES AND POLLINATORS ON ENERGY AND TRANSPORTATION LANDS

TO AMEND THE KANSAS AQUATIC SPECIES CONSERVATION AGREEMENT  A PROGRAMMATIC SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENT AND CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES (ICF. 2021 HEREIN REFERRED TO AS PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENT) TO INCLUDE AN ADDITIONAL AQUATIC SPECIES LISTED IN THE FWS 7 YEAR WORKPLAN. TO DEVELOP PROMOTIONAL AND INFORMATIONAL ACTIVITIES TO FACILITATE ENROLLMENT OF PRIVATE AND PUBLIC (NON FEDERAL) LANDOWNERS UNDER THE  PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENT . THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE PARTICIPANTS AN OVERVIEW OF THE PROCESS SPECIES THAT ARE COVERED, WHAT WORK WILL BE PERFORMED, AND PERIODIC UPDATES. VARIOUS METHODS IN THE FORM OF BROCHURES, SOCIAL MEDIA, WEBSITES, AND FACE TO FACE MEETINGS WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS TASK.

THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) PROPOSES TO PREVENT FRAGMENTATION AND CONVERSION OF A PARCEL OF NATIVE HABITAT ADJOINING ITS LOVE CREEK PRESERVE BY PURCHASING THE 378 ACRE HOREJSI RANCH FROM A PRIVATE LANDOWNER, MS. CONNIE HOREJSI. LOVE CREEK PRESERVE IS CURRENTLY 2,508 ACRES AND INCLUDES TWO TRACTS PURCHASED WITH PREVIOUS RECOVERY LAND ACQUISITION GRANTS. THE PRESERVE IS SURROUNDED BY A 4,160 ACRE SPECIES CONSERVATION BANK PERMITTED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO PROTECT THE GOLDEN CHEEKED WARBLER (SETOPHAGA CHRYSOPARIA), AN ENDANGERED SONGBIRD. BOTH THE GOLDEN CHEEKED WARBLER AND TOBUSCH FISHHOOK CACTUS (SCLEROCACTUS BREVIHAMATUS SSP. TOBUSCHII), A FEDERALLY THREATENED PLANT, OCCUR ON THE HOREJSI RANCH AND ADJOINING PRESERVE. TNC WILL OWN AND MANAGE THE HOREJSI RANCH AS PART OF THE LOVE CREEK PRESERVE. THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF THE RANCH IS ESTIMATED AT  2,400,000 WITH THE FIRM PRICE TO BE ESTABLISHED BY APPRAISAL. THE CONSERVANCY IS REQUESTING A RECOVERY LAND ACQUISITION GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF  1,800,000 WITH THE REMAINING VALUE OF THE RANCH TO BE DONATED BY THE LANDOWNER.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE WESTERN OREGON STATE FORESTS HCP TO ENSURETHAT 640,000 ACRES OF STATE FORESTS WEST OF THE CASCADE MOUNTAINS WILL BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE ESA, WHILEHAVING CERTAINTY IN OUR ABILITY TO IMPLEMENT FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES OVER A 70 YEAR PERMIT TERM.SPECIFICALLY, FY 22 FUNDING WILL SUPPORT PART 3 OF THE NEPA ANALYSIS AND CONSULTATION. THIS INCLUDES DEVELOPINGAND PUBLISHING THE FINAL EIS, FINALIZING THE HCP, DEVELOPING BIOLOGICAL OPINIONS AND SECTION 10 FINDINGS FOR 17COVERED SPECIES, ISSUANCE OF INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMITS (ITPS), AND THE RECORD OF DECISION ASSOCIATED WITH THE HCP.

CURRENT AND FUTURE DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES AND POPULATION GROWTH IN BELL AND CORYELL COUNTIES HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO IMPACT LISTED SPECIES OR SPECIES THAT MAY BECOME LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA). THIRTEEN LOCAL AND REGIONAL ENTITIES ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO PROACTIVELY ESTABLISH A CONSERVATION FRAMEWORK THAT WILL ALLOW FOR CONTINUED ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, WHILE SATISFYING ESA REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS. THIS GRANT PROPOSAL REQUESTS  1,000,000 IN FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN RHCP AND ASSOCIATED ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENT IN THESE TWO COUNTIES, INCLUDING ESTABLISHING A STAKEHOLDER COORDINATION PROCESS IN ACCORDANCE WITH CHAPTER 83 OF THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE CODE. THE SUCCESS OF THE BELCOR RHCP WILL DIRECTLY IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF THE REGION TO SUSTAIN VITAL ECONOMIC DRIVERS WITHOUT COSTLY REGULATORY DELAYS RELATED TO COMPLIANCE WITH THE ESA AND WILL SUPPORT THE COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION OF LISTED SPECIES IN THE REGION.

THE EAHCP IS PURSUING THE SECTION 6 HCP CONSERVATION PLANNING ASSISTANCE GRANT TO SUPPORT EFFORTS FOR HCPPLANNING AND ALTERNATIVE DEVELOPMENT, SUPPORTING PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, AND DEVELOPING REQUISITE DOCUMENTATION  I.E.,HCP AND NEPA DOCUMENT . FURTHERMORE, GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED TO ACQUIRE TECHNICAL SERVICES TO ASSIST IN THERENEWAL OF INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMIT  ITP TE-63663A-1 WHICH EXPIRES ON MARCH 31, 2028 AND FACILITATE CLIMATEANALYSIS, LISTEN AND LEARN WORKSHOPS, POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS, AND HABITAT SUITABILITYASSESSMENTS.THE EAHCP IMPLEMENTS CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES PAST THE 2028 EXPIRATION OF THE CURRENT ITP. THE RENEWED ITP ISINTENDED TO CONTINUE THEACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE CURRENT EAHCP AND PURSUE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES THAT HAVE THEPOTENTIAL TO FURTHER ADVANCE THE SUITABLE HABITAT OF THE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES THAT POPULATE THEEDWARDS AQUIFER REGION. MOREOVER, THE ITP RENEWAL FUNDED BY THE SECTION 6 HCP CONSERVATION PLANNING ASSISTANCEGRANT WILL ENSURE THE CONTINUATION OF GROUNDWATER CONSERVATION EFFORTS DURING PERIODS OF DROUGHT AND LONG-TERMSPRINGFLOWS IN THE COMAL AND SAN MARCOS RIVER SYSTEMS.

NOTATIOR ,AND AT-RISK WESTERN SPADEFOOT TOAD  SPEA HAMMONDII .
IN E-25-R-91 ASSESSMENT OF REGAL FRITILLARY HABITAT IN INDIANA

CONDUCT WESTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID SURVEYS OF KNOWN ORCHID POPULATIONS. INDIVIDUAL ORCHIDS (VEGETATIVE, ABORTIVE, AND FLOWERING) AND ORCHID SUB POPULATIONS WILL BE RECORDED FOLLOWING STANDARD NATURAL HERITAGE SURVEY PROTOCOL AND UTILIZING ESRI ARCPAD ON A TRIMBLE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEMS. THESE POINTS, ALONG WITH OTHER FEATURES COLLECTED IN THE FIELD, WILL BE POST PROCESSED USING ESRI ARCGIS, ACHIEVING SUB METER ACCURACY OF ORCHID LOCATIONS. DATA WILL BE ENTERED INTO THE BIOTICS SOFTWARE PROGRAM. BIOTICS IS A NATURESERVE BIODIVERSITY DATA MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE. BIOTICS IS AN INTEGRATED, WEB ENABLED PLATFORM FOR TABULAR AND SPATIAL DATA MANAGEMENT. USED BY MEMBERS OF THE NATURESERVE NETWORK, THE SYSTEM PROVIDES BUILT IN SUPPORT FOR OUR SHARED METHODOLOGY AND DATA STANDARDS

IN 2011 THE NEBRASKA GAME AND PARKS COMMISSION (COMMISSION) AND THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE,NEBRASKA FIELD OFFICE (SERVICE) ESTABLISHED THE CAPTIVE REARING AND REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM (PROGRAM) FOR THE SALTCREEK TIGER BEETLE (ELLIPSOPTERA  SYN. CICINDELA  NEVADICA LINCOLNIANA, SCTB). THE PROGRAM WAS INITIATED INRESPONSE TO THE 2005 ANNUAL SCTB POPULATION SURVEY WHICH FOUND EXTREMELY LOW POPULATION NUMBERS, JUST 153 IN THEWILD. THE VERY LOW POPULATION NUMBERS COMBINED WITH ONLY A FEW POPULATION LOCATIONS MEANT THE POPULATIONS ANDSPECIES WERE VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION DUE TO CONTINUED HABITAT DEGRADATION OR A CATASTROPHIC EVENT. TO PREVENTTHE EXTINCTION OF THE SPECIES IT WAS NECESSARY TO BEGIN CAPTIVE REARING SCTB FOR REINTRODUCTION. USING SECTION 6GRANTS, THE COMMISSION FUNDED RESEARCH THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA   LINCOLN ENTOMOLOGY DEPARTMENT (UNL)INTO CAPTIVE PROPAGATION OF SCTB. CAPTIVE REARING WAS THEN STARTED AT UNL, THE HENRY DOORLY ZOO AND AQUARIUM(HDZ) IN OMAHA, NE AND THE LINCOLN CHILDREN S ZOO (LCZ) IN LINCOLN, NE.THE PROGRAM HAS TWO COMPONENTS  THE FIRST IS THE PRODUCTION OF AMPLE NUMBERS OF INDIVIDUALS TO EFFECT POPULATIONNUMBERS IN THE WILD AND THE SECOND IS THE SUCCESSFUL REINTRODUCTION OF THOSE INDIVIDUALS INTO THE WILD. BOTH OFTHESE COMPONENTS ACCOMPLISH PRIORITY ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN THE 2017 SCTB RECOVERY PLAN DEVELOPED BY THE SERVICE.IN 2019 THE TOPEKA ZOO AND CONSERVATION CENTER (TZ) ALSO BEGAN PROPAGATION OF SCTB TO PROVIDE REDUNDANCY ANDENSURE THAT A CATASTROPHIC EVENT DOES NOT ELIMINATE THE CAPTIVE REARING EFFORT. THIS FACILITY ALSO HELPS PROVIDETHE CAPACITY TO REAR ADEQUATE NUMBERS OF SCTB FOR REINTRODUCTION PROJECTS.THESE FUNDS ALLOW FOR THE PROGRAM TO CONTINUE CAPTIVE REARING SCTBS AS WELL AS MONITOR WILD POPULATIONS AND THEIRHABITATS. WITHOUT THESE FUNDS THE FUTURE OF SCTB POPULATIONS WOULD BE IN JEOPARDY OF EXTINCTION.

THIS PROJECT WILL ANALYZE THE ACCURACY OF THE TWI METHOD FOR ASSESSING POTENTIAL WHOOPING CRANE MIGRATORY STOPOVER HABITAT WITHIN SELECTED AREAS THROUGHOUT THE DEFINED KANSAS PORTION OF THE ARANSAS WOOD BUFFALO POPULATION (AWBP) MIGRATORY CORRIDOR. IT WILL ALSO CREATE ALTERNATIVE MODELS  IF NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY PREDICT POTENTIAL WHOOPING SITE USE. ONCE MODEL ACCURACY HAS BEEN VALIDATED, MAP PRODUCTS WILL BE CREATED TO DETAIL LOCATIONS OF LIKELY SUITABLE MIGRATORY STOPOVER HABITAT. THESE PRODUCTS WOULD FURTHER CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR THE SPECIES BY INDICATING AREAS TO TARGET FOR CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND AVOIDANCE OF ADVERSE ANTHROPOGENIC DEVELOPMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A SURVEY OF FEDERALLY-LISTED MUSSELS IN THE KANKAKEE RIVER TO PROVIDE ROBUST AND LOCALLY RELEVANT EVALUATIONS OF DEMOGRAPHICS AND DENSITY. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE IL DNR, IN DNR, AND USFWS WITH INFORMATION ON THE CURRENT STATUS OF FEDERALLY-LISTED MUSSELS IN THE KANKAKEE RIVER. THIS INFORMATION MAY BE USED TO DEVELOP FUTURE STATUS ASSESSMENTS AND TO AID REGULATORY EVALUATIONS AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE SPECIES. THIS STUDY WILL BE THE FIRST IN MANY DECADES TO INCLUDE BOTH THE INDIANA AND ILLINOIS PORTIONS OF THE KANKAKEE RIVER AND COULD IMPROVE INTERSTATE MANAGEMENT OF ASSOCIATED FEDERALLY-LISTED MUSSELS. THIS PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE STATE OF INDIANA. THERE ARE NO SUB-GRANTEES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

LAS VEGAS BEARPOPPY, A RARE PLANT SPECIES LARGELY RESTRICTED TO GYPSUM SOILS, WAS RECENTLY PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ESA. IT OCCURS SPORADICALLY ACROSS A LARGE AREA OF THE EASTERN MOJAVE DESERT IN CLARK COUNTY, NEVADA AND ADJACENT ARIZONA. MANAGEMENT FOR ITS CONSERVATION WOULD BE GREATLY FACILITATED IF ITS CURRENT STATUS AND TRENDS AND ALSO ITS RANGE-WIDE DISTRIBUTION COULD BE BETTER DOCUMENTED. THIS IS DIFFICULT USING TRADITIONAL ON-THE-GROUND SURVEYS BECAUSE OF ITS OFTEN VERY SPARSE DISTRIBUTION ACROSS LARGE AREAS OF POTENTIAL HABITAT AND ALSO BECAUSE OF THE FRAGILE GYPSUM SOIL ENVIRONMENT WHERE IT IS FOUND. WE HAVE DEVELOPED DRONE  UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLE -BASED METHODOLOGY FOR ACCOMPLISHING LARGE-SCALE POPULATION CENSUS AND MONITORING FOR A CLOSELY RELATED SPECIES  DWARF BEARPOPPY, ARCTOMECON HUMILIS  IN A SIMILAR BADLANDS HABITAT. WE ARE CURRENTLY EXTENDING THIS APPROACH TO CENSUS LAS VEGAS BEARPOPPY IN THE GOLD BUTTE AREA OF CLARK COUNTY. WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE OUR CENSUS OF LAS VEGAS BEARPOPPY IN THE BITTER SPRINGS VALLEY, WHITE BASIN, RAINBOW GARDENS, AND VALLEY OF FIRE STATE PARK AREAS OF THE COUNTY, WHERE THE POPPIES ARE KNOWN TO OCCUR BUT WHERE LARGE AREAS OF POTENTIAL HABITAT REMAIN UNSURVEYED. WE PLAN TO DRONE-CENSUS AT LEAST 4,000 HA OF POTENTIAL HABITAT IN THESE AREAS. OUR CENSUS PRODUCT WILL INCLUDE COUNT DATA FOR DEFINED AREAS  POLYGONS  OF OCCUPIED HABITAT AND ALSO THE LOCATION OF EACH INDIVIDUAL POPPY ON MAPS GENERATED USING ARCPRO GIS SOFTWARE. OUR METHODOLOGY INCLUDES THE USE OF A DEEP LEARNING  ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE  OBJECT DETECTION PROGRAM TO QUICKLY AND ACCURATELY IDENTIFY, GEOLOCATE, AND COUNT INDIVIDUAL POPPY PLANTS IN THE DRONE IMAGERY.WE ALSO PROPOSE TO SET UP FOUR 0.6 HA LONG-TERM MONITORING PLOTS AT THREE POPULATIONS IN THE GOLD BUTTE AREA, THREE POPULATIONS IN THE BITTER SPRINGS VALLEY AREA, AND THREE POPULATIONS IN THE RAINBOW GARDENS AREA. GOLD BUTTE POPULATIONS WILL BE MONITORED FOR THREE YEARS, WHILE BITTER SPRINGS VALLEY POPULATIONS WILL BE MONITORED FOR TWO YEARS, AND RAINBOW GARDENS POPULATIONS WILL BE MONITORED FOR ONE YEAR. OUR ESTABLISHED METHODOLOGY USES VERY HIGH RESOLUTION DRONE IMAGERY TO GEOLOCATE, MEASURE, AND SCORE FLOWERING STATUS FOR HUNDREDS OF INDIVIDUAL POPPIES, ALL WITHOUT ANY SURFACE DISTURBANCE. THESE PERMANENT PLOTS CAN THEN BE MONITORED YEARLY TO FOLLOW POPULATION TRENDS BASED ON RECRUITMENT, GROWTH, FLOWERING, AND MORTALITY OF INDIVIDUAL PLANTS. WE WILL THEN PROVIDE TRAINING MATERIALS TO ALLOW LAND MANAGERS OR THEIR CONTRACTORS TO CONTINUE MONITORING THESE PLOTS IN FUTURE YEARS.

LOCATED ALONG THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF WASHINGTON S CASCADE MOUNTAIN RANGE (MAP 1   CONTEXT MAP), THE PHASE 1 PARCELS PROTECT DIVERSE HABITAT INCLUDING MATURE MIXED CONIFER FORESTS  FRESHWATER WETLANDS  1.15 MILES OF ANADROMOUS STREAMS  AND VERNAL SEEPS AND SPRINGS. THIS IS A COLLABORATIVE, ONGOING PROJECT BETWEEN COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE, COLORADO NATURAL AREAS PROGRAM, AND COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE FIELD SURVEYS, MONITORING, AND DATA DEVELOPMENT FOR PLANT SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND OTHER PRIORITY PLANT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AS OUTLINED IN THE 2015 COLORADO STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THE DATA ACQUIRED FROM THESE ACTIONS, COMBINED WITH OTHER STATEWIDE OCCURRENCE DATA FOR ALL THREATENED AND ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES, WILL BE ENTERED INTO COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM S CENTRAL DATA REPOSITORY AND BE PROVIDED TO THE SERVICE. THE UP TO DATE DATA WILL PROVIDE THE SERVICE WITH A CURRENT AND COMPREHENSIVE DATA SET OF LOCATION, POPULATION, HABITAT, AND MANAGEMENT INFORMATION FOR ALL THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND PRIORITY SWAP PLANT SPECIES. THESE COMBINED OBJECTIVES WILL ENABLE THE SERVICE TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ON LISTING, DE LISTING, STATUS ASSESSMENTS, DESIGNATING CRITICAL HABITAT, FACILITATING SECTION 7 CONSULTATIONS, AND IMPLEMENTING RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR COLORADO S FEDERALLY LISTED, PROPOSED, AND PETITIONED PLANT SPECIES.

RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR UTAH PRAIRIE DOGS  UPD  HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO A POSITIVE LONG TERM TREND IN NUMBERS, YET SYLVATIC PLAGUE REMAINS AMONG THE MOST PRESSING THREATS TO UPD POPULATIONS  CURRENT EFFORTS TO MANAGE PLAGUE ARE TO TREAT UPD BURROWS WITH DELTAMETHRIN DUST TO SUPPRESS FLEA NUMBERS AND DECREASE THE PROBABILITY OF PLAGUE TRANSMISSION  HOWEVER, DUSTING WITH DELTAMETHRIN CAN BE EXTREMELY TIME CONSUMING TO IMPLEMENT AND FLEAS MAY EVENTUALLY BUILD UP A TOLERANCE TO DELTAMETHRIN  THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO CONTRIBUTE TO RESEARCH THAT MAY DEVELOP A MORE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE WAY TO CONTROL PLAGUE IN UPDS  A POTENTIAL REPLACEMENT OR COMPLIMENT TO DELTAMETHRIN TREATMENT IS FIPRONIL, AN INSECTICIDE COMMONLY USED TO TREAT DOMESTIC PETS FOR FLEA CONTROL  THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO EVALUATE IF A FIPRONIL BAIT OR  FIPBITS  CAN PROVIDE EFFECTIVE CONTROL OF FLEAS IN UPD COLONIES  THE LARGE SCALE RESEARCH PLAN FOR FIPBITS IS TO ESTABLISH AT LEAST 40 EXPERIMENTAL PAIRS OF PRAIRIE DOG PLOTS COLONIES, ON AT LEAST 10 SITES ACROSS THE WEST, WHERE ONE MEMBER OF EACH PAIR IS TREATED WITH FIPBITS AND THE OTHER MEMBER IS NOT TREATED WITH ANY PLAGUE MITIGATION TOOLS AS A BASELINE  WE PROPOSE TO EXTEND THE STUDY TO UPDS  WE WILL COLLECT BASELINE INFORMATION OF FLEAS IN THE COLONIES, DISTRIBUTE FIPBITS, THEN FOLLOW UP TO DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF DECREASING FLEA NUMBERS  IF SUCCESSFUL, FIPBITS MAY REDUCE THE COST OF FLEA CONTROL FOR UPDS BY UP TO 90  AND GREATLY AID IN THE SPECIES  RECOVERY

HOWELLIA AQUATILIS  WATER HOWELLIA  WAS REMOVED FROM THE FEDERAL LIST OF ENDANGERED AND THREATENED PLANTS ON JUNE 16, 2021  86 FR 31955   THIS ACTION TRIGGERS THE USE OF SECTION 4 G  1  OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  OF 1973, AS AMENDED  16 U S C  ? 1531 ET SEQ  , WHICH REQUIRES THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  TO WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE STATES TO IMPLEMENT A MONITORING PROGRAM FOR NOT LESS THAN 5 YEARS  THE INTENT OF THIS POST DELISTING MONITORING IS TO VALIDATE DELISTING ASSUMPTIONS AND VERIFY THE SPECIES IS SELF SUSTAINING WITHOUT THE PROTECTIONS AFFORDED UNDER THE ESA  THIS PROPOSAL WOULD ALLOW MONTANA TO WORK COOPERATIVELY FLATHEAD NATIONAL FOREST AND USFWS, AS WELL AS WITH THE WASHINGTON COMMITTEE, WHO IS ALSO PARTICIPATING IN THIS RANGE WIDE MONITORING EFFORT TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE ACROSS ITS RANGE UNDER THE ESA  THE POST DELISTING MONITORING  PDM  PLAN FOR HOWELLIA AQUATILIS WAS FINALIZED IN 2020 AND SPECIFIES THAT TWO CONSECUTIVE YEARS OF MONITORING MUST OCCUR AT THREE DISTINCT TIME INTERVALS OVER A 15 YEAR PERIOD  USFWS 2020   THE TWO CONSECUTIVE YEARS OF MONITORING ARE NECESSARY BECAUSE PLANTS MAY NOT EMERGE EACH YEAR DUE TO ITS ANNUAL LIFE  MONITORING IN CONSECUTIVE TWO YEAR BLOCKS AT THREE INTERVALS OVER A 15 YEAR PERIOD AVOIDS THE EXPENSE OF MONITORING ANNUALLY, THUS BECOMING COST EFFECTIVE WHILE AT THE SAME TIME ENSURING ACCURATE TREND DETECTION AND ACCOMPLISHING THE REQUIREMENTS UNDER THE ESA  THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE CONDUCTED JOINTLY BY THE MONTANA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  MTNHP  AND THE U S FOREST SERVICE  USFS  FLATHEAD NATIONAL FOREST  FNF , WHICH IS ALSO KNOWN AS THE MONTANA COMMITTEE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SURVEY AND COLLECT TWO CONSECUTIVE YEARS OF HOWELLIA AQUATILIS POPULATION DATA FROM A MINIMUM OF 30 PONDS IN MONTANA AS OUTLINED IN THE PDM PLAN  THEREBY, CREATING THE BASELINE CONDITIONS FROM WHICH TO DETERMINE TREND OVER THE 15 YEAR TIMEFRAME  THE PROJECT PROPOSES FIVE OBJECTIVES THAT TIE DIRECTLY TO THE PDM PLAN  FOR OBJECTIVE 1 MTNHP STAFF WILL SELECT A MINIMUM OF 30 HOWELLIA AQUATILIS OCCURRENCES  PONDS  FROM THE 221 KNOWN OCCURRENCES USING A STRATIFIED RANDOM SAMPLE AND CRITERIA LISTED IN THE PDM PLAN  FOR OBJECTIVE 2 SPECIES MONITORING WILL BE JOINTLY CONDUCTED BY THE MTNHP AND FNF IN 2022 AND 2023 FOLLOWING THE PROTOCOL OUTLINED IN THE PDM PLAN AND THE STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES TO BE DEVELOPED UNDER OBJECTIVE 1  A VIRTUAL COORDINATION MEETING WILL OCCUR PRIOR TO FIELD WORK  MONITORING AND TRAINING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN JULY USING INDIVIDUALS REPRESENTING MTNHP, USFS, USFWS, A CONSULTANT, AND QUALIFIED VOLUNTEERS  A MINIMUM OF 30 PONDS WILL BE SURVEYED TO QUANTIFY THE ABUNDANCE OF HOWELLIA AQUATILIS AND PHALARIS ARUNDINCEA, MEASURE WATER DEPTH ALONG A TRANSECT, PHOTOGRAPH CONDITIONS, AND RECORD ADDITIONAL SITE DATA  TRAINED VOLUNTEERS WILL BE USED TO ACQUIRE MONITORING DATA ON AN EXCESS OF 30 PONDS  FOR OBJECTIVE 3 AMBIENT TEMPERATURE WILL BE RECORDED DURING THE GROWING SEASON OF 2022 AND 2023 AT FIVE PONDS USING TEMPERATURE LOGGERS  HOWELLIA AQUATILIS  POPULATION SIZE DEPENDS UPON ANNUAL CYCLES OF POND FILLING AND POND DRYING  MEASURING BOTH AMBIENT TEMPERATURE AND WATER DEPTH IN MID SUMMER AND EARLY AUTUMN WILL HELP EXPLAIN POPULATION SIZE AND TEASE APART EFFECTS DRIVEN BY GROUNDWATER AND AIR TEMPERATURE  FOR OBJECTIVE 4, WATER DEPTH ALONG THE ESTABLISHED TRANSECT WILL BE MEASURED AT A MAXIMUM OF 30 HOWELLIA AQUATILIS OCCURRENCES IN SEPTEMBER 2022 AND 2023 TO DETERMINE IF POND DRYING OCCURRED  FOR OBJECTIVE 5, THE MTNHP BOTANIST WILL COMPLETE DATA ENTRY AND ANALYSIS AND WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE FNF BOTANIST TO REPORT THE FINDINGS AFTER THE 2022 AND 2023 MONITORING EFFORT  COPIES OF ALL DATA, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND REPORTS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE USFWS MONTANA ECOLOGICAL SERVICE FIELD OFFICE

RECOVERY OF THE BLACK FOOTED FERRET  MUSTELA NIGRIPES  FERRET  FROM THE THRESHOLD OF EXTINCTION IS ONE OF THE GREATEST CONSERVATION SUCCESS STORIES IN THE UNITED STATES  SINCE THE DISCOVERY OF A SINGLE EXTANT POPULATION IN 1981 NEAR MEETEETSE, WYOMING, INVOLVEMENT OF THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT  DEPARTMENT  IN FERRET RECOVERY AND MONITORING HAS BEEN ESSENTIAL TO THE REESTABLISHMENT OF FERRETS IN THE WILD  IN 1991, CAPTIVE BRED FERRETS WERE REINTRODUCED IN SHIRLEY BASIN, AND REGULAR MONITORING HAS CONFIRMED THAT THE SPECIES HAS PERSISTED FOR  25 YEARS  SPURRED BY THIS SUCCESS, A STATEWIDE 10 J  DESIGNATION UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT WAS APPROVED IN 2015 FOR FERRETS IN WYOMING  USFWS 2015 , PAVING THE WAY FOR THE ADDITION OF NEW REINTRODUCTION SITES  AS A RESULT, THE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED A SECOND REINTRODUCTION SITE IN MEETEETSE IN 2016, BRINGING FERRETS BACK TO WHERE THE SPECIES WAS REDISCOVERED 35 YEARS PRIOR STILL, THERE ARE MANY CHALLENGES TO OVERCOME TO ENSURE THESE POPULATIONS PERSIST AND TO SUCCESSFULLY PROGRESS TOWARDS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ADDITIONAL POPULATIONS  THIS PROJECT WOULD ENABLE THE DEPARTMENT TO EXPAND ANNUAL MONITORING AT CURRENT REINTRODUCTION SITES AND COORDINATE THE FIRST COMPLETE ASSESSMENT OF FERRET PRESENCE IN SHIRLEY BASIN  ADDITIONAL EFFORTS INCLUDE EVALUATING VARIOUS TREATMENTS TO ABATE THE SPREAD OF SYLVATIC PLAGUE THROUGH POPULATIONS OF PREY SPECIES, AND CONTINUED COLLABORATION WITH KEY PARTNERS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO CONTINUE WORK TOWARD STATEWIDE AND NATIONAL RECOVERY OBJECTIVES  THESE ACTIONS ARE CRITICAL TO EVALUATING PROGRESS TOWARD BOTH STATE  WGFC 2018  AND NATIONAL  USFWS 2013  MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY GOALS  ANNUAL VISUAL COUNT PLOTS TO EVALUATE CHANGES IN PRAIRIE DOG PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE ALLOW THE DEPARTMENT TO BETTER ASSESS HABITAT QUALITY, QUICKLY IDENTIFY DECLINES THAT MAY IMPACT FERRETS, AND ENACT APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AS NEEDED TO ENSURE REINTRODUCTION SITES REMAIN VIABLE AND HEALTHY  WITH THE COMPLETION OF SCENT DETECTION DOG SURVEYS AND SUBSEQUENT CONFIRMATION EFFORTS, THE DEPARTMENT WILL HAVE ASSESSED THE DISTRIBUTION OF FERRET PRESENCE ACROSS SHIRLEY BASIN, ULTIMATELY RESULTING IN BETTER INFORMED MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OF FERRETS  BY ACCOMPLISHING THESE OBJECTIVES, THE DEPARTMENT AND THE USFWS WILL BE ABLE TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN FERRET POPULATIONS OF SUFFICIENT NUMBERS THAT WILL ASSIST IN MEETING RECOVERY GOALS TO ALLOW DOWN LISTING AND EVENTUAL DELISTING OF THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES

THE DEPARTMENT S GRIZZLY BEAR PROGRAM INVOLVES MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS DESIGNED TO DETERMINE VARIOUS POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS AND HABITAT USE OF GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE WYOMING OF THE YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM AND TO MANAGE GRIZZLY BEAR LIVESTOCK AND GRIZZLY BEAR HUMAN INTERACTIONS  MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS ARE DIRECTED TOWARDS MONITORING THE GRIZZLY BEAR POPULATION TREND THROUGH OBSERVATION FLIGHTS THAT DEFINE THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRIZZLY BEARS WITHIN BEAR MANAGEMENT UNITS  BMUS , DOCUMENT FEMALES WITH CUBS OF THE YEAR, AND DETAILED MONITORING OF RADIO COLLARED INDIVIDUALS TO ASSESS IMPORTANT MOVEMENT, SEASONAL HABITATUSE, FOOD SELECTION, AND SURVIVAL ESTIMATES THIS APPLICATION WILL PROVIDE THE RESOURCES NECESSARY TO 1  ASSIST THE INTERAGENCY GRIZZLY BEAR STUDY TEAM  IGBST  IN DETERMINING FOOD HABITS, HABITAT USE, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION TREND, ALLOWABLE MORTALITY THRESHOLDS, AND OTHER IMPORTANT PARAMETERS FOR GRIZZLY BEARS WITHIN THE SOUTHERN BMUS  2  PROVIDE COMPARATIVE DATA TO THAT ALREADY GATHERED BY THE IGBST, IDAHO, AND MONTANA  3  MANAGE BEAR HUMAN INTERACTION, BEAR LIVESTOCK INTERACTION AND MORTALITY DATA SPECIFIC FOR EACH BMU TO AIDSTATE AND FEDERAL MANAGERS IN MINIMIZING HUMAN CAUSED MORTALITIES AND GRIZZLY BEAR CONFLICTS  4  CONTINUE TO PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION AND EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS TO ASSIST WITH BEAR CONSERVATION AND SAFETY ISSUES, DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO HUNTERS AND OTHER PUBLICS ON BEAR SAFETY, SUPPORT A SECTION ON  HUNTING IN BEAR COUNTRY  IN STATEWIDE HUNTER EDUCATION EFFORTS, AND CONTINUE TO CONDUCT NUMEROUS WORKSHOPS ON HOW TO LIVE SAFELY IN AREAS OCCUPIED BY BEARS

THE SALAMANDER MUSSEL  SIMPSONAIAS AMBIGUA  IS IMPERILED THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE AND IS CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW BY U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS  FOR PROTECTION UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA   THE DISTRIBUTION AND RANGE OF THE SALAMANDER MUSSEL AND ITS GLOCHIDIAL HOST, THE MUDPUPPY  NECTURUS MACULOSUS , ARE LARGELY UNKNOWN IN IOWA  THIS PROPOSAL IS FOR TARGETED SURVEYS FOR BOTH SPECIES FOCUSED ON THE BEST AVAILABLE SUITABLE HABITAT IN NORTHEAST IOWA  THE STUDY WILL IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RANGE AND DISTRIBUTION FOR THE SALAMANDER MUSSEL AND ITS HOST PROVIDING BASELINE INFORMATION ESSENTIAL TO CONSERVATION PLANNING IN THE FUTURE

BY THE TIME TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT WAS LISTED AS STATE ENDANGERED IN WASHINGTON STATE IN 2006, IT WAS EXTIRPATEDFROM ALL BUT ONE OF AT LEAST 30 PUGET LOWLAND SITES  STINSON 2005 , WITH EIGHT SITES LOST IN 1998 2006  STINSON2005, WDFW, UNPUB  DATA   NATURAL RECOLONIZATION WAS PRECLUDED BY HABITAT LOSS AND ISOLATION OF THE ONLYREMAINING PUGET LOWLAND POPULATION ON JOINT BASE LEWIS MCCHORD, WHICH LED TO ITS FEDERAL LISTING AS ENDANGERED IN2013  CAPTIVE REARING FOLLOWED BY REINTRODUCTION TO RESTORED SITES HAS BEEN EFFECTIVE IN REVERSING THESE TRENDS,WITH TWO NEW POPULATIONS ESTABLISHED AND EXPANDING INTO SURROUNDING HABITAT AND TWO ADDITIONAL SITES UNDERGOINGREINTRODUCTION  AS A RESULT OF THESE ACTIONS THIS REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM HAS SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED THEEXTIRPATION RISK IN THIS REGION BY EXPANDING THE NUMBER OF POPULATIONS AND GROWING THEIR SIZE TO A POINT WHERENATURAL COLONIZATION OF NEARBY SITES IS OCCURRING  WE ARE PROPOSING TO CONTINUE THIS IMPORTANT WORK IN 2023 ANDARE HERE REQUESTING PARTIAL FUNDING TO SUPPORT CAPTIVE REARING AT MISSION CREEK CORRECTIONS CENTER FOR WOMENUNDER THE GUIDANCE OF THE EVERGREEN STATE COLLEGE SUSTAINABILITY IN PRISONS PROGRAM  IN ADDITION, FUNDING WOULDSUPPORT SUBSEQUENT RELEASE OF CATERPILLARS  LARVAE  TO RESTORED FIELD SITES, EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING, DATAPROCESSING AND ANALYSIS, AND ASSOCIATED MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES  THE NEED FOR AND BENEFITS OF REINTRODUCTION ARECRITICAL TO THE SPECIES RECOVERY IN MANY PARTS OF ITS RANGE  THESE ACTIONS ARE OCCURRING IN CONNECTION WITHCONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT INCLUDE LAND ACQUISITION, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MAINTENANCE, POPULATION MONITORING,SPECIES RESEARCH AND LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS  HOWEVER, THE SPECIES REMAINS VULNERABLE DUE TO EXTREME AND VARIABLEWEATHER EVENTS AND SHIFTING CLIMATE, WHICH IN TURN AFFECT THE AVAILABILITY OF IMPORTANT FOOD PLANTS

THIS PROJECT INITIATES THE MONITORING OF ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF BULL TROUT SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS IN A COASTAL TRIBUTARY AND CONTINUES MONITORING IN A TRIBUTARY OF THE UPPER COLUMBIA RIVER  THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO MONITOR BULL TROUT POPULATIONS THAT ARE LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND DOCUMENT CHANGES IN THEIR ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION SO WE CAN EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF LONG TERM RECOVERY EFFORTS

PROJECTS FUNDED THROUGH THE CONSERVATION GRANTS PROGRAM ENSURE ACCURATE LISTING OF PLANT AND INVERTEBRATE SPECIES AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED, DESIGNATING THEIR CRITICAL HABITATS, AND DEVELOPING RECOVERY PLANS  PROPOSED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE POPULATION SURVEYS AS WELL AS HABITAT EVALUATION AND MANAGEMENT FOR DETERMINING THE LISTING, DOWN LISTING OR DELISTING OF SPECIFIED SPECIES  FUNDING WILL BE USED TO CONDUCT SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY NEW POPULATIONS, ASSESS KNOWN POPULATIONS, EVALUATE HABITAT CONDITIONS, DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL, AND ENHANCE PREDICTIVE MODELS FOR LISTED, CANDIDATE AND AT RISK SPECIES  THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH SURVEYS OF KNOWN   AND THE IDENTIFICATION OF NEW   POPULATIONS, ASSESSING HABITAT CONDITIONS, REFINING SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS, AND EVALUTION OF POPULATION DYNAMICS AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS

THE PRAIRIES AND OAK WOODLANDS OF THE PUGET TROUGH AND WILLAMETTE VALLEY OF SOUTHERN BRITISH COLUMBIA, WESTERN WASHINGTON, AND NORTHWESTERN OREGON ARE AMONG THE RAREST ECOSYSTEMS IN NORTH AMERICA   ONLY REMNANT PATCHES OF PRAIRIE AND OAK WOODLANDS REMAIN DUE TO HABITAT DESTRUCTION  CONVERSION TO AGRICULTURE, URBAN AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT , INTRODUCED WEEDS, AND CHANGES IN FIRE MANAGEMENT, AND MOST OF THESE AREAS ARE ON PRIVATE LANDS WITH MINIMAL PROTECTION  OVER THE PAST 25 YEARS, THE CONSERVATION COMMUNITY HAS MADE SIGNIFICANT INVESTMENTS IN RESTORING PRAIRIE HABITAT, ESTABLISHING NEW POPULATIONS OF RARE SPECIES, AND EXPANDING THE NUMBER OF PROTECTED AREAS THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH LAND OWNERS, CONSERVATION TRUSTS, AND PARTNERSHIPS LIKE THE CASCADIA PRAIRIE OAK PARTNERSHIP  CPOP   MOST OF THIS ACTIVITY HAS CENTERED ON THE GEORGIA BASIN IN BRITISH COLUMBIA, SOUTH PUGET SOUND NEAR OLYMPIA, WASHINGTON, AND THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY IN OREGON  THE PRAIRIES AND OAK WOODLANDS OF SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON  PARTICULARLY CLARK, COWLITZ, AND LEWIS COUNTIES  HAVE RECEIVED SIGNIFICANTLY LESS CONSERVATION ATTENTION DESPITE PROVIDING HABITAT FOR SEVERAL LISTED PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES OR POTENTIAL CANDIDATE SPECIES FOR LISTING UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, MANY OF WHICH DO NOT OCCUR IN THE SOUTH PUGET SOUND AREA IN WASHINGTON  CONSIDERABLE OPPORTUNITIES EXIST TO PROMOTE AND INCENTIVIZE CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS IN THE PRAIRIE REGION OF SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS WITH GROUPS LIKE CPOP, THE NON PROFIT ECOSTUDIES INSTITUTE, THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM OF THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE, WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES  DNR , WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  DFW , WASHINGTON STATE PARKS, WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION, WASHINGTON FARMLAND TRUST, WASHINGTON ASSOCIATION OF LAND TRUSTS, AND OTHER LOCAL AGENCIES  BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS WILL HELP CONSERVE POPULATIONS OF RARE SPECIES THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON PRAIRIES

WHITEBARK PINE  PINUS ALBICAULIS  IS A 5 NEEDLED CONIFER FOUND IN ALPINE KRUMMHOLZ AND UPPER SUBALPINE FORESTS INMOUNTAIN RANGES FROM NORTHERN BRITISH COLUMBIA AND ALBERTA TO CENTRAL CALIFORNIA, NORTHERN NEVADA, CENTRAL IDAHO,AND NORTHWESTERN WYOMING  WHITEBARK PINE IS REGARDED AS A KEYSTONE SPECIES BECAUSE OF ITS SIGNIFICANCE INPROVIDING COVER, SHELTER, AND FOOD FOR WILDLIFE  INCLUDING GRIZZLY BEARS  URSUS ARCTOS HORRIBILIS  AND CLARK SNUTCRACKERS  NUCIFRAGA COLUMBIANA   AND FOR RETAINING SOIL AND SNOW  OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, WHITEBARK PINE HASDECREASED BY MORE THAN 50  ACROSS ITS RANGE DUE TO MORTALITY FROM INTRODUCED WHITE PINE BLISTER RUST  CRONARTIUMRIBICOLA , INFESTATIONS OF MOUNTAIN PINE BEETLES  DENDROCTONUS PONDEROSAE , INCREASED WILDFIRE, AND IMPACTS FROMCLIMATE CHANGE  IN 2020, THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  FORMALLY PROPOSED LISTING WHITEBARK PINE ASTHREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA   A FINAL LISTING DECISION IS EXPECTED IN SUMMER 2022 IN 2018, USFWS CONTRACTED WITH THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  WNHP  TO ASSESS THE CONSERVATION STATUSOF WHITEBARK PINE IN WASHINGTON  WHITEBARK PINE WAS DETERMINED TO HAVE A S3  VULNERABLE  STATE CONSERVATIONSTATUS RANK IN WASHINGTON AND ADDED IT TO THE STATE SENSITIVE PLANT SPECIES LIST  WNHP ALSO IDENTIFIED TENPOTENTIAL ELEMENT OCCURRENCES  EOS  RANGING IN SIZE FROM 11,000 TO 2 1 MILLION ACRES  THESE EOS WERE DERIVEDUSING RANDOM FOREST MODELING WITH AN INPUT DATASET OF OVER 16,000 PRESENCE AND ABSENCE PLOTS OF WHITEBARK PINEAND 32 ENVIRONMENTAL PREDICTOR VARIABLES RELATING TO GEOLOGY, SOILS, VEGETATION COVER, TOPOGRAPHY, ELEVATION,PRECIPITATION, AND TEMPERATURE  INDIVIDUAL OCCURRENCES WERE CREATED BY INTERSECTING KNOWN PRESENCE POINTS OFWHITEBARK PINE WITH THE MODEL AND THEN USING A 5 KM SEPARATION DISTANCE  BASED ON FORAGING PATTERNS OF CLARK SNUTCRACKERS, ITS PRIMARY SEED VECTOR  TO DIFFERENTIATE OCCURRENCES  TO DATE, FORMAL EOS HAVE NOT BEEN ENTEREDINTO THE WNHP BIOTICS DATABASE WHERE LOCATION RECORDS FOR OTHER LISTED AND RARE SPECIES AND COMMUNITY ELEMENTSARE ARCHIVED  EOS ARE THE COMMON CURRENCY OF DATA STORAGE AND DISSEMINATION BY WNHP, SO THE ABSENCE OF WHITEBARKPINE EOS IMPACTS WNHP S ABILITY TO USE THESE DATA IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER DATA LAYERS IN BIOTICS FORCONSERVATION PLANNING OR CONSULTATION  THE TEN POTENTIAL EOS FROM THE MODELING STUDY ARE ALSO SIGNIFICANTLYLARGER AND COARSER THAN OTHER EOS IN THE WNHP DATABASE THIS PROJECT WILL REFINE THE WHITEBARK PINE MODEL PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED BY WNHP TO EXCLUDE AREAS OF UNLIKELYHABITAT BASED ON LOCAL TERRAIN FEATURES VEGETATION AND DEVELOPING MORE ACCURATE ELEMENT OCCURRENCE RECORDS WILLIMPROVE THE VALUE OF EO RECORDS AND MAKE IT EASIER TO PROCESS AND STORE THESE DATA IN BIOTICS AND OTHER WNHPDATABASE PRODUCTS  IMPROVING THE MODELS AND EOS WILL INCREASE THE ACCURACY OF THE LOCATION DATA AND MAKE THEMMORE USEFUL FOR ANSWERING MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS AND RESOLVING POTENTIAL CONFLICTS IN SEC 7 CONSULTATION THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE IMPROVED DATA ON THE DISTRIBUTION AND NUMBER OF ELEMENT OCCURRENCESOF WHITEBARK PINE IN WASHINGTON, WHICH WILL BENEFIT USFWS IN ASSESSING THREATS IN THE SEC 7 CONSULTATION PROCESSAND PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION FOR FUTURE SPECIES ASSESSMENTS

GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH  CASTILLEJA LEVISECTA  IS A YELLOW FLOWERED PERENNIAL HERB THAT IS RESTRICTED TO REMNANT PRAIRIE SITES IN THE SAN JUAN ISLANDS, PUGET TROUGH, AND WILLAMETTE VALLEY IN BRITISH COLUMBIA, WASHINGTON, AND OREGON  THE SPECIES WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  IN 1997  DURING THE PAST 25 YEARS, THE ABUNDANCE AND NUMBER OF POPULATIONS HAS INCREASED SIGNIFICANTLY DUE TO AN ACTIVE REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM, COORDINATED BY USFWS AND PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS IN STATE GOVERNMENT AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR  ANNUAL MONITORING HAS TAKEN PLACE AT MOST NATIVE AND INTRODUCED OCCURRENCES SINCE THE MID 1990S  MONITORING DATA ARE CRITICAL FOR ESTIMATING POPULATION NUMBERS, TREND, AND WHETHER RECOVERY OBJECTIVES ARE BEING REACHED  BASED ON MONITORING DATA AND OTHER TARGETS IN THE 2007 FIVE YEAR REVIEW  USFWS 2007 , THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  PROPOSED DELISTING GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH IN JUNE 2021  IF THE SPECIES IS DELISTED, YEAR ONE OF POST DELISTING MONITORING WILL BEGIN IN 2023  WITH SUBSEQUENT MONITORING IN 2025 AND 2027   POST DELISTING MONITORING IS REQUIRED UNDER THE ESA TO ENSURE THE SPECIES REMAINS SECURE FROM THE RISK OF EXTINCTION AND DOES NOT REQUIRE BEING RESTORED TO THE ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST  FUNDING IS REQUESTED FOR YEAR ONE OF POST DE LISTING MONITORING FOR 2023  OR IF THE SPECIES IS NOT DE LISTED, TO CONTINUE YEARLY MONITORING EFFORTS TO TRACK PROGRESS TOWARDS RECOVERY

WASHINGTON STATE CURRENTLY HAS 10 LISTED THREATENED OR ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES AND ONE PROPOSED THREATENEDSPECIES UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  EACH YEAR NEW INFORMATION IS DERIVED FROM ONGOING MONITORING STUDIES,FIELD SURVEYS, AND OTHER RESEARCH ON THE LIFE HISTORY OR MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF THESE SPECIES  LIFE HISTORY,STATUS, AND LOCALITY DATA FOR LISTED SPECIES ARE MAINTAINED IN THE WNHP ELEMENT OCCURRENCE DATABASE  BIOTICS , ANINTERACTIVE GIS MAP VIEWER DEVELOPED SPECIFICALLY FOR USFWS, THE ONLINE RARE PLANT FIELD GUIDE, AND OTHEROBSERVATION DATABASES  THIS PROJECT IS NEEDED TO INCORPORATE NEW DATA INTO THESE VARIOUS DATABASE, ENSURING USEOF WNHP S DATA PRODUCTS ARE BASED ON BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE  BESIDES SERVING USFWS STAFF, THESE DATABASES ANDPRODUCTS PROVIDE IMPORTANT RARE SPECIES DATA FOR OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES  SUCH ASTHE US FOREST SERVICE, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, WA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, WA DEPARTMENT OF NATURALRESOURCES  AND THE PUBLIC  WNHP ALSO PROVIDES USFWS AND OTHER AGENCIES EXPERTISE ON BOTANICAL MATTERS, INCLUDINGPARTICIPATION IN SPECIES TECHNICAL COMMITTEES, ANSWERING DATA REQUESTS, AND COMPILING ANNUAL OR BIENNIAL REPORTSSUMMARIZING THE STATUS OF LISTED SPECIES AND PLANT, LICHEN, AND BRYOPHYTE SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN INWASHINGTON  FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO CONTINUE ONGOING MONITORING, SURVEY, DATA ENTRY AND SYNTHESIS, ANDCONSULTING SERVICES MENTIONED ABOVE FOR A TWO YEAR PERIOD FROM 2023 2025

WATER HOWELLIA  HOWELLIA AQUATILIS  IS AN AQUATIC ANNUAL HERB FOUND IN SHALLOW PONDS THAT ARE SEASONALLY FLOODED IN SPRING BUT BECOME DRY IN LATE SUMMER AND FALL  IT OCCURS SPORADICALLY FROM WESTERN WASHINGTON TO NORTHWESTERN MONTANA AND SOUTH TO NORTHERN CALIFORNIA  THE SPECIES WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  IN 1994, BUT DELISTED IN JULY 2021 DUE TO THE DISCOVERY OF ADDITIONAL OCCURRENCES, REDUCED THREATS, AND INCREASED LOCAL PROTECTION ACROSS ITS RANGE  AS PART OF THE DELISTING DECISION, THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  DEVELOPED A POST DELISTING MONITORING PLAN TO MEASURE CHANGES IN POPULATION TRENDS AND HABITAT CONDITION OVER TIME   POST DELISTING MONITORING IS REQUIRED UNDER THE ESA TO ENSURE THE SPECIES REMAINS SECURE FROM THE RISK OF EXTINCTION AND DOES NOT REQUIRE BEING RESTORED TO THE ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST  USFWS 2017   DE LISTING MONITORING WILL BEGIN IN 2022  YEAR 1 AFTER DELISTING  AND CONTINUE IN YEARS 2  2023 , 7 AND 8, AND 14 AND 15  AFTER DE LISTING   THIRTY OCCURRENCES HAVE BEEN SELECTED FOR POST DELISTING MONITORING BY USFWS AND THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  FUNDING IS REQUESTED FOR YEAR TWO OF POST DE LISTING MONITORING IN 2023  EXISTING FUNDS WILL COVER YEAR ONE

CLIMATE CHANGE HAS EMERGED AS ONE OF THE PRIMARY THREATS TO THE LONG TERM PERSISTENCE OF MANY RARE PLANT SPECIES  SPECIES VARY IN THEIR VULNERABILITY TO CLIMATE CHANGE, DEPENDING ON THEIR DEPENDENCE ON SNOWPACK, PREDICTABLE PRECIPITATION, STABLE TEMPERATURES, UNUSUAL GEOLOGIC SUBSTRATES, SPECIALIZED POLLINATORS, ADEQUATE GENETIC DIVERSITY, DISPERSAL ABILITY, OR OTHER FACTORS  NATURESERVE, THE UMBRELLA NETWORK OF STATE AND PROVINCIAL NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAMS, HAS DEVELOPED THE CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX  CCVI  TOOL TO ASSESS RISK FROM CLIMATE CHANGE FOR PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES BASED ON 29 CLIMATIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES  THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  WNHP  HAS RECEIVED FUNDING FROM US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  UWFWS , BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM , AND US FOREST SERVICE  USFS  TO APPLY THE CCVI PROTOCOL TO FEDERALLY THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND SENSITIVE PLANT SPECIES  OF THE 371 VASCULAR PLANT TAXA TRACKED BY WNHP AS SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN, CCVIS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED FOR 107  FERTIG 2022   TWELVE OF 37 SPECIES RATED EXTREMELY OR HIGHLY VULNERABLE ARE EITHER LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  OR ARE USFWS SPECIES OF CONCERN IDENTIFIED BY FERTIG  2020  AS POTENTIAL CANDIDATES FOR LISTING BASED ON THEIR HERITAGE RANKS OF G1 TO G3 OR T1 TO T3 ONGOING BLM, USFS, AND USFWS GRANTS WILL FUND CCVI WORK FOR APPROXIMATELY 50 ADDITIONAL PLANT SPECIES, INCLUDING ALL REMAINING USFWS TAXA LISTED OR PROPOSED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  AN ADDITIONAL 40 HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES IDENTIFIED BY FERTIG  2020  AS USFWS SPECIES OF CONCERN WILL NOT BE COVERED BY EXISTING FUNDING SOURCES  AS SUCH, FUNDING IS REQUESTED FOR 2 YEARS TO COMPLETE CCVI ASSESSMENTS FOR 20 OF THESE SPECIES, WITH THE OTHER 20 TO BE COMPLETED CONTINGENT ON ADDITIONAL FUNDING

WHITE BLUFFS BLADDERPOD  PHYSARIA DOUGLASII SSP  TUPLASHENSIS  WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  ESA  IN 2013  ANNUAL MONITORING STUDIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED AT A SERIES OF TRANSECTS NEAR THE NORTH END OF THE POPULATION SINCE 1997 TO EXTRAPOLATE OVERALL ABUNDANCE AND DOCUMENT POPULATION TRENDS  IN 2020 THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  PROVIDED FUNDING TO THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM  WNHP  TO IDENTIFY ADDITIONAL AREAS IN THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF THE WHITE BLUFFS TO ESTABLISH MORE MONITORING TRANSECTS TO BETTER ESTIMATE TOTAL NUMBERS FOR THE ENTIRE POPULATION  FERTIG 2021   ANNUAL MONITORING DATA HAVE DOCUMENTED OSCILLATIONS IN THE NUMBERS OF FLOWERING OR FRUITING PLANTS THAT MAY CORRELATE WITH WINTER OR SPRING PRECIPITATION PATTERNS  USFWS 2020   THE LIFE HISTORY OF THE SPECIES IS STILL INCOMPLETELY KNOWN, HOWEVER, ESPECIALLY SURVIVORSHIP RATES BETWEEN KEY LIFE STAGES  SUCH AS THE TRANSITION BETWEEN SEEDLINGS AND MATURE PLANTS , THE LONGEVITY OF PLANTS, AND HOW FREQUENTLY INDIVIDUALS REPRODUCE DURING THEIR LIFE TIME  UNDERSTANDING THESE LIFE HISTORY PATTERNS REQUIRES ADDITIONAL LONG TERM DEMOGRAPHIC PLOTS IN WHICH INDIVIDUAL PLANTS ARE TAGGED AND MONITORED FOR 5 10 YEARS  DATA FROM DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING WILL HELP DETERMINE THE LONG TERM VIABILITY OF THE POPULATION AND AID IN THE MANAGEMENT OF NEW OUT PLANTINGS NEEDED TO MEET RECOVERY OBJECTIVES  FUNDING IS REQUESTED FOR 2 YEARS TO ESTABLISH DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING PLOTS FOR WHITE BLUFFS BLADDERPOD AND COLLECT INITIAL DATA TO BUILD A LIFE HISTORY MODEL AND CONDUCT A PRELIMINARY POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSIS  PVA

THE WESTERN YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO  COCCYZUS AMERICANUS  IS A NEOTROPICAL MIGRANT THAT WINTERS IN SOUTH AMERICA AND BREEDS IN RIPARIAN WOODLANDS IN WESTERN NORTH AMERICA  THE CUCKOO HAS DECLINED FROM MUCH OF ITS HISTORIC RANGE IN THE WESTERN U S , AND THESE DECLINES HAVE BEEN LINKED TO PESTICIDE USE, LOSS OF RIPARIAN HABITAT IN NESTING AREAS AS A CONSEQUENCE OF FRAGMENTATION, INUNDATION BY RESERVOIRS, STREAM CHANNELIZATION, AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT  IN OCTOBER 2014 THE WESTERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF THE YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO WAS DESIGNATED THREATENED UNDER THE ESA  79 FR 59992 , WHICH WAS REAFFIRMED IN SEPTEMBER 2020  85 FR 57817   THE HISTORICAL AND RECENT STATUS OF THE YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO IN NEVADA IS POORLY UNDERSTOOD  E G , HABITAT REQUIREMENTS, POPULATION SIZE, POPULATION TREND, AND BREEDING STATUS , WITH FEW CONFIRMED NESTING ATTEMPTS CONFIRMED  THIS SPECIES IS ELUSIVE, SECRETIVE, AND OFTEN EXHIBITS ERUPTIVE BREEDING BEHAVIOR, ALL OF WHICH MAKE IT DIFFICULT TO DETECT, DOCUMENT NESTING ACTIVITY, OR ACCURATELY ESTIMATE THE TREND OF CUCKOO OCCURRENCE AND BREEDING IN NEVADA  NONETHELESS, AVAILABLE DATA DOES SUGGEST A GENERAL DECLINE COMPARED TO HISTORICAL OBSERVATIONS  NDOW IS WORKING TOWARDS IMPLEMENTING VARIOUS GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND ACTIONS RELATING TO THE YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO, A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION PRIORITY, AS DESCRIBED IN THE NEVADA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  2012  AND THE NEVADA COMPREHENSIVE BIRD CONSERVATION PLAN A MULTI STATE COMPETITIVE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT  WESTERN YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO RANGE WIDE OCCUPANCY ASSESSMENT  CSWG  WAS AWARDED IN 2021 TO MANY OF THE WESTERN STATES CONTAINING THE WESTERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT  DPS  OF YELLOW BILLED CUCKOOS WEST OF THE CONTINENTAL DIVIDE, PROVIDING FUNDING FOR STANDARDIZED WEST WIDE THE HOUSTON TOAD  ANAXYRUS HOUSTONESIS  IS A FEDERAL AND STATE LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES AND A HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN   G1 S1  IN THE TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN  2012   THE SPECIES IS ENDEMIC TO 9 COUNTIES IN THE XERIC, SANDY LOST PINES AND POST OAK SAVANNAH ECOREGIONS OF EASTERN CENTRAL TEXAS  FORSTNER AND DIXON, 2010   RANGE WIDE MONITORING SUGGESTS IT IS AT HISTORICALLY LOW OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE LEVELS  THE MAIN THREAT FACING THIS SPECIES IS THE LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF PINE OAK SAVANNA ECOSYSTEMS  MUCH OF THE POST OAK SAVANNA HAS BEEN CONVERTED TO NON NATIVE PASTURES FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION  HOWEVER, WITHOUT ACTIVE PROCESSES SUCH AS FIRE, EVEN THE REMAINING PINE OAK SAVANNAS RAPIDLY TRANSITION  WITHIN 10 15 YEARS  FROM AN OPEN UNDERSTORY WITH A DIVERSE GROUND COVER LAYER OF WARM SEASON BUNCH GRASSES AND FORBS TO AN UNDERSTORY INFESTED WITH WOODY BRUSH  THESE DEGRADED SAVANNAS ARE DETRIMENTAL FOR BOTH HUMAN AND WILDLIFE USE, DUE TO EXCESSIVE WOODY FUEL FOR WILDFIRES AND REDUCED HERBACEOUS PRODUCTIVITY, RESULTING IN A STATE SHIFT TO A MORE MESIC UNDERSTORY WITH LITTLE LIGHT REACHING THE SAVANNA FLOOR  SPARKS ET AL , 2012   FORTUNATELY, WE HAVE THE TOOLS IN PLACE TO RESTORE THESE DEGRADED SAVANNAS  SELECTIVELY REMOVING THE UNDERSTORY BRUSH LAYER USING A FORESTRY MULCHER, ALLOWING SUNLIGHT TO PENETRATE TO THE FLOOR AND FOLLOWING UP WITH HERBICIDE AND PRESCRIBED FIRE HAS BEEN DEMONSTRATED TO HAVE POSITIVE IMPACTS ON THE STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION OF SAVANNA ECOSYSTEMS  MITCHELL ET AL , 2005  MCINNERNEY ET AL , 2020   HERE WE PROPOSE TO IMPLEMENT THESE RESTORATION TOOLS AT THE CEDAR HILL RANCH IN MILAM COUNTY TO DIRECTLY IMPROVE 140 ACRES OF HABITAT FOR THE HOUSTON TOAD  THIS SITE IS PROPOSED AS A FUTURE REINTRODUCTION SITE FOR THE SPECIES  WHILE THE FOCAL SPECIES OF THIS PROJECT IS THE HOUSTON TOAD, NUMEROUS OTHER SGCN BIRD AND PLANT SPECIES THAT RELY ON OPEN PINE OAK SAVANNA HABITATS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS RESTORATION WORK, SUCH AS NORTHERN BOBWHITE QUAIL  COLINUS VIRGINIANUS  AND CENTERVILLE BRAZOS MINT  BRAZORIA TRUNCATA VAR  PULCHERRIMA

SNOWY PLOVERS ARE A LOCAL SHOREBIRD WHOSE YOUNGSTERS LOOK LIKE CUTE LITTLE FUZZBALLS WITH Q TIPS FOR LEGS  INWASHINGTON STATE, THESE BIRDS ARE LOCAL TO JUST PACIFIC AND GRAYS HARBOR COUNTIES BUT, ARE RARE AND IMPERILED ONLY AROUND 100 OF THESE BIRDS STILL SURVIVE  THEY PRIMARILY LIVE AT THREE SMALL BEACH LOCATIONS ON THESOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON COAST  THEY ARE AN ENDANGERED SPECIES IN WASHINGTON AND THREATENED THROUGHOUT THEIRRANGE THE ADULT PLOVERS ARE HARDY AND DURABLE ENOUGH TO SURVIVE THE ENTIRE YEAR LIVING EXPOSED ON THE BEACH  THOSEADULT SNOWY PLOVERS ARE DEVOTED PARENTS  HOWEVER, PEOPLE CAN UNKNOWINGLY HARM THE CHANCES FOR SNOWY PLOVERS TORAISE A FAMILY  THEIR ABILITY TO PRODUCE YOUNG IS IMPACTED BY HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND PREDATION THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO TAKE ACTIONS THAT PROTECT SNOWY PLOVERS AND INCREASE THEIR ABILITY TO SUCCESSFULLYRAISE YOUNG  THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  WDFW  WILL WORK TO PREVENT DISTURBANCE TO NESTINGPLOVERS BY PEOPLE AND, REDUCE THE LOSS OF NESTS TO PREDATORS  WILL WILL PROTECT NESTING PLOVERS THROUGH  POSTINGNO TRESPASS SIGNS AND FENCES AROUND CRITICAL NESTING SITES, CONDUCTING IN PERSON PATROLS, AND EDUCATINGBEACHGOERS THROUGH RADIO TV PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS FINALLY, WDFW WILL FORMALLY SURVEY AND MONITOR SNOWY PLOVERS TO ACCURATELY COUNT THE NUMBERS CURRENTLY LIVING INWASHINGTON STATE  THROUGH OUR CONTINUED EFFORTS, THE NUMBERS OF SNOWY PLOVERS IN WASHINGTON HAVE STEADILYINCREASED SINCE 2011  BY OBTAINING ACCURATE COUNTS, WE CAN ASSESS WHETHER SNOWY PLOVERS HAVE CHANGED FORM THEIRSTATUS AS AND ENDANGERED SPECIES IN WASHINGTON

IN 1992, THE MARBLED MURRELET WAS LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973 AS A THREATENED SPECIESIN CALIFORNIA, OREGON AND WASHINGTON  A RECOVERY PLAN WAS PUBLISHED THAT OUTLINED RECOVERY STRATEGIES INCLUDINGDEVELOPING AND CONDUCTING STANDARDIZED AT SEA SURVEYS  U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 1997   THESE SURVEYS WEREVIEWED AS IMPORTANT BECAUSE THEY ALLOW RESEARCHERS TO MODEL POPULATION TRENDS AND BECAUSE DETECTING CHANGES INPOPULATIONS ARE CRITICAL TO EVALUATING THE OUTCOME OF RECOVERY ACTIONS AND ULTIMATELY FOR DETERMINING RECOVERYSUCCESS OR FAILURE  IN ADDITION, WHEN DEVELOPING THE NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN, IT WAS DECIDED THAT AT SEA MURRELETSWERE TO BE USED TO ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE PLAN  IN RESPONSE TO THIS RECOVERY GOAL AND THE NEEDS OF THEFOREST PLAN, THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U S  FOREST SERVICE AND STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES INITIATED AMARBLED MURRELET MONITORING STRATEGY IN 2000  RAPHAEL ET AL  1999, 2004, 2007  MILLER ET AL  2006   THE GOAL OFTHIS MONITORING STRATEGY IS TO ESTIMATE MARBLED MURRELET POPULATION SIZE AND TO DETECT CHANGES IN POPULATION SIZEFOR THE AREA BETWEEN SAN FRANCISCO AND THE WASHINGTON   CANADA BORDER  SINCE 2000, WDFW HAS BEEN SURVEYING BOTHTHE SALISH SEA  ZONE 1  AND COASTAL WASHINGTON  ZONE 2  USING AT SEA LINE TRANSECTS  FOR THESE SURVEYS, FOURWDFW WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS CONDUCT THE SURVEYS  MID MAY   END OF JULY 2023  IN ZONE 2 AND ARE SUPERVISED BY SCOTTPEARSON AND MONIQUE LANCE  DATA FROM THESE SURVEYS IS USED TO EVALUATE MURRELET POPULATION TRENDS AND PROVIDESINFORMATION ON DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE  THE SERVICE USES THESE RESULTS TO EVALUATE ANY USFWS INCIDENTAL TAKECRITERIA, TO ASSESS RECOVERY PROGRESS, AND TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS  WE ARE ALSOUSING THIS INFORMATION IN A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON IDENTIFY IMPORTANTHABITATS FOR MURRELETS  AND OTHER SPECIES  AND TO IDENTIFY THE FACTORS DRIVING POPULATION DECLINES  THESE ARECRITICAL STEPS NEEDED TO MOVE CONSERVATION FORWARD  BECAUSE WE RECORD ALL BIRDS AND MAMMALS DETECTED DURINGTHESE SURVEYS, THIS EFFORT PROVIDES ONE OF THE ONLY LARGE SCALE DATASETS AVAILABLE TO ASSESS CHANGES IN MARINEBIRD AND MAMMAL POPULATIONS IN WASHINGTON S MARINE WATERS  A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING THE RESULTS IS PRODUCED INNOVEMBER FOLLOWING THE SURVEYS  BECAUSE THESE FUNDS ARRIVE IN JUNE OR LATER, IT IS IMPORTANT TO OBLIGATE THESEFUNDS IN THIS ROUND OF FUNDING BECAUSE THE WASHINGTON COAST FIELD SEASON BEGINS IN MAY OF 2023

THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER HAS BEEN A SPECIES OF CONCERN IN OREGON FOR OVER THREE DECADES AND WAS STATE LISTED IN 1989 UNDER THE OREGON ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  THE SPECIES WAS SUBSEQUENTLY LISTED ALONG THE PACIFIC COAST BY THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  IN 1993 AND A DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN WAS DEVELOPED AND FINALIZED IN 2007  USFWS 2007   THE LIMITING FACTORS ON THE COASTAL POPULATION IN OREGON INCLUDE CHANGES AND LOSS OF HABITAT, INCREASED HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND DISTURBANCE, INCREASED PREDATION DUE TO HUMAN CAUSED CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT, AND INSUFFICIENT KNOWLEDGE ON THE STATUS AND ECOLOGY OF THE SPECIES STATE MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY ACTIONS HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN SINCE THE LATE 1970S, INITIALLY ORIENTED TOWARD REDUCING RECREATIONAL IMPACTS ON AREAS USES BY PLOVERS  SINCE 1990, RECOVERY EFFORTS HAVE BEEN EXTENDED TO NEST AND BROOD PROTECTION, EXTENSIVE HABITAT RESTORATION, DIRECTED PREDATOR MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION AS OUTLINED IN THE USFWS RECOVERY PLAN  IN OCTOBER 2007, THE OREGON PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT  OPRD  COMPLETED A REVISED HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN AND EIS TO OBTAIN AN INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMIT FOR THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER ON COASTAL BEACHES  ICF INTERNATIONAL 2010   THE INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMIT  2010  ALLOWS SOME LEVEL OF TAKE  HARM  IN EXCHANGE FOR MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MONITOR AND PROTECT BREEDING PLOVERS ON LANDS MANAGED BY OPRD  OREGON WORKS CLOSELY WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANAGEMENT AGENCIES IN WASHINGTON AS PART OF THE SAME RECOVERY UNIT UNDER THE FEDERAL RECOVERY PLAN  WDFW 2008   SNOWY PLOVERS BANDED IN OREGON ARE NOW FOUND ON WASHINGTON BEACHES IN GREATER NUMBERS THE POPULATION DECLINE OF THE 70 S AND 80 S HAS BEEN REVERSED  IN 2021 WE ESTIMATED THE RESIDENT NUMBER OF SNOWY PLOVERS ON THE OREGON COAST WAS 604 INDIVIDUALS, AN INCREASE FROM THE 2020 SEASON AND WAS THE HIGHEST NUMBER SINCE MONITORING BEGAN IN 1990  SEVEN HUNDRED AND TWELVE NESTS WERE MONITORED IN 2021  OVERALL APPARENT NEST SUCCESS WAS 27 , LOWER THAN IN MOST PREVIOUS YEARS  NEST FAILURES WERE ATTRIBUTED TO DEPREDATION  UNKNOWN AVIAN DEPREDATION, CORVID DEPREDATION, MAMMALIAN DEPREDATION, HARRIER DEPREDATION  ABANDONMENT, ONE EGG NEST, GULL DEPREDATION, WIND WEATHER, OVER WASHING, AND INFERTILITY  WE SAMPLED 140 OF 217 KNOWN BROODS THAT PRODUCED 162 FLEDGLINGS AND ESTIMATED 250 TOTAL FLEDGLINGS  OVERALL BROOD SUCCESS WAS 75 , FLEDGING SUCCESS WAS 44 , AND BASED ON THE OVERALL NUMBER OF RESIDENT MALES, 0 62 CHICKS FLEDGED PER RESIDENT MALE  1 16 CHICKS FLEDGED PER SAMPLED BROODFIELD OBJECTIVES FOR THE 2023 PROJECT WILL INCLUDE   CONDUCT SURVEYS AT ALL CORE PLOVER SITES TO COUNT ADULTS PRESENT DURING THE BREEDING SEASON  LOCATE AS MANY NESTS AS POSSIBLE DURING THE BREEDING SEASON  DOCUMENT NEST LOCATIONS WITH GPS  ERECT PROTECTIVE NEST EXCLOSURES, WHEN APPROPRIATE, AND AS ALLOWED BY USFWS RECOVERY PERMIT  DEPLOY NEST CAMERAS AS APPROPRIATE AND AS ALLOWED BY USFWS RECOVERY PERMIT  DETERMINE FATE OF ALL KNOWN NESTS  DOCUMENT PREDATION AND OTHER CAUSES OF NEST AND BROOD FAILURE  BAND BROODS AT UP TO 80  OF THE KNOWN NESTS, AND UNBANDED ADULTS ASSOCIATED WITH THESE NESTS  MONITOR BANDED BROODS TO DETERMINE FLEDGING SUCCESS  RECORD HUMAN RELATED DISTURBANCE AT NESTING SITES

WILL WRITE FOR A SERIES OF TOP PRIORITY MCFARLANES FOUR OCLOCK POPULATIONS  THE DEVELOPMENT OF HMPS IS NOT ONLY A CRITERION FOR ADMINISTRATIVE RECOVERY BUT IS CRITICAL FOR GUIDING THE ONGOING PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF MCFARLANES FOUR OCLOCK POPULATIONS COOKS LOMATIUM  LOMATIUM COOKII  IS A FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PLANT ASSOCIATED WITH RARE VERNAL POOL HABITATS IN SOUTHWEST OREGON  IN 2021, AND INSTITUTIONS TO PRESENT A COMPREHENSIVE VIEW OF THE SPECIES STATUS  ADDITIONAL OCCURRENCES HAVE NOT BEEN SURVEYED IN 10 20  YEARS, WITH SOME REPORTING THOUSANDS OF COOKS LOMATIUM PLANTS IN THEIR MOST RECENT SURVEY, AND MANY WITH A FEW HUNDRED OR LESS  WE WILL HELP BOOST RECOVERY OF THIS SPECIES BY  1  SURVEYING THE COOKS LOMATIUM AT THOSE SITES NOT EVALUATED IN 2021, 2  IDENTIFICATION OF PRIORITY SITES FOR FUTURE RECOVERY ACTION, AND 3  CONTRIBUTING TOWARD THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SEED INCREASE PROGRAM TO GENERATE A LARGE VOLUME OF SEED OFF SITE  BY COLLECTING SEED FROM NATURAL POPULATIONS, ODA CAN PROVIDE THE INITIAL SOURCE SEED REQUIRED FOR SUCH A LARGE SCALE SEED PRODUCTION THAT CAN BE USED TO INCREASE POPULATION NUMBERS AT PRIORITY SITES THE THREATENED GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE NATIVE PLANT CONSERVATION PROGRAM  ODA  WILL PARTNER WITH A LOCAL SPECIALISTS TO MONITOR GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH POPULATIONS ACCORDING TO THE ESTABLISHED POPULATION CENSUS METHOD
