STATUS

THE STUDY WILL OBTAIN ANNUAL ADULT ESTIMATES FOR OREGON POPULATIONS OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY  EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA TAYLORI  IN 2023   FOR EACH OF TWO POPULATIONS, REPEATED ADULT COUNTS WILL OCCUR ALONG PERMANENT TRANSECTS AT INTERVALS THROUGHOUT THE FLIGHT SEASON TO OBTAIN ABUNDANCE DATA FOR THAT YEAR  THREATS TO THE BUTTERFLY AND IT S HABITATS WILL BE NOTED TO INFORM SITE MANAGERS OF RESTORATION PRIORITIES THIS ANNUAL COUNT AND THREAT ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY HAS BEEN USED FOR ROUGHLY TWO DECADES  SUCH CONSISTENCY NOT ONLY ALLOWS FOR MEANINGFUL CONSECUTIVE YEAR COMPARISONS OF ABUNDANCE, BUT ALSO REVEALS LONG TERM TRENDS IN POPULATION GROWTH DECLINE AND RESILIENCE IN RESPONSE TO NATURAL  WEATHER, DISEASE, PREDATION  AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS  HABITAT RESTORATION

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE KEY HABITAT FOR THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY ON THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION S BIG CREEK PROPOERTY ON THE CENTRAL OREGON COAST  THE HABITAT UNDER RESTORATION IS CURRENTLY OCCUPIED BY THE SPECIES, AND PAST RESTORATION ACTIONS HAVE BEEN EFFECTIVE IN INCREASING THE QUALITY OF BOTH LARVAL HABITAT AND ADULT NECTARING HABITAT FOR THE SPECIES  THE HABITAT HAS BEEN INCREASINGLY UTILIZED BY EGG LAYING FEMALES RELATIVE TO SURROUNDING UNMANAGED HABITATS  WITHOUT ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THESE MEADOWS, INVASIVE SPECIES INVASION AND SUCCESSION TO SHRUBLAND AND FOREST HABITATS WILL ELIMINATE THE LITTLE REMAINING HABITAT THAT IS LEFT IN THE VICINITY  HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS INCLUDE  1  VEGETATION MANAGEMENT TO ENHANCE AND EXPAND EARLY SUCCESSIONAL EARLY BLUE VIOLET AREAS  2  MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND COMPETING WOODY VEGETATION TO ALLOW FOR PERSISTENCE OF DESIRABLE VEGETATION  3  MONITORING HABITAT QUALITY AND TREATMENT EFFECTIVENESS  AND 4 PRODUCTION OF ESSENTIAL NATIVE SEED AND PLANTS FOR USE IN RESTORATION

THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY  SPEYERIA ZERENE HIPPOLYTA  IS LISTED AS THREATENED, AND THE CASCADE HEAD, BRAY PT  AND ROCK CREEK POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED GREATLY IN RECENT YEARS AS HAVE ALL THE KNOWN POPULATIONS ON THE OREGON COAST  THE HABITAT AT CASCADE HEAD, BRAY PT , ROCK CREEK, AND OTHER COASTAL SITES CONTINUES TO SUFFER FROM COMPETITION WITH EXOTIC GRASSES AND OTHER VEGETATION  VARIOUS TECHNIQUES ARE BEING IMPLEMENTED TO RESTORE HABITAT, THESE INCLUDE CUTTING AND REMOVAL OF BOTH NATIVE AND NON NATIVE INVADING VEGETATION, SOLARIZATION, PLOWING, REPLANTING AND SEEDING  HOWEVER, RESTORATION PROCEEDS SLOWLY AND SOME OF THESE ACTIONS CAN NEGATIVELY IMPACT RESIDENT BUTTERFLIES  CAPTIVE REARING IS ALLOWING POPULATIONS TO BE MAINTAINED WHILE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY AT CASCADE HEAD, BRAY PT  AND ROCK CREEK  CAPTIVE BRED OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLIES CAN BE USED TO ENHANCE THE EXISTING POPULATIONS, PREVENT LOCAL EXTINCTION AND PRESERVE GENETIC DIVERSITY  ADDITIONALLY, BEHAVIORAL RESEARCH CONDUCTED ON BUTTERFLIES PRIOR TO RELEASE HAS HELPED GUIDE SOME ASPECTS OF RESTORATION  E G  INTERPLANT DISTANCES   CAPTIVE REARING EFFORTS ARE THEREFORE AN ESSENTIAL PART OF THE POPULATION RECOVERY PLAN

THIS PROJECT IMPLEMENTS CRITICAL MEASURES TO RECOVER  DOWNLIST OR REMOVE FROM THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST  THE ENDANGERED FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY  PROPOSED ACTIONS INCLUDED ARE THOSE RECOMMENDED IN THE USFWS RECOVERY PLAN FOR PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON, WHICH INCLUDES FENDER S BLUEBUTTERFLY AND ITS HOST PLANT, KINCAID S LUPINE  PRIMARY FACTORS LIMITING FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY ARE HABITAT LOSS AND HABITAT DEGRADATION FROM INVASIVE WEEDS AND WOODY SHRUBS  PROPOSED ACTIONS WOULD INCLUDE ENHANCEMENT AND EXPANSION OF TWO OF THE POPULATION AREAS RECOGNIZED AS AT RISK IN THE USFWS 2019 SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT FOR THE SPECIES  LUPINE MEADOWS AND GREASY CREEK  THE VIABILITY OF BOTH POPULATION AREAS IS CURRENTLY IDENTIFIED AS LOW, WITH LOCAL EXTINCTION POSSIBLE IF SITES ARE MANAGED AS THEY ARE NOW  GREENBELT LAND TRUST SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE VIABILITY OF BOTH POPULATION AREAS TO PREVENT THESE POPULATION AREAS FROM GOING LOCALLY EXTINCT, THROUGH HABITAT EXPANSION AND ENHANCEMENT ON TWO PERMANENTLY CONSERVED AND MANAGED GREENBELT PROPERTIES  THE PROPOSED WORK INCLUDES HABITAT EXPANSION AND ENHANCEMENT AT LUPINE MEADOWS  IN THE LUPINE MEADOWS POPULATION AREA  AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT  INCLUDING KINCAID S LUPINE INTRODUCTION  AT LONE STAR RANCH  GREASY CREEK POPULATION AREA   THESE ACTIONS ADDRESS THE PRIMARY LIMITING FACTORS FOR FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY IN TWO AT RISK POPULATION AREAS, AND ARE EXPECTED TO IMPROVE THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES

FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY, A FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES AND AN OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY SPECIES, IS FOUND ONLY IN THE GRASSLANDS  AND OAK SAVANNAS  OF THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY OF OREGON  THE APPARENT POSITIVE RESPONSE OF THIS SPECIES TO HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT MAKES IT A HIGH PRIORITY FOR CONTINUED CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT FOR RECOVERY  FENDER S BLUE IS DEPENDENT ON NATIVE GRASSLAND HABITATS, AND ITS PREFERRED HOST PLANT, KINCAID S LUPINE  ACCURATE INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF LOCAL POPULATIONS IS ESSENTIAL TO TRACK AND EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OFRECOVERY EFFORTS FOR FENDER S BLUE  THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT ANNUAL MONITORING OF A SUBSET OF FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY POPULATIONS AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT QUALITY ASSESSMENTS AT KEY SITES FOR FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY RECOVERY  THIS WILL CONTRIBUTE DATA REQUIRED FOR THE USFWS RECOVERY ANALYSIS FOR FENDER S BLUE AND SUPPORT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF CONSERVATION SITES

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS AT TWO SITES OCCUPIED BY TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY  EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA TAYLORI  TCB  IN OREGON AND TO MONITOR THE TCB BUTTERFLY POPULATIONS  TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY IS A FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES AND AN OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGYSPECIES  RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL IMPROVE TCB HABITAT AND MONITORING DATA WILL PROVIDE THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFESERVICE  USFWS  AND BENTON COUNTY ACCURATE INFORMATION FOR RESTORATION AND POLICY DECISIONS  BEAZELL MEMORIAL FOREST  BEAZELL  AND CARDWELL HILL, BOTH IN BENTON COUNTY, OREGON, ARE HOME TO THE LAST REMAINING POPULATIONS OF THE TCB IN OREGON  BEAZELL IS OWNED AND MANAGED BY BENTON COUNTY NATURAL AREAS AND PARKS DEPARTMENT AND CARDWELL HILL HAS THREE PRIVATELY OWNED MEADOWS  THE LARGEST MEADOW AND SURROUNDING FOREST AT CARDWELL HILL IS ENROLLED IN THE USFWS PARTNERS PROGRAM  DUE TO HABITAT LOSS, DEGRADATION AND FRAGMENTATION, BOTH OF THE REMAINING IMPERILED TCB POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED DRASTICALLY  THE PRIMARY THREATS TO TCB HABITAT ATBOTH SITES ARE INCREASED DOMINANCE OF NON NATIVE PLANT SPECIES, TREE AND SHRUB ENCROACHMENT INTO THE MEADOWS, LACK OF CONNECTIVITY AND DECLINING ABUNDANCE OF TCB HOST AND NECTAR PLANTS  CONTINUED RESTORATION EFFORTS ARE NEEDED IF THE REMAINING TCB POPULATIONS IN OREGON ARE TO REMAIN EXTANT  PROPOSED HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INVASIVE WEED TREATMENTS, SHRUB AND TREE REMOVAL, ENGLISH PLANTAIN WILD SEED COLLECTION AND NATIVE AND BUTTERFLY RESOURCE PLANT COMMUNITY AUGMENTATION BY DIRECT SEEDING TO PREPARED AREAS  IN ADDITION, ANNUAL TCB POPULATION DATA IS ESSENTIAL TO TRACK AND EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF RECOVERY EFFORTS  DATA IS USED BY THE USFWS TO INFORM POLICY DECISIONS AND BY THE COUNTY AND LOCAL LAND MANAGERS TO ASSESS EFFICACY OF RESTORATION ACTIONS

NEARLY HALF OF THE HAWAIIAN FLORA IS CONSIDERED RARE AND 424 PLANTS ARE LISTED THREATENED OR ENDANGERED BY THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  THESE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS ARE IN DECLINE DUE TO THE IMPACTS FROM INVASIVENON NATIVE SPECIES, WILDFIRES, AND LAND CONVERSION  AS A RESULT, REGENERATION OF MANY PLANT SPECIES IN SITU HAS BEEN INTERRUPTED CAUSING A RAPID DECLINE IN THE NUMBERS OF POPULATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS  THE DLNR DOFAW STATEWIDE RARE PLANT PROGRAM SUPPORTS THE GOAL OF IN SITU PLANT RECOVERY, WHEN THESE SPECIES CAN MAINTAIN STABLE OR INCREASING NATURALLY REPRODUCING POPULATIONS IN SECURE, ADEQUATELY SIZED, SUITABLE HABITAT WITH ONLY A LOW LEVEL OF MANAGEMENT  HOWEVER, HABITAT PROTECTION ALONE WILL NOT PROVIDE FOR FULL RECOVERY OF HAWAII S RARE PLANTS  DIRECT INTERVENTION BY THE DLNR DOFAW THROUGH THREAT CONTROL, EX SITU PROPAGATION, AND HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS ARE MAJOR AND NECESSARY ASPECTS OF AN INTEGRATED CONSERVATION STRATEGY  THE ACTIONS TO BE SUPPORTED BYTHIS PROJECT INCLUDE SURVEYING FOR AND MONITORING CRITICALLY RARE PLANT POPULATIONS, COLLECTING PROPAGULES FOR STORAGE AND REINTRODUCTION PROJECTS, STORING AND PROPAGATING SEEDS IN SEED BANKS AND NURSERIES, OUTPLANTING TO CREATE NEW POPULATIONS, AND IN SITU MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THREATS

HAWAII S INVERTEBRATES FACE DIRECT THREATS FROM HABITAT DESTRUCTION AND ALTERATION, LOSS OF HOST PLANTS, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND THE INTRODUCTION OF NONNATIVE PREDATORS, COMPETITORS AND PATHOGENS  THE HAWAII INVERTEBRATE PROGRAM HIP , WHICH ENCOMPASSES THE SNAIL EXTINCTION PREVENTION PROGRAM  SEPP , FACILITATES RESEARCH, CONSERVATION AND APPLIED MANAGEMENT OF SOME THE MOST RARE, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED NATIVE INVERTEBRATES ACROSS THE STATE  THE HIP AND SEPP PROGRAMS COLLABORATE WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AT MANOA  UHM , AS WELL AS OTHER STATE, FEDERAL AND PRIVATE PARTNERS, TO IMPLEMENT NOVEL IN SITU AND EX SITU MANAGEMENT APPROACHES TO STABILIZE AND RECOVER DECLINING SPECIES  THE CAPTIVE REARING LABORATORIES CURRENTLY SUPPORT OVER 45 DIFFERENT INVERTEBRATE SPECIES FROM FIVE DIFFERENT ISLANDS  THESE FACILITIES PROVIDE A CRUCIAL GENETIC SAFETY NET FOR THE RARE SPECIES THEY HOUSE, SEVERAL OF WHICH ARE NOW EXTINCT IN THE WILD  FIELD STAFF CONDUCT SURVEYS, MONITORING, TRANSLOCATIONS AND REINTRODUCTIONS OF TARGET SPECIES  CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF PREDATOR PROOF FENCES, PREDATOR CONTROL, HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ARE ALSO INTEGRAL TO SPECIES RECOVERY  FUNDS ARE REQUESTED TO CONTINUE SUPPORT FOR HIP AND SEPP OPERATIONS AND STAFF ON OAHU AND MAUI  A SMALL AMOUNT OF FUNDING WILL ALSO BE DIRECTED TO THE HAWAIIAN DROSOPHILA RESEARCH STOCK CENTER AT UHM, WHICH MAINTAINS STOCKS OF RARE PICTURE WING DROSOPHILA SPECIES, MANY WHICH ARE ALSO FROM POPULATIONS NO LONGER FOUND IN THE WILD

GUAM IS THE MOST DENSELY POPULATED ISLAND IN MICRONESIA, WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 153,836 IN 2020  BSP2021   GUAM S ECONOMY DEPENDS PRIMARILY ON TOURISM, DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE  DOD  SPENDING, AND LOCALLY OWNED BUSINESSES  THE FORESTRY AND SOIL RESOURCES DIVISION OF THE GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE  DOAG  WORKS TO CONSERVE, PROTECT, AND ENHANCE GUAM S ENVIRONMENT AND SUSTAIN THE NATURAL RESOURCES THAT DEPEND ON HEALTHY FORESTS  GUAM S NATIVE FORESTS HAVE BEEN EXTENSIVELY ALTERED THE PURPOSE AND DESIRED FUTURE STATE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE PROPAGATION OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FLORA SPECIES FOR REINTRODUCTION INTO SUITABLE HABITATS ACROSS THE ISLAND  ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A PLATFORM FOR COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, HIGHLIGHTING THE VALUE AND IMPORTANCE OF KEYSTONE SPECIES WITHIN AN ECOSYSTEM   REINTRODUCE OR AUGMENT POPULATIONS OF SELECTED SPECIES ON GOVERNMENT OF GUAM MANAGED LANDS   DEVELOP A LONG TERM MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR SELECTED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FLORA SPECIES ON GUAM

THE KO KO   HYPOTAENIDIA OWSTONI  AND SIHEK  TODIRAPMPHUS CINNAMOMINA  ARE TWO ENDEMIC GUAM SPECIES IMPACTED BY THE INTRODUCTION OF THE BROWN TREESNAKE  BOIGA IRREGULARIS   THESE SPECIES WERE BROUGHT INTO CAPTIVITY PRIOR TO THEIR EXTINCTION IN THE WILD IN THE MID 1980S  THIS PROJECT IS COMPLEMENTARY TO THE WORK DONE BY US ASSOCIATION OF ZOOS AND AQUARIUMS, WHICH ARE PARTNERS OF GUAM DEPT OF AGRICULTURE AND ARE CRUCIAL TO THE MAINTENANCE OF THESE BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY AND THE RESTORATION OF THEM TO GUAM  THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE STAFF AND MOST NECESSITIES NEEDED TO MANAGE THE CAPTIVE POPULATIONS FOR KO KO  AND SIHEK ON GUAM  AS THE KO KO  AND SIHEK ARE TWO OF THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S TRUSTED RESOURCES, THIS PROJECT ENSURES THESE SPECIES WILL NOT GO EXTINCT

BULL TROUT RECOVERY ACTIONS WILL SOON BEGIN IN THE NORTH FORK MALHEUR RECOVERY UNIT AND FISHERIES MANAGERS ARE LACKING A LONG TERM MONITORING PROGRAM THAT CAN TRACK THE STATUS AND TREND OF THE BULL TROUT POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT, PROVIDE AN EARLY WARNING SYSTEM FOR INTRODUCTIONS OF NON NATIVE BROOK TROUT, AND DETECT A THERMAL HABITAT RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND RECOVERY ACTIONS  LOCAL FISHERIES MANAGERS ALSO HAVE SOME QUESTIONS ABOUT THE ACTUAL NUMBER OF LOCAL BULL TROUT POPULATIONS EXIST IN THIS BASIN AND THE FULL DISTRIBUTION OF SPAWNING  THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO COLLECT DATA THAT WOULD BE THE BASIS FOR A LONG TERM MONITORING PROGRAM AND FILL IN INFORMATION GAPS ABOUT BULL TROUT IN THIS BASIN  OUR FOUR PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1  DETERMINE DISTRIBUTION OF SPAWNING AND EARLY REARING FOR BULL TROUT AND BROOK TROUT AND COLLECT TISSUE SAMPLES FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS BY CONDUCTING YOUNG OF THE YEAR  AGE 0  FISH OCCUPANCY SURVEYS THROUGHOUT THE BASIN  2  DESCRIBE SPAWNING AND EARLY REARING HABITAT AND RIPARIAN CONDITIONS BY CONDUCTING HABITAT SURVEYS THROUGHOUT THE BASIN  3  BOLSTER POPULATION MONITORING BY USING GENETIC TOOLS TO DETERMINE POPULATION STRUCTURE, CALIBRATE CENSUS SPAWNING SURVEYS WITH ESTIMATES OF EFFECTIVE NUMBER OF BREEDERS, AND DETECT PRESENCE AND LOCATION OF BROOK TROUT OR HYBRIDS  AND 4  DEVELOP A STREAM TEMPERATURE MODEL FOR MONITORING OF BASIN WIDE THERMAL HABITAT

WITH 33 TAXA LISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED, THE NATIVE AVIFAUNA OF HAWAI I ARE THE MOST ENDANGERED BIRD FAUNA IN THE WORLD  REED ET AL 2012   THE MOST CRITICALLY ENDANGERED IN THIS GROUP ARE THE HAWAIIAN FORESTBIRDS, WITH TWELVE OUT OF 21 EXTANT SPECIES LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED  PAXTON ET AL 2018   THE MAJOR THREATS CONFRONTING ALL SPECIES ARE LOSS OF HABITAT, AVIAN DISEASE, LOW REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, PREDATION, AND COMPETITION WITH ALIEN SPECIES  CONSERVATION BREEDING  ALSO KNOWN AS CAPTIVE PROPAGATION  IS ONE OF THE MANY TOOLS NEEDED TO HELP RECOVER THESE SPECIES, PARTICULARLY THOSE THAT ARE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED AND ON THE BRINK OF EXTINCTION  DOFAW S CONSERVATION BREEDING PROJECT IS BEING USED TO INCREASE PRODUCTION AND PROVIDE INDIVIDUALS FOR RELEASE BACK INTO PROTECTED HABITAT TO AUGMENT DECLINING WILD POPULATIONS, AND TO REESTABLISH EXTINCT LOCAL POPULATIONS  THE PURPOSE OF THIS EFFORT IS TO PREVENT THE EXTINCTION AND PROMOTE THE RECOVERY OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS, USING HUSBANDRY, AVICULTURE, AND CONSERVATION BREEDING TECHNIQUES  THE PUAIOHI OR SMALL KAUAI THRUSH  MYADESTES PALMERI   AKIKIKI OR KAUAI CREEPER  OREOMYSTIS BAIRDI   AND AKEKEEOR KAUAI AKEPA  LOXOPS CAERULEIROSTRIS  ARE ENDEMIC TO KAUAI  THEY ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED BY THE FEDERAL ANDHAWAII STATE GOVERNMENTS AND CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR CONSERVATION OF NATURE  THE POPULATIONS OF THESE THREE SPECIES ARE THOUGHT TO NUMBER FEWER THAN 500, 500, AND 1,000 INDIVIDUALS, RESPECTIVELY  CRAMPTON ET AL  2017, PAXTON ET AL  2016   A FOURTH SPECIES, IIWI  DREPANIS COCCINEA , IS LISTED AS THREATENED,WITH AN APPROXIMATE POPULATION OF 2700 BIRDS ON KAUAI  PAXTON ET AL  2016   ALL FOUR SPECIES ONLY OCCUR IN THE INTERIOR OF KAUAI IN WET   3,000 MM RAIN YEAR  MONTANE FOREST IN NARROW STREAM VALLEYS AND ASSOCIATED RIDGES ABOVE 1,050 METERS ELEVATION  THEIR BREEDING POPULATIONS ARE RESTRICTED TO AN AREA OF   80 KM2 ON THE SOUTHERNAND CENTRAL PLATEAU OF THE ALAKAI WILDERNESS PRESERVE  FOR PUAIOHI AND AKIKIKI, THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESEARCH NATURAL HISTORY OF, AND THREATS TO KAUAI S ENDANGERED FOREST BIRDS, AND USE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT TO INVESTIGATE TECHNIQUES TO PROMOTE THEIR RECOVERY  RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT ARE FOCUSED AT THE POPULATION LEVEL TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE THREATS TO NATIVE BIRDS, THEREBY PROVIDING GUIDANCE FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT THE  ALALA OR HAWAIIAN CROW  CORVUS HAWAIIENSIS  IS ENDEMIC TO THE ISLAND OF HAWAI I HISTORICALLY, AND IT, OR ACLOSELY RELATED AND ECOLOGICALLY SIMILAR SPECIES IS PRESENT IN THE SUBFOSSIL RECORD ON MAUI  DECLINES WERE NOTED PRIOR TO 1900, AND BY THE 1980S ONLY RELICT AND WIDELY SCATTERED SMALL POPULATIONS REMAINED  THESE REMNANT POPULATIONS WERE CONTINUOUSLY HINDERED BY A SUITE OF THREATS INCLUDING HABITAT LOSS ASSOCIATED WITH HUMANS, FERALUNGULATES, FIRE, AND INVASIVE PLANTS  DISEASE  HUMAN PERSECUTION  AND PREDATION BY NON NATIVE MAMMALS  BY 2002, ALALA WAS EXTINCT IN THE WILD  USFWS 2003   CURRENTLY, OVER 125 INDIVIDUALS EXIST IN CAPTIVE BREEDINGFACILITIES  THIS GRANT OUTLINES THE RESOURCES NEEDED TO ACHIEVE THE NEW DIRECTIONS OF THE PROJECT, PRIMARILY THE PLANNING AND COORDINATION OF  ALALA RELEASES WITHIN MAUI NUI, AND THE OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WORK NEEDED TO LAY A FOUNDATION OF SUPPORT FOR  ALALA RELEASES AND NATIVE HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRD CONSERVATION WITHINMAUI NUI, AND SECONDARILY, PARTIAL FIELD SUPPORT FOR THE  IO RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ON HAWAII ISLAND

GRIZZLY BEAR POPULATION MONITORING IS REQUIRED UNDER THE USFWS S GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY PLAN  SUPPLEMENT  REVISED DEMOGRAPHIC RECOVERY CRITERIA FOR THE YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM , THE CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR THE GRIZZLY BEAR IN THE YELLOWSTONE AREA, AND THE STATE OF IDAHO YELLOWSTONE GRIZZLY BEAR MANAGEMENT PLAN  ALL MONITORING EFFORTS ARE UNDERTAKEN AS PART OF THE INTERAGENCY GRIZZLY BEAR STUDY TEAM  IGBST , WHICH IS A GROUP OF STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL PARTNERS THAT WORK TOGETHER TO MONITOR THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM  GYE  GRIZZLY BEAR POPULATION  THE STUDY TEAM S PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITIES ARE TO  1  MONITOR THE BEAR POPULATION, INCLUDING STATUS AND TREND, POPULATION ESTIMATE, REPRODUCTION, AND MORTALITY  AND 2  MONITOR GRIZZLY BEAR HABITATS, FOODS, AND IMPACTS OF HUMANS  IN THE PAST, IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  IDFG  PERSONNEL HAVE MONITORED RADIO COLLARED GRIZZLY BEARS AND PERFORMED CAMERA SURVEYS TO OBSERVE BEARS  IDFG WILL USE FFY22 SECTION 6 FUNDING TO PURCHASE RADIO COLLARS, CAMERAS, AND OTHER MONITORING SUPPLIES TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE LARGER MONITORING EFFORT INCOORDINATION WITH THE IGBST

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE IDAHO PANHANDLE BEES TO BEARS CLIMATE ADAPTATION PROJECT  B2B  IS TO IMPROVE LANDSCAPE CLIMATE RESILIENCY FOR WESTERN BUMBLE BEES  BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS  AND GRIZZLYBEARS  URSUS ARCTOS HORRIBILIS  THROUGH RESTORATION OF APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES OF DEGRADED FORESTED LOWLAND HABITAT ON IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME S BOUNDARY SMITH CREEKWILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  BSCWMA   TO ACHIEVE THIS OVERARCHING GOAL THE PROJECT INCLUDED THE CONSTRUCTION OF APPROXIMATELY 16 ACRES OF TOPOGRAPHICALLY MODIFIED AREAS KNOWN AS COOL AIRREFUGIA  CAR , PLANTING OF 25 ACRES OF TREES AND SHRUBS AND APPROXIMATELY 50 ADDITIONAL ACRES PLANTED WITH DESIRABLE NATIVE PLANT SPECIES  THE B2B PROJECT INITIALLY BEGAN IN 2017 WITH THE MAJORITY OF CONSTRUCTION AND PLANTING EFFORTS OCCURRING IN 2018 AND 2019  WHILE MAINTENANCE AND MONITORING HAS CONTINUED SINCE INITIAL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT, CHALLENGES HAVE ARISEN RELATED TO INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL, SOIL CONDITIONS, PERSONNEL SHORTAGES AND EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS  THESE CHALLENGES HAVE RESULTED IN THE NEED TO REPLANT OVER MUCH OF THE ORIGINAL PROJECT AREA AND THUS HAS LED TO THIS NEXT PHASE OF B2B OR THE  IDAHO PANHANDLE B2B CLIMATE ADAPTATION REPLANTING PROJECT   PLANTING ON THE CAR STRUCTURES HAS BEEN PARTICULARLY CHALLENGING DUE TO THE SLOPES OF THE CAR SAND LESS WATER AVAILABILITY LEADING TO THE FAILURE OF PREVIOUS PLANTING EFFORTS  TO INCREASE THE PROBABILITY OF SUCCESS OF REPLANTING IN THESE AREAS, WE PLAN TO USE THE HYDRO SEEDING METHOD TO PLANT ON THE CARS  HYDROSEEDING IS A TECHNIQUE THAT SPREADS A SPECIALIZED MIX OF CHOSEN SEEDS, MULCH, WATER, AND FERTILIZER TO AID IN PLANT GROWTH AND HELPS PREVENT EROSION  APPROXIMATELY 12 OF 16 CAR ACRES WILL BE HYDROSEEDED WHILE THE REMAINING 4 ACRES WILL BE PLANTED USING TRADITIONAL METHODS  BY UTILIZING BOTH METHODS WE WILL BE ABLE TO DETERMINE IF HYDROSEEDING IS SUPERIOR FOR ESTABLISHING NATIVE PLANT SPECIES ON CAR STRUCTURES AND IF THE ADDED COST OF DOING SO IS JUSTIFIED  MUCH OF THE ORIGINAL 100 ACRE PROJECT AREA IS ALSO IN NEED OF REPLANTING AND WILL BE COMPLETED USING TRADITIONAL METHODS  THIS WILL INCLUDE THE PLANTING OF NATIVE SPECIES WITHIN THE TREE AND SHRUB CAGES TO HELP CONTROL INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES GROWING IN THE AREA  ADDITIONALLY, TO FURTHER IMPROVE PROBABILITY OF SUCCESS OF REPLANTING EFFORTS, FERTILIZER WILL BE APPLIED TO MUCH OF THE PROJECT AREA TO IMPROVE THE CONDITIONS OF THE CURRENTLY NUTRIENT POOR SOIL  AND FINALLY, AFTER REPLANTING AND SOIL APPLICATION HAS TAKEN PLACE, VEGETATION MONITORING WILL OCCUR OVER AREAS THAT HAVE BEEN REPLANTED TO DETERMINE IF PREVIOUSLY MENTIONED EFFORTS HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL INESTABLISHING NATIVE PLANT SPECIES

THIS PROPOSAL IS TO CONTINUE RESEARCH ON THE EFFECTS OF HABITAT RESTORATION TREATMENTS ON NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL  NIDGS  DEMOGRAPHY  SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT ADDS A FOURTH COHORT OF JUVENILE NIDGS TO THE STUDY TO GENERATE A SUFFICIENT SAMPLE SIZE FOR A MORE COMPLETE ASSESSMENT OF THE EFFECTS OF THINNING AND BURNING ON ABUNDANCE AND POPULATION HEALTH OF ALL AGE CLASSES OF NIDGS  RESTORING AND MAINTAINING HABITAT IS A PRIMARY COMPONENT OF THE NIDGS RECOVERY PLAN  SINCE 2012, THE IDAHO COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT AT THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO  UI  HAS COLLECTED DATA ON ANNUAL SURVIVAL, DIET, REPRODUCTION, AND SELECTION OF HIBERNACULA TO EXAMINE NIDGS RESPONSE TO FOREST THINNING AND PRESCRIBED FIRE  THE STUDY EXPANDED IN 2020 TO INCLUDE JUVENILE SQUIRRELS IN THE SAMPLE  THE OVERARCHING COLLABORATIVE STUDY TO WHICH THIS PROJECT TIERS HAS AMASSED 9 YEARS OF DETAILED PRE TREATMENT DATA THAT DESCRIBED VARIATION IN HABITAT QUALITY, GROUND SQUIRREL FORAGING AND HIBERNATION BEHAVIOR, AND GROUND SQUIRREL SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTION  FOR EXAMPLE, DATA HAVE SHOWN THAT NIDGS AT SOME SITES MOVE 100 M OR MORE INTO THE FOREST TO HIBERNATE, AND AS A RESULT, HABITAT COMPONENTS FOR HIBERNACULA DIFFER SUBSTANTIALLY FROM HABITAT COMPONENTS DURING THE ACTIVE SEASON  THIS SUGGESTS THAT NIDGS AS A POPULATION  ACROSS ALL AGE CLASSES  MAY REQUIRE A MORE HETEROGENEOUS LANDSCAPE THAN PREVIOUSLY BELIEVED  THE STUDY IS TRANSITIONING TO POST TREATMENT DATA COLLECTION, WHICH PROVIDES THE FOUNDATION FOR COMPARISONS THAT WILL FORM THE BASIS OF AN ASSESSMENT OF NIDGS RESPONSE TO RESTORATION TREATMENTS  THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LARGER EFFORT BY  1  EXAMINING DIFFERENCES AMONG AGE CLASSES, WHICH WILL PROVIDE A MORE COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF HOW HABITAT TREATMENTS AFFECT NIDGS POPULATION DEMOGRAPHY   2  IDENTIFYING WHICH COMPONENTS OF RESTORATION POTENTIALLY PROMOTE NIDGS POPULATION GROWTH AND SPATIAL EXPANSION  AND  3  ENSURING THAT THINNING AND BURNING, WHICH ARE THE STANDARD TECHNIQUES TO IMPROVE HABITAT, WILL BE EFFECTIVE AND STRATEGIC  ADDITIONALLY, ANY REMAINING FUNDS WILL BE USED TO CONTRIBUTE TO A UI NIDGS DIET ANALYSIS

THE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL  UROCITELLUS BRUNNEUS  NIDGS  IS A FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED SPECIES  THE RECOVERY PLAN, PUBLISHED IN 2003, ESTABLISHED CRITERIA FOR ASSESSING HOW THE SPECIES WAS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY AND EVENTUAL DELISTING  THOSE CRITERIA INCLUDED GOALS FOR NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION ON THE LANDSCAPE  ANNUAL POPULATION MONITORING SURVEYS HAVE SHOWN THAT SEVERAL METRICS OF ABUNDANCE AND TREND HAVE BEEN ON AN UPWARD TRAJECTORY SINCE 2011, AND ARE SUBSTANTIALLY HIGHER THAN WHEN THE RECOVERY PLAN WAS PUBLISHED IN2003  HOWEVER, NO POPULATION METRIC IDENTIFIED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN HAS BEEN ACHIEVED  NIDGS STILL OCCURS MOST FREQUENTLY IN SMALL POPULATIONS THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY AND GENETICALLY SEPARATED FROM ONE ANOTHER  WELL DEFINED, REPEATABLE SURVEYS ARE NEEDED TO TRACK IF, AND TO WHAT EXTENT, THE NIDGS POPULATION IS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY  WITHOUT SUCH DATA, RECOVERY CRITERIA CAN NOT BE MEASURED, AND IT BECOMES MORE DIFFICULT TO DIRECT MEANINGFUL CONSERVATION ACTIONS WHERE THEY WILL HAVE THE MOST BENEFIT  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OBTAIN CURRENT INFORMATION ON NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION USING A PROVEN SURVEY DESIGN, ANALYZE RESULTS TO ASSESS POPULATION TRAJECTORY, AND SHARE THIS INFORMATION WITH OTHER PARTNERS IN RECOVERY TO INFORM THEIR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HABITAT, EVALUATE NIDGS RESPONSE TO HABITAT TREATMENTS, AND DEVELOP CONSERVATION ACTIONS ON PRIVATE LAND  CHANGES IN DISTRIBUTION DETECTED ON SURVEYS WILL INFLUENCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL AID IN DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND, ULTIMATELY, RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES  ANTICIPATED PRODUCTS INCLUDE  1  A STATISTICAL SUMMARY AND FINAL REPORT OF 2022 SURVEY DATA, INCLUDING ESTIMATES OF NIDGS ABUNDANCE, POPULATION TREND, AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION   2  UPDATED SPATIAL DATA LAYERS OF NIDGS OCCURRENCE THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO RECOVERY PARTNERS  AND  3  A COMPLETE DATA SET OF SURVEY AND MARK RECAPTURE RESULTS FROM THE 2023 FIELD SEASON

WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS  WMAS  OWNED BY IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  IDFG  ARE HOME TO MULTIPLE POLLINATOR SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED, AND MAY PLAY AN INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT ROLE IN POLLINATOR CONSERVATION INTO THE FUTURE  OF PARTICULAR INTEREST ARE THE WESTERN BUMBLE BEE  BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS  AND SUCKLEY CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE  BOMBUSSUCKLEYI , TWO SPECIES THAT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN PETITIONED FOR LISTING AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED  THIS PROJECT WILL USE NEW POLLINATOR CONSERVATION AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT TOOLS PRODUCED BY THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST BUMBLE BEE ATLAS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR THESE TWO SPECIES AT IDFG WMAS  OVER THE COURSE OF THREE YEARS, THIS PROJECT WILL PURCHASE POLLINATOR FRIENDLY NATIVE SEEDS AND PLUGS AND PROVIDE THEM TO WMA MANAGERS TO HELP THEM IMPLEMENT HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIONS

THESE FUNDS WILL SUPPLEMENT DATA MANAGEMENT EFFORTS WITHIN THE IDAHO FISH AND  WILDLIFE INFORMATIONSYSTEM  IFWIS  BY FOCUSING ON THE PROCUREMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING SPATIAL AND TABULAR DATA FOR FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND PETITIONED SPECIES THAT ARE UNDER FWS REVIEW  INCLUDING BUT NOTLIMITED TO  WESTERN RIDGED MUSSEL, MONARCH BUTTERFLY, NORTHERN BOG LEMMING, NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL, WOLVERINE, WHITE BARK PINE, YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO, WESTERN BUMBLE BEE, SUCKLEY CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE, GRIZZLY BEAR, SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS, AND LITTLE BROWN BAT   INFORMATION GATHERED FROM CURRENT YEAR SECTION 6 GRANTS, PARTNER AGENCIES, NGOS, AND OR COMMUNITY SCIENCE EFFORTS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE IFWIS STATEWIDE COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE TO HELP INFORM FUTURE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN REVISION AND IMPLEMENTATION, IDFG TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND PROVIDE A BACKBONE OF INFORMATION FOR THE IDAHO CONSERVATION PLANNER

GRIZZLY BEARS WERE LISTED IN 1975 AND RECOVERY EFFORTS HAVE BEEN UNDERWAY SINCE  USFWS1993   BEAR NUMBERS AND DISTRIBUTION HAVE BEEN INCREASING, ESPECIALLY IN THE SELKIRK AND CABINET YAAK ECOSYSTEMS, BUT ARE NOT YET AT RECOVERY LEVELS  IT IS IMPORTANT TO EVALUATE THE CURRENT POPULATION LEVELS, TREND, DISTRIBUTION, RELATEDNESS, AND GENETIC INTERCHANGE IN THESE ECOSYSTEMS  SOME OF THESE OBJECTIVES CAN BE MET WITH BARBED WIRE HAIR SNARE SITES TO COLLECT DNA AND REMOTE CAMERAS  GRIZZY BEAR RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVES S111, S12, AND S33 WILL BE ADDRESSED THROUGH THESE ACTIONS  USFWS 1993   HUMAN CAUSED MORTALITY HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS AN IMPORTANT VARIABLE IN GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE  EDUCATION AND ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS CAN FUNCTION AS BOTH A PREVENTATIVE MEASURE AND A DETERRENT  EDUCATION RELATED TO SANITATION IS A HIGHLY EFFECTIVE METHOD TO PREVENT FOOD HABITUATED BEARS   AN ISSUE IN THE SELKIRK AND CABINET YAAK ECOSYSTEMS IN THE RECENT YEARS  RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVES S131, S2112, S2113, AND S62 WILL BE ADDRESSED THROUGH THESE ACTIONS  USFWS 1993   THEREFORE, SECTION 6 FUNDS, IN CONJUNCTION WITH STATE AND PRIVATE FUNDS, WILL BE USED TO ESTABLISH CAMERA AND DNA SITES TO DOCUMENT GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY PLAN CRITERIA  IN ADDITION, THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  IDFG  WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC OUTREACH, SANITATION EDUCATION, CONFLICT PREVENTION AND MITIGATION MEASURES, ENFORCEMENT PRESENCE, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE ENTITIES  THESE ACTIVITIES ARE PRIMARILY INTENDED TO REDUCE THREATS TO THE SPECIES AND PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION AS NEEDED  THIS WORK IS A KEY PART OF THE OVERALL CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE CABINET YAAK AND SELKIRK ECOSYSTEMS WITH THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF ACHIEVING GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY  IDFG HAS RECEIVED SECTION 6 FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT IN THE PAST  IDFG HAS CONTRIBUTED TO RECOVERY OF GRIZZLY BEARS THROUGH MONITORING EFFORTS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, BEAR CONFLICT RESOLUTION AND MITIGATION, PARTICIPATION IN GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY TEAMS AND MEMBERSHIP ON THE INTERAGENCY GRIZZLY BEAR STUDY COMMITTEE AT THE REGIONAL AND ECOSYSTEM LEVEL  IDFG PROVIDES CONTINUITY ON THIS PROJECT AND PROVIDES A HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE OF RECOVERY OF GRIZZLY BEARS

WE WILL PARTICIPATE IN SEVERAL EFFORTS RELATED TO SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS RECOVERY  WE WILL FOCUSON SURVEYS AND ASSESSMENTS OF SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS OCCURRENCES ON MUNICIPAL LANDS NEAR BOISE, AND OTHER PRIORITY AREAS ON STATE AND FEDERAL LANDS TO VERIFY THAT SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS IS EXTANT  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL WORK WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND OTHERS IN THE RECOVER PLANNING PROCESS AND AN ANALYSIS OF HABITAT INVENTORY AND POPULATION MONITORING DATA

THE WESTERN RIDGED MUSSEL  GONIDEA ANGULATA  WRM  IS 1 OF ONLY 7 SPECIES OF NATIVE FRESHWATER MUSSEL THAT OCCUR IN THE WESTERN U S  THE RANGE OF WRM IS THE SMALLEST OF THE MUSSEL SPECIES OCCURRING IN THE WEST  IDAHO AND NEVADA REPRESENT THE EASTERN EXTENT OF THE RANGE  BLEVINS ET AL  2017   THE WRM WAS PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN AUGUST 2020, PRIMARILY DUE TO SUBSTANTIAL DECLINES IN RANGE WIDE DISTRIBUTION  POTENTIALLY AS HIGH AS 43   AND SUDDEN, ENIGMATIC DIE OFFS  OCCURRENCE RECORDS IN IDAHO ARE VERY LIMITED IN NUMBER AND IN GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT  IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME S  IDFG  ANIMAL OBSERVATIONS SPECIES DIVERSITY DATABASE CONTAINS ONLY 181 RECORDS OF WRM, OF WHICH ONLY 34 ARE FROM THE LAST 20 YEARS  WRM POPULATIONS HISTORICALLY EXISTED IN MUCH OF THE SNAKE, CLEARWATER, SALMON AND LITTLE SALMON RIVERS, BUT DATA SUGGEST THE SPECIES HAS BEEN LOST FROM MANY OF THESE AREAS  RECENT SURVEYS OF 11 HISTORIC SITES IN IDAHO FOUND LIVE MUSSELS AT ONLY 5 OF THOSE SITES  THE XERCES SOCIETY 2020   CONTEMPORARY RECORDS OF WRM OCCUR IN THE BRUNEAU, JARBIDGE, MALAD, SNAKE, AND SALMON RIVERS IDFG PROPOSES TO CONTINUE A MULTI YEAR EFFORT TO CONDUCT A STATE WIDE SURVEY AND INVENTORY PROJECT TO DOCUMENT CONTEMPORARY OCCURRENCES OF WRM AND DETERMINE THESTATUS OF EXTANT POPULATIONS THROUGH THE PRESENCE OF DIFFERENT AGE CLASSES  TO MAKE OUR SURVEYS MOST EFFECTIVE, WE WILL COLLABORATE WITH SEVERAL PARTNERS TO FOCUS OUR EFFORTS ON  1  HISTORICAL LOCATIONS THAT WILL BE REVISITED TO ASSESS PERSISTENCE OR LOSS,  2  RECENT STREAM REACHES IDENTIFIED WITH EDNA AS CONTAINING WRM THAT WILL BE VISITED TO CONFIRMPRESENCE AT A FINER SCALE, AND  3  LOCATIONS THAT BRIDGE GAPS IN SAMPLING OCCURRING UNDER OTHER STUDIES  COLLECTIVELY THESE LOCATIONS WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE REPRESENTATION ACROSS IDAHO

WHITEBARK PINE  PINUS ALBICAULIS  IS CURRENTLY PROPOSED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIESACT AS THREATENED BY THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS   IN 2016, THE FWS ESTIMATED THAT 51  OF ALL STANDING WHITEBARK PINE WERE DEAD WITH THE PRIMARY THREATS BEING WHITE PINE BLISTER RUST, MOUNTAIN PINE BEETLES, ALTERED WILDFIRE PATTERNS AND CLIMATE CHANGE  WHITEBARK PINE IS A KEYSTONE SPECIES, CONTRIBUTING TO CRITICAL ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION IN ALPINE ENVIRONMENTS  IF MATURE TREES REPEATEDLY FAIL TO REPLACE THEMSELVES OVER TIME THIS WILL LEAD TO POPULATION DECLINE AND LOSS WE KNOW OF ONLY ONE OTHER STUDY IN THE SALMON REGION OF IDAHO THAT RIGOROUSLY ASSESSED DISEASE AND BEETLES ON WHITEBARK PINE AND THAT STUDY FOCUSED ON IN DEPTH MONITORING AT FOUR DIFFERENT LOCATIONS  OUR STUDY ACROSS A BROADER SPATIAL SCALE WILL PROVIDE PERTINENT INFORMATION ON WHITEBARK PINE HEALTH AND REPRODUCTIVE STATUS, WHICH MAY BE HELPFUL TO THE FWS IN FUTURE LISTING DECISIONS FOR THE SPECIES  ADDITIONALLY, RATHER THAN CREATING OUR OWN PROTOCOL, WE WILL USE A PROTOCOL THAT HAS BEEN TESTED AND DEVELOPED BY THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE WHITEBARK PINE MONITORING WORKING GROUP  THIS IS ALSO THEREFORE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR COORDINATION AT A LARGER SPATIAL SCALE  PROVIDING CONSISTENT BROAD SCALE DATA WILL HELP LAND MANAGERS IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF WHITEBARK PINE HEALTH, DISTRIBUTION AND DENSITY WITHIN STANDS ACROSS IDAHO, AND ITS WESTERN RANGE, TO DETERMINE THEIR ABILITY TO PERSIST IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHERTHREATS

THE MARIANA CROW IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES CURRENTLY ONLY FOUND ON THE ISLAND OF ROTA, COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS  THE LAST COUNT ESTIMATED THE POPULATION AT 178 INDIVIDUALS  KRONER AND  HA 2017   CONTINUED RESEARCH AND MONITORING EFFORTS ON THE WILD POPULATION OF THE MARIANA CROW ON ROTA IS ESSENTIAL IN ORDER TO PROVIDE UPDATED INFORMATION ON THE POPULATION SIZE AND CAUSES OF DECLINE, AND TO SUPPORT RECOVERY EFFORTS OF THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES  POPULATION MONITORING IS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE CAPTIVE REAR AND RELEASE PROGRAM  THESE ONGOING EFFORTS INCLUDE  LONG TERM MONITORING OF THE POPULATION OF MARIANA CROWS ON ROTA  LOCATING AND MONITORING OF CROW BREEDING TERRITORIES, NESTS, AND PAIRS  MONITORING ACTIVE NESTS  RESIGHTING OF BANDED BIRDS  BANDING ADULT AND JUVENILE CROWS AND COLLECTING BLOOD SAMPLES FROM WILD CROWS  AND POST RELEASE MONITORING OF REHABILITATED AND CAPTIVELY REARED CROWS  EVERY OTHER YEAR AN INTENSIVE EFFORT IS MADE TO COUNT EVERY ADULT MARIANA CROW ON THE ISLAND IN WHAT IS REFERRED TO AS AN ISLAND WIDE PAIR SURVEY  IT IS SCHEDULE TO OCCUR DURING THIS GRANT PERIOD  THE MARIANA CROW CONSERVATION RESEARCH PROGRAM HAS FIVE OBJECTIVES  1  DETERMINE MARIANA CROW POPULATION TRENDS, DISPERSAL PATTERNS AND SURVIVAL RATES 2  CONDUCT ISLAND WIDE SURVEY TO DETERMINE POPULATION TRENDS AND MORTALITY RATES  3  MONITOR NESTING EFFORTS OF MARIANA CROW PAIRS TO DETERMINE REPRODUCTIVE RATES, BAND FLEDGLINGS, AND SUPPORT COLLECTION OF EGGS AND OR NESTLINGS FOR THE CAPTIVE REAR AND RELEASE PROGRAM  4  SOFT RELEASE AND MONITOR VIA RADIOTELEMETRY OF REHABILITATED AND CAPTIVELY REARED CROWS 5  PROMOTE BIRD CONSERVATION AND INFORM PUBLIC ABOUT MARIANA CROW PROGRAM ON ROTA  THIS WORK WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE UPDATED INFORMATION ABOUT THE MARIANA CROW POPULATION ON ROTA THAT WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT RECOVERY EFFORTS OF THE SPECIES  SUCH INFORMATION INCLUDES  CURRENT POPULATION SIZE, LONG TERM POPULATION TRENDS, SURVIVAL RATES, REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, DISPERSAL PATTERNS  AND COLLECTION OF BLOOD SERUM FOR DISEASE SCREENING AND BLOOD SAMPLES FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS  INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COLOR BANDED BIRDS ON ROTA WILL GREATLY ASSIST MONITORING EFFORTS AND WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE THE TOTAL NUMBER OF ADULTS IN THE ISLAND WIDE PAIR SURVEY THIS YEAR  THIS WORK ALSO PROVIDES CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF THE MARIANA CROW CAPTIVE REAR AND RELEASE PROGRAM  IT PROVIDES INFORMATION ON CURRENT PAIR AND NEST LOCATIONS, AND NEST STATUS NECESSARY FOR THE COLLECTION OF EGGS FOR THE MARIANA CROW CAPTIVE REAR AND RELEASE PROGRAM, AND THEN SUPPORTS THE MONITORING VIA RADIOTELEMETRY OF REHABILITATED AND CAPTIVELY REARED CROWS AS REQUIRE BY FEDERAL PERMIT  NEST MONITORING AND RADIOTRACKING ALSO PROVIDE THE NECESSARY SAMPLES TO IDENTIFY THE CAUSES OF MORTALITY CURRENTLY AFFECTING THE POPULATION THE ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO SUPPORT RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES

THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS HAS 21 LISTED MAMMALS, BIRDS, REPTILES AND INVERTEBRATES AS WELL AS 14 LISTED PLANT SPECIES  MANY OF THESE ARE ENDEMIC SPECIES  AMONGST THESE, ARE THREE ENDANGERED PLANTS ALL ENDEMIC TO ROTA AND GUAM  OUR CURRENT EFFORTS TO CONSERVE THESE SPECIES HAS DETECTED NO NATURAL RECRUITMENT OF OSMOXYLON MARIANNENSEOR SERIANTHES NELSONII  NESOGENES ROTENSIS IS AN HERB ENDEMIC TO ROTA OCCURRING AT EXTREMELY LOW ABUNDANCE, PRIMARILY IN ONE LOCATION  THUS, IT IS VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION  RETAINING THESE THREE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PLANTS  NESOGENES ROTENSIS, OSMOXYLON MARIANNENSE, AND SERIANTHES NELSONII  INTO THE FUTURE REQUIRES ACTIVE PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING AS WELL AS AMELIORATING THREATS  WE FOCUS ON  1  SURVEYS, MAINTENANCE, PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING TO SUSTAIN THREE ENDANGERED PLANTS, AND  2  PROTECTION OF OUTPLANTING THROUGH FENCING AREAS

THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS HAS 35 LISTED SPECIES, MANY OF THESE ARE ENDEMICS  THUS, THE COMMONWEALTH OF THENORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS  COMMONWEALTH  REQUIRES DEDICATED LEADERSHIP TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE AND RECOVER ENDANGERED SPECIES, SPECIFICALLY THE MARIANA CROW AND ENDANGERED PLANTS  THIS POSITION WILL BE SITUATED IN THE DEPARTMENT OF LANDS AND NATURAL RESOURCES  DLNR  ON SAIPAN AND WILL BE THE COMMONWEALTH S POINT OF CONTACT FOR THE MARIANA CROW CONSERVATION EFFORT AS WELL AS THE CONSERVATION OF LISTED PLANTS  DURING THE PERIOD OF THIS GRANT, THE INDIVIDUAL WILL CONTINUE TO ACT AS THE PRIMARY REPRESENTATIVE FOR DLNR FOR COLLABORATIVE MANAGEMENT WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE  ON MARIANA CROW CONSERVATION EFFORTS  ADDITIONALLY, THE COMMONWEALTH HAS CONTINUING RESPONSIBILITIES RELATED TO THE MARIANA CROW CONSERVATION AREA AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ROTA ISLAND WIDE CONSERVATION STRATEGY  LASTLY, DLNR REQUIRES A DEDICATED STAFF MEMBER TO MANAGE SECTION 6 GRANT FUNDS  THIS INDIVIDUAL WILL BE THE DLNR POINT OF CONTACT FOR ALL SECTION 6GRANT RELATED ISSUES  THIS INDIVIDUAL ALSO SEEKS ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES RESEARCH AND RECOVERY

THE NON NATIVE LAKE TROUT SUPPRESSION IN UPPER PRIEST LAKE  UPL  PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON REDUCING THREATS TO ESA LISTED BULL TROUT  SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS  AND OTHER NATIVE FISH SPECIES BY REMOVING NON NATIVE LAKE TROUT FROMUPL  BULL TROUT IN UPL ARE LESS ABUNDANT THAN THEY HISTORICALLY WERE  LAKE TROUT EXPANSION IN UPL IS THE PRIMARY LIMITING FACTOR TO RECOVERY OF THIS BULL TROUT POPULATION  THEREFORE, LONG TERM PERSISTENCE OF BULL TROUT IN UPLIS DEPENDENT ON MINIMIZING LAKE TROUT ABUNDANCE TO THE GREATEST EXTENT POSSIBLE  SPRING GILLNETTING IS ANEFFECTIVE METHOD OF SUPPRESSING LAKE TROUT IN UPL  AS EVIDENCE, BULL TROUT REDD COUNTS IN UPL SPAWNING TRIBUTARIES ARE TRENDING POSITIVELY FOLLOWING IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT IN PRIOR YEARS  THIS PROJECT WILL EMPLOY A COMMERCIAL SCALE GILLNETTING EFFORT IN MAY 2023 TO MAXIMIZE ANNUAL REMOVAL OF LAKE TROUT FROM UPL  COMMERCIAL GILLNETTING SERVICES, INCLUDING AN 11 M RESEARCH VESSEL AND CREW, WILL BE CONTRACTED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT  MORE THAN 49 KM OF GILL NET EFFORT WILL BE APPLIED THROUGHOUT UPL IN A TWO WEEK PERIOD  VARIABLE GILLNET MESH SIZES WILL BE USED TO TARGET REMOVAL OF ALL SIZES OF LAKE TROUT  BASED ON IMPLEMENTATION IN PRIOR YEARS, WE ANTICIPATE REMOVAL OF 1,000 TO 3,000 LAKE TROUT IN THE TWO WEEK NETTING PERIOD  SUCCESS OF LAKE TROUT REMOVAL EFFORT WILL BE EVALUATED PRIMARILY USING TRENDS IN BULL TROUT REDD OBSERVATIONS IN PRIMARY SPAWNING TRIBUTARIES OF UPL  A STABLE TO INCREASING LONG TERM TREND IN REDDS COUNTED WILL BE AN INDICATION LAKE TROUT ARE BEING MANAGED EFFECTIVELY  IN ADDITION, TRENDS IN LAKE TROUT GILL NET CATCH RATE IN WILL PROVIDE A METRIC TO EVALUATE PROGRESS MADE TOWARD MANAGING LAKE TROUT EXPANSION IN UPL
GEOMORPHIC AND SEDIMENT ANALYSIS OF THE UPPER BRAZOS RIVER IN REPONSE TO SALTCEDAR CONTROL

THIS RESEARCH WILL GENERATE NEW DATA ON KEY PHYSIOLOGICAL TOLERANCES AND OTHER FUNCTIONAL TRAITS FOR MULTIPLE IMPERILED PLAINSFISH SPECIES, INCLUDING FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. THESE NEW FUNCTIONAL TRAIT DATA CAN BE USED TOMECHANISTICALLY UNDERSTAND FACTORS AFFECTING SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS FOR THESE IMPERILED SPECIES AS WELL AS TO MODEL SPECIESESPONSES TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. FURTHERMORE, WE WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO TEST FOR ADAPTIVE CAPACITY FOR A FEW SPECIES FOR WHICHPREVIOUS PHYSIOLOGICAL DATA EXIST FROM MORE THAN 20 YEARS AGO. OUR SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY STRUCTURED SAMPLING DESIGN WILLALLOW FOR ASSESSMENT OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIATION IN SPECIES TRAITS WHICH HAS MEANINGFUL IMPLICATIONS FOR CONSERVATIONACTIONS AND PLANNING. TOGETHER, FINDINGS FROM THIS WORK WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOVERY PLANS, AND PROVIDE TIMELY INFORMATION FOR LISTING DECISIONS FOR PETITIONED SPECIES. FINDINGS WILL CONTRIBUTE NEW TOOLS TO ENHANCE PRIORITY RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION OF PLAINS FISHES AND DIRECTLY INFORM CONSERVATION ACTIONS, SUCH AS THE NEED FOR INTERVENTIONS DURING PERIODS OF EXTREME DROUGHT AND IDENTIFYING POTENTIALLY RESILIENT STOCKS FOR REPATRIATION EFFORTS.

THE WHOOPING CRANE (GRUS AMERICANA) HAS BEEN SLOWLY RECOVERING FROM HISTORIC LOWS IN THE 1940S TO CURRENT POPULATION ESTIMATES OF ~500 INDIVIDUALS WINTERING IN TEXAS AND ~70 INDIVIDUALS IN THE NON-MIGRATORY POPULATION OF LOUISIANA. SINCE RECOVERY EFFORTS BEGAN FOR THE ARANSAS-WOOD BUFFALO POPULATION, CRANES HAVE PRIMARILY WINTERED AT ARANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND SURROUNDING AREAS. MORE RECENTLY, CRANES HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED OUTSIDE OF THESE AREAS AND SPECIFICALLY MORE INLAND IN UPLAND HABITAT AND NON-TRADITIONAL HABITAT INCLUDING AGRICULTURAL AREAS. DUE TO THESE RECENT CHANGES IN WINTERING HABITAT USE AND WITH RECOVERY GOALS OF POPULATION EXPANSION, THERE IS A CLEAR NEED TO IDENTIFY AND EXAMINE USE OF NON-TRADITIONAL HABITATS IN TEXAS BY BOTH THE WINTERING MIGRATORY POPULATION AND INDIVIDUALS FROM LOUISIANA THAT "STRAY' INTO TEXAS. USING EXISTING TELEMETRY DATA AND SPATIAL HABITAT LAYERS, WE WILL IDENTIFY AND ESTIMATE USE OF NON-TRADITIONAL HABITAT FOR WINTERING CRANES FROM THE TWO POPULATIONS TO PRIORITIZE LAND CONSERVATION FOR FUTURE POPULATION GROWTH AND PROVIDE SITING GUIDELINES FOR RENEWAL ENERGY PRODUCTION. PROJECT SUCCESS WILL BE DEFINED BY THE DEVELOPMENT AND PRODUCTION OF RELIABLE AND PREDICTIVE HABITAT MAPS (LAYERS) TO GUIDE WHOOPING CRANE RECOVERY AND ASSIST TPWD AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS IN CONSERVATION PLANNING ON PRIVATE AND NON-PRIVATE LANDS BALANCED AGAINST OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE DEMANDS INCLUDING RENEWABLE ENERGY.

THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) CONDUCT REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY AND SEED ECOLOGY STUDIES FOR HYMENOXYS TEXANA, AND 2) SURVEYPOPULATIONS TO ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZES FOR HYMENOXYS TEXANA. THESE TWO PROJECT GOALS WILL BE MET BY CONDUCTINGSITE VISITS TO KNOWN LOCATIONS THAT ARE ACCESSIBLE FOLLOWED BY GERMINATION STUDIES IN THE LABORATORY. THIS PROJECT WILLMEET THE PRIMARY FUNDING REQUEST POSTED BY TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT TO "INVESTIGATE THE REPRODUCTIVEBIOLOGY OF THE FEDERALLY LISTED TEXAS PRAIRIE DAWN (HYMENOXYS TEXANA)." IN PARTICULAR, THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS THEBREEDING SYSTEM OF THE SPECIES, WILL DOCUMENT POTENTIAL POLLINATORS, AND WILL INVESTIGATE THE SEED DISPERSAL MECHANISMS OF THE SPECIES. IN ADDITION, SEED GERMINATION STUDIES, AN ASSESSMENT OF PLOIDY, AND POPULATION COUNTS WILL BE CONDUCTED. LASTLY, FROM THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT AND ANY OTHER EXISTING DATA ON THE SPECIES, AN EVIDENCE-BASED RATIONALE SHOULD BE GIVEN FOR HOW THAT SPECIES' POPULATIONS CAN BE DELINEATED.

THOMAS AND ST. JOHN

THIS IS A SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA. HUMAN DISTURBANCE OF MATERNITY CAVES AND HIBERNACULA IS A SUBSTANTIAL CONTRIBUTOR TO THE HISTORIC AND PRESENT POPULATION DECLINES OF BATS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES AND THIS APPEARS TO BE A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR IN THE POPULATION DECLINES FOR OBLIGATE CAVE-DWELLING SPECIES LIKE THE OZARK BIG-EARED BAT (CORYNORHINUS TOWNSENDII INGENS) AND GRAY BAT (MYOTIS GRISESCENS). LOW REPRODUCTIVE RATES, LONG GENERATION TIMES AND CONCENTRATED POPULATIONS INHABITING A RELATIVELY SMALL NUMBER OF CAVES, MAKE THESE BAT POPULATIONS ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND SLOW TO RECOVER FROM THESE DISTURBANCES. THE MAJORITY OF CAVES KNOWN TO BE IMPORTANT TO OZARK BIG-EARED AND GRAY BATS OCCUR ON PRIVATE PROPERTY. SOME OF THESE ARE WELL PROTECTED BY THEIR OWNERS; HOWEVER, SOME ARE NOT AND EXPERIENCE PERIODIC HUMAN ENTRY OR DISTURBANCE. THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CAVE PROTECTION PLANS ARE NEEDED FOR SPECIFIC CAVES TO PROTECT THE REMAINING MATERNITY COLONIES AND HIBERNACULA. TWO PROTECTION TECHNIQUES VIEWED AS EFFICIENT METHODS OF DETERRING HUMAN DISTURBANCE WITHIN CAVES ARE 1) THE CONSTRUCTION OF CAMOUFLAGED FENCING AROUND CAVE ENTRANCES AND 2) THE CONSTRUCTION OF INTERNAL GATES OR GRILLS WITHIN CAVE PASSAGES.OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN PROTECTING GRAY BAT MATERNITY CAVES AND BOTH MATERNITY CAVES AND HIBERNACULA FOR THE OZARK BIG-EARED BAT. TO DATE, TWENTY- FOUR BIOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT CAVES, SOME WITH MULTIPLE ENTRANCES, HAVE BEEN GATED IN THE OKLAHOMA OZARKS. ALL OF THESE CAVES ARE MONITORED PERIODICALLY TO EVALUATE THEIR USE BY ENDANGERED BAT POPULATIONS. AN EQUALLY IMPORTANT ASPECT OF THIS PROJECT IS THE MONITORING OF BAT COLONIES AFTER THE CONSTRUCTION OF GATE/GRILL STRUCTURES IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN THE PROTECTIVE SYSTEMS AND TO DOCUMENT THE POPULATION RESPONSE OF THE BAT COLONIES WITHIN EACH CAVE. ADDITIONALLY, THERE IS A NEED TO CONDUCT BIOLOGICAL SURVEYS WITHIN OTHER CAVES IN THE OKLAHOMA OZARKS TO DETERMINE THEIR IMPORTANCE TO THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BATS, THE OZARK CAVEFISH AND A DIVERSITY OF RARE CAVE-DEPENDENT SPECIES SUCH CAVE CRAYFISH, GROTTO SALAMANDERS, AND SUBTERRANEAN AMPHIPODS AND ISOPODS. THESE SURVEYS ARE IMPORTANT TO ASSESS AND PRIORITIZE CAVES FOR FUTURE PROTECTION EFFORTS IN ORDER TO MAXIMIZE THE CONSERVATION BENEFITS FOR LISTED SPECIES AND SUBTERRANEAN BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY.THIS PROJECT SERVES MANY PURPOSES FOR CONSERVATION OF LISTED BAT SPECIES IN OKLAHOMA. THE PROTECTION OF MATERNITY COLONIES SHOULD RESULT IN GREATER SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION AND RECRUITMENT OF YOUNG BATS INTO THE LOCAL POPULATION. THE PROTECTION OF MAJOR HIBERNACULA SHOULD RESULT IN INCREASED ADULT OVER-WINTER SURVIVAL RATES FOR OZARK BIG-EARED BATS. THIS PROJECT SHOULD ALSO HELP INCREASE THE LOCAL OZARK BIG-EARED BAT AND GRAY BAT POPULATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIFIC CAVES AND MAY FACILITATE THE RECOLONIZATION OF NEW CAVES THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY INHABITED BY THESE SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO HELP TO EDUCATE CAVE OWNERS AND DEMONSTRATE TO THEM THE SIGNIFICANCE OF CAVES AND THE INTEREST THAT EXISTS FOR BATS AND THEIR CONSERVATION. POST-CONSTRUCTION MONITORING OF BAT COLONIES WILL DOCUMENT THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CAVE PROTECTION MEASURES. THE BIOLOGICAL INVENTORY OF NEW CAVES WILL IDENTIFY BIOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT CAVES FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND WILL ADD TO OUR OVERALL KNOWLEDGE OF THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF OZARK CAVE FAUNA.

THE COOPERATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION FUND  SECTION 6 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  PROVIDES FUNDING TO STATES AND TERRITORIES FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS ON LISTED, CANDIDATE, AND AT RISK SPECIES AND RARE HABITATS OCCURRING ON NON FEDERAL LANDS  THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES  LDWF  SEEKS 2022 2023 TRADITIONAL SECTION 6 FUNDING TO  1  ADMINISTER, PLAN, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ON ENDANGERED, THREATENED, AND AT RISK FLORA AND FAUNA OF THE STATE OF LOUISIANA   2  COORDINATE WITH USFWS, SEAFWA, AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS  AND  3  PARTICIPATE IN USFWS SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS  THE FUNDING WILL SUPPORT MONITORING EFFORTS FOR TWO FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES   THE LOUISIANA PINESNAKE  PITUOPHIS RUTHVENI  AND THE GOPHER TORTOISE  GOPHERUS POLYPHEMUS   PINESNAKE DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USING BOX TRAP ARRAYS AND CAMERA TRAP ARRAYS, AND THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO INFORM THE USFWS 5 YEAR REVIEW OF THE SPECIES  GOPHER TORTOISE SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN WASHINGTON, ST  TAMMANY, AND TANGIPAHOA PARISHES  THESE DATA WILL ALLOW BIOLOGISTS TO OBTAIN A MORE ACCURATE POPULATION ESTIMATE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE SPECIES IN THE STATE  LDWF ALSO SEEKS 2022 2023 TRADITIONAL SECTION 6 FUNDING TO SUPPORT SURVEY EFFORTS FOR BOG SPICEBUSH  LINDERA SUBCORIACEA , A SPECIES THAT IS CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW FOR LISTING BY USFWS  THIS PLANT IS EXPECTED TO UNDERGO A SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT BY 2024

THIS IS A SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA. THE FROSTED ELFIN, CALLOPHRYS IRUS, IS A BUTTERFLY IN THE FAMILY LYCAENIDAE (GOSSAMER-WING BUTTERFLIES) AND IS A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN IN NORTH AMERICA DUE TO RECENT PRECIPITOUS POPULATION DECLINE (USFWS-NY 2018). IT IS CURRENTLY BEING CONSIDERED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), WITH A RULING EXPECTED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2024.OKLAHOMA IS AT THE WESTERN PERIPHERY OF THE SPECIES RANGE IN NORTH AMERICA, WHERE A DISJUNCT SUBSPECIFIC POPULATION EXISTS. THE SUBSPECIES C. IRUS HADROS IS FOUND ONLY IN ARKANSAS, LOUISIANA, TEXAS, AND OKLAHOMA. FOCUS OF RESEARCH CAN FURTHER BE TURNED TO INVESTIGATION OF LIFE HISTORY, BEHAVIOR, AND ECOLOGY OF C. IRUS HADROS. MONITORING OF FROSTED ELFIN POPULATIONS IN OKLAHOMA WILL PROVIDE FOR MUCH NEEDED ADDITIONAL DATA FOR CALLOPHRYS IRUS HADROS. THOSE DATA WILL ALLOW US TO LEARN MORE OF THE LIFE HISTORY, BEHAVIOR, AND ECOLOGY OF THE HADROS SUBSPECIES. SOME OF THE ASPECTS WE HOPE TO INVESTIGATE FURTHER INCLUDE: HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS AND BIOGEOGRAPHICAL RELATIONSHIPS, LARVAL DEVELOPMENT AND PUPATION, AND GAINING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF MYRMECOPHILY (ANT ASSOCIATIONS) WITH FROSTED ELFINS. ALL OF THIS DATA GATHERING AND ANALYSES WILL AID THE USFWS IN ASSESSING THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE FROSTED ELFIN SO THEY CAN MAKE A RULING ON WHETHER THIS SPECIES SHOULD BE CONSIDERED THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ESA.

THE RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER (DRYOBATES BOREALIS, RCW) IS A FEDERALLY-ENDANGERED, COOPERATIVELY BREEDING SPECIES THAT INHABITS MATURE PINE SAVANNAHS AND WOODLANDS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. RCWS EXCLUSIVELY USE LIVING, MATURE PINES (PINUS SP.) FOR FORAGING AND CAVITY EXCAVATION. AT ITS WESTERNMOST RANGE PERIPHERY IN THE SOUTHCENTRAL U.S., TWO POPULATIONS OF RCWS OCCUR, ONE IN OKLAHOMA AND ONE IN ARKANSAS, WITH BOTH ON STATE AND FEDERAL LANDS WITHIN THE OUACHITA MOUNTAINS ECOREGION. BY THE MID-1970S, RCWS IN OKLAHOMA HAD DWINDLED TO FEWER THAN 30 FAMILY GROUPS WITHIN MCCURTAIN AND PUSHMATAHA COUNTIES. THE PRIMARY THREATS TO THESE REMAINING GROUPS ARE 1) HABITAT DEGRADATION DUE TO GRADUAL CHANGES IN VEGETATION STRUCTURE THAT OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF APPROXIMATELY 80 YEARS OF FIRE SUPPRESSION, AND 2) POOR NESTING SUCCESS DUE TO MULTIPLE FACTORS INCLUDING NEST DEPREDATION, CAVITY KLEPTOPARASITISM, REDUCED FOOD BASE AND POTENTIAL INBREEDING.SINCE 1992, THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC), WITH ASSISTANCE FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS), HAS WORKED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS ON THE MCWA WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING THE POPULATION OF RCWS ON THE AREA TO 45 BREEDING GROUPS. THESE EFFORTS INCLUDE ENHANCING EACH NESTING STAND BY PLACING PREDATOR GUARDS ON CAVITY TREES, PLACING RESTRICTOR PLATES AROUND EXISTING CAVITIES TO EXCLUDE LARGER WOODPECKER SPECIES (E.G. PILEATED WOODPECKER), AND INSTALLING ARTIFICIAL CAVITY INSERTS IN STANDS OF MATURE TREES ADJACENT TO EXISTING CAVITIES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF POTENTIAL NESTING AND ROOSTING SITES. THESE SAME MEASURES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED AT INACTIVE NESTING STANDS, CALLED RECRUITMENT STANDS, TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF SECURE, POTENTIAL NESTING AREAS INTO WHICH YOUNG WOODPECKERS MAY DISPERSE. IN COOPERATION WITH USFS, THE ODWC HAS ESTABLISHED A PRESCRIBED BURNING PROGRAM ON THE AREA THAT IS CONDUCTED DURING THE WINTER MONTHS IN THE PORTIONS OF THE MCWA THAT ARE DOMINATED BY MATURE SHORTLEAF PINES. THE REINTRODUCTION OF FIRE INTO THIS SYSTEM IS SLOWING REDUCING THE WOODY UNDERSTORY AND MID-STORY VEGETATION AND OVER TIME THIS WILL REDUCE THE COMPETITION FOR MOISTURE AND LIGHT FOR THE MATURE PINES. PRESCRIBED BURNING ALSO MAINTAINS AND RESTORES THE HERBACEOUS UNDERSTORY THAT ONCE OCCURRED WITHIN THE PINE-DOMINATED STANDS, THUS INCREASING THE INSECT PREY BASE FOR THE RCW POPULATION. DURING THE PAST 19 YEARS, THESE HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS HAVE STABILIZED THE POPULATION OF RCWS ON THE MCWA.THE DIRECT HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF RECRUITMENT STANDS SHOULD ULTIMATELY INCREASE THE CURRENT POPULATION SIZE AND LONG-TERM POPULATION VIABILITY OF RED-COCKADED WOODPECKERS (RCW) IN OKLAHOMA. GIVEN THE POTENTIAL FOR LOCAL RCW WOODPECKER DISPERSAL, THIS PROJECT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE SPECIES POPULATION SIZE AND GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN THE LARGER META-POPULATION THAT EXISTS WITHIN THE OUACHITA MOUNTAINS OF OKLAHOMA AND ARKANSAS. ON-GOING SHORTLEAF PINE/BLUESTEM SAVANNAH RESTORATION ON THOUSANDS OF ACRES OF OUACHITA NATIONAL FOREST LAND SURROUNDING THE MCCURTAIN COUNTY WILDERNESS AREA WILL ULTIMATELY CREATE NEW HABITAT INTO WHICH WOODPECKERS CAN DISPERSE. EXPANSION OF THE MCWA WOODPECKER POPULATION IS NEEDED TO HELP THE PINE/BLUESTEM SAVANNAH ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION REACH ITS FULL POTENTIAL.

GRANT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THE 20178 MEXICAN WOLF RECOVERY PLAN. EFFORTS INCLUDE REPATRIATION OF MEXICAN WOLVES TO IMPROVE GENETIC RESILIENCY THROUGHOUT THE HISTORICAL RANGE OF THE SPECIES. ACTIVITIES WILL PRIMARILY INCLUDE FOSTERING OF PUPS FROM CAPTIVITY INTO SUITABLE WILD DENS. GRANT FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT ANNUAL CENSUS EFFORTS TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES TOWARDS MEETING RECOVERY CRITERIA.

WEST VIRGINIA IS HOME TO SEVERAL FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES INCLUDING THREE BATS (A FOURTH LISTED BAT IS CONSIDERED ACCIDENTAL IN THE STATE), TEN FRESHWATER MUSSELS, TWO CRAYFISH, A TERRESTRIAL SNAIL, AN AQUATIC CAVE ISOPOD, TWOFISH, A BUMBLE BEE, AND A TERRESTRIAL SALAMANDER. TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF THESE SPECIES, AND TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY ACTIONS, POPULATION TREND AND HEALTH INFORMATION IS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT PLANNED SURVEYS AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES FOR FEDERALLY LISTED ANIMALS IN WEST VIRGINIA. SURVEYS ANDMONITORING HAVE BEEN CAREFULLY PLANNED USING POWER ANALYSIS, SIMULATION STUDIES, AND OTHER ADVANCED STATISTICAL TECHNIQUES TO ALLOW FOR RELIABLE DETECTION OF CHANGES IN SPECIES' STATUS AND/OR DISTRIBUTION IN WEST VIRGINIA. FOR SPECIES THAT OCCUR IN MULTIPLE STATES, ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN PLANNED AS RELEVANT WITH REGIONAL AND INTER-STATE WORKING GROUPS AND PARTNERS. IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS WORK DIRECTLY ADDRESSES RECOVERY OBJECTIVES FOR ALL COVERED SPECIES.

TITLE: RECOVERY AND RESEARCH OF THE THREE FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES IN NH IN FFY2022;SMALL WHORLED POGONIA (ISOTRIA MEDEOLOIDES), JESUPS MILK VETCH (ASTRAGALUS ROBBINSII VAR. JESUPII) AND NORTHEASTERN BULRUSH (SCIRPUS ANCISTROCHAETUS.THIS PROJECT INVOLVES WORKING WITH LANDOWNERS TO CONDUCT SURVEYS ON THEIR PROPERTY TO LOOK FOR KNOWN POPULATIONS OF 1 FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES THAT IS ONLY FOUND ALONG THE CT RIVER AND NOWHERE ELSE ON THE PLANET(JESUP'S MILK VETCH).  ALSO, SCIENTISTS WILL SEARCH FOR POPULATIONS OF 1 FEDERALLY THREATENED PLANT (ORCHID) SPECIES (SMALL WHORLED POGONIA) AND 1 SPECIES (NORTHEASTERN BULRUSH) THAT HAS BEEN PROPOSED TO BE DELISTED FROM THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT.  SCIENTISTS WILL RETURN TO SITES THAT HAVE KNOWN POPULATIONS AND WILL COUNT STEMS AS WELL AS FRUIT OF JESUP'S MILK VETCH AND SMALL WHORLED POGONIA.  WITH LANDOWNER PERMISSION, THEY WILL ALSO LOOK FOR NEW POPULATIONS.  THIS DATA WILL ASSIST IN ASSESSING POPULATION VIABILITY OF EACH SPECIES.

HE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (PRDNER) IS THE STATE AGENCY WITH THE MANDATE TO PROTECT AND CONSERVE THE PUERTO RICOS NATURAL RESOURCES.  THE PRDNER ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM IS IN CHARGE OF COORDINATING THE EFFORTS DIRECTED TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT THE SPECIES LISTED AS ENDANGERED OR THREATENED.  CURRENTLY THERE ARE SEVERAL PROJECTS BEING IMPLEMENTED TO RESTORE SOME OF THESE SPECIES POPULATION AND RESEARCH THAT SEEKS TO OBTAIN INFORMATION NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND HOW TO SUPPORT THE SPECIES POPULATION SUCH AS REDUCING THREATS, ENHANCING REPRODUCTION OR REQUIREMENTS FOR A SPECIES TO GROW.  TO DETERMINE HOW TO BETTER USE THE FUNDS, PRDNER STAFF DISCUSS CURRENT INFORMATION AND EFFORTS AND IDENTIFY THE GAPS AND NEEDS FOR THE LISTED SPECIES.  AS A RESULT, THE FOLLOWING TASKS ARE PROPOSED FOR THE NEXT SECTION 6 SEGMENT: (1) COORDINATE THE ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM (2) SUPPORT THE RESPONSE TO STRANDED MANATEES (3) PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THE RECOVERY ACTIONS WITH THE PUERTO RICAN CRESTED TOAD (4) CONTINUE MONITORING THE MONA GROUND IGUANA AND THE VI BOA THROUGH SURVEYS TO ESTABLISH TRENDS IN THE POPULATION (5) CONDUCT A SURVEY USING A DRONE (NOT PURCHASE WITH SECTION 6 FUNDS) TO IDENTIFY THE PRESENCE OF GREEN IGUANAS, AN INVASIVE SPECIES THREATENED THE MONA GROUND IGUANA, TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THEIR NATURAL BEHAVIOR OF ROOSTING IN TREE BRANCHES AT CERTAIN TIME DURING THE DAY TO DESIGN ERADICATION STRATEGIES (6) TO PROVIDE MAINTENANCE TO THE EXCLUSION FENCE IN MONA THAT PREVENTS SEA TURTLE AND MONA GROUND IGUANA NEST FAILURE DUE TO PREDATION (7) TO REFURBISH AND MAINTAIN A PLANT NURSERY AT MONA TO CONDUCT HABITAT RESTORATION OF THE NESTING AREAS (8) TO DESIGN THE METHODOLOGY AND CONDUCT A SURVEY OF THE MONA ISLAND BOA, CHILABOTHRUS MONENSIS, WHOSE STATUS IS UNKNOWN (9) CONTINUE THE PROJECT THAT PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF THE SHARP-SHINNED HAWK, ACCIPITER STRIATUS VENATOR, AND THE YELLOW-SHOULDERED BLACKBIRD, AGELAIUS XANTHOMUS, AND (10) CONTINUING REINTRODUCTION OF POLYSTICHUM CALDERONENSE AND CYATHEA DRYOPTEROIDES TO NATURAL HABITAT IN PUERTO RICO, ADDING ELAPHOGLOSSUM SERPENS.REGARDING THE SSH THE PROJECT AIMS TO SEARCH AND SURVEY FOR INDIVIDUALS AND NEW TERRITORIAL PAIRS AND REVISIT KNOWN TERRITORIES TO DETERMINE POPULATION STATUS AND IDENTIFY NESTING PAIRS; SELECT HALF OF THE NESTING PAIRS FOR PROPAGATION AND COLLECT AND ARTIFICIALLY INCUBATE THEIR EGGS, HATCH AND RAISE THE YOUNG IN CAPTIVITY THEN RELEASE YOUNG BACK TO THE WILD BY HACKING AND MONITOR THEM TO DETERMINE SURVIVAL; AND MONITOR WILD NESTING PAIRS AND TREAT NESTS FOR NEST FLY (PHILORNIS) PARASITISM TO PREVENT NESTLING MORTALITY AND  INCREASE THE HAWKS PRODUCTIVITY.FOR THE YSBL, BESIDES CONTINUING THAT ACTIVITIES THAT MANAGE THE ARTIFICIAL NESTING STRUCTURES (ANS) IN THE WEST, WE WOULD LIKE TO EXPAND THE PLACEMENT OF ANS TO CEIBA AND SALINAS AND CONDUCT SHINY COWBIRD CONTROL AT CEIBA, BASED ON THE OBSERVATIONS OF THE PREVIOUS STUDY.TO MONITOR THE POPULATION TREND, SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED AT THE MAIN AREAS WHERE THE YSBL HAS BEEN REPORTED.  ANOTHER TASK OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE THE SURVEYS AT CEIBA, SALINAS AND IN THE SOUTHWEST. THE GRANT WILL ALSO PROVIDE FUNDS FOR 10% OF THE SALARY OF THE COORDINATOR.  THE COORDINATOR HAS THE DUTY OF PREPARING AND SUBMITTING THE REQUIRED REPORTS FOR THE GRANT AS WELL AS OVERSEEING ITS IMPLEMENTATION.  IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR MAINTAINING COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS, SEEKING COLLABORATORS FOR ONGOING INITIATIVES, ADDRESSING EMERGING ISSUES THAT COULD AFFECT LISTED SPECIES OR THEIR HABITAT, AND SUPPORT AND IMPLEMENT ON GOING STRATEGIES FOR THE RECOVERY OF THE LISTED SPECIES.   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESTHIS PROJECT WILL RENDER THE REPORTS, DATABASE AND DOCUMENTS REQUIRED AND NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT THE GRANT, IN ADDITION TO DATA NEEDED FOR ADEQUATE MANAGEMENT.  WE EXPECT THE GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION OF AN ARRAY OF LISTED SPECIES.

TWO FEDERALLY LISTED BATS, AND TWO BATS CURRENTLY UNDERGOING STATUS REVIEW, OCCUR IN PENNSYLVANIA (PA): INDIANA BAT, NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT, LITTLE BROWN BAT, AND TRICOLORED BAT. TWO FEDERALLY LISTED BIRDS ALSO OCCUR IN THE COMMONWEALTH: PIPING PLOVER AND RED KNOT. THE GAME COMMISSION IS REQUESTING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO IMPLEMENT RECOVERY PLANS FOR THESE LISTED SPECIES. WITH THE SUPPORT OF SECTION 6 FUNDING, THE GAME COMMISSION WILL CONTINUE OUR WORK TO DEVELOP CUTTING EDGE PLACE-BASED RESPONSE TO WNS, INCLUDING: CONDUCTING SURVEYS TO REFINE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF INDIANA BAT FALL MIGRATION, CONTINUED TESTING OF NOVEL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES SUCH AS CLIMATE MANIPULATION, IMPLEMENTING HABITAT PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT, WORKING TO IMPLEMENT VITAL RESEARCH FROM COLLABORATORS WITHIN THE WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME RESPONSE TEAM, AND CONTINUING PGC'S SUCCESSFUL WORK TO DEVELOP AND EVALUATE TREATMENTS FOR WNS. GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVERS ARE A CRITICALLY ENDANGERED POPULATION AND A 2C RECOVERY PRIORITY FOR THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. SINCE 2007, THE GAME COMMISSION HAS COORDINATED A PIPING PLOVER AND COMMON TERN RECOVERY PARTNERSHIP, COMPRISED OF FEDERAL, STATE, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS. CONTINUED SUCCESS OF PIPING PLOVERS IN PENNSYLVANIA, AND THE ADVANCES CONTRIBUTING TO SPECIES RECOVERY, IS DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE GAME COMMISSION'S CAPACITY TO COORDINATE AND SUPPORT THE ACTIVITIES OF MULTI-AGENCY PARTNERS, SUCH AS PRESQUE ISLE STATE PARK'S HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES, REGULAR SHOREBIRD MONITORING TO DETECT BREEDING INDIVIDUALS. DETECTION OF BIRDS TRIGGERS A CASCADE OF MULTI-PARTNER ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PROTECTING NESTS WITH PREDATOR EXCLOSURES, INSTALLATION OF REMOTE CAMERAS TO DETECT THREATS, IMMEDIATE RESPONSE TO NEST FLOODING AND OTHER THREATS, AND COLOR BANDING OF ADULTS AND CHICKS TO CONTRIBUTE TO GREAT LAKES BASIN PIPING PLOVER STUDIES RELATED TO SURVIVAL, RECRUITMENT, DISPERSAL, AND ECOLOGY. THE RECOVERY ACTIONS OUTLINED IN THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL WILL CONTRIBUTE TO REDUCING THE RISK OF POSSIBLE EXTIRPATION FROM PA AND EXTINCTION OF THESE SPECIES IN THE WILD, WHILE THE RESULT OF TAKING NO ACTION WILL BE THE CONTINUED OR INCREASED RATE OF DECLINE AMONG THESE IMPERILED BAT AND SHOREBIRD SPECIES.

ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR TWO ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES (HARPERELLA, SHALE BARREN ROCKCRESS), MANAGEMENT PLANNING AND POST DE-LISTING MONITORING EFFORTS FOR RUNNING BUFFALO CLOVER, AND UPDATING THE STATUS OF AN AT-RISK SPECIES IN WEST VIRGINIA (TENNESSEE PONDWEED). FIELD WORK WILL INCLUDE MONITORING EXTANT OCCURRENCES, VALIDATING HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELS, AND CONDUCTING DE NOVO SURVEYS. PLANNING EFFORT WILL BRING THE MONONGAHELA NATIONAL FOREST INTO COMPLIANCE WITH THE NATIONAL FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN. HERBARIUM WORK WILL FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING POSSIBLE TENNESSEE PONDWEED VOUCHER SPECIMENS. FIELD AND LAB RESULTS WILL INFORM HSM DEVELOPMENT, INFORM SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, AND ACCOMPLISH RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR LISTED AND RECENTLY DE-LISTED SPECIES.

WE PROPOSE IMPLEMENTATION OF TWELVE PROJECTS TO AID CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY FOR MULTIPLE SPECIES WITHIN TENNESSEE. PROJECTS ADDRESS PROPAGATION, INTRODUCTION OF SPECIES INTO SUITABLE HABITATS WITHIN THEIR HISTORIC RANGES, SPECIES STATUS SURVEYS, ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE GENETIC HEALTH AND POPULATION STRUCTURE, ENHANCEMENT OR RESTORATION OF HABITAT, AND DEVELOPMENT OF MONITORING AND CONSERVATION PLANS.PROJECT SUMMARIES: E5-26 - RARE FISH PROPAGATION - PROPAGATION AND INTRODUCTION OF SPECIES INTO SUITABLE HABITATS: PROPOSED WORK IS IN LINE WITH THE FOLLOWING RECOVERY TASKS FOR EACH SPECIES: SMOKY MADTOM-P1: 3.1,3.2; YELLOWFIN MADTOM-P3: 2.2, 2.3; SPOTFIN CHUB-P3: 2.2,2.3,5; DUSKYTAIL (CITICO) DARTER-P1: 6, P2: 10; BOULDER DARTER-P1: 3, P2: 4; BARRENS TOPMINNOW-N/A (RECOVERY OUTLINE); E5-25 RARE MUSSEL MANAGEMENT, $34,752.48 - SPECIES STATUS SURVEYS, INTRODUCTION OF SPECIES INTO SUITABLE HABITATS, PROPAGATION, RESEARCH, MONITORING: PROPOSED WORK IS IN LINE WITH THE FOLLOWING RECOVERY TASKS FOR EACH SPECIES: OYSTER MUSSEL - P1: 4.1,4.2,4.4,4.5,4.7; CUMBERLANDIAN COMBSHELL - P1: 4.1,4.2,4.4,4.5,4.7; DROMEDARY PEARLYMUSSEL - P3: 2.2,2.3,2.4; ALABAMA LAMPMUSSEL - P2: 1.1.1; BIRDWING PEARLYMUSSEL - P3: 2.2, 2.3, 2.4; PINK MUCKET - P2: 1.1; SNUFFBOX - N/A (RECOVERY OUTLINE); A REASSESSMENT OF THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE PALE LILLIPUT - SPECIES STATUS SURVEYS: RECOVERY TASKS FROM THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR A FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THIS RESEARCH, WHICH WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS RECOVERY OBJECTIVES (1.2.1); (1.2.2); (2.1 & 2.2). LIFE HISTORY, STATUS, AND TRENDS INFORMATION WILL HAVE DIRECT RELEVANCE FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR FOCUS SPECIES - FEDERALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES - THE PALE LILLIPUT, A SOUTHEASTERN ENDEMIC; THE SOUTHEAST REGION IS THE LEAD REGION FOR A RECOVERY PLAN;
