THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND AID IN THE RECOVERY OF POPULATIONS OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT RISK SPECIES WITHIN THE COMMONWEALTH. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE HABITAT ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT TO IMPROVE FROSTED ELFIN HABITAT; INVENTORY, MONITORING, MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION OF THE NORTHERN RED-BELLIED COOTER; AND EVALUATION OF POPULATION LEVEL RESPONSES TO HABITAT CHANGES THROUGH STANDARDIZED POPULATION ASSESSMENTS OF AT-RISK TURTLES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE PROTECTION AND RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT-RISK SPECIES WITHIN MASSACHUSETTS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES PROPOSED.

THE PLANT CONSERVATION PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE OR EXPAND MONITORING EFFORTS TO FILL IN DATA GAPS FOR SELECTED OCCURRENCES AND SITES. WHENEVER POSSIBLE, MONITORING EFFORTS AND HABITAT RESTORATION WILL TAKE PLACE ON PLANT CONSERVATION PRESERVES. THE PROGRAM WILL ALSO CONTINUE ONGOING PERMITTING, CONDUCT PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PLANS, AS WELL AS IMPLEMENTATION OF SPECIES-SPECIFIC PRIORITY PROJECTS.THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS ARE CURRENTLY PLANNED UNDER THIS AWARD:STATEWIDE IMPERILED SPECIES MONITORINGHABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENTREGULATORY PROGRAMS AND PROTECTED PLANT PERMITSPUBLIC OUTREACHIMPERILED PLANT PROTECTION PROJECTSMANAGEMENT PLANS FOR PCP PRESERVES

THE REQUESTED GRANT AWARD AMOUNT IS $137,937, OF WHICH THE FEDERAL SHARE IS $102,550. THE MATCHING SHARE OF $35,387 WILL BE PAID BY THE STATE LANDS DIVISION OF THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND SUBRECIPIENTS. WE ARE REQUESTING THAT THE GRANT AWARD PERIOD RUN FROM OCTOBER 1, 2022 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 2023.THIS AWARD SUPPORTS MULTIPLE PROJECTS TO CONSERVE PLANT SPECIES PROTECTED UNDER THE ESA. TARGET SPECIES INCLUDE THE APALACHICOLA WILD INDIGO (BAPTISIA MEGACARPA), SUN-FACING CONEFLOWER (RUDBECKIA HELIOPSIDIS), APIOS PRICEANA, AND CLEMATIS MOREFIELDII, AND FLORIDA WILLOW (SALIX FLORIDANA).

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR SPECIES THAT ARE FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE. THERE ARE SEVEN SPECIES OF WILDLIFE LISTED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) WHICH OCCUR, OR HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO OCCUR IN NEW HAMPSHIRE. FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO IMPLEMENT RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY (LYCAEIDIS MELISSA SAMUELIS), ROSEATE TERN (STERNA DOUGALLII), DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL (ALASMIDONTA HETERODON) AND FEDERALLY THREATENED PIPING PLOVER (CHARADRIUS MELODUS). RECOVERY ACTIONS INCLUDE MONITORING (E.G., DOCUMENTING BREEDING SUCCESS), MANAGEMENT (E.G., ERECTING SYMBOLIC FENCE), TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND A CAPTIVE POPULATION PROGRAM. PROPOSED ACTIONS WILL BENEFIT THESE LISTED SPECIES.

MAINE'S POPULATION OF PIPING PLOVERS CONTINUES TO EXHIBIT HIGH PRODUCTIVITY COMPARED TO POPULATIONS IN OTHER ATLANTIC COAST STATES. THIS SUCCESS IS IN DESPITE OF INTENSE RECREATIONAL USE OF THE FINITE SAND BEACH HABITATS AVAILABLE TO PLOVERS IN MAINE. RECENT SUCCESS IS LARGELY A RESULT OF INCREASED INVOLVEMENT OF LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES WITH OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP OF STATE, FEDERAL AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS TO BUILD UPON THE EFFECTIVE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOVERY PROGRAM. THIS INVESTMENT OF AN AGGRESSIVE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES DESIGNATING OFF-LIMITS AREAS FOR BEACHGOERS; ERECTING ENCLOSURES AROUND ACTIVE NESTS; AND PREDATOR CONTROL MEASURES HAS LED TO RECENT RECORD-SETTING POPULATION ABUNDANCE THAT FEW WOULD HAVE ANTICIPATED IN THE RECENT PAST. BY CONTINUING DIRECT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ACROSS MAINE'S PLOVER NESTING AREAS, THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE AND MAINE AUDUBON SOCIETY HOPE THAT HIGH PRODUCTIVITY IN 2022 WILL ONCE AGAIN CONTRIBUTE BIRDS TO THE ATLANTIC COAST POPULATION AND BRING PARTNERS CLOSER TO ACHIEVING RECOVERY GOALS FOR THIS SPECIES.

TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE FEDERALLY LISTED, CANDIDATE OR AT-RISK WILDLIFE, THE ALABAMA DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES MUST CONDUCT RESEARCH AND SURVEYS TO GAIN INFORMATIONAL DATA ON THESE SPECIES' POPULATION STATUS, HABITAT, AND MOVEMENT TO MAKE INFORMED DECISION REGARDING CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECOVERY NEEDS. THIS ANNUAL ALABAMA SECTION 6 ENDANGERED SPECIES GRANT WILL FUND VARIOUS RESEARCH, SURVEY, MONITORING PROJECTS AS WELL AS MANAGEMENT TOWARD HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS AND RECOVERY EFFORTS. THE ASSOCIATED GRANT PROJECTS HAVE VARIED OBJECTIVES RELATING TO CURRENT FEDERALLY LISTED OR AT-RISK SPECIES INFORMATION NEEDS THAT WILL ASSIST WITH SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS NECESSARY TO SUSTAIN VIABLE POPULATIONS IN ALABAMA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH, MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT PROJECTS THAT HAVE DIRECT CONSERVATION BENEFITS FOR FEDERAL LISTED, RECENTLY DELISTED, AND CANDIDATE PLANT SPECIES THAT ARE FOUND IN TENNESSEE. MANY OF THESE PLANT SPECIES ARE ONLY KNOWN FROM TENNESSEE. ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS GRANT WILL CONSIST OF THE MONITORING AND IMPROVEMENT OF PLANT POPULATIONS THROUGH DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MAINTENANCE, AND THE CONTINUATION OF RE-INTRODUCTION AND SEED COLLECTION EFFORTS WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THREE FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES HAVE BEEN RECOVERED THROUGH THIS LONGSTANDING GRANT PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE STATE OF TENNESSEE.

THE TAR RIVER SPINYMUSSEL (PARVASPINA STEINSTANSANA), DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL (ALASMIDONTA HETERODON), YELLOW LANCE (ELLIPTIO LANCEOLATA), CAROLINA HEELSPLITTER (LASMIGONA DECORATA), CAPE FEAR SHINER (NOTROPIS MEKISTOCHOLAS), WACCAMAW SILVERSIDE (MENIDIA EXTENSA), SPOTFIN CHUB (CYPRINELLA MONACHA), LITTLEWING PEARLYMUSSEL (PEGIAS FABULA), APPALACHIAN ELKTOE (ALASMIDONTA RAVENELIANA) AND, JAMES SPINYMUSSEL (PARVASPINA COLLINA), ATLANTIC PIGTOE (FUSCONAIA MASONI), CAROLINA MADTOM (NOTURUS FURIOSUS) AND ROANOKE LOGPERCH (PERCINA REX) ARE FEDERALLY LISTED FRESHWATER SPECIES IN NORTH CAROLINA. ONLY 2 VIABLE POPULATIONS OF THE TAR RIVER SPINYMUSSEL EXIST IN THE TAR RIVER BASIN. THE DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL AND YELLOW LANCE OCCUR IN THE TAR AND NEUSE RIVER BASINS; HOWEVER, THE DISTRIBUTION OF BOTH SPECIES HAS BEEN GREATLY REDUCED IN THE NEUSE RIVER BASIN. THE CAROLINA HEELSPLITTER OCCURS IN ONLY 2 CREEKS IN OUR STATE. ATLANTIC PIGTOE OCCUR IN THE YADKIN-PEE DEE, CAPE FEAR, TAR, NEUSE, AND ROANOKE RIVER BASINS, BUT ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION IS GREATLY REDUCED, PARTICULARLY IN THE YADKIN-PEE DEE AND CAPE FEAR BASINS. BOTH THE CAPE FEAR SHINER AND WACCAMAW SILVERSIDE ARE ENDEMIC TO NORTH CAROLINA AND OCCUR IN RELATIVELY SMALL AREAS OF THE STATE. THE SPOTFIN CHUB, APPALACHIAN ELKTOE, AND LITTLEWING PEARLYMUSSEL ARE NATIVE TO THE TENNESSEE RIVER BASIN IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA. THE CAROLINA MADTOM IS ENDEMIC TO THE TAR AND NEUSE RIVER BASINS, BUT POPULATIONS HAVE SIGNIFICANTLY DECLINED. THE ROANOKE LOGPERCH HAS RECENTLY BEEN DISCOVERED IN A FEW LOCATIONS IN THE ROANOKE RIVER BASIN IN NORTH CAROLINA. SIGNIFICANT POINT AND NONPOINT SOURCES OF POLLUTION EXIST IN THESE AREAS, AND THE POTENTIAL FOR NEW LAND AND WATER USE MODIFICATIONS EXISTS IN ALL HABITAT AREAS. UP-TO-DATE POPULATION AND DISTRIBUTION DATA ARE REQUIRED TO ASSIST LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS WITH THE CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES. ALSO, RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGH CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND TRANSLOCATION WILL BE UTILIZED AS APPROPRIATE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE INITIATION AND CONTINUATION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES MONITORING, RESEARCH AND RECOVERY PROJECTS TO GUIDE AND ENHANCE CONSERVATION ACTIONS. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO COLLECT, ANALYZE, AND DISSEMINATE BIOLOGICAL AND POPULATION INFORMATION NECESSARY FOR THE SOUND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF ENDANGERED SPECIES IN MARYLAND AND TO IMPLEMENT APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO RECOVER THESE ENDANGERED POPULATIONS.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO MONITOR AND MANAGE NEW JERSEY'S POPULATIONS AND HABITATS OF FEDERALLY ENDANGERED AND THREATENED WILDLIFE SPECIES AND MONITOR POPULATION RESPONSE TO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS UNDERTAKEN TO RESTORE THEIR POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION, RESEARCH AND MONITORING ON THE HEALTH, ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF RED KNOTS AND PIPING PLOVERS IN NEW JERSEY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE COLLECTION OF SCIENTIFIC DATA TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT WILL SUPPORT NEW JERSEY FISH AND WILDLIFE'S MISSION TO PROTECT AND MANAGE THE STATE'S FISH AND WILDLIFE AND MAXIMIZE ITS LONG-TERM BIOLOGICAL, RECREATIONAL AND ECONOMIC VALUES FOR ALL NEW JERSEYANS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO VIEW AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.
FY22 SECTION 6 GRANT-IN-AID PROJECTS (E-15-22)
E-1-37 SURVEYING, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT-RISK PLANTS IN KENTUCKY (STUDY 156-163)

WITH SEVERAL YEARS OF KENTUCKY MONARCH CONSERVATION PLAN (KMCP) IMPLEMENTATION UNDERWAY THROUGH ON THE GROUND CONSERVATION WORK AND EDUCATION, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE CONTINUE TO INVEST RESOURCES TO ENSURE HIGH IMPACT ENGAGEMENT WITH OUR PUBLIC AND PARTNERS. MAINTAINING SUPPORT FOR THE KMCP WILL ENSURE CONTINUED ACTION AND TARGETED CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN KENTUCKY THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITHIN OUR ACTIVE STAKEHOLDER GROUP.PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES: 1.SERVE ON THE MAFWA STATE MONARCH TECHNICAL TEAM TO AID IN IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MID-AMERICA MONARCH CONSERVATION STRATEGY (MAMCS) AND PARTICIPATE IN THE ONGOING STRATEGY EDITING PROCESS. 2.IMPLEMENTATION OF THE KMCP.

SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACH SURVEY PROGRAMS IN FLORIDA ARE OVERSEEN BY THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH INSTITUTE (FWRI) OF THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION (FWC). THE GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO FACILITATE AND OVERSEE NESTING BEACH SURVEYS THAT PROVIDE THE LONG-TERM DATA NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY ASSESS SEA TURTLE NESTING ACTIVITY AND NEST SUCCESS TRENDS ON FLORIDA BEACHES. STANDARDIZED, SYSTEMATIC SURVEYS OF SEA TURTLE NESTING IN FLORIDA ARE NEEDED TO CONTINUE ASSESSMENTS OF NESTING DISTRIBUTION, NESTING SEASONALITY, RELATIVE NESTING DENSITIES, AND HATCHLING PRODUCTION, AND TO MONITOR LONG-TERM TRENDS IN FLORIDA NESTING POPULATIONS. THESE ASSESSMENTS PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACHES. THERE ARE THREE NESTING BEACH SURVEY PROGRAMS IN FLORIDA. THE STATEWIDE NESTING BEACH SURVEY (SNBS) IS NEEDED TO ACQUIRE COMPLETE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL NESTING DISTRIBUTIONS OF THE VARIOUS SPECIES OF MARINE TURTLES THAT NEST ON FLORIDA BEACHES. THE INDEX NESTING BEACH SURVEY (INBS) PROGRAM IS NEEDED TO EXAMINE NESTING TRENDS. THE NEST ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (NPA) IS NEEDED TO ESTIMATE ANNUAL HATCHLING PRODUCTION (I.E., RECRUITMENT), AND IDENTIFY SOURCES OF EGG MORTALITY. ASSOCIATED WORK INVOLVES THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF THE WEB- AND MOBILE-BASED REPORTING PLATFORM FOR NESTING DATA THAT WILL STREAMLINE DATA ENTRY FOR ALL THREE PROGRAMS. A NETWORK OF TRAINED SURVEYORS (I.E., PERMIT HOLDERS AND AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL) FROM A VARIETY OF ORGANIZATIONS CONDUCTS NESTING BEACH SURVEYS AND NEST FATE EVALUATIONS UNDER FWRI GUIDANCE AND TRAINING FOLLOWING PROCEDURES DESCRIBED IN THE FWC MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION HANDBOOK. FWRI STAFF WILL (I) CONDUCT ANNUAL WORKSHOPS FOR PERMIT HOLDERS AND AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL TO REVIEW NESTING BEACH SURVEY AND NEST EVALUATION METHODOLOGIES AND PROTOCOLS; (II) CONDUCT SITE-VISITS OF SURVEY AREAS DURING THE NESTING SEASON AND MEET WITH THE LOCAL PERSONNEL TO ADDRESS ANY ISSUES RELATED TO PROPERLY FOLLOWING METHODOLOGIES AND PROTOCOLS AS THEY ARISE AND TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL HANDS-ON TRAINING AND; (III) CONTINUE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE STREAMLINED WEB- AND MOBILE-BASED NESTING DATA COLLECTION APPLICATION AND PROVIDE TRAINING TO THOSE WHO WILL BE USING THIS APPLICATION. AT THE END OF THIS PROJECT, WE ANTICIPATE THE COMPLETION OF ANOTHER YEAR OF HIGH-QUALITY NESTING BEACH SURVEY WORK AND AN ENHANCEMENT OF OUR ABILITIES TO MORE QUICKLY AND COMPLETELY ENTER AND EVALUATE ALL THE ASSOCIATED DATA AS WELL AS PROVIDING THESE DATA IN ANNUAL REPORTS TO ALL INTERESTED PARTIES.
SC ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM - RESEARCH, MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF THE NORTHERN RECOVERY UNIT OF THE LOGGERHEAD SEA TURTLE (CARETTA CARETTA) ON BEACHES IN SOUTH CAROLINA.

IN THIS GRANT, 12 PROJECTS ARE PROPOSED THAT DIRECTLY HELP CONSERVE AT LEAST 25 SPECIES OF FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS AND AT LEAST 12 AT-RISK PLANT SPECIES. THESE PROJECTS SPAN FROM THE NORTHWESTERN FLORIDA PANHANDLE TO THE SOUTHEASTERN FLORIDA ATLANTIC COASTAL RIDGE. TWO STATE-FUNDED PROJECTS PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR TWO STAFF POSITIONS WITHIN THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND CONSUMER SERVICES' FLORIDA FOREST SERVICE; ONE STAFF TO ADMINISTER THE PROGRAM AND CONDUCT RARE PLANT CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND ONE TO HELP CONSERVE 15 FEDERALLY LISTED PLANTS AND ONE FEDERALLY LISTED LICHEN WITHIN ONE STATE FOREST. PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS PROPOSE PROJECTS WHICH AID IN THE RECOVERY OF THE RAREST PLANT SPECIES IN FLORIDA, ALONG WITH THEIR HABITATS. THESE ORGANIZATIONS INCLUDE THREE BOTANICAL GARDENS, A BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH STATION, THE STATE HERITAGE PROGRAM FOR FLORIDA, AND TWO CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS.IN THIS GRANT, THE PROGRAM SEEKS ITS 31ST YEAR OF FUNDING FOR FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT CONSERVATION IN FLORIDA. THE TWO STAFF POSITIONS WITH THE FDACS FLORIDA FOREST SERVICE HAVE BEEN FUNDED ANNUALLY SINCE THE EARLIEST YEARS OF THE PROGRAM, STARTING IN 1991. FUNDING ALLOCATED FOR THE PROGRAM OVER THE PAST 30 YEARS HAS SUPPORTED NUMEROUS RESEARCHERS, LAND MANAGERS, AND CONSERVATIONISTS. IN RETROSPECT, THE PROGRAM HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN RECOVERING SOME SPECIES AND PROVIDING FUNDS TO HELP RECOVER MANY OTHERS. PROJECTS ARE CONDUCTED ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS BY STATE (E.G., STATE PARKS, UNIVERSITIES), COUNTY, CITY, AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS, WITH HELP FROM MANY LOCAL VOLUNTEERS.

THE BLACK RAIL WAS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER ESA IN 2020 IN RESPONSE TO POPULATION DECLINES. DECLINES IN SC APPEAR LESS DRAMATIC COMPARED TO MID-ATLANTIC STATES. COASTAL SC OFFERS HABITAT IN TIDAL AND IMPOUNDED WETLANDS AND SUPPORTS AN INCREASING PROPORTION OF THE BLACK RAILS. SUSTAINED MONITORING AND TARGETED MANAGEMENT ARE NECESSARY FOR CONSERVATION. OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) MONITOR STATUS OF BLACK RAILS IN COASTAL SC DURING THE 2023 BREEDING SEASON, 2) PROMOTE AND ASSIST TARGETED HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON SCDNR PROPERTIES,3) MONITOR OUTCOMES OF TARGETED HABITAT MANAGEMENT TO REFINE MANAGEMENT APPROACHES. WE EXPECT THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT BLACK RAILS BECAUSE IT WILL INCREASE EFFECTIVENESS OF CURRENT AND FUTURE CONSERVATION EFFORTS, WILL INCREASE ABILITY TO RECOGNIZE AND RESPOND TO POPULATION DECLINES. THE PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO STABILIZATION AND RECOVERY OF BLACK RAILS IN SC AND THE ATLANTIC COAST. OUR DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A PROJECT REPORT SUMMARIZING OUTCOMES OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND RESEARCH. TO ACHIEVE OUR OBJECTIVES, MONITORING SUPPLIES AND SEASONAL STAFF, WORKING WITH A STATE-FUNDED BIOLOGIST, ARE NEEDED TO COMPLETE BLACK RAIL AND WATER LEVEL MONITORING ON CORE PROPERTIES.THE RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER(RCW) HAS BEEN FEDERALLY ENDANGERED SINCE 1973, DUE TO LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF HABITAT. THOUGH RCWS ARE USE HABITAT WITH OTHER MATURE PINES, SUCH AS LOBLOLLY, THEY PREFER AND OCCUPY MATURE STANDS OF LONGLEAF PINE AND ARE A KEY INDICATOR SPECIES FOR THE RESTORATION AND RECOVERY OF THE LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEM. SUSTAINED CONSERVATION EFFORTS ARE NECESSARY FOR CONTINUED RECOVERY OF RCW ON STATE-OWNED AND PRIVATE LANDS IN SC. SCDNR IMPLEMENTS TWO TARGETED EFFORTS TO AID IN RECOVERY; ADMINISTRATION OF THE SAFE HARBOR PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES BENEFIT TO BOTH RCWS AND LANDOWNERS INTERESTED IN MAINTAINING QUALITY PINE HABITAT, AND ACTIVE MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF RCW GROUPS ON STATE PROPERTIES. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) INITIATE AND ENCOURAGE RCW HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON PRIVATE LANDS BY ENROLLING PROPERTIES IN SAFE HARBOR, CONDUCT INSPECTIONS AND GATHER ANNUAL REPORTS TO ENSURE ENROLLEES UPHOLD AGREEMENTS AND 2) MONITOR, MANAGE AND ENCOURAGE RCW POPULATIONS AT THIRTEEN PROPERTIES AND WORK TO ESTABLISH POPULATIONS AT OTHERS THAT MAY SUPPORT RCW. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF EFFORTS INCLUDE RECOVERY OF RCW POPULATIONS ON STATE-OWNED PROPERTIES AND REVERSAL IN DECLINE OF RCW ON PRIVATE LAND. MANAGEMENT OF STATE-OWNED PROPERTIES FOR RCW RESULTS IN QUALITY HABITAT AND PROVIDES BENEFIT TO RCW AND THE PUBLIC. THE SAFE HARBOR PROGRAM PROVIDES BENEFIT TO LANDOWNERS AND RCWS BY PROVIDING REGULATORY ASSURANCES TO LANDOWNERS IN EXCHANGE FOR RCW HABITAT MANAGEMENT. PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT AND EXECUTION OF NEW SAFE HARBOR ENROLLMENTS, MAINTENANCE AND TRANSFER OF CURRENT SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENTS AND MONITORING AND REPORTING ON RCW GROUPS ON STATE LAND.RUFA RED KNOTS HAVE DECLINED LEADING TO FEDERAL LISTING. RESEARCH ON DECLINE HAS FOCUSED ON DELAWARE BAY. RECENT TAGGING IN SC DOCUMENTED SPRING FLIGHTS FROM SC TO JAMES BAY SUGGESTING SOUTH-ATLANTIC STOPOVERS ARE IMPORTANT. OUR PROJECT WILL 1)INVESTIGATE IMPORTANCE OF SC AS A STOPOVER SITE, 2)REDUCE HUMAN DISTURBANCE WHILE KNOTS ARE IN SC. ACTIVITIES ARE NANOTAGGING DURING APRIL AND MAY, ANALYZING DATA FROM NANOTAGS TO DETERMINE MIGRATION PATHWAYS/TIMING. IF AVAILABLE, DEPLOY TRANSMITTERS TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE OF MIGRATION PATTERNS. WE WILL SUPPORT STEWARDSHIP PROGRAMS AT KIAWAH AND SEABROOK ISLANDS TO LIMIT DISTURBANCE ON BEACHES. SUPPORT WILL BE SCDNR STAFF TIME TO EXPAND BEACH STEWARD PROGRAM. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE MANUSCRIPT SUMMARIZING MIGRATION RESEARCH AND STEWARDSHIP REPORT. EXPECTED OUTCOME IS INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF MIGRATION TIMING TO ENABLE IDENTIFYING HABITAT MANAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN SC. UNDERSTANDING RED KNOT MIGRATION IS IMPORTANT IN INTERPRETING POPULATION DECLINES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE RED KNOTS. REDUCING DISTURBANCE MAY LEAD TO INCREASED SURVIVAL RATES.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY AND PERSISTENCE OF THE FEDERALLY LISTED PIPING PLOVER IN DELAWARE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE CONDUCTING SURVEYS AND MONITORING OF KNOWN BREEDING SITES, MAINTAINING A DATABASE OF ANNUAL PIPING PLOVER BREEDING INFORMATION, INSTALLING PREDATOR EXCLOSURES AROUND PLOVER NESTS, INSTALLING TEMPORARY FENCING TO PROTECT BEACH AREAS WHERE PLOVERS ARE NESTING, ANALYZING DATA AND PREPARING REPORTS SUMMARIZING NESTING SEASON, AND PARTICIPATING IN MEETINGS WITH OTHER STATES AND FEDERAL PARTNERS TO DISCUSS NESTING SEASON FINDINGS AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES TO IMPROVE COORDINATED RECOVERY EFFORTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE DELAWARE SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION PLAN AND EVALUATION OF POPULATION STATUS, DEVELOPMENT OF ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND DIRECT MANAGEMENT OF THREATS TO IMPROVE NEST SUCCESS AND RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE ALL WHO CARE ABOUT BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY AND THE ROLE ALL SPECIES PLAY IN HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS, BIRDERS, CONSERVATION PARTNERS INCLUDING FEDERAL PARTNERS WHO ALSO MANAGE PIPING PLOVER HABITAT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE NOT INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT.

PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES:'EVALUATE THE PRESENT STATUS OF MULTIPLE IMPERILED SPECIES AND IDENTIFY THE MOST SUITABLE METHODS FOR ENHANCING AND STABILIZING THOSE POPULATIONS.'CULTURE, PROPAGATE, AND REAR JUVENILES OF UP TO LISTED SPECIES WHEN BROODSTOCK IS AVAILABLE, AND EVALUATE GROW-OUT METHODS AND HOLDING FACILITIES.'DOCUMENT THE SUCCESS OF AUGMENTATIONS, REINTRODUCTIONS, AND CURRENT TRENDS WITH HATCHERY REARED MUSSELS RELEASED IN THE WILD. WE SPECIFICALLY WILL BE MONITORING POPULATIONS IN THE GREEN, LICKING, SALT, KENTUCKY, AND OTHER OHIO RIVER TRIBUTARIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY AND PERSISTENCE OF FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES IN DELAWARE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY NEW POPULATIONS AND MONITORING OF KNOWN SITES FOR LISTED PLANT SPECIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DATA TO CONTRIBUTE TO RECOVERY OF LISTED PLANT SPECIES, GUIDING MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION EFFORTS FOR THESE SPECIES, AND SECURING THE CONSERVATION STATUS IN DELAWARE AND RANGE-WIDE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ALL WHO CARE ABOUT BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY AND THE ROLE ALL SPECIES PLAY IN HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE NOT INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT.

MAINE SUPPORTS POPULATIONS OF THREE FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES, PEDICULARIS FURBISHIAE (FURBISHS LOUSEWORT)  LISTED ENDANGERED, ISOTRIA MEDEOLOIDES (SMALL WHORLED POGONIA) LISTED THREATENED, AND PLATANTHERA LEUCOPHAEA (EASTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID) LISTED THREATENED.  MAINE HAS A HIGH GLOBAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE CONSERVATION OF PEDICULARIS FURBISHIAE, AND A HIGH REGIONAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE CONSERVATION OF ISOTRIA MEDEOLOIDES AND PLATANTHERA LEUCOPHAEA.  THE PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPLEMENT THE RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED AND THREATENED PLANT TAXA IN MAINE AND TO HELP MEET THE OBJECTIVES TO JUSTIFY DOWNLISTING OR DE-LISTING.  PROPOSED WORK IS GEARED TOWARD DEVELOPING STRONG SCIENCE AS A FOUNDATION UPON WHICH TO MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT THE HEALTH OF EACH LISTED SPECIES AND ITS HABITAT IN MAINE AND IS BASED ON THE RESPECTIVE RECOVERY PLANS, AND FOR PEDICULARIS FURBISHIAE, THE RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY.  THE COMBINATION OF MONITORING, RESEARCHING HABITAT CONDITIONS, EXPLORING OPTIONS FOR INCREASING POPULATIONS, AND WORKING WITH AND INFORMING LANDOWNERS WILL BENEFIT THESE SPECIES AND PROVIDE DATA FOR FUTURE DOWNLISTING OR DE-LISTING ANALYSIS.

OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, THE FLORIDA PANTHER POPULATION HAS EXPANDED SIGNIFICANTLY IN SOUTHWEST FLORIDA FROM AN ESTIMATED 30 ANIMALS IN 1995 TO A CURRENT POPULATION ABUNDANCE RANGING BETWEEN 120-230 TODAY. PANTHER POPULATION EXPANSION CONTINUES SLOWLY BUT THE CONVERSION OF AGRICULTURAL LANDS TO MORE INTENSIVE USE THREATENS TO INHIBIT RECOVERY BOTH IN HISTORIC AND NEW PANTHER HABITAT.THE UNPREDICTABLE PROFITABILITY OF RANCHING OPERATIONS FROM YEAR TO YEAR IS ONE OF THE FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTES TO LAND CONVERSION. AS THE FLORIDA PANTHER'S RANGE EXPANDS, AN INCREASE IN DEPREDATION EVENTS ON COMMERCIAL CATTLE OPERATIONS CAN DECREASE PROFITS AND INCREASE RESISTANCE TO THE PRESENCE OF PANTHERS. PUBLIC SUPPORT IS CRITICAL TO FLORIDA PANTHER RECOVERY. THE COMBINATION OF ECONOMIC LOSS FROM PANTHER DEPREDATION, LOSS OF CATTLE FORAGE VALUE WHEN PROVIDING/IMPROVING PANTHER HABITAT, AND THE POTENTIAL COST OF HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACTS AS A DISINCENTIVE TO LANDOWNERS WHO MIGHT BE WILLING PARTNERS IN PANTHER CONSERVATION. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCENTIVIZE LANDOWNERS TO PROTECT PANTHER HABITAT AND ENCOURAGE POPULATION EXPANSION.FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE COMPENSATION TO LANDOWNERS FOR DEPREDATION. WE WILL USE CURRENT VERIFICATION PROCESSES, AS DELINEATED IN THE INTERAGENCY FLORIDA PANTHER RESPONSE PLAN. COMPENSATION WILL REFLECT THE RANCHER'S INVESTMENT IN THE DEPREDATED CALVES AND BE TIED TO LOCAL MARKET PRICES. CONCURRENT WITH THE LAUNCH OF THIS COMPENSATION PROGRAM, A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS WILL BE HELD TO DEVELOP AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE COVERING THE RANGE OF AVAILABLE PROTECTION MEASURES. FINALLY, LANDOWNERS WHO PROVIDE PANTHER HABITAT AND MANAGE FOR PANTHER OCCUPANCY MAY RECEIVE A PAYMENT FOR ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, RELATIVE TO THE QUALITY OF THE HABITAT PROVIDED, THROUGH A PILOT PROGRAM INITIATED WITH THESE FUNDS.

ALL 19 SUBPOPULATIONS OF POLAR BEARS WERE LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2008 (73 FR 28211), INCLUDING THE TWO SUBSPECIES WHOSE RANGES INCLUDE ALASKA. POLAR BEAR MANAGEMENT IN ALASKA REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF ITS SUBPOPULATIONS (I.E., SOUTHERN BEAUFORT SEA [SBS] AND CHUKCHI SEA), WHICH ARE HARVESTED BY ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLE. ABUNDANCE AND TREND DATA FOR THE SBS SUBPOPULATION IS DEFICIENT. SOME BEARS DEN ON LAND WITHIN ALASKA'S ACTIVE OIL AND GAS DEVELOPMENT AREAS, AND SEA ICE (AN IMPORTANT POLAR BEAR HABITAT) IS ALSO DECREASING RAPIDLY. AS SUCH, THE SBS SUBPOPULATION IS AT THE FOREFRONT OF SEVERAL MANAGEMENT CONCERNS RELATING TO HARVEST, DISTURBANCE FROM OIL AND GAS ACTIVITIES, AND CLIMATE CHANGE.A FUNDAMENTAL NEED FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF SBS POLAR BEARS IS A RELIABLE ESTIMATE OF ABUNDANCE AND INFORMATION ABOUT PRODUCTIVITY AND SURVIVAL TO ESTIMATE TRENDS IN ABUNDANCE. THE MOST CURRENT ESTIMATE OF 573 BEARS COMES FROM DATA COLLECTED DURING 2006-2015 FOR THE PORTION OF THE SUBPOPULATION IN ALASKA ONLY, WHICH WAS SHOWN TO BE STABLE DURING THAT TIME. HOWEVER, LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SBS SUBPOPULATION TREND SINCE THEN. THIS SUBPOPULATION HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR RELATIVELY HIGH COMBINED ANNUAL HARVEST BY U.S. AND CANADIAN SUBSISTENCE HUNTERS.REDUCED SEA ICE HAS MADE IT INCREASINGLY DIFFICULT TO USE ESTABLISHED POLAR BEAR RESEARCH METHODS, SUCH AS USING HELICOPTERS TO LOCATE, IMMOBILIZE, AND FIT POLAR BEARS WITH SATELLITE-LINKED TRANSMITTERS (COLLARS). IN ADDITION, THERE IS ALSO A STRONG SENTIMENT AMONG COASTAL ALASKA COMMUNITIES AND THE ALASKA NANNUT CO-MANAGEMENT COUNCIL AGAINST INVASIVE HANDLING OF POLAR BEARS. THESE CONCERNS PROVIDED THE MOTIVATION FOR THIS PROJECT TO DEVELOP AND USE ALTERNATIVE NONINVASIVE METHODS OF IDENTIFYING INDIVIDUAL BEARS TO ESTIMATE ABUNDANCE AND ASSESS TRENDS.THIS PROJECT USES A NEWLY DEVELOPED METHOD OF COLLECTING A THIN LAYER OF SNOW FROM FRESH POLAR BEAR TRACKS TO ANALYZE POLAR BEAR DNA. GENETIC MATERIAL (I.E., DNA) FROM SLOUGHED SKIN IN THE TRACKS IS ANALYZED TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL POLAR BEARS AND THEIR SEX. SNOW FROM TRACKS WILL BE COLLECTED BY HUNTERS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND OIL INDUSTRY PERSONNEL ALONG THE BEAUFORT SEA COAST OF ALASKA. DATA COLLECTED ALONG WITH THE SNOW SAMPLE INCLUDES DATE AND LOCATION OF COLLECTION, SIZE OF TRACKS, AND NUMBER OF BEARS IN THE GROUP. GENETICALLY IDENTIFIED INDIVIDUALS CAN BE RE-IDENTIFIED BY SUBSEQUENT TRACK SAMPLING. RE-IDENTIFIED INDIVIDUALS PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT MOVEMENTS, AGE, AND REPRODUCTIVE STATUS OF FEMALES (I.E., WHETHER A SOW HAS CUBS WITH HER). WITHOUT THIS PROJECT, NEEDED INFORMATION ON ABUNDANCE AND TREND IN ABUNDANCE WILL NOT BE AVAILABLE, WHICH COULD ALLOW THE SBS TO BE UNKNOWINGLY OVERHARVESTED AT GREAT RISK TO THE VIABILITY OF THE SUBPOPULATION.

SEVERAL BUMBLE BEE SPECIES HAVE BEEN IN DECLINE IN RECENT DECADES, PROMPTING THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL DATA ANDCONSERVATION ACTIONS. CURRENTLY THE WESTERN BUMBLE BEE (WBB), BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS, IS UNDERGOING A SPECIES STATUSASSESSMENT (SSA) BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THE SSA WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE IF LISTING OF THE WBBUNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IS WARRANTED. PREVIOUSLY WBB COMPRISED TWO SUBSPECIES: BOMBUS OCCIDENTALISOCCIDENTALIS, WHICH IS FOUND THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN CONTIGUOUS US AS WELL AS WESTERN CANADA BUT HAS NOT BEENCOLLECTED IN ALASKA; AND BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS MCKAYI, WHICH WAS THOUGHT TO BE THE NORTHERN SUBSPECIES OF B.OCCIDENTALIS AND IS PRESENT IN ALASKA BUT HAS NOT BEEN COLLECTED IN THE LOWER 48. RECENTLY, WHAT HAD BEENCONSIDERED THE TWO SUBSPECIES OF B. OCCIDENTALIS HAVE EACH BEEN RECOGNIZED AS SEPARATE SPECIES. WHAT HAD BEENCALLED BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS MCKAYI IN ALASKA IS NOW THE SPECIES BOMBUS MCKAYI (MCKAY'S BUMBLE BEE (MBB)). THE WBBIS NOW RECOGNIZED WITH THE SPECIES NAME BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS (WBB). INFORMATION GAPS REMAIN ON THE DISTRIBUTIONAND ABUNDANCE OF BOTH SPECIES IN ALASKA.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF WBB AND MBB IN SOUTHERN ALASKA RELATIVETO OTHER BUMBLE BEE SPECIES. PROFESSIONAL BIOLOGISTS AND CITIZEN SCIENTISTS WILL CONDUCT BEE SURVEYS IN SOUTHERNREGIONS OF THE STATE BUT WILL EXPAND ON THESE EFFORTS WITH TARGETED SAMPLING IN LOCATIONS KNOWN TO PROVIDESUITABLE HABITAT FOR THESE BUMBLE BEE SPECIES. THESE TARGETED SAMPLING LOCATIONS INCLUDE HAINES AND SKAGWAY,WHICH ARE DRIER PARTS OF SOUTHEASTERN ALASKA IN WHICH MBB HAS PREVIOUSLY BEEN DOCUMENTED TO OCCUR. PRIORITIZINGTHESE AREAS WILL ALLOW US TO 1) ASCERTAIN IF THESE SPECIES STILL OCCUR THERE (MOST OF THE RECORDS ARE OVER 2DECADES OLD, AND 12 RECORDS ARE FROM THE FIRST HALF OF THE 1900S; 2) OBTAIN FRESH SPECIMENS FOR DNA BARCODING TOHELP CONFIRM SPECIES IDENTIFICATIONS; AND 3) DOCUMENT FLORAL RESOURCES USED - DATA CURRENTLY MISSING FROMHISTORIC SAMPLES. RESULTS FROM THIS WORK WILL BETTER INFORM ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTING DECISIONS AS WELL ASWILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH PRIORITIES FOR BOTH MBB AND WBB.

A LONG-TERM MONITORING PROJECT FOR EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE POPULATIONS IN SOUTHERN GEORGIA WAS INITIATED IN 2010. THESE POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN MONITORED ANNUALLY SINCE THEN AND THE SURVEY DESIGN WAS EXPANDED IN 2016 TO ACCOMMODATE MORE SURVEY SITES. IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONTINUE THIS PROJECT TO DETERMINE WHETHER OR NOT POPULATIONS ARE STABLE AND RESPONDING TO ONGOING MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THUS, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE MONITORING EASTERN INDIGO SNAKES ON SUITABLE OVERWINTERING SITES THROUGHOUT THE ALAPAHA, ALTAMAHA, AND SATILLA RIVER DRAINAGES. CONDUCTING SURVEYS IN AN OCCUPANCY MONITORING FRAMEWORK WILL ALLOW US TO CALCULATE OCCUPANCY RATES THAT ARE CORRECTED FOR IMPERFECT DETECTION (I.E., THE INABILITY TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF THE ANIMAL EVEN IF THE ANIMAL IS PRESENT). THIS SURVEY METHODOLOGY ALSO ALLOWS US TO SAMPLE OVER A LARGE GEOGRAPHIC AREA, WHILE CONTINUING TO COLLECT DATA THAT CAN BE USED IN OTHER INDIGO SNAKE CONSERVATION PROJECTS (E.G., POPULATION MODELING AND DISEASE TESTING). OVERALL, OCCUPANCY RATES CALCULATED OVER LONG TIME PERIODS CAN BE USED TO ASSESS WHETHER OR NOT CURRENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ARE SUFFICIENT FOR MAINTAINING (AND INCREASING) INDIGO SNAKE POPULATIONS ON SUITABLE SANDHILL SITES IN SOUTHERN GEORGIA.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR), WILDLIFE RESOURCES DIVISION, WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SECTION (WCS) IN THEIR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), IDENTIFIED SURVEYS, MONITORING, STEWARDSHIP, AND SAFEGUARDING OF HIGH PRIORITY PLANT SPECIES AS HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIONS. DATA COLLECTED THROUGH THESE ACTIVITIES ENABLES THE UPDATING AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE GEORGIA RARE SPECIES DATABASE (BIOTICS) WHICH IS VITAL TO THE MISSION OF WCS, AS WELL AS TO THE OVERALL CONSERVATION COMMUNITY.SPECIFIC ACTIONS UNDERTAKEN DURING THE YEAR WILL DEPEND UPON AVAILABILITY OF GEORGIA PLANT CONSERVATION ALLIANCE (GPCA) RESOURCES, AS WELL AS CONDITIONS AND CIRCUMSTANCES OF FOCAL SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. THIS PROJECT IS MEANT TO BE FLEXIBLE AND RESPOND TO BOTH RARE SPECIES/HABITAT NEEDS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR GREATEST CONSERVATION SUCCESS.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPLEMENT HIGH PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTIONS NECESSARY TO RECOVER THE LOGGERHEAD SEA TURTLE INCLUDING MONITORING NESTING TRENDS, ASSESSING REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND IMPLEMENTING NEST PROTECTION PROGRAMS ON ALL BARRIER ISLAND BEACHES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) IMPLEMENT NEST SURVEY AND PROTECTION PROGRAMS ON STATE-OWNED ISLANDS (OSSABAW AND SAPELO ISLAND), 2) COORDINATE NEST SURVEY AND PROTECTION PROGRAMS ON ALL GEORGIA BARRIER ISLANDS, 3) REVIEW DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS WITH IMPLICATIONS FOR LOGGERHEAD RECOVERY AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND 4) MAINTAIN A STATEWIDE NESTING DATABASE AND ASSESS POPULATION STATUS IN AN ANNUAL REPORT. 5) PROVIDE DATA TO USFWS NATIONAL SEA TURTLE COORDINATOR FOR SPECIES ASSESSMENTS.

MONITORING, SURVEYS, AND RESEARCH WILL BE CONDUCTED BY THE ARKANSAS NATURAL HERITAGE COMMISSION TO DETERMINE THE HEALTH AND STATUS OF THREE FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES AND ONE PETITIONED SPECIES. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED FOR HABITAT AND RECOVERY MANAGEMENT PURPOSES, OR TO SUPPORT LISTING DECISIONS. THE WORK INCLUDES MONITORING AND SURVEYS FOR PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN POPULATIONS OF GEOCARPON (GEOCARPON MINIMUM), MISSOURI BLADDERPOD (PHYSARIA FILIFORMIS), SMALL-HEADED PIPEWORT (ERIOCAULON KOERNICKIANUM), AND PONDBERRY (LINDERA MELISSIFOLIA). IT ALSO INCLUDES SUPPLEMENTAL SEEDING EXPERIMENTS FOR GEOCARPON AND PONDBERRY, IF CONDITIONS ARE SUITABLE. PONDBERRY SEEDS, ROOTS, AND SOIL SAMPLES MAY ALSO BE COLLECTED TO SUPPORT ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, PENDING THE SERVICE'S APPROVAL OF THEIR RESEARCH PERMIT APPLICATION.

CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY-LISTED PLANT SPECIES ULTIMATELY REQUIRES COOPERATION AMONG FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AND OFTEN ALSO NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS. BASED ON A GROWING CONCERN FOR THE PERSISTENCE OF RARE PLANTS AND SPECIFIC NATIVE PLANT HABITATS, A PARTNERSHIP FORMED TO DEVELOP A MONTANA NATIVE PLANT CONSERVATION STRATEGY. THE PARTNERSHIP WOULD LIKE TO INCLUDE MONTANA'S FOUR FEDERALLY THREATENED AND PROPOSED PLANT SPECIES: HOWELLIA AQUATILIS, SILENE SPALDINGII, SPIRANTHES DILUVIALIS, AND PINUS ALBICAULIS. THE NEED TO INCLUDE THESE SPECIES IS MULTI-FACETTED. FIRST, THESE PLANTS GROW ACROSS LANDOWNERSHIP BOUNDARIES IN WHICH THREATENED PLANTS ARE AFFORDED FEW PROTECTIONS ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS. SECOND, MOST PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS PRIORITIZE THESE SPECIES IN THEIR PROJECT WORK BECAUSE OF THEIR STATUS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND FEEL THAT A COORDINATED, NON-REGULATORY STRATEGY CAN AID IN THEIR WORK. THIRD, EACH PLANT FACES A MULTITUDE OF UNIQUE AND SUBSTANTIATED THREATS IN WHICH A STATEWIDE, COORDINATED, AND NON-REGULATORY STRATEGIC APPROACH CAN FACILITATE CONSERVATION, PARTICULARLY ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS. FOR HOWELLIA AQUATILIS THIS STRATEGY COULD HELP MITIGATE RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH DE-LISTING THE SPECIES. FOR SILENE SPALDINGII THIS STRATEGY COULD HELP MAINTAIN COORDINATION NECESSARY FOR COLLECTING TREND DATA OVER A 20-YEAR PERIOD AS REQUIRED BY THE RECOVERY PLAN. FOR SPIRANTHES DILUVIALIS, THIS STRATEGY WOULD PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHERE MOST MONTANA POPULATIONS OCCUR. FOR PINUS ALBICAULIS THIS STRATEGY CAN HELP FACILITATE CONSERVATION MEASURES ACROSS LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES. WITHOUT THIS STRATEGY, LONG-TERM CONSERVATION EFFORTS, ESPECIALLY ON NON-FEDERAL LANDS WILL REMAIN LIMITED TO A PATCHWORK OF GUIDELINES. ANDREA PIPP, MONTANA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM BOTANIST WILL SERVE AS LEAD AUTHOR AND EDITOR, AND WILL ENSURE THAT THIS STRATEGY IS VOLUNTARY, NON-BINDING. THE PARTNERSHIP CONSISTS OF 26 MEMBERS WHO REPRESENT 21 ORGANIZATIONS. THE PARTNERSHIP SERVES TO PROVIDE OVERALL GUIDANCE AND DIRECTION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MONTANA NATIVE PLANT CONSERVATION STRATEGY. MEMBERS HAVE VARYING LEVELS OF INVOLVEMENT IN THE CREATION OF THE STRATEGY. IT WILL BE PEER-REVIEWED BY THE ENTIRE PARTNERSHIP WHICH INCLUDES THREE EMPLOYEES OF THE USFWS. DEVELOPMENT OF STRATEGIC CONTENT FOR THE FOUR SPECIES WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED UNDER THREE OBJECTIVES: 1) CONDUCTING RESEARCH AND COMPILING INFORMATION; 2) DEVELOPING A MONTANA SCORECARD; AND 3) CREATING CONSERVATION ACTIONS PERTINENT TO EACH CONSERVATION OBJECTIVE IN THE STRATEGY.FOR OBJECTIVE 1 STRATEGY CONTENT FOR HOWELLIA AQUATILIS, SILENE SPALDINGII, SPIRANTHES DILUVIALIS, AND PINUS ALBICAULIS WOULD USE EXISTING AND ACCEPTABLE GOVERNMENT DOCUMENTS, FOLLOW EXISTING LAWS, POLICIES, AND GUIDELINES, AND PUBLISHED, SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE. IT WILL ALSO COORDINATE WITH PEOPLE OR ORGANIZATIONS WE KNOW ABOUT WHO ARE DEVELOPING CONSERVATION MEASURES. OBJECTIVE 2 CREATES A MONTANA SCORECARD WHICH PROVIDES A BASELINE OF CONDITIONS AIMED TO ASSESS THE STATEWIDE OVERALL CONSERVATION RATING OF 'UNDER-', 'WEAKLY-', 'MODERATELY-', OR 'EFFECTIVELY-'-'CONCERNED'. DATA WILL BE QUERIED, SUMMARIZED, AND ANALYZED TO PROVIDE THE VARIOUS METRICS. IT WILL BE PROVIDED AS A DOWNLOADABLE SPREADSHEET. OBJECTIVE 3 CREATES SPECIES-SPECIFIC VOLUNTARY MEASURES RELATIVE TO THE CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES AND AS APPROPRIATE FOR THE SPECIES. THE STRATEGY WILL BE AN ELECTRONIC DOCUMENT. HOWEVER, IT WILL CONNECT WITH THE MONTANA FIELD GUIDE. WE HOPE IT WILL LINK TO AN ON-LINE 'PLANT STRATEGY' WEBPAGE HOSTED AT THE MTNHP OR MNPS WEBSITES. THE FINAL PRODUCTS AND LEVEL OF DETAIL WILL DEPEND UPON THE TIME AND LEVEL OF EFFORT PUT IN BY PEOPLE IN THE PARTNERSHIP.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO FUND 6 SUBCONTRACTORS TO CONDUCT SURVEYS AND MONITORING OF ARIZONA'S FEDERALLY-LISTED AND OTHER RARE PLANTS OF CONCERN.  SUBCONTRACTORS ARE GIVEN AWARDS BASED ON THE MERIT OF THEIR PROPOSALS AND THE CURRENT LISTING AND RECOVERY NEEDS OF THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN ARIZONA.  THIS WORK INCLUDES MONITORING AND DEMOGRAPHY STUDIES OF FIVE RARE PLANTS, ONE LISTED THREATENED, TWO CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW FOR LISTING, ONE A CONSERVATION AGREEMENT SPECIES, AND A NARROW ENDEMIC: ERIGERON RHIZOMATUS, GRAPTOPETALUM BARTRAMII, ERYNGIUM SPARGANOPHYLLUM, ERIGERON LEMMONII, AND ERIOGONUM ERICIFOLIUM, RESPECTIVELY.
